The term does not include the direct purchase of materials, equipment, or supplies by the City of Shawnee. Nothing herein shall prevent the city from constructing public improvements by the force account method. 
Section 4. - Signing of contracts. 
    All contracts of the city shall be signed by the city manager and attested by the city clerk. 
ARTICLE XVI. - CONFLICT OF INTEREST AND OTHER PROHIBITED ACTS OF PUBLIC OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 

Section 1. - Commissioners not to hold public employment; city officer and employees not to be interested in city contracts. 
    No member of the board of commissioners shall hold any other office or employment within the municipal government of Shawnee, compensation for which is paid out of public moneys, nor be elected or appointed to any office, the compensation of which was increased or fixed by the board of commissioners, while he was a member thereof, until after the expiration of at least one (1) year after he has ceased to be a member of said board of commissioners. No member of the board of commissioners or any officer of said city shall be pecuniarily interested directly or indirectly in any contract, purchase, or sale made by or with said city, or by any contractor or subcontractor of said city, nor in any manner wherein the rights of [or] liabilities of said city are, or may be involved, and such party, firm, or corporation shall be prohibited from recovering any compensation therefor, nor shall any member of the board of commissioners, or any officer or employee of said city be interested directly or indirectly in any public work or contract or contract made, supervised, or controlled, or which shall be paid for wholly or in part by said city or by any contractor or subcontractor thereof. Any member of the board of commissioners or any officer or employee of said city becoming interested directly or indirectly as aforesaid, or by commission, retainer, fee, gift, or a loan given or received at the time of the transaction, or before or after the same in any contract, franchise, work, purchase, or at sale by or with any of the agencies aforesaid, or who shall hold stock in any corporation contracting with said city or any contractor or subcontractor of said city shall forfeit all right or claim of title to his office and to any emoluments in any office which he shall happen to hold in said city, and shall be expelled therefrom by the board of commissioners; or if they shall fail to remove said officer, member, or commissioners, or any other city officer guilty, as aforesaid, he shall nevertheless be subject to removal upon the action of any five (5) citizens taken in the district court of Pottawatomie County, in such proceedings as are appropriate and proper. 
Section 2. - Graft prohibited. 
    The receiving directly or indirectly by any officer of said city for his own use and benefit or any other use or purpose other than is authorized and provided in this Charter and the laws of the state, of any interest, profits, or perquisites arising from the use or loan of public funds in his hands, or to be raised through his agency for city purposes, shall be deemed sufficient cause to forfeit his office, and the person so receiving shall then and there forfeit his office and be disqualified to hold office. 
Section 3. - Offering compensation for election or appointment to office prohibited. 
    No officer or employee of said city shall give or promise to give to any other person any portion of his compensation or any money or valuable thing, or promise employment to any person in consideration of having been, or of being nominated, appointed, voted for, or elected to any office or employment; and if any such promise or gift be made, the person making or accepting such gift or promise shall forfeit his office or employment and be debarred and disqualified from being elected, appointed, or employed in the services of said city. 
Section 4. - City officers not to receive gratuity from subordinate officer or candidate. 
    Any officer of said city who shall, while in office, accept any donation or gratuity in money or other valuable thing, either directly or indirectly, from any subordinate or employee, or from any candidate or applicant for any position as employee or subordinate under him, shall forfeit his office and be forever disqualified from holding any position in the services of said city. 
Section 5. - Officers and bond liable for approving and paying unauthorized claims. 
    Every officer who shall approve, allow, or pay any demand on the treasury not authorized by law, ordinance, or this Charter shall be liable to said city individually and on his official bond for the payment of the demand so illegally approved, allowed, or paid. 
State Law reference- Liability for voting unlawful claims generally, 11 O.S. § 17-104. 
Section 6. - Duty of officers to report violations concerning city contracts. 
    It shall be the official duty of every officer or person in the employment or service of said city, when it shall come to his knowledge that any contract or agreement with said city or with any officer has been or is about to be violated by the other contracting party forthwith to report to the mayor and board of commissioners all facts and information within his possession concerning such matter, and upon a willful failure to do so the board of commissioners shall remove the officer and/or employee. 
ARTICLE XVII. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Section 1. - Oaths to be administered by certain city officers. 
    The mayor, vice-mayor, city clerk, judge of the municipal court, and a notary public shall be, and they are hereby, authorized to administer oaths in all municipal affairs and government of said city. 
State Constitution reference- Oath of office, OK Const. Art. 15, § 1. 
Section 2. - Elective and appointive officers to take oath; office vacated when officer ceases to possess qualifications. 
    Every person elected or appointed to any office in said city shall, before he enters upon his duties, take the official oath prescribed by the Constitution of the State of Oklahoma, and such additional oaths as the board of commissioners may prescribe to secure a faithful performance of duty, and file same in the office of the city clerk. Any officer ceasing to possess any of the qualifications required of him at the time of his election shall instantly thereby forfeit his office and same shall be filled as herein provided. 
Section 3. - City books and records open for inspection; exceptions. 
    All records of the city and its departments which are required by law to be public records shall be open to public inspection at proper times and in proper manner during all regular business hours of each week; provided, however, that this shall not apply to any records required by law to be kept secret, nor shall it apply to records that if disclosed would defeat the purpose for which same are kept, including but not limited to criminal investigative records and personnel records, records prepared in anticipation or preparation of litigation, communications, memos, and opinions of the city attorney protected under the client-attorney privilege. 
Section 4. - No change in salaries of elective officers. 
    No salary of any elective officer of said city shall be increased or decreased during the term for which said officer was elected. 
Section 5. - Appointive officers; successor of officer holding under mayor and board of commissioners. 
    The mayor and board of commissioners elected under the provisions of this amended Charter and their successors in office shall be deemed in law and in fact the successors of the present mayor and board of commissioners, and all officers appointed by the board of commissioners, or otherwise as provided in this Charter, shall be deemed in law and in fact the successors of the present officers, whether elected or appointed. 
Section 6. - Ordinances and resolutions not in conflict with Charter continued. 
    All resolutions and ordinances not in conflict with or inapplicable under the provisions of this amended Charter which are in force and effect in said city, at the time of the approval and taking effect of this amended Charter, shall be and remain in full force and effect until the same shall expire by limitation, be repealed or amended; provided further, that all prosecutions of violations of ordinances of the city, whether begun, pending, or otherwise, shall be prosecuted to determination and effect as though this amended Charter had not been passed and approved. 
Section 7. - Abstaining votes. 
    If a member of the board of commissioners or a member of any board or agency of the city abstains from voting on an issue, said abstention shall not be recorded as a negative vote, but rather shall be reflected as an abstention and not counted in determining whether the item passed or failed. 
Section 8. - Repealer; construction of provisions. 
    All provisions of this Charter of the City of Shawnee as the same exists prior to the adoption of these amendments, which are inconsistent or contrary to the provisions hereof, shall be and the same are hereby repealed. 
Section 9. - Severability. 
    If any part, article, section, or subsection of this amended Charter shall be held invalid or unconstitutional for any reason, such holding shall not be construed to impair or invalidate the remainder of this amended Charter, notwithstanding such holding.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Ordinances, enactment, 11 O.S. § 14-102; ordinances, effective date, emergencies, 11 O.S. § 14-103. 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Shawnee City Code." 
(Code 1986, § 1-1; Code 2002, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Codification of ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-108; mandatory compilation of penal ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-109; notice and filing of penal ordinance compilation, 11 O.S. § 14-110. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and all other city ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city commission or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Annual, per annum. The term "annual" or "per annum" means that a license shall expire 12 months from the date of issue. 
    Bond schedule. The term "bond schedule" means a schedule compiled at the direction of, adopted by, and reviewable and amendable by the city commission, enumerating the amounts of bonds required by the city. 
    Charter. The term "Charter" means the Charter of the City of Shawnee, as ratified at the election on April 1, 1986, as amended. 
    City. The term "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "of Shawnee, Oklahoma." 
    City commission, commission, board of commissioners. Whenever the term "commission," "city commission" or "board of commissioners" is used, it shall be construed to mean the board of commissioners of the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma. 
    Code. The term "the Code" or "this Code" means "The Code of the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma." 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done, as provided in the civil procedure statutes, is computed by excluding the first day and including the last, unless the last day falls upon any legal holiday or on Saturday, in which case the last day is also excluded. 
State Law reference- Computation of time, 25 O.S. § 23. 
    County. The term "the county" or "this county" means Pottawatomie County, Oklahoma. 
    Day. A day is the period of time between any 12:00 midnight and the 12:00 midnight following. 
State Law reference- Fractions of a day, 25 O.S. § 23. 
    Daytime, nighttime. The term "daytime" means the period of time between sunrise and sunset. The term "nighttime" means the period of time between sunset and sunrise. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever any authority, duty or other activity is charged to a city officer or employee, it may be done as well by such person's duly appointed agent, so long as not prohibited by ordinance or the laws or Constitution of the state, and so long as such officer or employee retains supervision over the discharge of the duly delegated authority, duty or activity. 
    Fee schedule. The term "fee schedule" means a schedule compiled at the direction of, adopted by, and reviewable and amendable by the city commission, enumerating fees and similar charges imposed by the city for various city licenses, permits and services. 
    Fine schedule. The term "fine schedule" means a schedule compiled at the direction of, adopted by, and reviewable and amendable by the city commission, enumerating specific fines for specific code violations. 
    Gender. Words used in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 24. 
    Health officer or health department. Wherever reference is made to the "health officer" or "health department," it shall be construed as meaning the Pottawatomie County Health Officer or the Pottawatomie County Health Department, respectively. 
State Law reference- Local health officer defined, 63 O.S. § 1-102. 
    Highway. The term "highway" shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    In the city. The phrase "in the city" means and includes all territory over which the city has or shall acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or other regulatory powers. 
    Insurance schedule. The term "insurance schedule" means a schedule compiled at the direction of, adopted by, and reviewable and amendable by the city commission, enumerating the amounts of insurance required by the city. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more public officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such public officers or other persons. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 31. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 23. 
    Must. The term "must" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
    Number. Words used in the singular number shall include the plural, and the plural shall include the singular. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 25. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation. 
State Law reference- Affirmation, 12 O.S. § 72, 25 O.S. § 26. 
    Officer, employee, board, commission, department or office. Whenever any officer, employee, board, commission, department or office is referred to, it shall mean the respective officer, employee, board, commission, department or office of the city. 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a formal legislative act of the city council that has the force and effect of a continuing regulation and a permanent rule of conduct or government for the city. 
    O.S. The abbreviation "O.S." means the Oklahoma Statutes, and such term or any other reference to the statutes of the state means such statutes as now or hereafter amended, supplemented or recodified. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land or vendee in possession under a land sale contract. 
    Person. The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, associations, corporations, joint stock companies or their agents, servants and employees, when acting for the principal or employer, respectively. 
State Law reference- Person defined, 25 O.S. § 16. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and evidences of debt. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 26(3). 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 26(1). 
    Public grounds; public places; public buildings. The term "public grounds," "public places" or "public buildings" shall be construed to mean any park or open space adjacent thereto; any lake or stream; and any and every public ground, public square, public park, street or sidewalk or other public place within the city. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 25 O.S. § 26(3). 
    Resolution. The term "resolution" means a special or temporary act of the city council that is declaratory of the will or opinion of the city in a given matter and is in the nature of a ministerial or administrative act. A resolution is not a law and does not prescribe a permanent rule of conduct or government. 
    Roadway. The term "roadway" means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Shall, will and may. The terms "shall" and "will" are mandatory; the term "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription by mark. The term "signature" or "subscription by mark" includes a mark when the signer or subscriber cannot write, such signer's or subscriber's name being written near the mark by a witness who writes his own name near the signer's or subscriber's name; but a signature or subscription by mark can be acknowledged or can serve as a signature or subscription to a sworn statement only when one witness shall sign his own name thereto. 
State Law reference- Signature or subscription defined, 25 O.S. § 26. 
    State. The term "the state" or "this state" means the State of Oklahoma. 
    Statutory references. Reference to the statutes of the State of Oklahoma means the 1991 statutes, as amended. 
    Tenant; occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the present tense include the past and the future, and words used in the future tense include the present. 
State Law reference- Tense, 25 O.S. § 26. 
    Time standard. Whenever certain hours are named in this Code, they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in the city. 
    Week. A week consists of seven consecutive days. 
    Writing. The term "writing" includes any form of recorded message capable of comprehension by ordinary visual means. Whenever any notice, report, statement or record is required or authorized by this Code, it shall be made in writing, in the English language, unless it is expressly provided otherwise. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year, except where otherwise provided. 
(Code 1986, § 1-2; Code 2002, § 1-2; Ord. No. 2532NS, § 1, 3-3-2014) 
State Law reference- Fractions of a year, 25 O.S. § 23. 
Sec. 1-3. - Jurisdiction on city-owned or city-operated property outside city. 
    This Code and ordinances contained in this Code, as well as subsequent amendments or other enactments, are effective outside of the city boundaries on property owned or operated by the city. 
(Code 2002, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1986, § 1-3; Code 2002, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes and references. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code and the references scattered throughout the Code shall not be considered as part of the Code but are mere aids for the benefit of the user of the Code. 
(Code 2002, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-6. - Special provisions to control over general provisions. 
    Any general provision of this Code which is of general application to the entire Code, in case of conflict with any provision of a special or limited application and which fully, adequately and effectively operates, shall be subordinate to such special provision insofar as is necessary to give full effect to the special provision. 
(Code 1986, § 1-4; Code 2002, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - Continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The sections appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same in substance as those of ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1986, § 1-5; Code 2002, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-8. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising and guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness. 
(2)  Any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of taxes or for an annual budget. 
(3)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city or excluding territory as a part of the city. 
(4)  Any ordinance granting any franchise, permit or other right. 
(5)  Any ordinance accepting the beneficial interest in any trust created by a trust indenture or a declaration of trust. 
(6)  Any ordinance approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to any contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument. 
(7)  The zoning code and amendments thereto. 
(8)  Any ordinance relating to specific paving and sewer districts and special assessments. 
(9)  Any subdivision regulations. 
(10)  Any standard specifications for construction of water distribution mains or public sanitary sewer lines, or plans for extension of water and sewer boundary mains. 
(11)  Any temporary or special ordinance, including but not limited to calling elections, and also any ordinance pertaining to specific locations or specific persons. 
(12)  Any ordinance pertaining to salaries of city employees. 
(b)  All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1986, § 1-8; Code 2002, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to omit certain provisions from Code, 11 O.S. § 14-108. 
Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for any offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1986, § 1-9; Code 2002, § 1-9) 
State Law reference- Repeal does not revive statutes, 25 O.S. § 32. 
Sec. 1-10. - General penalty. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in other ordinance of the city, or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him, or it, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful, it shall be a misdemeanor unless otherwise specifically stated; and where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the city, or such rule, regulation, or order, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  If the violation is a Class A offense, it shall be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule and costs, and/or by imprisonment not exceeding 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment; 
(2)  If the violation is a Class B offense, it shall be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule and costs; 
(3)  If the violation is a Class C offense, it shall be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule and costs; 
(4)  If the violation is a Class D offense, it shall be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule and costs, and/or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or, by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  If any act or omission is declared to be a Class A, Class B, Class C, or Class D offense, it shall be punishable as indicated in subsection (a) of this section. In the absence of any other penalty, an offense shall be a Class C offense. 
(c)  Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, administrative adjudication and revocation of licenses or permits. 
(d)  Whenever a person either commits an act that is prohibited or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or fails to perform any required act, the failure of which is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor and that person is punished by a fine, there shall be added to each fine a technology fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. The fee will be deposited in a technology account. At the end of the fiscal year, the funds in this account will be moved to a designated fund balance account to be used solely and exclusively for the acquisition, operation, maintenance, repair and replacement of data processing equipment and software related to the administration of the municipal criminal justice system and the costs of prosecution, as budgeted by the city commission. 
(e)  Whenever a person either commits an act that is prohibited or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or fails to perform any required act, the failure of which is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor and that person is punished by a fine, there shall be added to each fine a communications support fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. The fee will be deposited in a communications support account. At the end of the fiscal year, the funds in this account will be moved to a designated fund balance account to be used solely for police communications equipment and software, as budgeted by the where the funds can be spent only for police radio equipment as budgeted by the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 1-7; Code 2002, § 1-10; Ord. No. 1948NS, § 1, 11-1-1999; Ord. No. 1997NS, § 1, 2-20-2001; Ord. No. 2618NS, § 1, 7-6-2004; Ord. No. 2394NS, § 1, 2-17-2009; Ord. No. 2532NS, §§ 2, 3, 3-3-2014; Ord. No. 2574NS, § 1, 9-8-2015) 
State Law reference- Penalties generally, 11 O.S. §§ 14-111, 27-104, 27-119; misdemeanor punishment, 21 O.S. § 10. 
Sec. 1-11. - Amendments to Code. 
    Amendments to any of the sections of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma (or Shawnee City Code), is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(Code 1986, § 1-10; Code 2002, § 1-11) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to amend and supplement Code, 11 O.S. § 14-108 et seq. 
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city commission. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city commission or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1986, § 1-11; Code 2002, § 1-12) 
State Law reference- Supplementation of Code, 11 O.S. § 14-108 et seq. 
Sec. 1-13. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    Each section of this Code and each numbered or lettered clause or paragraph within any such section is declared to be independent of every other section, and the invalidity of any section or part thereof shall not affect the validity, force or effect of the other sections or parts thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 1-6(a); Code 2002, § 1-13) 
Sec. 1-14. - Sections, clauses and paragraphs declared separate and distinct units. 
    Each section, as set forth and clearly indicated in this Code, and each numbered or lettered clause or paragraph of each such section is declared to be an entire unit and shall constitute a section for any purpose of amendment or repeal as required by law. 
(Code 1986, § 1-6(b); Code 2002, § 1-14) 
Sec. 1-15. - Effect of section renumbering on city signs and forms. 
    Sections of this Code may be renumbered from time to time by amendments. Former section numbers appearing on city signs or included in various forms used by the city shall be deemed to refer to those sections as amended and renumbered from time to time. 
(Code 2002, § 1-15; Ord. No. 2532NS, § 4, 3-3-2014) 
Sec. 1-16. - Altering Code. 
    It is unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to make electronic changes, or to alter or tamper with this Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 2002, § 1-16; Ord. No. 2532NS, § 5, 3-3-2014) 
Sec. 1-17. - Schedule of fees, fines, bonds, and insurance charges created. 
(a)  There is hereby created a schedule of fees, fines, bonds, and insurance charges, which shall contain those fees, fines, bonds, and insurance charges for the various licenses, permits and other fees and charges as designated by the council. Where a fee or charge is authorized to be collected by the city in any ordinance the amount of the fees, fines, bonds, and insurance charges shall be set by resolution and entered into the schedule of fees, fines, bonds, and insurance charges. The schedule shall be kept on file in the office of the clerk, to whom all fees and charges shall be paid unless otherwise provided. A copy may be obtained upon payment of a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(b)  The schedule of fees and charges hereby created shall also be known and may be cited as the "city fee schedule" or the "city fees, fines, bonds, and insurance schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2599NS, § 1, 3-20-2017) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Cities and towns, 11 O.S. § 1-101 et seq.; territory included in a city, 11 O.S. §§ 2-101, 2-104; qualifications for elected officers, 11 O.S. § 8-101; removal of officers, 22 O.S. § 1181 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City seal. 
(a)  The seal for the city shall be made of brass or other substantial metal, of circular form. The superscription shall be engraved thereon as follows: The words, "The City of Shawnee, Oklahoma" shall be engraved in a circular lane formed by two concentric circles, one of which is the circumference of the seal. The word "Seal" shall be engraved within the circular lane and inside the inner circle of the lane. The seal thus made and engraved shall be the corporate seal of the city and shall be used for the authentication of all documents required by law or the Charter to be sealed with the seal of the city. 
(b)  The city clerk shall be the lawful custodian of the corporate seal for the city, and he shall affix the seal to all documents requiring the seal. 
(c)  The use of the city seal to convey the appearance that the city has endorsed, supported, created, supervised, or provided any goods or services shall be an offense. 
(Code 1986, §§ 2-2, 2-126(16); Code 2002, § 2-2; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-2. - Hours of city offices. 
    The city manager is authorized to designate and determine the hours and times during which the city hall, city offices and departments shall remain open. 
(Code 1986, § 2-3; Code 2002, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-3. - Library. 
(a)  The purpose of this section is to provide for the membership of and participation by the city in the Pioneer Multi-County Library and to define the relationship between the city's existing library system and the multi-county library system. 
(b)  The city accepts membership in the multi-county library system, subject expressly to the limitations and conditions set forth in this section. 
(c)  A member of the library board of the city's library system shall be appointed by the city commission as the member of the board of trustees of the multi-county library district representing the city. 
(d)  Until such time as the county shall establish the special, annually recurring, two-mill tax levy for libraries, provided by OK Const. Art. 10, § 10A, the city, upon the request of the state department of libraries board, shall provide its agreed share of funds or shall act as the agent of such board in disbursing such funds as may be made available by the board to maintain and operate those multi-county library activities arising from the participation of the county in the multi-county library system, subject to the limitation that at any time before the county does establish such special tax levy, the city shall have full right, without further obligation, to terminate its membership in the multi-county library system. Such termination may be accomplished by ordinance or resolution, at the option of the city commission. The city clerk shall forward promptly to the state department of libraries board a certified copy of such ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1986, § 2-4; Code 2002, § 2-4) 
State Law reference- Municipal libraries, 11 O.S. § 31-101 et seq.; public libraries generally, 65 O.S. § 1-101 et seq.; library system governing boards, 65 O.S. § 4-103 et seq. 
Sec. 2-4. - Sale of real property. 
(a)  Any real property owned by the city which has been determined by the city commission to no longer be needed for public purposes may be sold by the city by public auction, sealed bids or on the open market. 
(b)  Before sale, the commission must obtain an appraisal of the property, with the appraised amount confidential. The appraisal will be kept in the office of the city manager. 
(c)  If the property is to be sold at public auction, notice of the sale shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days prior to the auction. 
(d)  If the property is to be sold pursuant to sealed bids, notice to prospective bidders shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days prior to the opening of bids. All bids shall be filed in duplicate, one with the city clerk and one with the city manager, and such bids shall be accompanied by a noncollusion affidavit. The city commission, in its discretion, may require a bid bond to accompany such bids. 
(e)  If the property is to be sold on the open market, notice that the property is available for purchase shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 60 days prior to the time the city will consider offers. No real estate or other sales commission will be paid by the city. The city commission, in its discretion, may require earnest money to accompany an offer. 
(f)  At the end of the auction, upon the opening of bids, or upon receipt of an offer, the city manager shall open the appraisal. If the price offered is not at least 80 percent of the appraised price of the property, the property will not be sold and the appraisal will remain confidential. If the property is sold by sealed bid or on the open market, the commission must review all bids and offers to determine the highest and best bid or offer. The commission may accept or reject any bid or offer for any reason. 
(Code 1986, § 2-5; Code 2002, § 2-5; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 3, 4-7-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority regarding property generally, 11 O.S. § 22-101. 
Sec. 2-5. - Sale of nonreal-estate property. 
    Any nonreal-estate property owned by the city that has been determined by the city commission to no longer be needed for public purposes may be sold by the city at either public auction, by sealed bids or through the use of an on-line auction service as the city commission may direct. If such sale is to be made at public auction, notice of the sale shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days prior to the sale. If such sale is to be made pursuant to sealed bids, notice to prospective bidders shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days prior to the opening of bids. All such bids shall be filed in duplicate. One shall be filed with the city clerk and the other filed with the city manager, and such bids shall be accompanied by a noncollusion affidavit. If such sale is to be made through the use of an on-line auction service, notice of the beginning of the sale shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days prior to the sale. Said notice shall describe the length of time that said on-line auction shall last, with such duration to be determined by the city manager. 
(Code 2002, § 2-6; Ord. No. 2105NS, § 1, 10-6-2003) 
Secs. 2-6-2-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COMMISSION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-29. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members elected to the city commission shall constitute a quorum to do business, but a lesser number may adjourn from time to time. 
(Code 1986, § 2-21; Code 2002, § 2-31) 
Sec. 2-30. - Preparation of agenda. 
    An agenda shall be prepared by the city manager. The city manager or any commissioner can place an item on the agenda. Once the agenda has been prepared, it shall be forwarded to the city clerk, who shall prepare and post the official agenda. If the item is to reconsider a previous vote of the city commission, the item to reconsider may only be placed on the agenda by commissioners who voted in the majority on the vote sought to be reconsidered. 
(Code 1986, § 2-21.1; Code 2002, § 2-32; Ord. No. 2311NS, § 1, 5-7-2007; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 4, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-31. - Presiding officer; calling meetings to order; reading of minutes. 
    The mayor shall act as presiding officer of the city commission at all meetings. He shall take the chair at the prescribed hour and shall call the city commission to order, order the calling of the roll by the clerk and determine whether a quorum exists. 
(Code 1986, § 2-22; Code 2002, § 2-33; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 5, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-32. - Rules of procedure at meetings. 
(a)  The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall govern the city commission in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with the ordinances, standing rules and orders of the commission. 
(b)  When any member speaks or otherwise presents any matter to the city commission, he shall confine himself to the matter under consideration and avoid personalities. 
(c)  When the mayor is putting any question or addressing the commission, no member thereof shall walk out or across the hall, nor, in such case or when a member is speaking, shall any other member entertain any private discourse. If any member leaves the room after an item has been called, he may not participate in debate or vote on that matter. 
(d)  No member shall text, e-mail, telephone or privately communicate with any other person, including any other member, during a commission meeting. 
(e)  Every member who shall be in the meeting when a question is put shall give his vote of aye, nay or abstain, unless the commission for special reasons shall excuse him. All motions to excuse a member from voting shall be made before the commission and before the call of the ayes and nays is commenced. Any member requesting to be excused from voting may make a brief verbal statement of the reason for making such request, and the question shall then be taken without further debate. An excused commissioner, or one who intends to abstain at the time of the vote, shall not participate in debate on the question. 
(f)  When a motion is made and seconded, it shall be stated by the mayor or, being in writing, it shall be handed to the chair and read aloud by the clerk before debate. 
(g)  Every motion shall be reduced to writing, if the mayor or any member shall request it. 
(h)  After a motion is stated by the mayor or read by the clerk, it shall be deemed to be in the possession of the commission, but it may be withdrawn at any time before a decision or amendment. 
(i)  When a question is under debate, no motion shall be received, but to adjourn, to lay on the table, for the previous question or to amend, which several motions shall have precedence in the order in which they are named in this subsection. 
(j)  A motion to adjourn and a motion to fix a day to which the commission shall adjourn shall always be in order. These motions and the motion to lay on the table shall be decided without debate. 
(k)  No motion or proposition on a subject different from that under consideration shall be admitted under color of amendment. No bill or resolution shall at any time be amended by annexing thereto or incorporating therewith any other bill or resolution pending before the commission. 
(l)  When a motion has once been made and carried in the affirmative or negative, it shall be in order for any member of the majority to move for the reconsideration thereof, at the same or the succeeding session, and each motion shall take precedence over all other questions, except a motion to adjourn. The motion to reconsider shall require for its adoption the same vote as was required on the vote reconsidered. 
(m)  Upon roll calls of the city commission or in taking the ayes and nays upon any question, the names of the members shall be called by the clerk or votes may be cast and shown by other means, so long as the vote of each commissioner is individually cast and recorded. 
(Code 1986, § 2-23; Code 2002, § 2-34; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 6, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-33. - Procedure for passage of ordinances, resolutions and other acts. 
    Every proposed ordinance, resolution and other act shall be presented to the city commission by the mayor, a member of the city commission or the city manager, and none other. Upon being presented to the city commission, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to at once enroll the proposed ordinance, resolution or other act, whereupon it shall be before the city commission and cannot be withdrawn without the consent of the commission. After reading the proposed ordinance, resolution or other act by title and consideration by the commission, a vote shall be taken, upon the motion of any member of the commission that the proposed ordinance, resolution or other act be passed and approved. Prior to a final vote, the proposed ordinance, resolution or other act shall be subject to amendment by any member of the commission or the mayor. Such amendments shall be in writing. When a proposed ordinance, resolution or other act is amended in any manner, it shall be the duty of the clerk to prepare the proposed ordinance, resolution or other act in its amended form before the final vote is taken. The vote shall be on the proposed ordinance, resolution or other act together with any amendments made thereto and shall be on the question "Shall the proposed ordinance, resolution or other act be passed and approved?" Proposed ordinances, resolutions and other acts that fail passage shall be filed by the city clerk in the archives of his office. Proposed ordinances, resolutions and other acts that are passed and approved shall be engrossed by the city clerk and presented to the mayor or acting mayor, as the case may be, for his signature and shall be attested by the city clerk, after which they shall be published as required by law or the Charter and the original engrossed copy filed in the archives of the city clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 2-24; Code 2002, § 2-35) 
State Law reference- Municipal ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-101 et seq.; publication of ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-106. 
Sec. 2-34. - Duties of mayor at meetings. 
    At meetings of the city commission, the mayor shall preserve order and decorum and may speak on points of order in preference to other members. He shall decide all questions of order, subject to appeal to the commission by any member. 
(Code 1986, § 2-25; Code 2002, § 2-36; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 7, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-35. - Appointment of committees. 
    All committees of the city commission shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city commission, unless otherwise specifically directed by the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 2-26; Code 2002, § 2-37; Ord. No. 2248NS, § 1, 4-17-2006) 
Sec. 2-36. - Signing and attesting of ordinances, resolutions or other acts. 
    All ordinances, resolutions or other acts of the city commission shall be signed by the mayor or acting mayor, as the case may be, and attested by the city clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 2-27; Code 2002, § 2-38) 
Sec. 2-37. - Duties of chief of police; sergeant at arms. 
    The chief of police shall be ex officio sergeant at arms, and it shall be his duty to attend the city commission during its sessions, to execute the commands of the commission from time to time, together with all such process, issued by authority thereof, as shall be directed to him by the mayor. 
(Code 1986, § 2-28; Code 2002, § 2-39) 
Sec. 2-38. - Executive sessions. 
    The city commission may at any time go into executive session by a vote of a majority of the commission in favor thereof, at which session only those subjects shall be considered that are mentioned in the motion for the session, and no ordinances shall be passed, claims allowed, or any other action taken at the session. In all respects the conduct of an executive session shall be in conformance with the laws of the State of Oklahoma. 
(Code 1986, § 2-29; Code 2002, § 2-40; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 8, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-39. - Record of proceedings. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to attend every meeting of the city commission and to keep a journal of all the proceedings taken by the city commission. He shall enter every motion with its second in such journal, together with the action taken thereon by the city commission. The journal shall show when and by whom each proposed ordinance was introduced and the action taken thereon by the city commission. Such journal shall further show the action taken by the commission in every matter by which the city may be bound in law. 
(Code 1986, § 2-30; Code 2002, § 2-41) 
State Law reference- Ordinance book, 11 O.S. § 14-105. 
Sec. 2-40. - Mayor as official representative of city. 
    The mayor, in addition to the duties imposed upon him by the Charter, shall be the official representative of the city in all matters of state, public ceremony and public gatherings. As such, he shall address formal gatherings in an appropriate manner and in the city's behalf. 
(Code 1986, § 2-31; Code 2002, § 2-42) 
Sec. 2-41. - Citizen participation at city commission meetings. 
(a)  It is the intent and purpose of the City of Shawnee by adoption of the ordinance codified in this section to ensure that persons desiring to address the city commission on matters pertaining to public business are afforded an opportunity to do so. 
(b)  At every regular city commission meeting, a time for citizen participation shall be placed on the agenda before commissioners comments and before the commission takes up its regular business. Citizen participation shall be limited to that portion of the meeting except when related to public hearings. 
(c)  Citizen comments are limited to three minutes per individual, 12 minutes per topic and 24 minutes per meeting unless an extension is proposed by a commission member and approved by a majority of commission members. 
(d)  Citizens wishing to address the city commission in accordance with this section shall abide by the following rules: 
(1)  Stand and be recognized by the mayor or presiding officer. 
(2)  Approach the podium, state name, and sign the sign-in sheet. 
(3)  Distribute any handouts to the city commission and city clerk. 
(4)  Restrict comments to city business, whether or not on the agenda. Speaking for or against candidates for public office, issues on a ballot pending an election, personnel issues, and city business involving arbitration or litigation are prohibited. 
(5)  State whether speaking as an individual or for a group or organization. 
(6)  Address comments to the commission as a body, not to any member thereof. 
(7)  Address questions to the mayor or presiding officer. 
(8)  Speak respectfully. Profanity and personal attacks will not be tolerated. 
(e)  City commission members shall not enter into a dialogue with the speaker during the speaker's allotted time except to ask for clarification. After the speaker leaves the podium and before the next speaker is called, commissioners may respond to speaker's comments, subject to rules of the Oklahoma Open Meeting Act. 
(f)  The city commission will take no action on matters presented during citizens participation. If the item is elsewhere on the agenda, it will be addressed by the commission at that time. Questions may be referred to the city manager for an answer, or the matter may be placed on a future meeting agenda. 
(g)  Speakers may not speak with commission members after leaving the podium and may not speak from their seat unless called upon by the mayor or presiding officer. 
(h)  If any citizen violates these rules, the mayor may declare the speaker out of order and retake the floor. If the speaker does not comply, they may be asked to leave or if necessary, escorted from the meeting. 
(Code 2002, § 2-43; Ord. No. 2558NS, § 1, 2-17-2015) 
Secs. 2-42-2-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VICE-MAYOR 

Sec. 2-71. - Office created. 
    The office of vice-mayor of the city is created. 
(Code 1986, § 2-46; Code 2002, § 2-71) 
Sec. 2-72. - Member of city commission; election; term. 
    The vice-mayor shall be one of the members of the city commission. The vice-mayor shall be elected by the city commission and shall serve for a term of 12 months from the date of election by the city commission or until his successor has been named by the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 2-47; Code 2002, § 2-72) 
Sec. 2-73. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The duties of the vice-mayor shall be to act in the absence or incapacity of the mayor in connection with an emergency situation that requires immediate action and that would result in irreparable damage to persons or property if such action were delayed. The vice-mayor shall, in such emergency situations, have the power to act and do any and all things reasonable and necessary that the mayor could do if personally present. 
(Code 1986, § 2-48; Code 2002, § 2-73) 
Sec. 2-74. - Emergency appointment or removal of officers. 
    The vice-mayor shall have no power to make appointments or remove officers appointed by the mayor, and his power shall be limited to such emergency situations as are normally arising out of natural disasters, fires, acts of violence and similar occurrences. 
(Code 1986, § 2-49; Code 2002, § 2-74) 
Secs. 2-75-2-91. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY MANAGER 

Sec. 2-92. - Control of administrative work. 
    All administrative work of the city government shall be under the control of the city manager, except such functions as are by the Charter and appropriate sections of this Code or any other city ordinances in accordance therewith assigned otherwise. 
(Code 1986, § 2-66; Code 2002, § 2-101) 
Sec. 2-93. - Appointment and dismissal of officers and employees. 
(a)  The city manager, except as otherwise provided in the Charter, shall appoint all employees in the administrative service under his control. 
(b)  The city manager shall have power to transfer employees from one department to another and to remove and discharge the employees at his pleasure. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided by the Charter, the city manager may, in his discretion, dismiss the head of any department or any employees therein. He shall have the power to set aside the action taken by any official or employee working under his supervision and may supersede him in the functions of his office or employment. Where no provision is made by the Charter, this Code or any other city ordinance authorizing a subordinate official to act as department head if a vacancy occurs, the city manager may designate an interim acting head or perform personally the functions of the office. 
(Code 1986, § 2-67; Code 2002, § 2-102) 
Sec. 2-94. - Investigation and survey of departments, bureaus, divisions, offices and employees. 
    The city manager shall have power to investigate and make a survey of any city department, bureau, division, office or employee and, with the approval of the city commission, may employ experts, legal counsel or consultants to aid him in such investigation or survey. 
(Code 1986, § 2-68; Code 2002, § 2-103) 
Sec. 2-95. - Rules and regulations for conduct of departments. 
    The city manager may prescribe such general rules and regulations as he may deem necessary or expedient for the general conduct of the administrative departments. The director or head of each department shall in like manner prescribe such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary and expedient for the proper conduct of his department, not inconsistent with the general rules and regulations made by the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 2-69; Code 2002, § 2-104) 
Sec. 2-96. - Preparation and coordination of budget. 
    The city manager, as the city's chief budget officer, shall be held responsible for planning the activities of the city government and for adjusting such activities to the finances available. To this end, he shall prepare annually a complete financial plan for the ensuing year and shall be responsible for the administration of such plan when adopted by the city commission. He shall be charged with the bringing together of estimates covering the city's financial needs, with the checking of these estimates against the information relative to past expenditures and income, with the preparation of the budget document and supporting schedules and with the presentation of the budget to the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 2-70; Code 2002, § 2-105) 
State Law reference- Municipal finances, 11 O.S. § 17-101 et seq.; Municipal Budget Act, 11 O.S. § 17-201 et seq.; application of act, 11 O.S. § 17-203. 
Sec. 2-97. - Approval of vouchers and requisitions. 
    The city manager shall approve all requisitions and vouchers for the administrative departments in person or through such assistants as he may designate for the purpose. 
(Code 1986, § 2-71; Code 2002, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-98. - Purchases of supplies and equipment. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by applicable law or ordinance, all city purchases shall be made by the city purchasing agent. The city manager shall act as purchasing agent until otherwise provided by this Code or any other city ordinance consistent with applicable law and the Charter. To this end, he shall prepare suitable forms for the estimated needs of the several departments and determine the time and the manner of filing the forms in his office. He is authorized to make any purchases that he deems necessary for the proper functioning of the city government, provided that all purchases shall conform strictly to the conditions of the budget and the Charter. 
(b)  Pursuant to article XV, section 1 of the Charter, the city manager shall contract for and purchase or shall issue purchase orders for all services, supplies, materials and equipment for the offices, departments and agencies of the city government in an amount not exceeding $25,000.00, if budgeted, without prior approval of the city commissioners. If the city manager contracts for or issues purchase orders for services, supplies, materials or equipment with funds not previously budgeted, he may only expend up to $10,000.00 without prior approval of the city commission. The commission shall invite competitive written bids upon all contracts or purchases involving expenditures over $25,000.00. However, nothing contained in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit the expenditure of funds, the making of purchases or the letting of contracts without competitive bidding in an emergency. 
(Code 1986, § 2-72; Code 2002, § 2-107; Ord. No. 2315NS, § 1, 6-18-2007; Ord. No. 2340NS, § 1, 3-10-2008; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 9, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-99. - Purchase of personal property by negotiation. 
    Whenever the city shall have advertised for bids to purchase supplies, goods, products, equipment, machinery or any other tangible personal property and either no bid is received or the lowest bid received is unacceptable to the city, the city commission may authorize the city manager to make such purchases on the open market by negotiation. If such purchases are to be made after an unacceptable bid has been received, the price paid by the city shall not exceed the lowest bid received. 
(Code 1986, § 2-73; Code 2002, § 2-108) 
State Law reference- Negotiation of certain construction contracts, 61 O.S. § 119.1. 
Sec. 2-100. - Airport manager. 
    The city manager shall serve as airport manager. 
(Code 1986, § 2-74; Code 2002, § 2-109) 
Sec. 2-101. - Department reports; annual report. 
    The city manager shall determine the nature, quantity and frequency of information to be presented to him in the form of periodic or special reports by the heads of the several departments. Such information shall include the services rendered by the department, projects under way, general conditions in the department, comparative unit cost and proposals of the department head for increasing the efficiency of such department and the service rendered by it to the public. The city manager shall prepare and present to the city commission an annual report of the city's affairs. 
(Code 1986, § 2-75; Code 2002, § 2-110) 
Sec. 2-102. - Police powers. 
    The city manager shall have power to take personal charge over the police in times of an emergency for the protection of persons and property. He shall have power, in times of emergencies, to deputize or otherwise employ such other persons as he may consider necessary for the purpose of protecting the city and its residents. 
(Code 1986, § 2-76; Code 2002, § 2-111) 
Sec. 2-103. - Enforcement of franchises. 
    The city manager shall be charged with the enforcement of all obligations resting upon the holder of any franchise granted by the city and to impose such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary in the interest of the city and as provided by the terms of the franchise. 
(Code 1986, § 2-77; Code 2002, § 2-112) 
Sec. 2-104. - Responsibility for public utilities. 
    The city manager shall secure and keep the necessary data and shall be responsible for the proper determination of public utility rates and charges. He shall see that the city is adequately represented in all controversies to which the city is a party before any utility commission or lawfully constituted board of any character. 
(Code 1986, § 2-78; Code 2002, § 2-113) 
State Law reference- Corporation Commission of Oklahoma, 17 O.S. § 1 et seq. 
Secs. 2-105-2-121. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal officers, 11 O.S. § 8-101 et seq.; certain officers to give bond, 11 O.S. § 8-105. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-122. - Compliance with orders and rules. 
    It shall be the duty of the head of each department, together with every employee thereof, to be governed by the orders, rules and regulations established and promulgated by the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 2-91; Code 2002, § 2-141) 
Sec. 2-123. - Political activities. 
(a)  City employees may attend and express their views at city commission meetings or any other public meetings of municipal entities. 
(b)  Any city employee may actively participate in partisan and nonpartisan political activities, provided the political activity in which the employee participates shall be exercised only during off-duty hours and while not in uniform. Any federal statutes restricting the political activities of certain city employees shall supersede this section as to such employees. 
(c)  No city employee shall file as a candidate for public office of the city while employed by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 2-93; Code 2002, § 2-143) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 11 O.S. § 22-101.1. 
Sec. 2-124. - Surrender of property to successor. 
    No person having been a city officer shall wrongfully refuse to surrender all books, papers or other property coming into his possession as such officer, when so requested to do so by his successor in office or upon the written order of the city manager or city commission or other duly authorized city official. 
(Code 1986, § 2-94; Code 2002, § 2-144) 
Secs. 2-125-2-146. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY ATTORNEY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Prosecuting officer in municipal court, 11 O.S. § 27-108; legal advisor of police pension board, 11 O.S. § 50-108; use of city attorney's name in municipal action or proceeding, 21 O.S. § 577; enforcement of liquor laws by city attorney, 37 O.S. § 569; procedures as to sinking funds, 62 O.S. § 541. 

Sec. 2-147. - Department of law. 
    The department of law shall consist of the city attorney and such assistants of a special or general nature as the city commission shall approve. The employees of the department of law shall be governed by all city personnel policies and general directives of the city manager; however, they shall be under the daily control of the city attorney, including, for purposes of recommending to the commission or initial employment, discipline and termination. 
(Code 1986, § 2-106; Code 2002, § 2-171; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 11, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-148. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal adviser of the city government and of all its departments, and he shall represent the city as attorney and counsel in all proceedings in which the city is a party before any court or any governmental commission with judicial power. 
(Code 1986, § 2-107; Code 2002, § 2-172) 
Sec. 2-149. - Employment of special investigators. 
    With the approval of the city manager, the city attorney shall have authority to employ competent persons to investigate cases and other matters in his charge and to perform further necessary services in connection therewith. The city attorney shall have authority to require such persons to gather and preserve the evidence in any case in which the city may be a party. All costs arising on account of such services or by virtue of any investigation authorized in this section shall be paid out of the city's general fund. 
(Code 1986, § 2-108; Code 2002, § 2-173) 
Sec. 2-150. - Records. 
    The city attorney shall preserve in his office a record of all cases in which the city is interested in any of the courts and shall enter or cause to be entered therein abstracts of all proceedings of such cases. He shall also preserve in his office copies of all written opinions furnished by him to the city commission, city manager or any city officer or employee. Any docket, copies and papers kept by the city attorney under this section shall be the city's property, and the city attorney shall, on retiring from office, deliver the docket, copies and papers, together with all accounts, vouchers and necessary information related thereto, to his successor in office. 
(Code 1986, § 2-109; Code 2002, § 2-174) 
Sec. 2-151. - Custody of papers; use of documents. 
    The city attorney shall have charge of all legal papers, books and dockets belonging to the city and, upon leaving a receipt therefor, may demand and receive from any city officer or employee any book, paper or document necessary to be used in any suit or required for the purposes of his office. 
(Code 1986, § 2-110; Code 2002, § 2-175) 
Sec. 2-152. - Furnishing of opinions. 
    Whenever the city manager, the head of any department, the city commission, a member of the commission or other responsible city officer may desire the city attorney's opinion on any matter affecting his official capacity, he shall clearly state to the city attorney in writing the question on which the opinion is desired. Within a reasonable time the city attorney shall reply orally or in writing, as requested, to such inquiry. 
(Code 1986, § 2-111; Code 2002, § 2-176) 
Sec. 2-153. - Preparation of ordinances, bonds, contracts, bonds and other instruments. 
    The city attorney shall prepare, when requested to do so, all ordinances, resolutions, contracts, bonds and other instruments in writing in which the city is concerned. 
(Code 1986, § 2-112; Code 2002, § 2-177) 
Sec. 2-154. - Attendance at meetings. 
    The city attorney shall be present at all meetings of the city commission and upon invitation in writing at any committee meeting of the commission or any meeting of city officials. 
(Code 1986, § 2-113; Code 2002, § 2-178) 
Sec. 2-155. - Examination of records of officers. 
    It shall be the duty of the city attorney, acting upon the request of the city commission or the city manager, to examine the records of the different city officers, to give legal advice in connection with the records and to make reports to the city manager or to the commission as the conditions may justify. 
(Code 1986, § 2-114; Code 2002, § 2-179) 
Sec. 2-156. - Enforcement of obligations and contracts. 
    When an obligation or contract made on behalf of the city, granting a right or easement or creating a public duty, is being evaded or violated, the city attorney shall apply for and seek to obtain such legal relief as the case may warrant. 
(Code 1986, § 2-115; Code 2002, § 2-180) 
Secs. 2-157-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Commission on training municipal clerks, treasurers and finance officers, 11 O.S. § 52-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-181. - Powers and duties. 
    The city clerk shall, in addition to the duties imposed on him by general law, perform such duties as are set forth by this Code or any other city ordinances, including the following: 
(1)  Custody of papers. The city clerk, after being duly qualified and sworn, shall take possession of all books, papers and all other property of the nature of records belonging to the city and pertaining to his office, and he shall keep the books, papers and records safe and in a convenient place, subject to the inspection of any member of the city commission within the established office hours. 
(2)  Attendance at meetings. The city clerk shall attend the meetings of the city commission and shall keep a correct and complete record of the proceedings at every meeting of the commission. 
(3)  Removal of records. The city clerk shall permit no city records, public papers or other city documents, kept and preserved in his office, to be taken therefrom, except by such city officers as may be entitled to the use of the records, papers or documents, and then only upon their leaving a receipt therefor. 
(4)  Preparation of commissions. The city clerk shall prepare all commissions of officers that the mayor or city manager is required to sign and shall countersign the commissions and affix the seal of the city thereto. He shall keep a complete record of all commissions issued and of the official oaths and bonds of all city officers. 
(5)  Drawing of warrants. It shall be the duty of the city clerk, after any claim has been allowed by the city commission, to draw a warrant in settlement of the claim. After such warrant has been examined and compared with the fund on which it is drawn and approved and signed by the city manager, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to attest the warrant with the official seal. All warrants shall be charged on the appropriation book before they are attested. 
(6)  Ordinance record. The city clerk shall keep all ordinances passed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, in their original form, in a manner required by the city commission. In a separate book, to be kept for that purpose, he shall keep printed copies of all ordinances, notices and other publications required by law, passed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, with the printer's certificate of publication attached thereto. He shall index the ordinances under the respective heads or titles. All old ordinances, records or other documents shall be carefully preserved in a manner approved by the city manager. 
(7)  Notice record. The city clerk shall procure a blank book with proper index in which he shall keep a copy of all notices required to be published or posted by order of the city commission or under this Code or any other city ordinances. Such notices shall have attached the printer's affidavit of publication, when notices are required to be published, or the city clerk's certificate under seal of the city, when the notices are required to be posted, mailed or served in any other manner. Such certificate shall show that such notice is a true and correct copy of the notices so posted, published or delivered by him; the number of the notices issued and the date of issuance; and whether done by special order of the city commission or by general ordinance, and the fact of publication shall be a matter of record. 
(8)  License record. The city clerk shall procure a blank book with proper index in which he shall keep a record of all licenses issued by him under this Code or any other city ordinances, showing the date of the issuance of the licenses, to whom issued, the time for which the licenses are issued, the amount paid to the city treasurer-finance director for the licenses, the city treasurer-finance director's receipt number and the nature of the license. The entries therein contained shall be competent evidence of the facts so set forth and shall be sufficient proof thereof. He shall issue all licenses authorized by this Code or any other city ordinance upon compliance with all provisions relating thereto. 
(9)  Permit record. The city clerk shall procure a blank book with proper index in which he shall keep a record of all permits issued, showing the date of issuing the permits, to whom issued, the amount paid, the nature of the privilege granted and the city treasurer-finance director's receipt number. 
(10)  Petition record. The city clerk shall keep in a suitable file a complete record of all petitions and communications under which the city commission shall order public work to be done at the expense of property fronting thereon, together with all resolutions relating to such. The petition file shall include all memorials or petitions and other communications addressed to the city commission for its action as a body. 
(11)  Correspondence file. The city clerk shall keep a suitable file for all correspondence and communications on matters pertaining to the city affairs coming into his possession. 
(12)  Delivery of communications. The city clerk shall, without unnecessary delay, deliver to the city officers and to all committees of the city commission all resolutions and communications referred to those officers or committees by that body. He shall also, in the same manner, deliver to the mayor all ordinances or resolutions which may require his approval or other action to be taken by him. 
(13)  Copies of ordinances. The city clerk shall furnish copies of all ordinances passed by the city commission and shall preserve the original in his office. He shall be obligated to furnish written copies of ordinances or other papers for the use of any city officer without charge; attest any copy of a paper, document or record presented to him; and affix the seal of the city thereto. A charge in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per page shall be made for every photocopy made for individual use or a charge in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per page for certifying all ordinances, papers, records or commission proceedings desired for individual use, to be paid by the person ordering the photocopy. 
(14)  Filing date; indexing. The city clerk shall endorse the date of filing upon every paper or document filed in his office. All books and records kept by him shall be fully and properly indexed. 
(15)  Insurance file. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep and carefully preserve a file of all insurance policies in which the city has any interest. A suitable record shall be prepared of the insurance file showing the name of the insurer, the insured, the nature of the policy, the date and expiration of the policy, the amount of insurance and the amount of premium paid on each policy. It shall be his further duty to call the city commission's attention to the approaching maturity of any policy within such time as is reasonably necessary to provide for the renewal or extension of the policy. 
(16)  Bond file. The city clerk shall prepare and keep a file for all surety bonds, to be kept in an approved manner. A suitable record shall be kept of every surety bond in which the city shall be interested, in which shall be entered the date of the beginning of the undertaking and the date of the terminations of the liability on such bond; the names of the principals, sureties, cosureties and other parties to the bond; and the nature and the amount of the obligation. 
(17)  Issuance of notices. Wherever by this Code, any city ordinance or otherwise a notice is required for any obligation due the city, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue the notice. 
(Code 1986, § 2-126; Code 2002, § 2-206) 
State Law reference- Ordinance book, 11 O.S. § 14-105; warrants, 11 O.S. § 17-102, 62 O.S. § 551 et seq.; report of statistics as to fire department, 11 O.S. § 49-124; furnishing minutes to legal newspapers, 25 O.S. § 115; administration of oaths, 51 O.S. § 21; reports under workers' compensation law, 85 O.S. § 24.1. 
Sec. 2-182. - Employment of deputy city clerks. 
    The city manager shall appoint such deputy city clerks as may be necessary for the efficient discharge of the duties of such office, such appointments being made with the approval of the city commission. Such deputy clerks shall perform the duties assigned to them respectively by the city manager and the city clerk. They shall have power to perform any duties authorized by the city manager or city clerk to exercise the general powers of the city clerk insofar as necessary in the performance of the specific duties assigned them respectively. 
(Code 1986, § 2-127; Code 2002, § 2-207) 
Secs. 2-183-2-202. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RETIREMENT PLAN[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Retirement and pensions, 11 O.S. § 48-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-203. - Control and management of retirement system. 
    The control and management of the retirement system, the qualifications of the persons eligible for retirement benefits, the minimum age for retirement of employees and the limitations of the amounts to be paid to persons eligible for retirement benefits shall be as provided in this division and in state law. 
(Code 2002, § 2-236) 
Sec. 2-204. - Adopted; purpose. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the State of Oklahoma, and for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious service on the part of city employees and thereby promote public efficiency, there is hereby authorized created, established, and approved and adopted, effective as of January 1, 2011, the amended and restated plan designated "Employee Retirement System of the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma, Defined Benefit Plan," (hereinafter called system), an executed counterpart of which is marked Exhibit "A" (joinder agreement) and Exhibit "B" (amended and restated plan) which are on file in the office of the city clerk for public inspection and which are made a part of this division by reference. 
(Code 1986, § 2-141; Code 2002, § 2-237; Ord. No. 2448NS, § 1, 12-6-2010; Ord. No. 2509NS, § 1, 6-17-2013; Ord. No. 2554NS, § 1, 11-17-2014) 
Sec. 2-205. - Board of trustees.
