    For the purpose of administration of the employee retirement system, there is established a board of trustees, which shall be composed of the members of the city commission. The powers and duties of the board of trustees shall be as set forth in such system. 
(Code 1986, § 2-142; Code 2002, § 2-238) 
State Law reference- Control and management of system, 11 O.S. § 48-102. 
Sec. 2-206. - Establishment and use of fund. 
    A fund is hereby provided for the exclusive use and benefit of the persons entitled to benefits under the system. All contributions to such fund shall be paid over to and received in trust for such purpose by the city. Such fund shall be pooled for purposes of management and investment with similar funds of other incorporated cities, towns, and municipal trusts in the state as a part of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund in accordance with the trust agreement of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, a public trust. The city shall hold such contributions in the form received, and from time to time pay over and transfer the same to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, as duly authorized and directed by the board of trustees. The fund shall be nonfiscal and shall not be considered in computing any levy when the annual estimate is made to the county excise board. 
(Code 1986, § 2-143; Code 2002, § 2-239; Ord. No. 2448NS, § 2, 12-6-2010) 
Sec. 2-207. - Appropriations by city. 
    The city is hereby authorized to incur the necessary expenses for the establishment, operation, and administration of the system, and to appropriate and pay the same. In addition, the city is hereby authorized to appropriate annually such amounts as are required in addition to employee contributions to maintain the system and the fund in accordance with the provisions of the defined benefit plan. Any appropriation so made to maintain the system and fund shall be for deferred wages or salaries, and for the payment of necessary expenses of operation and administration to be transferred to the trustees of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund for such purposes and shall be paid into the fund when available, to be duly transferred to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund. 
(Code 1986, § 2-144; Code 2002, § 2-240; Ord. No. 2448NS, § 3, 12-6-2010) 
State Law reference- Annual appropriations, 11 O.S. § 48-104. 
Sec. 2-208. - Execution of instruments; contract with other municipalities. 
(a)  The mayor and city clerk be and they are each hereby authorized and directed to execute (in counterparts, each of which shall constitute an original) the system instrument, and to do all other acts and things necessary, advisable, and proper to put said system and related trust into full force and effect, and to make such changes therein as may be necessary to qualify the same under sections 401(a) and 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States. The counterpart marked as Exhibit "A" and Exhibit "B", which has been duly executed as aforesaid simultaneously with the passage of the ordinance from which this division derives and made a part hereof, is hereby ratified and confirmed in all respects and are on file in the office of the city clerk for public inspection and which are made a part of this division by reference. 
(b)  This committee is hereby authorized and directed to proceed immediately on behalf of the city to pool and combine the fund into the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund as a part thereof, with similar funds of such other cities and towns, for purposes of pooled management and investment. 
(Code 1986, § 2-145; Code 2002, § 2-241; Ord. No. 2448NS, § 4, 12-6-2010) 
Sec. 2-209. - Defined contribution plan. 
    The City of Shawnee Employee Retirement System Defined Contribution Plan is amended as shown on Ordinance No. 2643NS and incorporated herein by reference. 
(Code 2002, § 2-242; Ord. No. 2086NS, § 1, 3-3-2003; Ord. No. 2243NS, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2351NS, §§ 1-6, 5-5-2008; Ord. No. 2397NS, §§ 1-4, 3-2-2009; Ord. No. 2448NS, §§ 1-4, 12-6-2010; Ord. No. 2507NS, § 1, 6-17-2013; Ord. No. 2508NS, § 1, 6-17-2013; Ord. No. 2510NS, § 1, 6-17-2013; Ord. No. 2555NS, § 1, 11-17-2014; Ord. No. 2556NS, § 1, 11-17-2014; Ord. No. 2566NS, § 1, 6-15-2015; Ord. No. 2567NS, § 1, 6-15-2015; Ord. No. 2568NS, § 1, 6-15-2015; Ord. No. 2643NS, § 1, 10-1-2018) 
Secs. 2-210-2-226. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal finances, 11 O.S. § 17-101 et seq.; purchases and sales generally, 11 O.S. §§ 22-101, 22-104; supplies furnished by members of council, 21 O.S. § 355 et seq.; sale to city by person with criminal background, 51 O.S. § 24.3; competitive bids, 61 O.S. § 101 et seq.; contracts and expenditures, 62 O.S. § 310.1 et seq.; central purchasing, 74 O.S. § 85.1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-227. - Composition of treasury department. 
    The treasury department shall consist of the city treasurer-finance director and such subordinate officers as may be authorized from time to time. 
(Code 1986, § 2-161; Code 2002, § 2-271) 
Sec. 2-228. - Ex officio treasurers for certain purposes. 
    For the purpose of convenience in the enforcement of this Code and any other city ordinances relating to taxes, fees, licenses, certificates and other revenue sources, the city treasurer-finance director shall designate an official in each department or institution receiving money on any account for the city to act ex officio as deputy treasurer. Such deputy treasurer shall have the power and it shall be his duty to issue a treasurer's receipt for all money received by him on account of the performance of any duty lying within his department. 
(Code 1986, § 2-163; Code 2002, § 2-273) 
Sec. 2-229. - Obligations paid to treasury. 
    Every person indebted to the city shall pay such obligation in lawful money directly into the city treasury. 
(Code 1986, § 2-164; Code 2002, § 2-274) 
Sec. 2-230. - Collection of claims and money due to city. 
    The city treasurer-finance director shall make demand and receive from the county treasurer or other source all money received by him for the use of the city. Whenever any person is indebted to the city in any manner and the means of collection of such debt are not otherwise provided for by law or ordinance, the city treasurer-finance director shall be authorized and it shall be his duty to demand and receive the money. When any claim shall not be collectable by other methods, the city treasurer-finance director shall report the failure to collect the claim to the city manager. He shall maintain a continuous inspection of such taxes, licenses and privilege charges in order to effectuate their collection. 
(Code 1986, § 2-165; Code 2002, § 2-275) 
Sec. 2-231. - Receipts. 
    The city treasurer-finance director shall give a receipt for all money coming into his possession, to the payee of the money, showing from whom received, on what account the money was paid, the date of payment, the name of the payee and the amount actually paid. He shall supply each ex officio deputy treasurer with suitable blank receipt books to be used for the purposes provided in this section. It shall be the duty of the city treasurer-finance director and of each ex officio deputy treasurer to keep duplicate copies of every receipt issued by him, and each ex officio deputy treasurer shall make a daily settlement in full with the city treasurer-finance director for all money received by him as shown by his duplicate receipts. 
(Code 1986, § 2-166; Code 2002, § 2-276) 
Sec. 2-232. - Issuance of receipts to deputy treasurers. 
    The city treasurer-finance director shall issue a general receipt to each ex officio deputy treasurer at the time money is received from him by the city treasurer-finance director. Such receipt shall be issued for the exact amount of money received, showing the date, the amount and the department in which the money was collected. Such payments of money shall be accompanied by duplicate receipts of the ex officio deputy treasurer showing the sources of such money, and they shall balance with the money paid in. 
(Code 1986, § 2-167; Code 2002, § 2-277) 
Sec. 2-233. - Records of receipts; accounts. 
    The city treasurer-finance director shall keep such books of record as will show the full amount of money received, the source from which it was obtained, the nature or occasion for the payment of the money, the date and the person paying the money. He shall establish an account for each fund provided by the Charter, this Code, city ordinance or state law, charging himself with all money going into such funds and crediting himself for such amounts as he may lawfully pay out of each of such funds. 
(Code 1986, § 2-168; Code 2002, § 2-278) 
State Law reference- Deposits by treasurers, 62 O.S. § 516.5. 
Sec. 2-234. - Maintenance of revolving funds. 
    With the approval of the city manager, the city treasurer-finance director may establish and maintain a revolving fund in the office of any ex officio deputy treasurer sufficient for the needs of such office, provided that such amount shall be approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 2-169; Code 2002, § 2-279) 
Sec. 2-235. - Keeping of cash accounts. 
    The city treasurer-finance director shall keep the city's cash accounts, which accounts shall clearly and fully show all money received and disbursed by him in behalf of the city, setting forth the date of receipt, from whom received, the date of disbursement, to whom disbursed, the amount of such disbursement and for what or on what account the money was received or disbursed. His accounts shall provide for all special funds provided by ordinance or funds of a general or special nature required by the Charter or state law. 
(Code 1986, § 2-170; Code 2002, § 2-280) 
Sec. 2-236. - Payment of money. 
    The city treasurer-finance director shall pay out money only on warrant drawn, signed and attested as required by the Charter, provided that he shall make such investments, purchases and payments out of the sinking fund as are authorized by the Charter and state law, and such payments shall be in the manner provided by the Charter and state law. Further, special funds may be disbursed by the treasurer-finance director by the issuance of treasurer's checks. 
(Code 1986, § 2-171; Code 2002, § 2-281) 
State Law reference- Payment of invoice or account, 11 O.S. § 17-102; authorized investments generally, 62 O.S. § 348.1; sinking fund, 62 O.S. § 431 et seq.; warrants, 62 O.S. §§ 471 et seq., 551 et seq.; investment of sinking funds, 62 O.S. §§ 541, 562. 
Sec. 2-237. - Records and cancellation of warrants and bonds. 
(a)  The city treasurer-finance director shall keep a register of all warrants paid by him and shall describe each warrant by date, number and amount and the name of the payee. All warrants so paid shall be cancelled. Warrants cancelled by paying banking institutions shall be considered as cancelled, as required by this section. 
(b)  The city treasurer-finance director shall keep a book, in which shall be kept for that purpose a complete list of every bond and coupon outstanding against the city, showing the date of maturity, to whom sold and the amount of the payment falling due, whether principal or interest. Such book shall also show the date of payment of any outstanding bond or interest coupon, the amount thereof actually paid and the number of the bond or interest coupon retired. 
(c)  The city treasurer-finance director shall cancel all bonds, coupons, warrants and other evidences of debt against the city, unless cancelled by the paying banking institution, whenever paid by him, by writing or stamping across the face thereof the word "paid," with the date of payment written or stamped thereon. 
(Code 1986, § 2-172; Code 2002, § 2-282) 
State Law reference- Record of warrants issued, 62 O.S. §§ 472, 475; marking of warrants when paid, 62 O.S. § 551. 
Sec. 2-238. - Receipts and warrants to indicate affected fund. 
    All receipts for money received shall show, on their face, the particular account or fund to which the money shall be applied. Every warrant which the city treasurer-finance director shall pay shall show on its face the particular account or fund out of which the warrant shall be paid. 
(Code 1986, § 2-173; Code 2002, § 2-283) 
State Law reference- Warrants recorded in the numerical order issued on each fund, 62 O.S. § 472. 
Sec. 2-239. - Monthly report. 
    It shall be the duty of the city treasurer-finance director at the end of each month to report to the city manager a statement of the financial transactions of his office for the month ending, which statement shall be in writing and under his oath. 
(Code 1986, § 2-174; Code 2002, § 2-284) 
Sec. 2-240. - Investments; disposition of income. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by law, the city treasurer-finance director is authorized to invest any monies in his custody in the following: 
(1)  Direct obligations of the federal government to the payment of which the full faith and credit of the Government of the United States or of the state is pledged; 
(2)  Certificates of deposits of savings and loan associations, banks and trust companies when such certificates of deposits are secured by acceptable collateral as in the deposit of other public monies; or 
(3)  Savings accounts or savings certificates of savings and loan associations, banks and trust companies, to the extent that such accounts or certificates are fully insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, or the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. 
(b)  The investment may be made whenever the city commission shall determine by resolution that such monies cannot then be used for the purpose for which they are to be expended, provided that the income received from such investment may be placed in the general fund to be used for general governmental operations or in the sinking fund or the fund from which the investment was made. 
(Code 1986, § 2-175; Code 2002, § 2-285) 
State Law reference- Authorized investments generally, 62 O.S. § 348.1. 
Sec. 2-241. - Payment of judgments against city. 
    Any judgment rendered by any court of competent jurisdiction against the city may be paid by the city from currently available funds or pursuant to the provisions of state statutes regarding payment from the sinking fund. 
(Code 1986, § 2-176; Code 2002, § 2-286; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 13, 4-7-2014) 
State Law reference- Judgments against municipalities, 62 O.S. § 361 et seq. 
Sec. 2-242. - Purchases of goods, services and capital. 
(a)  All department heads are designated as purchasing officers and are authorized to make purchases against budget appropriation accounts under their direct control. Each department head may also designate one or more employees who are authorized to make purchases on his behalf. A written authorization form must be filed with and approved by the city treasurer-finance director for all employees authorized to make purchases in this manner. The city shall maintain an approved vendor listing for all purchases of goods and services by the city. It shall be the responsibility of the accounting department to establish procedures for an approved vendor. All purchases are to be made from the approved vendor list. 
(b)  Blanket purchase orders may be issued to vendors for recurring purchases of goods and services for up to $1,000.00. Only persons authorized in subsection (a) of this section shall be authorized to make such purchases. The authorization of blanket purchase orders shall only be issued to vendors on the approved vendor list. 
(c)  Except as exempted in this section, for purchases of goods, services or capital a requisition must be prepared providing information about the requested purchase including vendor name, description, quantity, and unit price. The requisition may be an electronic or paper document. Requisition procedures shall be as follows: 
(1)  It is the responsibility of the employee requesting the purchase to obtain the goods, services or capital at the lowest price possible to the city for comparable goods, services or capital. For large purchases, this responsibility includes adherence to the requirements for city commission approval and competitive bidding as described in section 2-98. For all purchases, the requisition should include documentation of bids or catalog prices from other vendors. If a purchase is requested that is not the lowest price available, justification must be included with the requisition. 
(2)  The requisition must be approved according to the routing schedule for each department. The approval routing process shall be reviewed by the accounting department to provide assurance that internal controls are maintained. If the requisition is a paper document, the department head must initial the requisition to document the department head's approval. If the requisition is an electronic document, the department head's approval must also be electronic. The electronic approval process must be under adequate computer security. 
(3)  After approval, the requisition is routed to the encumbering clerk who shall verify that there exist available unencumbered appropriations in the accounts to be charged. Upon such verification, the encumbering clerk shall attest to that fact by approving the requisition either through a manual or electronic approval process. If appropriations are not available for the proposed purchase or commitment, the purchase or commitment shall not proceed until budget amendments are authorized to provide sufficient appropriations. 
(4)  After the encumbering clerk has approved the requisition, it is routed to the city treasurer-finance director for final approval either through a manual or electronic approval process. Upon approval by the city treasurer-finance director, an encumbrance shall be recorded against the appropriation and expenditure records in the amount or estimated amount of the commitment, and the purchase order is issued. The purchase order will be signed by the city treasurer-finance director either through facsimile or manual signature. Appropriate computer and physical security must be maintained over the facsimile signature of the city treasurer-finance director. 
(5)  These encumbering requirements shall not apply to the following type of purchases or commitments: 
a.  Payroll disbursements. 
b.  Debt service payments. 
c.  Interfund transfers. 
d.  Workers' compensation claims. 
e.  Contractual agreements. 
f.  Utility and telephone services. 
(d)  Each city department shall have designated employees as "receiving clerks." A form shall be on file in the accounting department disclosing the receiving clerks with each clerk's signature on file. The persons assigned shall be independent of any authority to make purchases. 
(e)  After satisfactory delivery of the merchandise or completion of contract provisions, an invoice shall be obtained adequately documenting the request for payment. The employee receiving satisfactory delivery of the merchandise or contract service shall acknowledge such fact by signing the bill of lading and/or receipt and forwarding these documents to the accounting department. The invoice shall be forwarded to the employee responsible for processing accounts payable who shall review the invoice for accuracy and propriety, including comparison to the authorized requisition, purchase order or contract, if applicable. After completion of the accounts payable review, all invoices ready for payment shall be listed on an accounts payable register. This register shall be submitted to the city treasurer-finance director for review and written approval. 
(f)  Upon approval of the accounts payable register, checks shall be prepared and submitted to the city treasurer-finance director, along with a copy of the accounts payable register. The treasurer-finance director shall compare the checks to the accounts payable register and verify their accuracy. Upon verification, the treasurer-finance director and the city manager shall sign the checks. The city clerk shall attest the city manager's signature. Facsimile signatures shall be used on these checks under appropriate computer and physical security. In addition, the city treasurer-finance director shall prepare or cause to be prepared a check register. 
(g)  The city treasurer-finance director shall record or cause to be recorded in the appropriate journals and ledgers the purchases and cash disbursements incurred and paid. 
(h)  A copy of the approved accounts payable register must be provided to the mayor and city commission for informational purposes each week prior to any payments; however, city commission approval is not required prior to the payment of the invoices, if incurred and paid in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1986, § 2-178; Code 2002, § 2-288) 
Sec. 2-243. - Debt service. 
(a)  All long-term city indebtedness, in the form of bonds, notes or lease purchase obligations, shall only be incurred in the manner provided by law. 
(b)  Once lawfully incurred, payments of principal and interest on the bonds or notes and payments on the lease purchase obligations shall be paid in accordance with the terms as specified in the bond indenture, note agreement or lease purchase contract by the city treasurer-finance director without further approval of the city commission. 
(c)  The manner of payment shall be consistent with the manner used for the payment of purchases of goods, services or capital as described in section 2-242. 
(d)  The city treasurer-finance director shall record or cause to be recorded in the appropriate journals and ledgers all debt service payments. 
(Code 1986, § 2-179; Code 2002, § 2-289) 
Sec. 2-244. - Interfund transfers. 
(a)  All transfers of resources between funds, both operating and residual equity transfers, shall only be made in accordance with city commission appropriations. Such appropriations shall be contained in the original or amended city budget. 
(b)  Once lawfully appropriated, interfund transfer payments may be made by the city treasurer-finance director without further city commission approval. Such transfers, however, may not exceed the amount lawfully appropriated. 
(c)  The manner of payment shall be consistent with the manner used for payment of purchases of goods, services and capital as described in section 2-242. 
(d)  The treasurer-finance director shall record or cause to be recorded in the appropriate journals and ledgers all interfund transfers. 
(Code 1986, § 2-180; Code 2002, § 2-290) 
Sec. 2-245. - Petty cash. 
(a)  As provided for in 11 O.S. § 17-102(D), the city may have petty cash accounts for use in making certain small payments for costs incurred in operating the city. 
(b)  Each petty cash account established shall require city commission approval, including the amount of the petty cash imprest balances. However, in no case shall the imprest balance exceed $1,000.00. 
(c)  The petty cash accounts shall be reimbursed by utilizing properly itemized invoices or petty cash voucher slips and by then processing the reimbursement in the manner used for payment of purchases of goods, services and capital as described in section 2-242. 
(Code 1986, § 2-181; Code 2002, § 2-291; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 15, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-246. - Workers' compensation claims. 
(a)  For workers' compensation claims, the city shall designate a service agent and retain a licensed adjuster, as required. The personnel director shall act as service agent unless otherwise designated by the city manager. The adjuster is responsible to review all claims to determine that they are valid and meet all requirements of the state statutes. The adjuster will recommend to the service agent the appropriate disposition of each claim. The service agent shall approve the disposition of these claims. 
(b)  After the claims are approved by the service agent, checks shall be prepared in payment of the claims. At the discretion of the city treasurer-finance director, these checks may be prepared in a manner consistent with the payment of purchases of goods, services and capital, as described in section 2-242, or may be prepared by the licensed adjuster and drawn against a special city bank account established for the payment of workers' compensation claims. The checks shall be forwarded to the city treasurer-finance director along with a check register and other reports providing appropriate information about each claim. The treasurer-finance director will review the checks and accompanying reports for accuracy and verify that appropriations are available to pay the claims. After this review, the treasurer-finance director will sign the checks and release them for distribution. 
(c)  The city treasurer-finance director shall record or cause to be recorded in the appropriate journals and ledgers all workers' compensation disbursements. 
(Code 1986, § 2-182; Code 2002, § 2-292) 
Sec. 2-247. - Financial reporting. 
    The city treasurer-finance director shall prepare a monthly budget status report. The report shall be placed on the agenda for city commission acknowledgment at the second meeting following the close of the previous month. At a minimum, the report shall include the following information for each budgetary account within each fund included in the annual budget: 
(1)  Total budget. 
(2)  Year-to-date expenditures. 
(3)  Remaining budget. 
(4)  Outstanding encumbrances. 
(Code 1986, § 2-183; Code 2002, § 2-293) 
Sec. 2-248. - Applicability to public trusts. 
(a)  For all public trusts created pursuant to 60 O.S. §§ 176-180 for which the city is beneficiary and for which the trust's governing body (trustees) is comprised entirely of members of the city commission, the requirements of sections 2-242 through 2-247 shall apply. 
(b)  For the purposes of the public trusts, as used in subsection (a) of this section, the term "governing body" shall mean board of trustees of the trust, the term "chief executive officer" shall mean the trust manager as appointed by the trustees, and the term "city treasurer" shall mean the trust treasurer as appointed by the trustees or required by the trust indenture. 
(Code 1986, § 2-184; Code 2002, § 2-294) 
Secs. 2-249-2-274. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AUDITOR[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Annual audit of books and accounts, 11 O.S. § 17-105 et seq. 

Sec. 2-275. - Employment; qualifications; duties. 
    The city commission shall appoint an independent auditor for the city. Such auditor shall be a certified public accountant. It shall be his duty to keep and maintain a continuous current audit of the city's fiscal affairs to the end that all money received and disbursed shall be received in the manner provided by law, by the Charter or by ordinance and shall be disposed of strictly as provided by law, by the Charter or by ordinance. Audits and financial reports prepared by the auditor shall be directed to the city commission, and copies thereof shall be distributed to other persons as may be required by the city commission. The city auditor shall so perform the duties set forth in this division and such others as are generally accepted as in line with his duty so that he shall be in a position to give, on demand at any time by the city manager or the city commission, a report on the city's financial affairs or of any city officer or employee in full and complete form. 
(Code 1986, § 2-186; Code 2002, § 2-321) 
Sec. 2-276. - Advising board and manager. 
    The city auditor shall advise the city manager and the city commission of any occurrences which in his opinion need to be corrected. 
(Code 1986, § 2-187; Code 2002, § 2-322) 
Sec. 2-277. - Financial advice to employees. 
    It shall be the duty of the city auditor to advise every city official and employee receiving or paying out any money on the city's behalf as to the manner, propriety and the procedure for all acts of a fiscal nature. 
(Code 1986, § 2-188; Code 2002, § 2-323) 
Sec. 2-278. - Checking of accounts. 
    It shall be the duty of the city auditor to check each account of every city official from time to time as may be required by the city manager or the city commission. Such checking of the account shall include a complete examination of the money on hand or deposit, the receipts issued by such official, the balance on hand and the true and correct amount which should be in the possession of such official at the time of such examination. 
(Code 1986, § 2-189; Code 2002, § 2-324) 
Sec. 2-279. - Examination of relationships between accounts. 
    It shall be the duty of the auditor to examine into the relations of the financial affairs between different city officials who are required to receive or pay over money to one another to determine if the books and accounts of the one balance properly with the other. 
(Code 1986, § 2-190; Code 2002, § 2-325) 
Sec. 2-280. - Examination of receipts, warrants, drafts. 
    The auditor shall examine a sufficient sampling, according to established auditing standards, of all receipts, warrants and drafts drawn or issued by the city to determine if the receipts, warrants and drafts have been properly issued and applied. 
(Code 1986, § 2-191; Code 2002, § 2-326) 
Sec. 2-281. - Examination and report of deposits. 
    The auditor shall examine the condition of the accounts in any depository, the standing of such depository, the collateral deposited against deposits on hand and shall report whether or not they conform in all respects with the law, the Charter, this Code or any other city ordinances. 
(Code 1986, § 2-192; Code 2002, § 2-327) 
State Law reference- Deposits by treasurers, 62 O.S. § 516.5. 
Sec. 2-282. - Reporting of irregularities. 
    The auditor shall report at once to the city manager any irregularities that he may discover in the books of account or financial procedure of any city official or employee. 
(Code 1986, § 2-193; Code 2002, § 2-328) 
Sec. 2-283. - Study and recommendations as to fiscal affairs and procedure. 
    It shall be the duty of the auditor to make constant study of the methods employed in the city's fiscal affairs, with the view of simplifying and improving the methods, and he shall make such recommendations as his experience and study shall suggest. 
(Code 1986, § 2-194; Code 2002, § 2-329) 
Secs. 2-284-2-314. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HUMAN RIGHTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-315. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Place of public accommodation means and includes any place, store or other establishment, either licensed or unlicensed, which supplies goods or services to the general public or which solicits or accepts the patronage or trade of the general public or which is supported directly or indirectly by government funds, except that a private club is not a place of public accommodation, if its policies are determined by its members and its facilities or services are available only to its members and their bona fide guests. The term "place of public accommodation" does not include barbershops or beauty shops or privately owned resort or amusement establishments or an establishment located within a building which contains not more than five rooms for rent or hire and which is actually occupied by the proprietor of the establishment as his residence. 
(Code 1986, § 2-206; Code 2002, § 2-356; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 16(a), 4-7-2014) 
State Law reference- Definitions, 25 O.S. §§ 1201, 1401. 
Sec. 2-316. - Violations. 
    No person shall violate any of the sections of this article. Any person violating any section of this article, upon being found guilty thereof by the municipal court, shall be subject to a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs, for each offense. Each day that any offense is continued in violation of this article is to be construed as a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 2-207; Code 2002, § 2-358; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 16(b), 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-317. - Limitation on rights granted. 
(a)  No section of this article is intended nor should any section of this article be construed to grant to any person a right of entry upon the premises of a place of public accommodation for any purpose other than the express and obvious purposes for which a place of public accommodation is open to the general public, and only during its normal hours of operation. 
(b)  No section of this article is intended nor should any section of this article be construed to grant a right of entry upon the premises of a place of public accommodation to any person who is drunk, disorderly, vagrant, loitering, begging, disturbing the peace, soliciting, selling, advertising, vending goods or presenting himself for entry in any manner, state of dress, demeanor or condition for which the general public, regardless of race, religion, color, creed, ancestry, sex, age, handicap or national origin, would be excluded by such place of public accommodation. 
(Code 1986, § 2-218; Code 2002, § 2-360; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 16(c), 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-318. - Discriminatory practices. 
    No person who is the owner, lessee, manager, proprietor, concessionaire, custodian, agent or employee of a place of public accommodation within the city shall, because of any person's race, religion, color, creed, ancestry, sex, age, handicap or national origin: 
(1)  Deny or refuse any privilege, facility, goods, merchandise, commodity, service or accommodation. 
(2)  Segregate or require the placing of any person in any separate section or area of the premises or facilities of such place of public accommodation. 
(3)  Place, post, maintain or display any written or printed advertisement, notice or sign to the effect that any of the accommodations, facilities, privileges, goods or merchandise of such place of public accommodation will be or may be refused, withheld from or denied to any person. 
(Code 1986, § 2-214; Code 2002, § 2-362; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 16(d), 4-7-2014) 
State Law reference- Discrimination in public accommodations generally, 25 O.S. § 1401 et seq. 
Secs. 2-319-2-339. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Human Rights Commission, 74 O.S. § 951 et seq.; local commissions, 25 O.S. § 1701 et seq. 

Sec. 2-340. - Established; purpose. 
    For the purpose of administering this article, there is established the human relations commission. 
(Code 1986, § 2-210; Code 2002, § 2-391) 
Sec. 2-341. - Composition; appointment; qualifications. 
    The human relations commission shall be composed of from seven to 11 members, serving without compensation. The individual members of the human relations commission shall be representative of the various racial, religious, business and other groups in the city. All members of the human relations commission, including the chairman, shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 2-211; Code 2002, § 2-392) 
Sec. 2-342. - Terms of office. 
    The term of office of each member of the human relations commission shall end on December 31 of each year, but all members shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1986, § 2-220; Code 2002, § 2-393) 
Sec. 2-343. - Vacancies. 
    If at any time a vacancy occurs in the human relations commission, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner that the office was previously filled. 
(Code 1986, § 2-219; Code 2002, § 2-394) 
Sec. 2-344. - Appointment, duties of antidiscrimination committee. 
    An antidiscrimination committee shall be appointed by the human relations commission, with the approval of the city commission, and shall have full operating responsibility, under the supervision of the human relations commission, for carrying out this article. 
(Code 1986, § 2-213; Code 2002, § 2-395) 
Sec. 2-345. - Powers and duties. 
    The human relations commission shall have the power and duty to: 
(1)  Initiate on its own or receive, investigate and seek to adjust all complaints of discriminatory practices prohibited by this article. 
(2)  By itself or through the antidiscrimination committee, hold public hearings, subpoena witnesses and require their attendance, administer oaths and take the testimony of any person under oath relating to any matter under investigation or in question. 
(3)  Make rules as to the procedure for the issuance of subpoenas by the antidiscrimination committee. Contumacy or refusal to obey a subpoena pursuant to this section may be certified to the municipal court for appropriate action. 
(Code 1986, § 2-212; Code 2002, § 2-396) 
State Law reference- Powers of local commissions, 25 O.S. § 1704. 
Sec. 2-346. - Annual reports; recommendations. 
    The human relations commission shall report to the city commission annually the disposition of all complaints referred to it and any matters which it deems appropriate to be brought to the attention of the city commission, including any recommendations it deems desirable and necessary to the accomplishment of the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 2-217; Code 2002, § 2-397) 
Secs. 2-347-2-365. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ANNEXATION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Annexation and detachment, 11 O.S. § 21-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-366. - Map adopted; maintenance; changes. 
(a)  There is established an official map showing the city limits and boundaries of the city, which map is designated as the "City Limit Map." Such map is made a part of this section by reference as if the map were set forth in full in this section. It shall be the duty of the director of planning to keep such map on public display in his office. 
(b)  It shall be the further duty of the director of planning that, if the boundaries of the city are changed by ordinance, he shall modify such map showing such changes. 
(Code 1986, § 2-236; Code 2002, § 2-426) 
Sec. 2-367. - Detachment of territory. 
(a)  Territory may be detached from the corporate limits of the city by the city commission when: 
(1)  An ordinance of the city commission so directs; or 
(2)  A petition requesting detachment, signed by at least three-fourths of the registered voters and by the owners of at least three-fourths (in value) of the property to be detached, is filed with the city commission. 
(b)  Only land which is within the city limits and upon its border and not laid out in lots and blocks or land which had been annexed to the city may be detached by petition. Notice of any city commission action on a petition requesting detachment and appeal to the district court shall be in the same manner provided for petitions requesting annexation. 
(Code 1986, § 2-238; Code 2002, § 2-427) 
Sec. 2-368. - Publication of notice. 
    No final action shall be taken by the city commission upon any petition presented in pursuance of section 2-367 until notice of the presentation of such petition has been given by the petitioners, by publication at least once in each week for two successive weeks, in some newspaper published in the city. 
(Code 1986, § 2-239; Code 2002, § 2-428) 
Sec. 2-369. - Appeal. 
    Upon the failure of the city commission to grant the request contained in a petition presented in accordance with this article and for 30 days after the last publication of the notice provided for in section 2-368 or upon a refusal to grant such request, the petitioners may present their petition to the district court of the county by filing such petition with the clerk of such court. Notice of such filing shall be served by the petitioners upon the mayor, together with a notice of the time and place when and where a hearing shall be had upon such petition, at least ten days before the date of such hearing. The hearing on the petition may be had at a regular or special term of the district court or by the court in vacation. 
(Code 1986, § 2-240; Code 2002, § 2-429) 
Sec. 2-370. - Action of district court. 
    If, upon the hearing held pursuant to section 2-369, the court shall find that the request of the petitioners ought to be granted and can be so granted without injustice to the inhabitants or persons interested, the court shall so order. If the court shall find against the petitioners, the petition shall be dismissed at the cost of the petitioners. 
(Code 1986, § 2-241; Code 2002, § 2-430) 
Sec. 2-371. - Recordation of maps. 
    When any territory is annexed by ordinance or by a decree or order of the court to the city, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to cause an accurate map of such added territory, together with a copy of the ordinance for the annexation or a copy of the decree or order of the court therefor, duly certified, to be filed and recorded in the office of the register of deeds of the county in which such added territory or the greater portion of it is situated. If territory is disconnected or excluded from the city, a copy of the ordinance or decree therefor shall be so filed and recorded at the expense of the petitioners therefor. Failure to file such ordinance, map or decree in the office of the register of deeds shall not invalidate such annexation or deannexation. 
(Code 1986, § 2-242; Code 2002, § 2-431) 
Secs. 2-372-2-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RECORDS MANAGEMENT[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Open Records Act, 51 O.S. § 24A.1 et seq.; Records Management Act, 67 O.S. § 203 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-401. - Definitions. 
    The definitions in 68 O.S. § 202(d)-(i), as amended, are adopted by reference in this section as if set forth in full. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Active records means those records in current use which must be retained in offices because frequent reference is necessary in the conduct of day-to-day operations. 
    Appraisal means the process of determining the value and, thus, the disposition of records based upon their legal, fiscal, administrative and archival requirements. 
    Disposition means actions taken with regard to records and nonrecords following their appraisal. These actions include the transfer of inactive records to the records center or the destruction of records or nonrecords no longer required in the course of the city's business. 
    Duplicate records means copies or reproductions of original records, whether or not the same physical form as the original, which are retained for personal reference or for operational requirements. 
    Inactive records means those records which are seldom referred to, but which must be retained, temporarily or permanently, because of legal, fiscal, administrative or archival value. 
    Maintenance of public records means the creation, maintenance, protection, use and disposition of all public records of the city, including the establishment and maintenance of a system of filing and indexing public records. 
    Municipal records means all records, whether of public or private origin, housed and administered by the city. 
    Nonrecord means material which is not retained in the regular course of business or which is a temporary aid, not created for the purpose of preserving its own documentary or informational content for future reference. This includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Transmittal letters and acknowledgments which do not add any information to the material transmitted. 
(2)  Requests for printed material after the requests have been filled. 
(3)  Informal notes, work sheets and rough drafts of letters, memoranda or reports that do not represent basic steps in the preparation of documents. 
(4)  Shorthand notes, including stenographic notebooks and stenotype tapes, and dictating media that have been transcribed. 
(5)  Miscellaneous notices of community affairs, employee meetings or holidays. Notices required under the Oklahoma Open Meeting Act do not fall into this category; they are considered official records. 
(6)  Stocks of publications or unused blank forms that are kept for supply purposes only. 
(7)  Tickler, followup or suspense copies of correspondence. 
(8)  Extra copies of documents already in an official file. 
(9)  Publications or reference materials received or acquired from outside sources such as professional organizations, conferences, seminars or workshops. 
(10)  Library and museum materials made or acquired and preserved solely for reference or exhibition purposes. 
    Original records means the first or initial documentation, of which anything else is a copy or reproduction, or a duplicate record with any original documentation. 
    Public or official records means all documents, papers, letters, maps, books, tapes, photographs, films, sound recordings or other materials, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance or in connection with the transaction of official business by any city officer or employee. However, the term "public records" shall not be construed to mean those public records that are deemed by law to be confidential or that are prohibited from being inspected by the public or that shall be exempt from this article or from the provisions of the Oklahoma Preservation of Essential Records Act. 
    Record copy means a reproduction of an original record which is retained in lieu of the original record as the official city record. 
    Record series means file units or documents arranged in accordance with a filing system or maintained as a unit because they relate to a particular subject or function, because they result from the same activity, because they have a particular form or because of some other relationship arising out of their creation, receipt or use. A record series may consist of records of a single type or format and can be described, handled and disposed of or retained as a unit. 
    Records disposition schedule means a listing of record series by department, indicating for each series the length of time it is to be maintained in office areas and in the records center. The schedule constitutes authority for the destruction of records listed thereon, after required retention periods have lapsed. 
    Records management officer means the city clerk or appointed designee. 
    Records management program means a formulated plan to establish a citywide system that achieves integrated control of all departmental subsystems so than an orderly and efficient flow of paperwork is provided from creation to ultimate disposition. 
    Writing means handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, photographing and every other means of recording upon any form of communication or representation, including letters, words, pictures, sounds or symbols or a combination thereof, and all papers, maps, magnetic or paper tapes, photographic films and prints, magnetic or punched cards, discs, drums and other documents, retained in the ordinary course of business. Writings are record or nonrecord material. 
(Code 1986, § 2-251; Code 2002, § 2-461) 
Sec. 2-402. - Purpose and intent. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Records Management Program of the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma," providing for the proper and efficient management of the city's records. 
(Code 1986, § 2-252; Code 2002, § 2-462) 
Sec. 2-403. - Authority to establish program; goals; records management officer. 
(a)  The office of city clerk is authorized to establish and administer the records management program for the city pursuant to legal, fiscal, administrative and archival requirements. To this end, the city clerk will implement, but not be limited to, a program to encompass such areas of records management as are required to preserve and keep in order all books, papers, documents, records, and files of the city to achieve the following goals: 
(1)  Release space and reduce the need for storage and filing equipment. 
(2)  Establish an efficient retrieval operation for both active and inactive municipal records. 
(3)  Provide for routine disposition of paperwork. 
(4)  Maintain total security over municipal records. 
(5)  Communicate the need of an effective records management program. 
(b)  The city clerk is authorized to appoint a records management officer to assist in carrying out the goals in subsection (a) of this section. The city manager shall be responsible for ensuring proper management of records in city government. 
(Code 1986, § 2-253; Code 2002, § 2-463) 
Sec. 2-404. - Records disposition schedule. 
(a)  The records disposition schedule will serve as the basis for the city's records management program. The head of each department shall prepare a records disposition schedule for the department and any subsequent proposed amendments thereto. With the assistance of the records management officer, this preparation shall include the following: 
(1)  A physical inventory and appraisal of all records to determine their legal, fiscal, administrative and archival value. 
(2)  Identification of an official record series title for all department records and specific and accurate descriptions of records listed thereunder in accordance with guidelines developed by the city clerk. Terms used as record series titles or as a description of files on the records disposition schedule or any revision thereto shall be descriptive. They shall not include the use of the words "miscellaneous" or "various," or words of similar connotation, nor shall any such schedule or request bearing such nomenclature be submitted to the city clerk and the city attorney for their consideration and approval. 
(3)  A periodic review or audit of records to make sure they are properly covered by the records disposition schedule. 
(b)  Following the review or audit, the city clerk will be notified of any proposed amendments to the records disposition schedule that are needed. Such amendments may include the addition of new record series titles to the records disposition schedule or requests to have superseded record series titles removed from the records disposition schedule. 
(c)  Final approval of the records disposition schedule shall require the written consent of the department head, the city attorney and the city clerk. The records disposition schedule must then be approved by the city commission by resolution. Amendments and revisions thereto shall require the written consent of the department head, the city attorney and the city clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 2-254; Code 2002, § 2-464) 
Sec. 2-405. - Responsibilities of certain city officers. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, the city clerk shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for the maintenance of all official records with the following exceptions: 
a.  Records identified pursuant to this article in the records disposition schedule, which are entrusted to the custody of other city officers or departments. 
b.  Newly created or unidentified record series, which shall be the responsibility of the originating department, until properly identified within the records disposition schedule. 
c.  Inactive records which have been transferred to noncity organizations. 
d.  Records which are legally maintained by other government agencies. 
(2)  Be responsible for the administration of a uniform records management program assisting all city departments and for the development, administration and coordination of procedures thereunder. 
(3)  Administer a records center for the efficient and economical storage, maintenance and servicing of inactive city records. 
(4)  Appoint a records management officer who shall serve in the office of the city clerk as the head of the records management program. 
(5)  Develop and implement a confidentiality policy for all inactive records designated "confidential" and in the physical custody of the city clerk's office, providing such policy does not conflict with any federal law or state statutes. 
(6)  Develop and institute a vital records program to ensure the safety of essential records if a disaster occurs. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, the records management officer, under the direction of the city clerk, shall: 
(1)  Provide effective control over the identification, appraisal, maintenance, protection, preservation, transfer, retention and disposition of all city records. This shall include: 
a.  Providing assistance and guidelines to departments in the preparation of their records disposition schedules and amendments thereto. 
b.  Establishing proper procedures for securing necessary revisions to the records disposition schedule, with the approval of the city attorney. 
c.  Providing direct technical assistance and guidance to departments that will aid in resolving specific files and related records problems. 
(2)  Operate the records center in an orderly and efficient manner. This operation shall include: 
a.  Providing information, assistance and records to using departments to ensure optimum utilization of the records center. 
b.  Notifying using departments periodically when records held by the records center are eligible for destruction. 
c.  Causing to be destroyed records held by the records center only after receiving proper authorization from the responsible department head. 
(c)  For the purposes of this article, each department head shall: 
(1)  Cooperate with the city clerk to ensure proper administration and implementation of the city's records management program. 
(2)  Ensure the proper application of the records disposition schedule to the department's records. 
(3)  Ensure that records are transferred to the records center for storage at the end of the office retention period listed in the records disposition schedule. 
(4)  Review the records disposition schedule and recommend to the city clerk any amendments thereto which are necessary due to changing requirements. 
(5)  Comply with procedures mentioned in this article regarding the destruction of records and nonrecords. 
(6)  Appoint a records coordinator to serve as liaison between the records management officer and the department and to assist in the implementation of the records management program. 
(Code 1986, § 2-255; Code 2002, § 2-465) 
Sec. 2-406. - Ownership of municipal records; custodianship responsibilities. 
(a)  All records created or received by a department shall remain the property of the city. The city clerk is the legal custodian of the city's records. The records management division of the city clerk's office is the physical custodian of all records transferred to the Shawnee Municipal Records Center (SMRC), microfilm center or Shawnee Archives. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each city officer and employee to protect, preserve, store and transfer municipal records in accordance with state and federal statutes, the Charter and ordinances or rules promulgated and approved by the city commission or city manager. The records shall be delivered by outgoing officials and employees to their successors or the officials and employees shall surrender the records upon the written order of the city commission, city manager or other duly authorized city official. 
(Code 1986, § 2-257; Code 2002, § 2-466) 
Sec. 2-407. - Destruction of records. 
(a)  Eligibility. Municipal records defined in this article as original public records may be destroyed as directed by the city commission or city manager with the advice and consent of the city attorney, unless otherwise required by federal or state law, in accordance with the records disposition schedule set out in the city's records management manual. No record shall be destroyed until it has been properly inventoried, appraised, entered in the records disposition schedule and duly audited. Furthermore, before a record is eligible for destruction, the department head must first make the following determinations: 
(1)  Required retention periods listed in the records disposition schedule have lapsed. 
(2)  The record is maintained by the department. 
(3)  The record is no longer required to fulfill any legal, fiscal, administrative or archival interests of the city or the public. 
(4)  The record series title is descriptive and does not include the use of the words "miscellaneous" or "various" or words of similar connotation. 
(5)  A notice of proposed destruction of all municipal records, including records series titles, descriptions, inclusive dates and volumes, shall first be given to the records management officer of the city clerk's office for permanent keeping. 
(6)  Any original municipal public record, the subject matter of which is in litigation, may not be destroyed until such litigation is finally terminated. 
(7)  Any testing laboratory results or the inspection records of public improvements of the city may not be destroyed. 
(b)  Procedures. Before records are destroyed, the department head shall: 
(1)  In compliance with the records disposition schedule, exercise a final review over all records eligible for destruction for the purpose of determining any further legal, fiscal, administrative or archival needs. 
(2)  Ensure that, if the records disposition schedule does not specify records for transfer to the records center, the records shall be destroyed at the end of the listed office retention period in compliance with the records disposition schedule. 
(3)  Ensure that, if the records disposition schedule does specify records for transfer to the records center and this has not occurred, the records shall be destroyed, providing they have exceeded their total retention requirement (office plus records center). 
(4)  Destroy duplicate records and nonrecords when they are no longer needed in the course of the city's business. 
(c)  Method of destruction. The method of destruction for all records identified in this article shall be by a paper shredder, with the shred cut size to be at least one-fourth inch, with the exception of those records which may be determined by the city clerk to be disposed of in a different manner, notwithstanding that records of confidentiality may be destroyed in a manner prescribed by law. 
(d)  Destruction of all other municipal records. Municipal records other than those records defined in this article as original public records may be disposed of upon approval of the city clerk and the departmental custodian. 
(Code 1986, § 2-256; Code 2002, § 2-467) 
Sec. 2-408. - Storage of records. 
(a)  All records may be photographed, micro-photographed, photostated, reproduced on film, or stored on optical, digital or other electronic media. Such film or reproducing media shall be of durable material and the device used to reproduce such records on film or other media shall be such as to accurately reproduce and perpetuate the original records in all details. 
(b)  The photostatic copy, photograph, microphotograph, photographic film or optical, digital or electronic version of the original records shall be deemed to be an original record for all purposes, and shall be admissible in evidence in all courts or administrative agencies and available to the public in the same manner as the original record. A facsimile, exemplification or certified copy thereof shall, for all purposes recited herein, be deemed to be a transcript, exemplification or certified copy of the original. Such records may be disposed of in accordance with the policy of this article for the destruction and disposal of the original record. 
(c)  All versions of a record as authorized herein shall be placed in conveniently accessible files and provisions made for indexing, preserving, examining and using same shall be the same as for the original records. Once such procedures have been followed, the city manager may certify to that fact. Following such certification, the governing body may, by resolution, authorize the disposal, archival storage or destruction of the original records and papers before the expiration of the retention period established by statute, local ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 2002, § 2-468; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 17, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-409. - Identity theft prevention program (red flag policy). 
    For purposes of complying with 16 CFR § 681.2, and in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft, the identity theft prevention program and policy of the City of Shawnee is incorporated by reference in this section as though fully set forth herein. 
(Code 2002, § 2-469; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 19, 4-7-2014) 
Secs. 2-410-2-431. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MICROGRAPHICS 

Sec. 2-432. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Index means a list describing the items of a collection and where they may be found; a catalog. 
    Microfilm means a film containing photographic records or images considerably reduced in size from the original material filmed. 
    Microform means a generic name for any medium containing micro-images, i.e., reduced images. 
    Microform record means any record preserved in one of the various formats of microfilm. 
(Code 1986, § 2-261; Code 2002, § 2-496; Ord. No. 2541NS, § 18, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 2-433. - Authorized. 
    The office of the city clerk is authorized to provide a micrographics operation which accurately and permanently copies, reproduces or originates on microform media any municipal record of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 2-262; Code 2002, § 2-497) 
Sec. 2-434. - Types of records to be filmed. 
    The micrographics operation under the administration of the records management division of the office of the city clerk may be applied to any municipal record of the city, including, but not limited to, ordinances, resolutions, contracts, deeds, conveyances, minutes, notices, correspondence, memoranda, any writing or communication or any record of any city department. 
(Code 1986, § 2-263; Code 2002, § 2-498) 
Sec. 2-435. - Standards. 
    The first generation microform medium shall meet the requirements of the United States of America Standards Institute for archival quality, density, resolution and definition, except that microform media which is intended only for shortterm use, as determined by the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 2-264; Code 2002, § 2-499) 
Sec. 2-436. - Certification of records. 
    The city clerk shall check and certify that each microform record is a true and correct duplication of the original municipal record. 
(Code 1986, § 2-265; Code 2002, § 2-500) 
Sec. 2-437. - Indices to records. 
    The records management division of the office of the city clerk shall index the microform records. 
(Code 1986, § 2-266; Code 2002, § 2-501) 
Sec. 2-438. - Public access. 
    The public shall have free access to information in microform records to which the public is entitled under law, just as if the microform record were the original record. 
(Code 1986, § 2-267; Code 2002, § 2-502) 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING AND SIGNS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    Any terms not contained within this section shall be construed to be used in this chapter as defined in the latest edition of Webster's Unabridged Dictionary. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory sign means any advertising device which identifies or displays information concerning the proprietor of the business conducted on the premises. 
    A-frame sign, sandwich sign or swinger sign means an advertising device which is ordinarily in the shape of an "A," spring mounted on a fixed base, or some variation thereof, located on the ground, but not otherwise attached thereto, and which is usually two-sided. 
    Aggregate use means a group of primary uses integrated in a single development not separated by an opened public street, under common ownership, and sharing private parking facilities and other services in common. 
    Animation means any visible mechanical movement in any sign, or apparent movement achieved by electrical pulsations or by other means, such as sequential light phasing. 
    Architectural projection means any projection, excluding signs, which is not intended for occupancy and which extends beyond the face of an exterior wall of a building, including but not limited to roof overhangings, wing walls, mansards, unenclosed exterior balconies, marquees, canopies, pilasters, fascias and awnings. 
    Attached sign means an accessory sign attached to, painted on or in any other way represented on a building or the structural element of a building. An attached sign includes a canopy sign, combination sign, fascia sign, marquee sign, module sign, parapet wall sign, projecting sign, roof sign and wall sign. 
    Awning means a fixed, backlit or movable shelter supported entirely from the exterior wall of a building, which can be retracted, folded or collapsed against the face of the supporting building. 
    Banner means any pennant, streamer, flag, sign, picture, figure or other object, regardless of the materials of which it is made, which is suspended or otherwise designed for decoration or advertisement or to attract the attention of passersby; excepting, however, official warning devices, public service facilities, streetlights and similar safety devices. 
    Billboard, including poster and panel types, means a nonaccessory sign or sign structure upon which advertising may be posted, painted or affixed and which is primarily designed for the rental or lease of the sign space for advertising not related to the use of the property upon which the sign is located. 
    Building code means the latest building code as amended and adopted by the city. 
    Canopy means a permanently roofed shelter covering over a sidewalk, service station, driveway or other similar area, which is supported by posts or by the building to which it is attached. 
    Canopy sign means an attached accessory sign painted on or attached to the vertical side of or erected on the roof surface of a canopy. 
    Chief code enforcement official means the person charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter or the chief code enforcement official's duly authorized representative. 
    Combination sign means any single attached accessory sign incorporating any combination of the features of the projecting, parapet wall, canopy, marquee, wall and fascia signs. 
    Decoration means illustrations, symbols, flags, streamers, bunting, wreaths, figures, insignias and other devices employed to express and illustrate a message of patriotic, holiday or seasonal character and are not considered signs for the purpose of this chapter. 
    Directional and information sign, accessory means signs which direct attention to the location of a facility or group of facilities on the same property on which the sign is located or which display brand name information as provided in this chapter. Such signs may include entrance and exit signs, restroom signs, handicapped parking signs, license or permit information signs and other similar groups. This also includes the following specific signs: telephone booths or service signs, brand name on petroleum products pumps or other dispensing apparatus located outside of a building, identification and informational signs on public utility apparatus and U.S. Post Office signs on postal apparatus. 
    Display surface means the surface of the sign upon, against or through which the message is displayed or illustrated. 
    Display surface area means the net geometrical area enclosed by the display surface of the sign including the outer extremities of all letters, figures, characters and delineations; provided, however, the term "display surface area" does not include the structural supports for freestanding signs if the structural supports are so arranged as not to become a part of the attention attracting aspect of the sign. Unless specifically provided in this chapter, the display area to be computed shall be based on the following standards: 
(1)  For signs of irregular design, the display surface area shall be determined by computing the area formed by an envelope of rectangles and triangles which shall be formed by drawing straight lines which connect the adjacent extreme points of the display surface of adjacent panels, figures, characters or delineations. 
(2)  Where a sign has two faces which are joined in a "V" shape forming an angle not to exceed 60 degrees or where such a sign contains three or more faces which are joined to form a polygon shape when viewed from above, the total display surface area of the sign may be increased by 150 percent of the allowable maximums as outlined in this definition, provided that no one side of the sign exceeds 75 percent of the normal maximum size as set forth. 
(3)  The maximum display surface area of a double-faced sign as defined in this section shall be calculated on the basis of only one sign face. 
(4)  The display surface area of a double-surface sign, when the two surfaces are greater than 36 inches apart and not joined to form a "V," as permitted in this definition, shall be computed by adding together the square footage of each display surface. 
(5)  The space between modules in a module sign as defined in this section shall not be counted. 
(6)  The display surface area of a fascia sign shall be calculated by adding together the individual display surface areas of the front and the larger size of the fascia sign. 
    Double-faced sign means any sign which has two display surface faces, each of which is parallel to the other and not more than 36 inches apart. 
    Electric sign means any sign containing electrical wiring, but not including signs illuminated solely by exterior light sources such as floodlights. 
    Electrical code means the latest electrical code as amended and adopted by the city. 
    Electronic reader board means a changeable message sign consisting of an LED matrix which is computer-controlled. 
    Erect means to build, construct, place, locate, relocate or structurally alter any sign or other advertising device upon the site where it is to be utilized, whether permanent or temporary. 
    Fascia means a continuous translucent panel illuminated from within which may extend around one or more corners and which is attached to and designed as a part of a building. 
    Fascia sign means a wall, canopy, marquee or parapet wall sign attached to or printed on a fascia surface. Unless specifically provided in this section, a fascia sign shall be subject to the standards covering the sign it represents. 
    Flare means any torch, fusee, wick or other illuminating device utilizing open names to attract attention to an establishment. 
    Flashing sign means an illuminated sign on which the artificial or reflected light is not maintained stationary and constant in light intensity as a part of the building. 
    Foot-lambert means the average brightness of any surface, or the uniform brightness of a perfectly diffusing surface, emitting or reflecting one lumen per square foot. Foot-lamberts are measured with an exposure meter equipped with a foot-lambert scale. 
    Frontage, building, means the horizontal, lineal dimension of that side of a building which abuts a street, a parking area, a mall or other circulation area open to the general public and having either a main window display of the enterprise or a public entrance to the building. (In industrial districts, a building side with an entrance open to industrial employees shall also qualify as a building frontage.) Where more than one use occupies a building, each such use having a public entrance or main window display for its exclusive use shall be considered to have its own building frontage, which shall be the front width of the portion of the building occupied by that use. 
    Frontage, street, means the lineal frontage of a lot or parcel abutting on a private or public street which provides principal access to or visibility of the premises. 
    Grade level means the average level of the finished or natural surface of the ground area adjacent to the exterior walls of a building or adjacent to the supports of a sign structure. In this instance, adjacent shall be limited to a radius of 25 feet from the center of the sign structure. 
    Ground sign means a freestanding accessory sign of limited height which is secured to a fixed base, usually at ground level or at a slight elevation above ground, rather than being pole mounted. A sign attached to a wall or fence which serves as the boundary of a parcel shall be considered a ground sign. 
    Height means the vertical distance measured from the elevation of the nearest sidewalk (or, in the absence of a sidewalk within 25 feet, then from the lowest point of the finished grade on the lot upon which the sign is located and within 25 feet of the sign) to the uppermost point on the sign or sign structure. 
    Identification nameplate means an accessory sign as permitted in this chapter which is attached to and flat against the wall of a building or suspended from a canopy or marquee. 
    Illuminated sign means any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs or outlines illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes, whether such sources of illumination are a part of a sign or not. 
    Illumination, direct, means illumination which is performed by electrical apparatus from within the sign structure or which is otherwise a part of the sign structure. 
    Illumination, indirect, means illumination which is performed by spotlights or other lighting devices and which is not a part of the sign proper. 
    Lighting. There are three basic methods of lighting signs: internal lighting that shines through a plastic or other translucent covering; direct external lighting, such as flood or spotlights; and lighting that is external but integral to the sign, such as bulbs that spell out the sign message. 
    Marquee means a permanent, fixed roof attached to, wholly supported by and projecting from a building. 
    Marquee sign means an attached accessory sign painted on or attached to the vertical side of, or erected on the roof surface of, a marquee. 
    Module means a separate unit of a sign which consists of an individual letter or an individual metal, plastic, masonry or wood unit upon which no more than one letter or message, as permitted in the definition of module sign, is mounted or printed. Modules shall be open on three sides or mounted on a building with no visible interconnections between modules. 
    Module sign means an accessory sign other than an identification sign or identification nameplate which is formed of individual modules which spell out only the name or nature of a business or the occupant of the premises. A module sign shall be erected so that there is a space between modules, and no more than one module shall contain information relating to the use of the property other than spelling out the business or occupant. This sign shall be governed by the regulations applicable to the type of accessory sign which the module sign represents. Any sign not meeting this definition shall be subject to the regular accessory sign regulations. 
    Moving sign means any sign or device which has any visible moving part, visible revolving part, or visible mechanical movement. 
    Nonaccessory sign means a sign or advertising device which directs attention to an activity, service or product sold or offered elsewhere than on the premises on which the sign is located. 
    Parapet wall sign means an attached accessory sign erected on the top surface of a parapet. 
    Portable sign means a transportable sign designed for temporary use in compliance with the structural requirements of this chapter. 
    Primary use means the single dominant use of any piece of property or lot. 
    Projecting sign means an attached accessory sign which projects from and which has one end attached to a building, and which does not employ ground support in any manner. 
    Roof sign. Types of roof signs shall be as follows: 
(1)  Type A means an attached accessory sign designed to permit, but not necessarily be limited to, the erection of a shield, symbol or similar trademark or brand name. Such sign shall be located immediately and entirely over the roof of a building and attached to a wall or pylon or similar physical support that is part of the physical and architectural design of the building. This definition shall apply only to a building which is four stories or less in height. 
(2)  Type B means an attached accessory sign erected on a vertical framework supported by and located immediately and entirely over the roof of a building which is five stories or more in height. 
    Sight triangle means an area which is clear of all structures or other sight impediments formed by measuring back equal distances along two intersecting lines of street curblines or driveway lines a distance of 30 feet, and connecting such points to form a triangle. 
    Sign means any structure or part thereof or any device permanently or temporarily attached to, painted on, supported by or represented on a building, fence, post or other structure, which is used or intended to be used to attract attention. The term "sign" does not include a flag, pennant or insignia of any nation, association of nations, state, city or other political unit. 
    Sign location means the site where one or more freestanding sign structures may be erected. Where more than one structure is placed on either a permanent or temporary basis, there shall be no more than a 12-inch separation between structures at the same sign location. 
    Structure means anything built or constructed, whether or not permanently attached to the ground. 
    Temporary sign means any sign or advertising device constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, portable cardboard, wood, wallboard, metal or other light materials, with or without frames, which is intended to be displayed for a limited period of time only and which is portable. 
    Wall sign means an attached accessory sign painted on or attached to the wall or surface of a building or display surface which is parallel to the supporting surface. A sign attached to a wall or fence located on the boundary of a parcel shall be regulated as a ground sign. 
    Window sign means any accessory sign painted on the surface of, located on the interior of or flashing through a display window. 
(Code 1986, § 3-1; Code 2002, § 3-1; Ord. No. 2169NS, § 1, 7-6-2004) 
Sec. 3-2. - Purpose and intent.
