3.  The time of its operation, which shall not exceed six months from the date of issuance. 
4.  The maximum number of porcine, goats, sheep or hoofed animals other than bovines or equines, which shall not exceed a maximum number of three. 
5.  The location of the enclosure and the ground area of the enclosure. 
c.  Criteria for issuance of the permit shall be as follows: 
1.  The permit is conditioned on the right of the city manager to revoke such permit when, in his judgment, the public health may require such revocation; 
2.  The permit shall in no case be construed as an authority to open, build, keep or maintain a pen for a porcine, goat, sheep or hoofed animal other than bovine or equine to be used to keep such animal when the pen is located within 250 feet of any structure used for dwelling purposes or business purposes, except that of the owner; and 
3.  The enclosure shall be kept clean and sanitary and well drained at all times, and such enclosure shall be erected in a place where good drainage may be obtained and kept dry at all times. 
d.  It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to notify the person who keeps a pen used to shelter or confine a porcine, goat, sheep or hoofed animal other than bovine or equine contrary to this section to remove the porcine, goat, sheep or hoofed animal within three days from the date of such notice. Upon failure to comply with the notice, the pen for a porcine, goat, sheep or hoofed animal, other than a bovine or equine, shall be abated as required by law, provided that this shall be cumulative of and in addition to the other subsections of this section. 
e.  The lot and stables wherein animals are kept shall be maintained in a clean condition and free from all filth at all times. Manure and feces shall be removed from the stable or shelter daily and the premises disinfected not less than once in each period of two weeks. Manure and feces shall be disposed of properly by either burying or removing it from the site on a weekly basis. 
(Code 1986, § 5-4; Code 2002, § 5-5; Ord. No. 2593NS, §§ 5,6, 12-19-2016) 
State Law reference- Nuisances, 11 O.S. § 22-121, 50 O.S. 
Sec. 5-6. - Keeping wild and exotic animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, maintain or have in possession or control, within the city, any poisonous reptile or other dangerous or carnivorous wild animal or reptile or any other wild or exotic animal or reptile of vicious or dangerous propensities. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, maintain or have in possession or control, within the city, any of the following animals: 
(1)  All poisonous animals, including rear-fang snakes. 
(2)  Apes: chimpanzees (Pan); gibbons (Hylobates); gorillas (Gorilla); orangutans (Pongo); and siamangs (Symphalangus). 
(3)  Baboons (Papio, Mandrillus). 
(4)  Bears (Ursidae). 
(5)  Cheetahs (Acinonyx jubatus). 
(6)  Constrictor snakes, six feet in length or more. 
(7)  Coyotes (Canis latrans) and hybrid coyote mixes. 
(8)  Crocodilians (Crocodylia), 30 inches in length or more. 
(9)  Deer (Cervidae), which includes all members of the deer family; for example, white-tailed deer, elk, antelope and moose. 
(10)  Elephants (Elephas and Loxodonta). 
(11)  Hippopotami (Hippopotamidae). 
(12)  Hyenas (Hyaenidae). 
(13)  Jaguars (Panthera onca). 
(14)  Leopards (Panthera pardus). 
(15)  Lions (Panthera leo). 
(16)  Lynxes (Lynx). 
(17)  Monkeys, old world (Cercopithecidae). 
(18)  Ostriches (Struthio). 
(19)  Piranha fish (Characidae). 
(20)  Pumas (Felis concolor); also known as cougars, mountain lions and panthers. 
(21)  Rhinoceroses (Rhinocerotidae). 
(22)  Sharks (class Chondrichthyes), unless kept in an aquarium. 
(23)  Snow leopards (Panthera uncia). 
(24)  Tigers (Panthera tigris). 
(25)  Wolves (Canis lupus) or wolf, canine mixes. 
(26)  Any other wild, dangerous or undomesticated animal which is not of a species customarily used as an ordinary household pet, but one which would ordinarily be confined to a zoo or one which would ordinarily be found in the wilderness of this or any other country or one which otherwise causes a reasonable person to be fearful of bodily harm or property damage. 
It shall be unlawful to raise and/or keep more than five adult mice or rats at any given time. 
(c)  Subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply to licensed pet shops, menageries, zoological gardens, exotic animal shows or sales and circuses if: 
(1)  Their location conforms to the provisions of the city zoning ordinance; 
(2)  All animals and animal quarters are kept in a clean and sanitary condition and are so maintained as to eliminate objectionable odors; 
(3)  Animals are maintained in quarters so constructed as to prevent their escape; and 
(4)  No person lives or resides within 100 feet of the quarters in which the animals are kept. 
(Code 1986, § 5-5; Code 2002, § 5-6) 
Sec. 5-7. - Keeping fowl. 
(a)  No person shall keep any domestic fowl or nondomestic fowl other than that customarily considered a household pet within the city, except in an agricultural zoning district. Such fowl shall be kept within an enclosure sufficient to prevent the fowl from escaping therefrom, and all coops, houses and roosts shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and disinfected in such a manner and to the extent necessary to prevent odors or unsanitary conditions. No person shall maintain, have or keep any pen, yard, building or enclosure for the purpose of keeping or restraining chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guineas, pigeons or other domestic or nondomestic fowl of any kind within 20 feet of any residence within the city or within 50 feet of the front line of any open and used street, road or avenue. 
(b)  No person shall keep fowl which may create a nuisance. A nuisance shall be deemed as the conduct or behavior of such fowl which damages private or public property or the fowl crows or makes other noises in an excessive, continuous fashion which annoys the comfort, health or peace or quiet of the people in the community. 
(Code 1986, § 5-7; Code 2002, § 5-7) 
State Law reference- Domesticated fowl deemed as "livestock" or "animals," 2 O.S. § 1-3. 
Sec. 5-8. - Fowl running at large. 
    No person shall allow any chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guineas or other domestic or nondomestic fowl to run or fly at large at any place within the city, other than the property of the owner or proprietor and other than as provided in section 5-7. All such fowl shall be kept in a sufficient enclosure and shall not be permitted to trespass upon the premises of others or in the city alleys or streets. 
(Code 1986, § 5-8; Code 2002, § 5-8) 
State Law reference- Failure to keep domestic animals enclosed, penalties, 4 O.S. § 99. 
Sec. 5-9. - Keeping rabbits. 
(a)  No person shall keep any domestic rabbits or nondomestic rabbits, except in an agricultural zoning district. Such rabbits shall be kept within an enclosure sufficient to prevent the rabbits from escaping therefrom, and all cages, hutches or houses shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and disinfected in such a manner and to the extent necessary to prevent odors or unsanitary conditions. No person shall maintain, have or keep any cage, hutch or enclosure for the purpose of keeping or restraining domestic or nondomestic rabbits of any kind within 20 feet of any residence within the city or within 50 feet of the line of any open and used street, road or avenue. 
(b)  No person shall keep domestic or nondomestic rabbits which may create a nuisance. A nuisance shall be deemed as the condition, conduct or behavior of such rabbits which damages private or public property. 
(Code 1986, § 5-14; Code 2002, § 5-9) 
Sec. 5-10. - Rabbits running at large. 
    No person shall allow any domestic or nondomestic rabbit to run at large at any place within the city, other than the property of the owner or proprietor and other than as provided in section 5-9. All such rabbits shall be kept in a sufficient enclosure and shall not be permitted to trespass upon the premises of others or in the city alleys or streets. 
(Code 1986, § 5-15; Code 2002, § 5-10) 
Sec. 5-11. - Livestock running at large. 
    No person having control of any horse, mule, donkey, bovine, llama or other hoofed animal, porcine, goat, sheep or any animal of the equine, bovine or swine family shall allow such animal to run at large within the city. For the purpose of this section, an animal is deemed to be running at large when the animal: 
(1)  Is staked out, picketed, roped or lariated to a stake in such a way that the animal can do injury to a shade tree or property of any person other than the owner of such animal. 
(2)  Is picketed or tied to a stake or fixture in such a way that, within the range of the full length of the rope, chain or picket, the animal can enter upon any lot or ground of any person other than the owner of such animal and for which the property owner's consent has not been obtained. 
(3)  Is tied to a stake or fixture picketed in such a way that the animal may enter upon any city street, alley, sidewalk or public ground. 
(4)  Intrudes upon the property of another person or city property other than the owner's. 
(Code 1986, § 5-6; Code 2002, § 5-11) 
State Law reference- Failure to keep domestic animals enclosed, penalties, 4 O.S. § 99; animals running at large, 11 O.S. § 22-115; diseased animals running at large, etc., 21 O.S. § 1221. 
Sec. 5-12. - Indecent exhibit or breeding in public. 
    No person shall indecently exhibit or cause or allow the indecent exhibition of any animal or fowl referenced in this chapter, and no person shall let or cause to be let any such animal to any animal or fowl of the opposite sex for sexual intercourse, unless such is in some enclosed place entirely out of public view. 
(Code 1986, § 5-9; Code 2002, § 5-12) 
Sec. 5-13. - Selling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, barter or give away any animal or fowl within the city limits, except on the owner's or proprietor's property or in a sales arena, sales barn or commercial establishment designed for that purpose. Itinerant sale of animals or pets is expressly forbidden. 
(Code 1986, § 5-10; Code 2002, § 5-13) 
Sec. 5-14. - Shooting or injuring birds or destruction of bird nests. 
    No person shall kill, wound, maim or injure, in any manner whatever, any bird. No person shall throw, fire or shoot at such birds with any gun, pistol or other deadly weapon or with any stone, arrow or other missile. No person shall break, tear down or destroy any bird's nest or the eggs or other contents of the nest. 
(Code 1986, § 5-11; Code 2002, § 5-14) 
State Law reference- Wounding or trapping birds in cemetery, 21 O.S. § 1684. 
Sec. 5-15. - Removal and disposal of dead animals. 
(a)  The animal control officer, when notified, shall remove dead animals and dispose of them in a sanitary manner, except as otherwise stated in this section. 
(b)  When deceased animals, other than those excluded in subsection (c) of this section, are found on a public thoroughfare, street, road or public land, they shall be removed and properly disposed of by the animal control officer. 
(c)  The removal and disposal of any deceased bovine, equine, porcine or other hoofed animal shall be the responsibility of the owner, and such owner shall make arrangements for proper and sanitary disposal thereof when such animal is found on public or private property. 
(Code 1986, § 5-13; Code 2002, § 5-16) 
State Law reference- Interment of animal remains, 11 O.S. § 26-101; disposal of infected animal carcasses, 21 O.S. § 1222 et seq. 
Sec. 5-16. - Abandoning animals in public or private place. 
    Any person who deposits any live dog, cat or other domestic animal along any private or public roadway, or in any other private or public place with the intention of abandoning the domestic animal, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus court costs. 
(Code 2002, § 5-17; Ord. No. 2381NS, § 1, 11-17-2008; Ord. No. 2395NS, § 3, 2-17-2009) 
Sec. 5-17. - Use of traps. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or set a trap capable of trapping animals unless authorized by the chief of police, or designee. Persons using traps not issued by the animal shelter may be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus court costs for each offense. 
(Code 2002, § 5-18; Ord. No. 2387NS, § 1, 12-1-2008; Ord. No. 2439NS, § 1, 8-16-2010; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 7, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-18. - Destruction of animals. 
    When an animal within the corporate limits of the city shall be so wounded, maimed, sick, diseased or injured as to render its recovery hopeless in the opinion of a police officer, animal control officer or licensed veterinarian, it shall become the duty of the police officer or animal control officer to kill or euthanize or cause to be killed or euthanized such animal as soon as practicable in such manner as in his judgment shall be the least painful. Once the animal is destroyed the officer shall cause the carcass to be removed and disposed of according to law. 
(Code 2002, § 5-19; Ord. No. 2384NS, § 1, 12-1-2008) 
Sec. 5-19. - Animal a nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to investigate any proper claim that an animal is a nuisance within the meaning of this chapter. Should the investigating official determine that a nuisance exists and it is necessary to abate the nuisance or should the official have reason to believe a threat to public health or safety exists, he shall refer the matter to the city prosecutor for approval of a verified complaint and an order from the court that the animal be impounded. Following the filing of such verified complaint and an evidentiary hearing, if the court finds upon a preponderance of the evidence that a nuisance existed, the court may order the animal euthanized as in the case of a vicious animal. In lieu of ordering the animal euthanized, the court shall, at the request of the animal owner, require that the owner abate and prevent such nuisance and give a good and sufficient bond within three days in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, satisfactory for a period not exceeding one year. In this event, the court may order the return of such animal to the owner. However, during the pendency of such bond, upon a finding by the court that the nuisance has reoccurred, the court may order the animal be impounded, euthanized and the owner's bond be forfeited. If the court shall find no nuisance existed, the court shall order the animal be surrendered to the owner. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, nuisance shall mean any animal that habitually commits any one or a combination of the following acts: 
(1)  Scratches or digs into any flower bed, garden, tilled soil, vines, shrubbery or small plants and in so doing injures the same; 
(2)  Overturns any garbage can or other vessel for waste products or scatters the contents of same; 
(3)  Chases any person or domestic animal, or kills any domestic animal; 
(4)  Barks, howls, brays or makes any other loud or offensive noise common to its species or peculiar to itself, so as to disturb the inhabitants of the community; 
(5)  Is running at large. 
(c)  At the option of the owner, but subject to the approval of the animal control officer, an animal impounded pursuant to this section may be impounded in a private kennel or veterinary clinic during the pendency of the nuisance action. The operators of the facility shall then assume full liability for the confinement and maintenance of such animal and shall not release it without first being authorized by the animal control officer or the court. All fees for such impoundment shall be the responsibility of the owner. In no event shall the city be liable for costs of fees charged by the private facility. Further, the city may assess to the owner the cost of transporting the animal to the privately operated impoundment facility. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the release from impoundment of any animal not properly licensed and vaccinated, or a threat to public health or safety. 
(e)  A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus court costs. 
(Code 2002, § 5-20; Ord. No. 2386NS, § 1, 12-1-2008; Ord. No. 2395NS, § 2, 2-17-2009; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 8, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-20-5-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IMPOUNDMENT GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Disposal of animals held in shelter, 4 O.S. § 501 et seq.; impoundment of animals, 22 O.S. § 22-115. 

Sec. 5-46. - City animal shelter established. 
    There is established a city animal shelter, located at such place as the city commission shall approve and provide. 
(Code 1986, § 5-31; Code 2002, § 5-46) 
Sec. 5-47. - Obstructing animal control officers. 
    No person shall interfere with or hinder any animal control officer in the performance of any duty of such agent or seek to release any animal in the custody of the city or its agents, except as otherwise provided by law. 
(Code 1986, § 5-35; Code 2002, § 5-47) 
State Law reference- Obstructing officer, 21 O.S. § 540. 
Sec. 5-48. - Reports of animal control officer. 
    The animal control officer shall render monthly reports in writing to the chief of police or designee of his acts as keeper of the city animal shelter. Such reports shall show distinctly all money received from claimants of impounded animals, the gross proceeds of all monetary receipts, all amounts retained by him as authorized by this Code or any other city ordinances and all money disbursed, indicating to whom paid and the amount to each person. He shall make an annual report which shall give an itemized summary of all disbursements and receipts on a monthly basis. 
(Code 1986, § 5-32; Code 2002, § 5-48) 
Sec. 5-49. - Domesticated animals or house pets. 
(a)  Any domesticated animal or house pet not specifically described or named elsewhere in this chapter shall not be allowed by its owner to run at large at any place within the city other than the property of the owner. 
(b)  Any domesticated animal which is picked up while it is running at large shall be impounded and subject to redemption as set forth in this article. 
(c)  All domesticated animals that are seized and impounded as provided in this section shall be kept in the city animal shelter for not less than 48 hours from the time they are impounded. If, at the expiration of such time, they are not called for, the animal control officer may dispose of such animals by euthanasia and dispose of the bodies according to law provided, however, any domesticated animal may be adopted out at the end of the impoundment period in lieu of disposal. For each animal that is adopted out, a fee as provided by the city fee schedule for the adoption, plus the impoundment fee shall be paid to the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-36; Code 2002, § 5-49; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 9, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-50. - Charges. 
    The city shall receive a fee for each animal the city seizes and impounds and an additional fee, per day, for the care and keeping of such animal that is impounded. The city shall also receive a fee for any animal that the animal control officer was required to tranquilize by the use of a tranquilizer dart when the animal was being seized and impounded by the city. Fees may be waived in whole or in part by the chief of police or his designee for hardship or special cases, including, but not limited to, animal owner death, owner incarceration, or owner hospitalization, to rectify adoption disputes, and for similar situations where the best interest of all parties are served by such waiver. Such fees and charges will be provided by the city fee schedule and shall be paid at the animal shelter before any such animal is released to the owner. 
(Code 1986, § 5-33; Code 2002, § 5-50; Ord. No. 2431NS, § 1, 4-19-2010; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 10, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-51. - Redemption. 
(a)  If the owner of any animal impounded by an animal control officer shall pay the animal control officer for the costs, charges and expenses incurred, at any time before the adoption of such animal, as established elsewhere in this chapter, the animal control officer shall release such animal. 
(b)  The animal control officer, before he releases any impounded animal to any person who claims that he is the owner, shall satisfy himself of the fact that such representations are true and, to this end, shall have the right to make such inquiry as may be necessary to establish such facts. He shall have the unreserved right to require the affidavit of the claimant to the effect that he is the true and lawful owner of such animal and that he has owned such animal for the time the claimant alleges. He shall have the further unreserved right to require the claimant to produce witnesses of the fact whose representations may or may not be reduced in writing and certified accordingly, as the animal control officer in his discretion shall determine. 
(c)  Any unclaimed domesticated animal, other than a dog or cat, that has been held ten days by animal control may be offered for adoption. Notice of adoption shall be posted ten days prior to the adoption. Animals will be adopted out by means of sealed bids, and the highest bidder shall be awarded the adoption. Such revenue received by sealed bids for unclaimed animals, sold by animal control, shall be accredited to the account of the animal control division. 
(d)  No person shall intentionally falsify information in an affidavit or supply false information in any form to any animal control officer in relation to the redemption of an impounded animal. A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus court cost. 
(Code 1986, § 5-34; Code 2002, § 5-51) 
Sec. 5-52. - Disposal of diseased or injured animals. 
    To prevent unnecessary suffering by any animal impounded by animal control and to protect the health and welfare of the remainder of the animal population held by animal control, any animal impounded and placed into the city's animal shelter that is determined by the animal control officer, to be suffering from a serious life-threatening injury or suspected of a contagious or infectious disease such as, but not limited to, mange, distemper, etc., may be euthanized or medically released to an approved animal rescue organization as soon as possible after immediate attempts to locate the owner of said animal by animal control are unsuccessful. 
(Code 2002, § 5-52; Ord. No. 2339NS, § 3, 2-19-2008; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 11, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-53-5-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Nuisances, 11 O.S. § 22-121, 50 O.S. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-81. - Parents' liability. 
    The parent or guardian of any minor claiming ownership of any dog shall be deemed to be the owner of such animal and shall be charged for all penalties and shelter fees imposed by this article. 
(Code 1986, § 5-57; Code 2002, § 5-81) 
Sec. 5-82. - Nuisances. 
(a)  Any person affected by a nuisance cited in subsection (b) of this section shall notify the animal control officer of the nuisance, and the animal control officer shall make an inspection to verify the complaint. The complainant shall be given the opportunity to file a written complaint with the animal control officer if the officer determines a nuisance exists. Following the receipt of a written complaint, the animal control officer may give the owner of the dog causing the nuisance a citation or a warning to mitigate the nuisance. Each day a nuisance exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  A nuisance condition exists when the owner of a dog allows feces of such animal to accumulate and, in the opinion of the animal control officer, causes odors and becomes offensive to smell and unsightly. 
(Code 1986, § 5-56; Code 2002, § 5-82) 
State Law reference- Nuisances, 11 O.S. § 22-121, 50 O.S. 
Sec. 5-83. - Running at large. 
    Every dog shall be confined within the owner's property by either a substantial fence of sufficient strength and height to prevent the dog from escaping therefrom or by being secured on the premises by a metal chain or leash sufficient in strength to prevent the dog from escaping from the owner's property and so arranged that the dog will remain upon the property when the leash or chain is stretched to full length. A dog may be off such premises if it is under the control of a competent person and restrained by a substantial leash. Any dog running at large within the city may be impounded. 
(Code 1986, § 5-51; Code 2002, § 5-83; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 12, 12-19-2016) 
State Law reference- Animals running at large, 11 O.S. § 22-115. 
Sec. 5-84. - Disturbing the peace. 
    No person shall keep, own or harbor any dog within the city which by loud, frequent or habitual barking, whining or the making of other noises shall annoy or disturb the peace and quiet of any neighborhood, family or person. It is the intent of this section to restrict the privilege of keeping or harboring any dog within the city to a dog of a quiet and peaceful nature, which is not given to the habit of howling, whining or barking, except by intentional provocation directed to such dog by some person, and then only while in the act of guarding or protecting the premises on which he is domiciled, of the master or of his household or effects. A violation of this section shall be considered a nuisance and is to be abated as set forth in section 5-82. 
(Code 1986, § 5-52; Code 2002, § 5-84) 
Sec. 5-85. - Proximity to residences. 
    No person shall keep or maintain any dog pen or shelter closer than 25 feet to the residence of any person other than the owner of such dog. 
(Code 1986, § 5-53; Code 2002, § 5-85) 
Sec. 5-86. - Maximum number. 
    It shall be unlawful for any premise or lot in the city to have in their possession or under their control more than two dogs over the age of four months. However, a premise or lot may have in possession three dogs over the age of four months, if all three dogs are altered in accordance with this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 5-58; Code 2002, § 5-86; Ord. No. 2623NS, § 1, 1-16-2018) 
Sec. 5-87. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that: 
(1)  Has inflicted injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property; or 
(2)  Has been previously found to be potentially dangerous, the owner having received notice of such by the animal control authority in writing and the dog thereafter aggressively bites., attacks or endangers the safety of humans. 
    Owner means any person, firm, corporation organization or department possessing, harboring, keeping, having an interest in, or having control or custody of an animal. 
    Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that when unprovoked inflicts bites on a human, either on public or private property. 
(Code 2002, § 5-87; Ord. No. 2383NS, § 1, 12-1-2008) 
Sec. 5-88. - Confiscation of a dangerous dog. 
(a)  Any dangerous dog may be immediately confiscated by a police officer or animal control officer if: 
(1)  The dog is not validly registered according to this chapter; 
(2)  The owner does not secure the liability insurance coverage or surety bond required by this chapter; 
(3)  The dog is not maintained in the proper enclosure; or 
(4)  The dog is outside of the dwelling of the owner or outside the proper enclosure and not under physical restraint of the responsible person. 
(b)  Any dangerous dog confiscated pursuant to this section and not reclaimed by its owner under the requirements of this chapter within 48 hours from the date of notice of confiscation shall be deemed abandoned and, at the discretion of the chief of police, euthanized pursuant to procedures provided by law in the city. 
(Code 2002, § 5-88; Ord. No. 2383NS, § 2, 12-1-2008; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 13, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-89. - Dogs not to be declared dangerous. 
    Dogs shall not be declared dangerous if the threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the dog, or was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog or has, in the past, been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(Code 2002, § 5-89; Ord. No. 2383NS, § 3, 12-1-2008) 
Secs. 5-90-5-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to tax, 11 O.S. § 22-115. 

Sec. 5-111. - Required generally; user fee. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Altered dog means either a male or female dog that, by a procedure rendered by a veterinarian, has been prevented from impregnating or from becoming impregnated. 
    Unaltered dog means a dog that has not been spayed or neutered by a veterinarian. 
(b)  Fee. Every person owning or harboring any dog within the city over the age of four months shall pay an annual license user fee provided by the city fee schedule for each unaltered male or female dog; and, a fee for each altered male or female dog having been neutered or sprayed. There shall be no charge for dogs used for the sight or hearing impaired, although such dogs shall be licensed by their owners. Senior citizens shall receive a 50 percent discount on licenses. Such license user fee shall cover a period of one year from the date of vaccination of such dog for rabies. Upon the expiration of a period of one year from the date of vaccination of such dog, the license shall expire. The license user fee shall become due and payable upon each dog attaining the age of four months and upon the expiration of the period covered by the license. 
(Code 1986, § 5-72; Code 2002, § 5-111; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 14, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-112. - Required after acquisition. 
    It shall be the responsibility of any person acquiring a dog, whether newly born or transferred from another owner, to obtain a new license, which shall be valid one year from the date such dog was vaccinated for rabies. 
(Code 1986, § 5-78; Code 2002, § 5-112) 
Sec. 5-113. - Exceptions. 
    Any dog brought into the city by any traveler or nonresident of the city, while with its owner or keeper, shall not be impounded, nor shall such owner or keeper be arrested for the reason that the dog is not lawfully licensed by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-71; Code 2002, § 5-113) 
Sec. 5-114. - Issuance. 
(a)  The animal control officer shall issue licenses for dogs as provided for in this article. User fees collected for the issuance of such licenses shall be remitted daily to the city treasurer-finance director, and an accurate record of all licenses issued and amounts collected shall be kept at all times. Such records shall be available for inspection at all reasonable times by the city manager or other persons designated by him to make inspections. 
(b)  The animal control officer shall record information concerning each such license issued, including the following: 
(1)  The date of issuance; 
(2)  The date of expiration; 
(3)  The name of the owner or the person in whose name the license was issued; 
(4)  The sex of the dog; 
(5)  The age, color and breed of the dog; and 
(6)  The date of vaccination and by whom vaccinated. 
(Code 1986, § 5-73; Code 2002, § 5-114) 
Sec. 5-115. - Receipt. 
(a)  The animal control officer shall issue a receipt to the person paying the dog license user fee. Such receipt shall show the following: 
(1)  The date and the amount of payment; 
(2)  The age of the dog, as stated by the owner; and 
(3)  The sex, color and breed of the dog. 
(b)  The dog user fee receipt shall operate as a license to own, keep or harbor the dog therein described for the year ending on the last day of the period covered by the license, which shall be valid for a period of one year from the date the dog was vaccinated for rabies. 
(Code 1986, § 5-74; Code 2002, § 5-115) 
Sec. 5-116. - Expiration; delinquent payment. 
    The license user fee required in this division shall become delinquent upon the expiration of the period covered by a license issued pursuant to this division. If the license user fee is not paid within ten days after the delinquency date, a penalty of 50 percent of the amount due shall be added to the delinquent fee and collected together with such fee. A senior citizen discount shall not apply to any penalty fees, and such penalty fee shall be 50 percent of the amount originally paid by the senior citizen. 
(Code 1986, § 5-77; Code 2002, § 5-116) 
Sec. 5-117. - Issuance and use of tags. 
    The animal control officer shall furnish any person who shall pay a dog license user fee a metal tag, on which shall be inscribed and stamped in a durable manner the year for which the fee was paid, a number separate and distinct from all other numbers used for like purposes in the same year, and the words "dog tag" in one line and "City of Shawnee" in another line. The owner of the dog shall provide a substantial collar to be worn by the dog at all times and to which such tag shall be firmly fixed in a good and substantial manner. 
(Code 1986, § 5-75; Code 2002, § 5-117) 
Sec. 5-118. - Unlawful use or disposal of tags. 
    No person shall unlawfully use or dispose of any dog license tag for any consideration, or without any consideration. 
(Code 1986, § 5-79; Code 2002, § 5-118) 
Sec. 5-119. - Issuance of duplicate tags. 
    Whenever a dog license tag is lost or stolen from any dog, the owner of the dog shall procure another tag from the animal control officer by making an affidavit to the effect that the license fee was paid for the lost tag, that all regulations have been complied with prior to the issuance of such tag, and that the tag was lost or stolen through no fault of his own. Upon the filing of such affidavit and payment of a fee provided by the city fee schedule, the animal control officer shall issue another tag. A senior citizen discount shall not apply to duplicate tag fees. 
(Code 1986, § 5-80; Code 2002, § 5-119; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 15, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-120-5-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RABIES CONTROL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Rabies control, 63 O.S. § 1-508. 

Sec. 5-146. - Vaccination required. 
(a)  No person shall own or harbor in the city any dog that has not been properly immunized against rabies by vaccination. The owner and/or keeper of any dog shall have such dog vaccinated against rabies by some licensed veterinarian at the age of four months with a second inoculation due within one year after the first, then to be vaccinated at least once every three years and shall procure from such veterinarian a certificate of vaccination showing the description of the dog vaccinated and the date of vaccination. 
(b)  The certificate shall be in force from the date of vaccination, through the effective lifespan of the vaccination dose administered to the dog as set forth in the certificate. 
(c)  Every dog shall be vaccinated on or before reaching four months of age. Any dog that is over the age of four months and that has not been vaccinated against rabies within the preceding 12 months and that has been kept within the city for a period of 30 days or more shall be vaccinated immediately. 
(Code 1986, § 5-91; Code 2002, § 5-146; Ord. No. 2251NS, § 1, 5-1-2006; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 16, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-147. - Registration for vaccination certificate. 
    The owner of every dog vaccinated pursuant to this division shall present the certificate therefor to the animal control officer, who shall register the vaccination certificate by noting in the dog register the date of vaccination and the veterinarian who administered the vaccine. No license shall be issued to keep or harbor a dog within the city until such certificate has been presented to the animal control officer, and the period covered by such license shall date from the date of immunization as shown on the certificate and shall be for the period of the certificate from the date of such immunization. 
(Code 1986, § 5-92; Code 2002, § 5-147; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 17, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-148. - Observation of dog that bites person. 
(a)  Any dog that bites a person within the city limits shall be reported to animal control. The owner of the dog shall place the dog in the care of a veterinarian. Exceptions to this rule include the following circumstances: 
(1)  Dogs involved in a first party ownership may be allowed to be placed in a home quarantine for a ten day period immediately following the bite. 
(2)  Dogs meeting the criteria of currently vaccinated against rabies, and not inflicting a severe injury, shall be placed in a home quarantine until the end of a ten-day period from the bite. In some instances, a certification of animal health obtained after examination by a licensed veterinarian on the tenth day may be required. 
(3)  Animals in service to the blind or hearing-impaired, and search and rescue dogs or other animals used for police enforcement duties shall be exempt from the quarantine when a bite exposure occurs and proper record of immunization against rabies is presented. A certification of animal health obtained after examination by a licensed veterinarian at the end of ten days may be required by the department. 
(b)  Within 24 hours, the dog will be placed under the care of a veterinarian. Failure to do so will constitute a violation of this article. 
(c)  The owner may elect at his own expense to have the animal euthanized by a licensed veterinary doctor and tested by the Oklahoma City Health Department for rabies. Once the testing is completed, the owner must supply a copy of the health department report to the city animal shelter. 
(d)  The veterinarian shall impound the dog for care and observation for a period of ten days from the date of the bite. 
(e)  When a dog under observation has been diagnosed as being rabid or suspected by a veterinarian as being rabid and dies while under observation, the veterinarian shall immediately send the dog to the Oklahoma City Health Department for rabies testing and shall notify the animal shelter of the test results. 
(f)  It shall be a violation of this article for any person to release any dog held for observation to any person prior to completion of the period of observation. 
(g)  The person to whom the dog is released shall have proof prior to release that the dog does not have rabies and that the dog has been properly vaccinated against rabies. 
(h)  If ownership of a dog that bites a person within the city limits cannot be verified, the dog shall be impounded for 24 hours and then euthanized and tested by the Oklahoma City Health Department for rabies. 
(Code 1986, § 5-54; Code 2002, § 5-148; Ord. No. 2043NS, § 3, 3-4-2002; Ord. No. 2048NS, § 1, 4-1-2002; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 18, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-149-5-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 5-176. - Authority of officers. 
(a)  The animal control officer, while on duty, may seize and impound, subject to this article, all dogs found running at large upon any public highway, street, alley, court, square, park, sidewalk or any other public property within the city limits, whether in the immediate presence of the owner or custodian or otherwise, as provided in this Code. 
(b)  The animal control officer, while on duty, may seize and impound, subject to this article, all dogs found running at large upon any unfenced lot, tract or parcel of land within the city limits, whether in the immediate presence of the owner or custodian or otherwise, and such animal control officer is authorized to enter upon any unfenced lot, tract or parcel of land for the purpose of seizing and impounding any dog running at large thereon, as provided in this Code. 
(c)  The animal control officer is empowered and authorized to enforce all aspects of this Code. Further, he is authorized and empowered to issue citations to any person in violation of this Code. He can cause the arrest of any person who resists the animal control officer's attempts at resolving animal-caused violations. 
(Code 1986, § 5-106; Code 2002, § 5-176; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 19, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-177. - Care of impounded dogs. 
    The animal control officer shall see that all dogs that are impounded shall have sufficient amounts of water and food and shall furnish shelter from the elements. Sanitary conditions will be maintained, and dogs will be cared for in a humane manner. 
(Code 1986, § 5-107; Code 2002, § 5-177) 
Sec. 5-178. - Redemption; release. 
    Any person appearing at the city animal shelter who satisfies the animal control officer of the fact of his ownership or right to the possession of any dog therein impounded shall have such dog returned to him upon the following conditions: 
(1)  If the dog so impounded has a valid city dog tag and vaccination tag, such dog may be returned to the owner upon his paying to the animal control officer an impounding fee provided by the city fee schedule, and a fee for each day the dog has been impounded. The animal control officer shall give a receipt to such claimant in duplicate for such payment and release the dog to the owner. 
(2)  If the dog impounded does not have a valid city tag or vaccination tag, the dog may be released to the owner upon his paying to the animal control officer an impounding fee provided by the city fee schedule, for each day the dog has been impounded and obtaining from the animal control officer a dog tag, as provided for in this article. The fees, as provided for in this subsection, shall be paid to the animal control officer and, upon presentation of evidence that such dog has been vaccinated for rabies, the animal control officer may authorize the release of the dog. A dog that is not currently vaccinated for rabies shall not be released or returned to its owner until the dog has been vaccinated as set forth in this article. 
(3)  If a licensed but untagged dog is impounded, it shall be the duty of the owner of such dog to comply with this article by filing his affidavit and procuring a duplicate tag within three days of impoundment. The animal control officer may then release the dog to the owner upon payment of the fees as provided in this section. If the affidavit is not filed within three days of impoundment or if the fees are not paid or if the order of release is not obtained within the three-day period, the dog shall be disposed of in the same manner as in all other cases. 
(Code 1986, § 5-108; Code 2002, § 5-178; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 20, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-179. - Disposal of unclaimed dogs. 
    All dogs seized and impounded, as provided in this chapter, that are not identified with a city license tag, shall be kept in the city animal shelter for a period of two working days, or not less than 48 hours from the time they are so impounded. However, a dog having on it a city license tag shall be held four working days, or not less than 96 hours from the time it is so impounded. If, at the expiration of such time, the dog is not called for and the fees paid as provided by this division, the animal control officer may dispose of such dog by euthanasia and dispose of the body according to law. However, any unlicensed dog impounded for more than two working days, or not less than 48 hours, or any licensed dog impounded for more than four working days, or not less than 96 hours, may be adopted out or released to a rescue organization at the end of the impoundment period in lieu of disposal. 
(Code 1986, § 5-109; Code 2002, § 5-179; Ord. No. 2066NS, § 1, 8-5-2002; Ord. No. 2252NS, § 1, 4-3-2006; Ord. No. 2339NS, § 1, 2-19-2008; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 21, 12-19-2016) 
State Law reference- Disposal of animals held in shelter, 4 O.S. § 501 et seq. 
Secs. 5-180-5-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - KENNELS 

Sec. 5-206. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Kennel means any lot or premises on which three or more dogs more than four months of age are kept. 
(Code 1986, § 5-121(a); Code 2002, § 5-206) 
Sec. 5-207. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall maintain or operate any kennel for the sale, exchange, boarding, training, breeding or raising of dogs within the city without first procuring from the animal control officer an annual license to operate such kennel. 
(b)  Each facility regulated by this division shall be considered a separate enterprise and shall require an individual license. 
(c)  No fee shall be required of any veterinary hospital or government-operated zoological park or city-operated facility. 
(d)  Failure to obtain a license before opening any facility covered in this division shall be an offense, punishable with each day constituting a separate violation. 
(Code 1986, § 5-121; Code 2002, § 5-207) 
Sec. 5-208. - License fee; permit terms and conditions. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a dog kennel shall pay an annual license fee provided by the city fee schedule for such privilege. All such dogs over four months of age shall be vaccinated in the same manner as other dogs. A city license shall also be required for each dog kept at an established licensed kennel. 
(b)  The license shall not be valid until approved in writing by the animal control officer, who shall make a notation of approval on a duplicate thereof. The property on which the kennel is kept shall be inspected by an animal control officer before the permit is issued. 
(c)  Each permit shall state the following: 
(1)  The name of the person to whom it is issued. 
(2)  The date of issuance. 
(3)  The period for which the permit is valid, which shall be one year from the date of issuance. 
(4)  The maximum number of dogs allowed, which will be determined with the restriction that each dog must have at least 35 square feet of unrestricted pen area with a solid floor. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to notify the person who keeps a kennel contrary to this section to correct the violation within three days from the date of such notice. 
(Code 1986, § 5-122; Code 2002, § 5-208; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 22, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-209. - Revocation of permit or license. 
(a)  The city manager may, after opportunity for hearing before the city manager or designate, revoke any dog kennel license if the person holding the license refuses or fails to comply with this chapter, the regulations promulgated by the animal control officer or any law governing the protection and keeping of animals. 
(b)  Any person whose license is revoked shall, within ten days thereafter, humanely dispose of all animals owned, kept or harbored by such person. No part of the license fee shall be refunded. 
(c)  It shall be a condition of the issuance of any license that the animal control officer shall be permitted to inspect all dogs and the premises where dogs are kept at any time. The city manager shall, if permission for such inspection is refused, revoke the license of the refusing owner, after affording an opportunity for hearing before the city manager or designate. 
(d)  If the applicant has withheld or falsified any information on the application, the animal control officer shall refuse to issue a license. No person who has been convicted of an offense related to cruelty to animals shall be issued a permit or license to operate a commercial animal establishment or kennel. 
(e)  Any person having been denied a license may not reapply for a period of 30 days. Each reapplication shall be accompanied by a fee, as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1986, § 5-125; Code 2002, § 5-209) 
Sec. 5-210. - Standards and sanitation. 
(a)  Standards for dog kennels shall be developed by animal control as a policy and shall be administered by the department. 
(b)  Any building, fence, pen or other enclosure in which the dogs are confined shall be located 50 feet from any structure used for dwelling purposes or business purposes, and no human habitation shall be allowed within the animal establishment. 
(c)  The kennel wherein dogs are kept shall be maintained in a clean condition and free from filth at all times. Dog feces shall be removed from the kennel daily and the premises disinfected not less than once in each period of two weeks. Feces shall be disposed of properly by either burying or removing it from the site on a weekly basis. 
(Code 1986, § 5-123; Code 2002, § 5-210) 
Sec. 5-211. - Vaccination required. 
    It shall be the responsibility of any holder of a kennel license to provide proof that all dogs, four months and older, under the holder's control have had the required rabies vaccinations by a licensed veterinarian. 
(Code 1986, § 5-124; Code 2002, § 5-211; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 23, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-212-5-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CATS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-241. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cat means any feline, regardless of age or sex. 
(Code 1986, § 5-131; Code 2002, § 5-241) 
Sec. 5-242. - Identification. 
    Every person residing in the city and owning or having in possession any cat over four months old shall have the cat bear identification. 
(Code 1986, § 5-131; Code 2002, § 5-242) 
Sec. 5-243. - Rabies vaccination. 
(a)  Every person residing in the city and owning or having in possession any cat over four months old shall be required to have the cat inoculated for rabies. Every veterinarian who vaccinates any cat shall collect his fee for the vaccination from the owner or keeper of the cat and shall issue a certificate of vaccination to such owner or keeper. He shall state in the certificate the name of the owner or keeper, the date of vaccination. 
(b)  Any person or entity owning, harboring, or keeping a cat which in the preceding ten days has bitten any person, shall upon receipt of written notice by the local animal control authority or department designee, place such animal in quarantine under the supervision of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten days from the date the person was bitten. The impoundment and observation of the cat or shall be conducted at the veterinarian's facility, or a recognized animal control facility. Unvaccinated animals shall be vaccinated against rabies on the final day of the ten-day observation period prior to discharge from the veterinarian's supervision and the date of vaccination. 
(c)  Exceptions to this rule include the following circumstances: 
(1)  Cats involved in a first party ownership may be allowed to be placed in a home quarantine for a ten-day period immediately following the bite. 
(2)  Cats meeting the criteria of currently vaccinated against rabies, and not inflicting a severe injury, shall be placed in a home quarantine until the end of a ten-day period from the bite. In some instances, a certification of animal health obtained after examination by a licensed veterinarian on the tenth day may be required by the department or local animal control authority. 
(Code 1986, § 5-135; Code 2002, § 5-243; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 24, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-244. - Maximum number. 
    It shall be unlawful for any premise or lot in the city to have in possession or under control more than three unaltered cats over the age of four months. However, a premise or lot may have under control six felines, all of which are altered as provided by article V of this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 5-133; Code 2002, § 5-244; Ord. No. 2623NS, § 2, 1-16-2018) 
Sec. 5-245. - Parents' liability. 
    The parent or guardian of any minor claiming ownership of any cat shall be deemed to be the owner of such animal and shall be charged for all penalties and shelter fees imposed by this article. 
(Code 1986, § 5-132; Code 2002, § 5-245) 
Sec. 5-246. - Noise. 
    Every person owning, possessing or harboring a cat shall prevent such cat from whining or making other sounds common to its species in excessive, continuous or untimely fashion which shall annoy or disturb the peace and quiet of any neighborhood, family or person. 
(Code 1986, § 5-136; Code 2002, § 5-246) 
Sec. 5-247. - Running at large. 
    No person shall permit his cat to run at large within the city limits at any time. A cat shall be deemed running at large when off the premises of its owner or keeper without being under adequate control of its owner or keeper. 
(Code 1986, § 5-137; Code 2002, § 5-247) 
Sec. 5-248. - Disposition of feral or vicious cats. 
    Any feral or vicious cat found running at large which, because of its disposition or diseased condition, it is too hazardous to apprehend, may be destroyed when so ordered by the chief of police or the animal control officer. In an emergency, if the chief of police or animal control officer cannot be contacted in time to avoid danger to any person, any police officer may destroy such animal without first contacting the chief of police or animal control officer. 
(Code 1986, § 5-140; Code 2002, § 5-248; Ord. No. 2250NS, § 1, 5-1-2006) 
Secs. 5-249-5-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 5-276. - Required generally; fee. 
    Every person owning or harboring any cat within the city over the age of four months shall pay: an annual license user fee provided by the city fee schedule for each unaltered male or female cat, and a fee, for each altered male or female cat having been neutered or spayed. Senior citizens shall receive a 50 percent discount on licenses. Such license user fee shall cover a period of one year from the date of vaccination of the cat for rabies. Upon the expiration of a period of one year from the date of vaccination of the cat, the license shall expire. The license user fee shall become due and payable upon each cat attaining the age of four months and upon the expiration of the period covered by the license. 
(Code 1986, § 5-134(a); Code 2002, § 5-276; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 25, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-277. - Required after acquisition. 
    It shall be the responsibility of any person acquiring a cat, whether newly born or transferred from another owner, to obtain a new license, which shall be valid for one year from the date the cat was vaccinated for rabies. 
(Code 1986, § 5-134(f); Code 2002, § 5-277) 
Sec. 5-278. - Issuance; term. 
(a)  The animal control officer shall issue a receipt to the person paying the cat license fee. Such receipt shall show the following: 
(1)  The date and the amount of payment; 
(2)  The age as stated by the owner; and 
(3)  The sex, color and breed of the cat. 
(b)  The cat tag receipt shall operate as a license to own, keep or harbor the cat therein described for the year ending on the last day of the period covered by such license, which shall be one year from the date such cat was vaccinated for rabies. 
(Code 1986, § 5-134(b); Code 2002, § 5-278) 
Sec. 5-279. - Delinquent payment. 
    The license fee required in this division shall become delinquent upon the expiration of the period covered by a license issued pursuant to this division. If the fee is not paid within ten days after the delinquency date, a penalty of 50 percent of the amount due shall be added to such delinquent fee and collected together with such fee. A senior citizen discount shall not apply to any penalty fees. 
(Code 1986, § 5-134(d); Code 2002, § 5-279) 
Sec. 5-280. - Tag. 
    The animal control officer shall furnish any person who shall pay a cat license user fee a metal tag, on which shall be inscribed and stamped in a durable manner the year for which the fee was paid, a number separate and distinct from all other numbers used for like purposes in the same year, and the words "cat tag" in one line and "City of Shawnee" in another line. The owner of such cat shall provide a substantial collar to be worn by the cat at all times and to which such tag shall be firmly fixed in a good and substantial manner. 
(Code 1986, § 5-134(c); Code 2002, § 5-280) 
Sec. 5-281. - Duplicate tags. 
    Whenever a cat license tag is lost or stolen from any cat, the owner of the cat shall procure another tag from the animal control officer by making an affidavit to the effect that the license fee was paid for the lost tag, that all regulations have been complied with prior to the issuance of such tag and that the tag was lost or stolen through no fault of the owner. Upon the filing of such affidavit and payment of a fee provided by the city fee schedule, the animal control officer shall issue another tag. A senior citizen discount shall not apply to duplicate tag fees. 
(Code 1986, § 5-134(e); Code 2002, § 5-281; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 26, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-282-5-305. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 5-306. - Running at large or creating nuisance. 
    Any cat running at large or creating a nuisance, in violation of this article, is declared to be a public nuisance and may be impounded by the animal control officer, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1986, § 5-139(a); Code 2002, § 5-306; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 27, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-307. - Redemption. 
    Any person appearing at the city animal shelter who satisfies the animal control officer of the fact of his ownership or right to the possession of any cat therein impounded shall have such cat returned to him upon the following conditions: 
(1)  If the cat so impounded has a valid city cat tag and vaccination tag, such cat may be returned to the owner upon his paying to the animal control officer an impounding fee provided by the city fee schedule, and an additional fee for each day the cat has been impounded. 
(2)  If the cat impounded does not have a valid city tag or vaccination tag, the cat may be released to the owner upon his paying to the animal control officer an impounding fee provided by the city fee schedule, and an additional fee for each day the cat has been impounded and obtaining from the animal control officer a cat tag, as provided for in this article. The fees, as provided for in this subsection, shall be paid to the animal control officer and, upon presentation of evidence that such cat has been vaccinated for rabies, the animal control officer may authorize the release of the cat. A cat that is not currently vaccinated for rabies shall not be released or returned to its owner until the cat has been vaccinated as set forth in this subsection. 
(3)  If a licensed but untagged cat is impounded, it shall be the duty of the owner of such cat to comply with this article by filing his affidavit and procuring a duplicate tag within three days of impoundment. The animal control officer may then release the cat to the owner upon payment of the fees, as provided in this section. If the affidavit is not filed within three days of impoundment or if the fees are not paid or if the order of release is not obtained within the three-day period, the cat shall be disposed of in the same manner as provided in section 5-308. 
(Code 1986, § 5-139(b); Code 2002, § 5-307; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 28, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-308. - Term; disposition. 
    All cats seized and impounded, as provided in this article, that are not identified with a city license tag, shall be kept in the city animal shelter for a period of two working days or not less than 48 hours from the time they are so impounded. However, a cat having on a city license tag shall be held four working days or not less than 96 hours from the time it is so impounded. If, at the expiration of such time, the cat is not called for and the fees paid as provided by this division, the animal control officer may dispose of such cat by euthanasia and dispose of the body according to law. However, any unlicensed cat impounded for more than two working days or not less than 48 hours, or any licensed cat impounded for more than four working days or not less than 96 hours, may be adopted out or released to a rescue organization at the end of the impoundment period in lieu of disposal. 
(Code 1986, § 5-139(c); Code 2002, § 5-308; Ord. No. 2066NS, § 2, 8-5-2002; Ord. No. 2252NS, § 2, 4-3-2006; Ord. No. 2339NS, § 2, 2-19-2008; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 29, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-309-5-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - KENNELS 

Sec. 5-336. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Kennel means any lot or premises on which more than three unaltered cats or more than six altered cats, more than four months of age, are kept. 
(Code 1986, § 5-143; Code 2002, § 5-336) 
Sec. 5-337. - License and permit required. 
(a)  No person shall maintain or operate any cattery for the sale, exchange, boarding, training, breeding or raising of cats within the city without first procuring from the animal control officer an annual license to operate such kennel. 
(b)  Each facility regulated by this division shall be considered a separate enterprise and shall require an individual license. 
(c)  No fee shall be required of any veterinary hospital or government-operated zoological park or city-operated facility. 
(d)  Failure to obtain a license before opening any facility covered in this division shall be an offense, punishable with each day constituting a separate violation. 
(Code 1986, § 5-143; Code 2002, § 5-337) 
Sec. 5-338. - License fee; terms and conditions. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a cat kennel shall pay an annual license fee provided by the city fee schedule for such privilege. All such cats over four months of age shall be vaccinated in the same manner as other cats. A city license shall also be required for each cat kept at an established licensed kennel. 
(b)  The license shall not be valid until approved in writing by the animal control officer, who shall make a notation of approval on a duplicate thereof. The property shall be inspected by an animal control officer before the permit is issued. 
(c)  Each license shall state the following: 
(1)  The name of the person to whom it is issued. 
(2)  The date of issuance. 
(3)  The period for which the license is valid, which is one year from the date of issuance. 
(4)  The maximum number of cats allowed, which shall not exceed one cat per 12 square feet of unrestricted pen area with a solid floor. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to notify the person who keeps a kennel contrary to this division to correct the violation within three days from the date of such notice. 
(Code 1986, § 5-144; Code 2002, § 5-338; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 30, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-339. - Revocation of permit or license. 
(a)  The city manager may, after opportunity for hearing before the city manager or designate, revoke any cat kennel license if the person holding the license refuses or fails to comply with this article, the regulations promulgated by the animal control officer or any law governing the protection and keeping of animals. 
(b)  Any person whose license is revoked shall remove all cats within ten days thereafter. No part of the license fee shall be refunded. 
(c)  It shall be a condition of the issuance of any license that the animal control officer shall be permitted to inspect all cats and the premises where cats are kept at any time. The city manager shall, if permission for such inspection is refused, revoke the license of the refusing owner, after affording an opportunity for hearing before the city manager or designate. 
(d)  If the applicant has withheld or falsified any information on the application, the animal control officer shall refuse to issue a permit. No person who has been convicted of an offense related to cruelty to animals shall be issued a license to operate a commercial animal establishment or kennel. 
(e)  Any person having been denied a license may not reapply for a period of 30 days. Each reapplication shall be accompanied by a fee as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1986, § 5-147; Code 2002, § 5-339) 
Sec. 5-340. - Standards and sanitation. 
(a)  Standards for cat kennels shall be developed by animal control as a policy and shall be administered by the department. 
(b)  Any building, fence, pen or other enclosure in which the cats are confined shall be located 50 feet from any structure used for dwelling purposes or business purposes, and no human habitation shall be allowed within the animal establishment. 
(c)  The kennel wherein cats are kept shall be maintained in a clean condition and free from filth at all times. Feces shall be removed from the kennel daily and the premises disinfected not less than once in each period of two weeks. Feces shall be disposed of properly by either burying or removing it from the site on a weekly basis. 
(Code 1986, § 5-145; Code 2002, § 5-340) 
Sec. 5-341. - Rabies vaccination required. 
    It shall be the responsibility of any holder of a cat kennel license to provide proof that each cat, four months and older, under the holder's control shall have the required rabies vaccination by a licensed veterinarian. 
(Code 1986, § 5-146; Code 2002, § 5-341; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 31, 12-19-2016) 
Secs. 5-342-5-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DOG AND CAT STERILIZATION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Dog and Cat Sterilization Act, 4 O.S. § 499 et seq. 

Sec. 5-371. - Definitions. 
    The definitions of 4 O.S. § 499.1 are adopted by reference in this section as if fully set forth. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Immunization means a vaccination or inoculation given by a veterinarian or other person authorized by law, which reduces the likelihood of animals contracting rabies or other infectious diseases. 
    Neutered means a process performed by a veterinarian or other person authorized by law, which removes the reproductive organs of any animal. 
    New owner or owner means a person legally competent (18 years of age) to enter into a contract to acquire a dog or cat from the city animal shelter. 
    Porcine means pig, hog, potbellied pig or of the pig, hog, kine or swine family. 
    Senior citizen means any person 55 years of age or older. 
    Spay means a process performed by a veterinarian or other person authorized by law, which removes the reproductive organs of a female animal. 
    Sterilize means to spay or neuter a dog or cat. 
    Unaltered animal means an animal that has not been spayed or neutered by a veterinarian. 
    Vaccination means the inoculation given by a veterinarian or other person authorized by law, which reduces the likelihood of animals contracting rabies or other infectious diseases. 
(Code 1986, § 5-156; Code 2002, § 5-371) 
Sec. 5-372. - Sterilization or agreement and deposit required for adoption. 
    No dog or cat may be released for adoption from the city animal shelter unless the dog or cat has been surgically spayed or neutered or unless the adopting party signs an agreement to have the dog or cat sterilized and deposits funds with the city to ensure that the adopted dog or cat will be spayed or neutered. Rescue organizations may be exempt from deposits. 
(Code 1986, § 5-157; Code 2002, § 5-372; Ord. No. 2593NS, § 32, 12-19-2016) 
Sec. 5-373. - Sterilization required to refund deposit. 
    The funds deposited with the city as provided in section 5-372 shall be refunded to the adopting party upon the adopting party's presentation of a written statement signed by a licensed veterinarian that the adopted dog or cat has been spayed or neutered. However, no refund shall be made unless the dog or cat was spayed or neutered within 60 days of adoption of an adult dog or cat or, for an infant dog or cat, within 30 days of the date a female dog or cat has attained the age of six months or a male dog or cat has attained the age of eight months. 
(Code 1986, § 5-158; Code 2002, § 5-373) 
Sec. 5-374. - Form of agreement. 
    The sterilization agreement to be used by the city under this article shall be in substantially the following form: 
RECEIPT # ____________ 
STERILIZATION AGREEMENT 
This Agreement is made and entered into this ____________ day of ____________ , ____________ , by and between:

A Municipal Corporation 
By and Through Its City Animal Shelter 
City Hall 
Shawnee, Oklahoma 
273-1250

(1)  The City of Shawnee, Oklahoma agrees to release the above-listed animal into the care of the new owner and refund the new owner's spay/neuter deposit provided that: 
a.  The animal be sterilized by a licensed veterinarian by Date: ____________ . 
b.  A written agreement signed by the veterinarian performing the sterilization that the animal has been sterilized by the stated date if given to the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma. 
(2)  New owner accepts the above-listed animal and agrees: 
a.  To have the animal sterilized by a licensed veterinarian by Date: ____________ .

The City of Shawnee, Oklahoma
