Should the property owner fail to remove the sign after receiving notification from the city, the community development director of the city may cause the sign within the city to be torn down and removed, with the cost of said removal being affixed as a lien on the property, pursuant to the identical procedure set forth in section 7-582. 
(Code 2002, § 7-585; Ord. No. 2064NS, § 2, 7-15-2002) 
Secs. 7-586-7-610. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 7-611. - Compliance with article and payment of permit fees. 
    Persons licensed under this article must comply with all of the sections of this article relating to the work being done and must pay the permit fees required for demolishing buildings and structures. 
(Code 1986, § 7-54; Code 2002, § 7-611) 
Sec. 7-612. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any section of this article, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than the amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. Each day of such violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 7-51; Code 2002, § 7-612) 
Sec. 7-613. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the city inspector to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(Code 1986, § 7-55; Code 2002, § 7-613) 
Sec. 7-614. - License. 
(a)  Application required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of demolishing buildings or structures without first having secured a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made in writing to the city clerk. 
(b)  Fees. The fee for a license required under subsection (a) of this section shall be as described in the city fee schedule for an annual license, which will expire on December 31 of the year following the date of issue. 
(Code 1986, §§ 7-52, 7-53; Code 2002, § 7-614) 
Sec. 7-615. - Surety bond. 
    Every person licensed under this article shall file with the city clerk a bond in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, with sureties to be approved by the city manager or designee. Such bond shall be payable to the city and shall be conditioned that: 
(1)  The principal will at all times do all demolition work and associated work, including, but not limited to, the removal of all debris and the transportation and deposit thereof, strictly in accordance with this article; 
(2)  All work will be done in a good and workmanlike manner; 
(3)  The city shall be fully indemnified and held harmless from any cost, expense, damages to real or personal property or personal injury done to any person or property in the conduct of such work; and 
(4)  The licensee shall cause all streets, alleys and sidewalks that have been damaged in any manner to be repaired and put in the same condition as they were before the work was done. 
(Code 1986, § 7-56; Code 2002, § 7-615) 
Sec. 7-616. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Before any license is issued under this article, the applicant for the license shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy for an indemnity fund as provided in this section. 
(b)  Such insurance policy shall be issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state and shall provide public liability insurance for every operation or job performed by such person so engaged in the business of demolishing buildings or structures, including, but not limited to, the removal of all debris and the transportation and deposit thereof, for the injury or death of any one person, for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident and for property damage in any one accident arising out of such work, such insurance policy shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  The policy shall further provide that it cannot be cancelled until ten days' written notice of such cancellation has been given to the city clerk, and such policy shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city for any changes therein. 
(d)  The policy shall be approved by the city manager or designee. 
(e)  The policy shall be made for the use, benefit and protection of the city and for the use, benefit and protection of any person who may suffer injury either to his person or property because of any accident or omission or negligence of the licensee or his agents, servants and employees and all persons acting by, through or under the authority of such license. The policy of insurance shall remain in full force and effect during the life of any such license issued. If the policy is allowed to lapse or is not renewable by the payment of premiums, the city commission may cancel any license issued under this article, after notice to the licensee and after an opportunity to be heard. The cancellation of any policy shall in no way affect or terminate any liability arising prior to the effective date of such cancellation. 
(Code 1986, § 7-57; Code 2002, § 7-616) 
Secs. 7-617-7-645. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - STORM CELLARS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Storm shelters maintained by boards of education, 70 O.S. § 24-115. 

Sec. 7-646. - License required; fees. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of constructing or repairing storm cellars within the city unless such person applies for and obtains a license to conduct such business and pays to the city clerk a license fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, per annum. Such license fee shall expire on December 31 of each year following the date of issuance, and the full annual fee shall be paid in advance. No license shall be issued for less than the full annual fee. 
(b)  Late renewal of the license shall subject the licensee to an additional fee as described in the city fee schedule, and no license shall be renewed more than 90 days after expiration. 
(Code 1986, § 7-71; Code 2002, § 7-646) 
Sec. 7-647. - Surety bond. 
(a)  Before any license is issued to any person engaging in the business of constructing or repairing storm cellars, he shall file a surety bond with the city clerk in an amount as described in the city fee schedule payable to the city and conditioned that: 
(1)  The principal will at all times do all storm cellar construction and repair work strictly in accordance with this article; 
(2)  All work will be done in a good and workmanlike manner; and 
(3)  The city shall be fully indemnified and held whole and harmless from any cost, expense, damages to real property or injury done to any person or property in the prosecution of such work that may arise out of or be occasioned in the performance of such work. 
(b)  No license shall be issued to any person engaged in the business of constructing or repairing storm cellars until such bond has been filed with and approved by the city manager or designee. 
(Code 1986, § 7-72; Code 2002, § 7-647) 
Sec. 7-648. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Before any license required under this article is issued to a person engaged in the business of constructing or repairing storm cellars, he shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy for an indemnity fund as provided in this section. 
(b)  Such insurance policy shall be issued by any insurance company licensed to do business in the state and shall provide public liability insurance for every operation or job performed by such person engaged in the business of constructing or repairing storm cellars for the injury or death to any one person, for the injury or death to any number of persons in any one accident and for the property damage in any one accident growing out of such work. Such insurance policy shall provide coverage in the amount as established in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  The policy shall further provide that it cannot be cancelled until ten days' written notice of such cancellation has been given to the city clerk, and the policy shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city for any changes therein. 
(d)  The policy shall be approved by the city manager or designee and endorsed thereon. 
(e)  The policy shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. The policy shall be made for the use, benefit and protection of the city and for the use, benefit and protection of any person who may suffer injury either to his person or property because of any accident or omission or negligence of any person engaged in the business of constructing or repairing storm cellars. If the policy is approved by the city manager or designee, it shall remain in full force and effect during the life of any such license issued. If, after the approval of the policy and after the issuance of the license, the policy is allowed to lapse or is not renewed by the payment of premiums, the city commission may cancel any license issued under this article, after notice to the licensee and after an opportunity to be heard. The cancellation of any policy shall in no way affect or terminate any liability arising prior to the effective date of such cancellation. 
(Code 1986, § 7-73; Code 2002, § 7-648) 
Secs. 7-649-7-675. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Encroachments and obstructions in streets generally, 11 O.S. § 36-107. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-676. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall move any building or structure or thing onto, over or across any street or alley without having complied with all of the sections of this article, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. Each day of such violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 7-21; Code 2002, § 7-676) 
Sec. 7-677. - Liability. 
    No section or condition of this article shall be construed to limit the civil liability of any person moving any house, building or other thing on or over any of the city streets, avenues and alleys from any damages which may result as the proximate cause of such acts to any person or his property or to the city. 
(Code 1986, § 7-35; Code 2002, § 7-677) 
Sec. 7-678. - Passageway around structure. 
    Any person operating under a permit issued pursuant to this article or his laborer, servant, agent or employee shall cause a sufficient passageway to be kept open for vehicles to pass on one side or both sides of any building, structure, edifice, object or thing while it is being moved upon any street, avenue or alley, if the character of the building, structure, edifice, object or thing permits such, and when possible the building, structure, edifice, object or thing shall be kept moving each day without avoidable delay. 
(Code 1986, § 7-30; Code 2002, § 7-678) 
Sec. 7-679. - Protection of trees and utility wires and poles. 
(a)  Any person who has a permit to move a building or structure over any street within the city shall derive no right, by virtue of such permit, to injure or impair the condition of usefulness of any shade tree or electric light or telephone or telegraph lines or poles. 
(b)  No tree of any kind shall be cut, bruised, scarred or injured under any circumstances, without the expressed permission, in writing, of the owner of the tree and without the permission of the public works director. 
(c)  When necessary to remove any electric light, telephone or telegraph construction, it shall be the duty of the person moving the building or structure to give not less than 24 hours' notice to the public utility company or person owning or operating such construction. The notice shall state the place, the construction that is necessary to be removed or temporarily changed or altered and the day on which it is desired to have such clearance made, as well as the amount of time it will be necessary to keep such space clear. The 24-hour notice to the public utility shall be the minimum time of the notice, but the building shall not be moved over the streets until the public utility involved shall have had a reasonable time, not exceeding seven days, to make such clearance. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the person moving the building or structure to deposit an amount of money with the city clerk, estimated by the city clerk to be the amount necessary to cover the cost of changing or moving the public utility overhead construction and replacing the construction in its former condition. Upon making such deposit with the city clerk and upon delivery of the notice to the owner or operator of the electric light, telephone or telegraph poles and line construction, it shall be the duty of the person owning or operating the light, telephone or telegraph overhead construction to make such temporary changes as are reasonably necessary to comply with the conditions set forth in the notice made and delivered to him. 
(Code 1986, § 7-31; Code 2002, § 7-679) 
Sec. 7-680. - Caution lights. 
    It shall be the duty of each person issued a permit under this article to place red lights, plainly visible for not less than 200 feet, on every side of the building or structure that is being moved, at the close of day and to keep the lights burning throughout the entire night and until one hour after sunrise on the morning following. The lights shall be so placed and maintained that the view of the lights in any sense will not be obstructed. As many additional lights as may be necessary shall be placed at such other points on the building or structure as will enable any person of reasonable and ordinary prudence to take notice of the obstruction. 
(Code 1986, § 7-32; Code 2002, § 7-680) 
Sec. 7-681. - Persons on guard and notice to protect public. 
    It shall be the duty of every housemover to station sufficient persons on guard and to establish such notice by placard or boards in the immediate vicinity of the moving activities as will be necessary to apprise any reasonable person of any potential danger that might be incurred by approaching the moving operations or buildings or the instruments or equipment used in the moving of the buildings. 
(Code 1986, § 7-33; Code 2002, § 7-681) 
Sec. 7-682. - Notice to fire chief. 
    When any person desires to move any building and has a permit issued pursuant to this article, he shall show his permit to the chief of the fire department. If for any reason any delay is occasioned by any unforeseen contingency, it shall be the permittee's duty to inform the fire chief of such facts to the end that the fire chief may keep accurate and recent information of the true condition of the streets and alleys for the fire department. 
(Code 1986, § 7-34; Code 2002, § 7-682) 
Secs. 7-683-7-710. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 7-711. - Required. 
    No person, as principal, agent, laborer, servant or employee, shall use or occupy any of the streets, avenues, alleys or other public places within the city for the purpose of moving any building, structure or edifice or any other object or thing, of any kind or character, to be used or placed therein for the purpose of effecting the transportation of such structure, building, edifice or other thing without having first obtained from the building inspector a permit for such purposes, which permit shall first have been approved by the public works director and the building inspector. No permit shall be necessary to move buildings or other structures that are under 131/2 feet in height, when loaded, and under 14 feet in width and an overall length of 65 feet. 
(Code 1986, § 7-22; Code 2002, § 7-711) 
Sec. 7-712. - Application. 
    A permit required by this division will be obtained upon written application accompanied by a permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. The application will state the following: 
(1)  The character of the thing or object to be moved and transported along or through and upon the streets, avenues or alleys; 
(2)  The proposed route of such transportation; and 
(3)  The place where the equipment used in effecting such moving and transportation will be placed and secured. 
(Code 1986, § 7-24; Code 2002, § 7-712; Ord. No. 2533NS, § 5, 3-3-2014) 
Sec. 7-713. - Fees. 
    The fee for a permit for removing any building up to 24 feet in width shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule; from 24 feet to 30 feet in width the fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule; from 30 feet to 32 feet in width the fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. No fee shall be charged for removing any building or structure not more than 131/2 feet in height when loaded, nine feet wide, and an overall length of 50 feet. 
(Code 1986, § 7-23; Code 2002, § 7-713) 
Sec. 7-714. - Bonds. 
(a)  No permit required by this division shall be issued until the applicant for the permit shall have deposited with the officer issuing the permit a cash bond in such sum as may be reasonably necessary to cover all losses or damages to streets or pavements because of any negligence or improper occupancy of the streets, sidewalks and alleys. 
(b)  Every person engaged as principal in the business regulated by this article, in addition to the cash bond deposit, shall deliver a surety bond to be approved by the city manager or designee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, conditioned that such person shall save, indemnify and keep harmless the city against any liabilities, judgments, damages, costs and expenses that may in any way accrue against the city in consequence of the granting of the permit or while acting under the permit and that such person shall under all circumstances strictly comply with the terms of the permit. Such surety bond shall not in any manner be affected or limited by the cash deposit required. 
(Code 1986, § 7-25; Code 2002, § 7-714) 
Sec. 7-715. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Before any permit shall be issued to a housemover, every person obtaining such permit shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy for an indemnity fund as provided in this section. 
(b)  Such policy shall be an insurance policy issued by an insurance company licensed and authorized to do business in the state, providing public liability insurance coverage for each operation required in house moving for the injury or death of any one person, for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident growing out of the house moving and for property damage in any one accident, such insurance policy shall provide coverage in the amounts as described in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  The policy shall also provide that it cannot be cancelled until ten days' written notice of such cancellation has been given to the city clerk, and the policy shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city for any changes therein. 
(d)  The policy shall be approved by the city manager or designee and endorsed thereon, and it shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(e)  The policy shall be made for the use, benefit and protection of any person or property because of any accident, omission or negligence of any person engaged in house moving and shall remain in full force and effect during the life of any such permit issued. If, after the approval of the policy and after the issuance of the permit, such policy shall be allowed to lapse or shall not be renewed by the payment of premiums, the city commission may cancel any permit issued under this division, after notice to the permittee and after an opportunity to be heard. The cancellation of any policy shall in no way affect or terminate any liability arising prior to the effective date of such cancellation. 
(Code 1986, § 7-26; Code 2002, § 7-715) 
Sec. 7-716. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
(a)  The building inspector shall not approve any permit required under this division when he shall find, from a statement of the facts, that the building, structure, edifice or other thing is of such size, weight or dimensions as will result in any damage to the city pavements, curbs or sidewalks or shall be so large as to be impracticable of being moved without gross injury to shade trees or other property. He shall not approve any permit, unless he shall find that the applicant has all the necessary equipment, in a good condition, that may be necessary to move the building, structure, edifice or other thing and that the applicant is a person of such experience and ability that it is reasonable to expect the transportation of such building or other structure to be accomplished by him within the time prescribed in the permit. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued for the removal of any building exceeding 22 feet in height after such building is loaded upon the equipment used in the removal of the building or for any building of over 32 feet in width or 50 feet in length. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued to move any building until the sewer service line from such building to be moved has been plugged by a licensed plumber at the riser at a point not less than four feet deep from the surface of the ground. The owner of any property from which the building is moved shall immediately clean up the lot from which the building was moved by filling all holes and removing any debris and trash from the premises. Such owner shall deposit with the building inspector, before removing the building, an amount as described in the city fee schedule as a guarantee that the lot will be cleaned up, as stated in this subsection. If the owner does not clean up such lot within ten days after the removal of the building, the building inspector is authorized to clean up the lot and expend all or such portion of the deposit to clean up the lot. If the lot is cleaned up by the owner, the building inspector will refund the deposit. 
(Code 1986, § 7-27; Code 2002, § 7-716) 
Sec. 7-717. - Time limits for completion of moving. 
    At the time of application for a permit required under this division, it shall be the duty of the mover of any building or structure to estimate the reasonable time required for the moving of the building from its present location to its proposed location, and the applicant shall state in his application for a permit what he deems to be such reasonable time. The route and time allowed for the moving of the building shall be determined and fixed by the public works director. The permit shall especially provide that, from the time any part of the street is used for the moving of the building or structure, such building or structure shall be cleared from any of the city streets within a number of days specified therein, Sundays and holidays excepted. The mover shall bind himself to pay an amount as describe in the city fee schedule per day for each day or any part of which such building or structure remains on the street in excess of the number of days allowed in the permit, and his cash deposit shall, in addition to his bond, be secondarily liable for the payment of such amount. Nothing but the act of God shall be a defense against the payment of such sums. 
(Code 1986, § 7-28; Code 2002, § 7-717) 
Sec. 7-718. - Sundays and holidays excluded from time limits. 
    No permit required under this division shall be issued for any day which, according to the estimated number of days required to move the building or structure, shall, when counted from the date of the permit, include a Sunday or legal holiday, provided that this shall apply only where the permit provides that the person moving the building or structure shall begin the moving of the building or structure on the day of issuance of the permit. When a day is set on which the person moving the building shall begin to move the building and such day is different from the date of issuance of the permit, no permit shall be issued in such a way as to include a Sunday or holiday within the time allowed for moving the building. Where the number of days exceeds five, this section shall not apply. 
(Code 1986, § 7-29; Code 2002, § 7-718) 
Secs. 7-719-7-749. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - DOWNTOWN PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 7-750. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the Downtown Property Maintenance Code. 
(Code 2002, § 7-750; Ord. No. 2564NS, § 2, 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 7-751. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this code is to provide minimum standards and regulations to safeguard life, health, safety, property and public welfare by regulating the maintenance of structures in downtown Shawnee. 
(Code 2002, s 7-751; Ord. No. 2564NS, § 3, 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 7-752. - Scope and applicability. 
    This code shall apply to all properties zoned C-4: central business district. Every owner or tenant of property in the downtown area shall maintain property in compliance with this code. All buildings, structures and premises regulated by this code, both existing and new, shall be maintained in a sanitary, safe, and good condition, so as not to constitute a blighting influence on the city nor an element leading to the progressive deterioration of downtown Shawnee. 
(Code 2002, § 7-752; Ord. No. 2564NS, § 4, 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 7-753. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Downtown property means any property zoned C-4: central business district. 
    Owner means any person or entity claiming, or in whom is vested the ownership, dominion or title of real or personal property. 
    Tenant means any person or entity who occupies a structure or property, but who is not the owner. The term "tenant" includes, but is not limited to, a renter or lessee. 
(Code 2002, § 7-753; Ord. No. 2564NS, § 5, 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 7-754. - Maintenance requirements. 
(a)  Exterior of building and grounds. 
(1)  Pest control. Properties shall be maintained free of insects, bats, rodents, ants, vermin and other pests considered contrary to public health and safety and having an adverse effect on adjacent property. All exterior surfaces of the building shall prevent access by pests and vermin, including broken windows, loose or missing windows or doors, damaged or decayed wood, missing siding or other situation that allows such access and harboring. 
(2)  Sanitation. All exterior grounds shall be maintained in a safe, sanitary and clean condition, free of trash and debris or unwanted items considered contrary to public health and safety and/or the overall appearance, visibility and vitality of the downtown area. 
(3)  Structural members. Structural elements of any structure in the downtown area must be maintained free of deterioration and decay, and fully capable of bearing the dead and live loads placed upon them. 
(4)  Foundation walls. Foundation walls in the downtown area shall be able to carry the dead or live weight placed upon them. 
(5)  Exterior walls. All exterior walls, surfaces, and facades must be maintained free of holes, breaks, loose or decayed boards, loose plaster, peeling paint, leaks or other condition which might admit weather into this structure or an adjacent structure. Where an existing painted wall surface has areas of chipping, peeling, scaling or missing paint equal to or greater than 20 percent of the painted area, then such surface shall be repainted, or stripped or all paint and given a water-resistant coating if necessary. 
(6)  Roofs. The roof on every structure downtown shall be maintained structurally sound and free of leaks that pose a risk of causing substantial damage to the subject property or adjacent property. All roofs shall have an approved covering free of holes, cracks or excessively worn surfaces, which will prevent entrance of moisture into the structure and provide reasonable durability. Roof drainage, roof leakage, and roof runoff must not cause leaks, seepage or dampness to the interior or exterior of an adjacent structure. 
(7)  Decorative features. Cornices, corbels trim, facings, moldings, and other exterior trim shall be maintained free of decay and securely attached and surface coated to prevent decay. 
(8)  Exterior attachments. All awnings, stairs, marquees, signs, turnbuckles, fire escapes, conduit, standpipes, stacks, gutters, overhangs and similar attachments or extensions shall be maintained free of major decay and damage, securely attached and surface coated to prevent deterioration. Excessive weathering, ripping, discoloration, or holes shall be prohibited. Any item by reason of location above ground level that constitutes a danger of falling on persons or personal property in the vicinity thereof shall be removed or property secured. It shall be the duty of the owner to keep the premises free of loose and overhanging objects which by reason of location above ground level constitute a danger of falling on persons or personal property in vicinity thereof. 
(9)  Windows. Window glass shall be unbroken and shall be fitted into their frames in such a manner so as to secure, weather-proof and exclude pests and vermin. Windows that have minor chips or cracks that do not pose a safety hazard may remain. Windows kept open permanently for ventilation must be fitted with screens to exclude vermin. Windows shall not be covered with bars. Storage of materials, stock or inventory shall be prohibited in window display areas or other areas ordinarily exposed to public view unless said areas are screened from public view. It shall not be permitted to replace glass with plywood or other non-translucent material on the ground floor of a building except on an emergency basis (30 days or less) or during the duration of a building project operating under an approved building permit. On all floors above ground level, an entire window unit may be replaced with an opaque material provided that the sash and frame are removed and replaced with a building material suitable for exterior use and finished to match the adjacent wall surfaces. Nothing in this section provides relief, where particular windows, window coverings, or the absence of window coverings are required by the adopted building and fire code. 
(10)  Screening and visible walls (from sidewalk/public right-of-way). All screening of interiors shall be maintained in a clean and attractive manner and in a good state of repair. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit window displays which are in good condition and appropriately maintained. All walls and other portions of buildings and structures exposed to public view shall be kept in a good state of repair and shall be painted or finished in such a manner as to present a clean, neat, attractive and maintained appearance. 
(11)  Doors. Door glass shall be unbroken and shall be fitted into their frames in such a manner so as to secure, weather-proof and exclude pests and vermin. 
(12)  Dumpsters and garbage disposal. Dumpsters and garbage disposal shall be done in the alleyways downtown and not along Main Street or other public streets. Dumpsters and garbage receptacles shall not block vehicle traffic or maneuverability and shall be placed and stored on private property whenever possible. The owner or tenant shall provide or make provisions for regular pickup and disposal based on occupancy and use and shall provide, upon request by the city, proof of service for solid waste disposal. Shared or group service is permissible and encouraged to reduce the number of dumpsters downtown. 
(13)  Sidewalks. It shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owner or tenant to keep the sidewalk areas in front of their property clean, sanitary and free from excessive litter, grime, grease or debris. 
(b)  Interior of building. 
(1)  General. The interior of any structure downtown including any equipment and fixtures therein shall be maintained in a sound, safe and sanitary manner, so as to not pose a substantial threat to public health, safety and welfare to occupants or adjacent structures. 
(2)  Structural members. The structural members of every building downtown shall be maintained sound, and free of any major deterioration and fully able to bear the live and dead weight placed upon them. 
(3)  Damp. The entire structure, including cellars, crawl spaces, walls, and floors shall be maintained in such a way that they are kept reasonably free from, and are not conducive to, damp, decay and rot, including rising damp, seepage from party walls and inadequate plumbing. 
(4)  Applicable codes apply. All applicable building codes apply to downtown structures including, but not limited to, those addressing sanitation, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, building, zoning and other rules. 
(5)  Junk and trash. The interior of every structure downtown shall be maintained free of waste, rubbish, refuse, garbage, debris, and unlawful storage. 
(6)  Pests. All structures downtown must be free of, and maintained in a manner that excludes, insects, rodents, bats, rats, birds and other vermin. 
(Code 2002, § 7-754; Ord. No. 2564NS, § 6, 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 7-755. - Enforcement process. 
(a)  The enforcement authority for this code shall be the community development director or their designee. 
(b)  Vacant or occupied structures included in the scope of this code that have violations or suspected violations of this code are subject to inspection by the city during regular business hours. Where there are violations or suspected violations that are not in plain view, the city may pursue issuance of a warrant to inspect the property if an owner or tenant does not provide right of entry. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of a citation and penalty as set forth in subsection (e) of this section, the city shall notify the owner of the property in writing of suspected violations to this article. The owner shall have 15 calendar days to respond and begin the necessary repairs. Up to two additional 15-calendar day extensions may be granted administratively by the city if a good-faith effort is being made and the repairs are extensive or if there have been weather delays. An owner may submit reports from third party experts to demonstrate compliance with this code and the city is authorized to require such reports in accordance with adopted codes. The submittal of such reports does not guarantee acceptance and approval by the city. 
(d)  Exception. Should an owner or tenant of the property and structure have an active building permit, they shall be given the appropriate time set forth in the building code to complete repairs or the remodel project. However, under no circumstance, shall an owner or tenant allow a violation of this code to persist greater than 12 months, unless written authorization from the community development director is provided. 
(e)  Violations of this article and associated penalties shall follow the process set forth in section 7-2. Nothing in this article shall be construed as preventing the city from pursuing other code enforcement action allowed by other provisions of the Shawnee Municipal Code. 
(Code 2002, § 7-755; Ord. No. 2564NS, § 7, 5-18-2015) 
Chapter 8 - BUSINESSES, PERMITS AND LICENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Occupational license taxes and regulations, 11 O.S. §§ 22-106, 22-107; riots and disturbances, 11 O.S. § 22-110; Sunday to be observed, 21 O.S. § 907; false increase of weight, 21 O.S. § 1505; false weights and measures, 21 O.S. § 1551 et seq.; employment of children, 40 O.S. § 71; taxation of coin-operated music or amusement devices, 68 O.S. § 1511. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Bonds and insurance. 
    Notwithstanding any section in this Code to the contrary, all bonds and insurance required as conditions precedent to the issuance of any licenses and permits by the city may be approved by the city manager or designee rather than the city commission. The amounts of all bonds, insurance and fees related to the issuance of licenses and permits set out in this chapter shall be set by resolution of the commission. 
(Code 1986, § 14-1; Code 2002, § 8-1; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 1, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-2. - Suspension and revocation of licenses and permits. 
(a)  The city manager is delegated the power to suspend summarily any license or permit issued by the city without notice and without hearing when it is necessary for the protection of the public peace, health, safety, morals or welfare. Licenses or permits suspended as provided in this section may be revoked in the manner provided in this section. 
(b)  All licenses or permits issued by the city shall be subject to revocation by the city commission. Whenever it appears that any of the terms and conditions under which a license or permit is issued by the city have been violated or whenever it appears that it may be necessary for the protection of the public peace, health, safety, morals or welfare that a license or permit issued by the city should be revoked, the city commission shall direct the city clerk to give written notice to the holder of such license or permit requiring him to appear before the city commission to show cause, if any there may be, why such license or permit should not be revoked. The notice shall set forth the date, time, place and purpose of the hearing and shall contain a brief statement of the grounds for the proposed revocation. The notice shall be served by sending it by certified mail to the licensee or permittee at the address shown on the current city license or permit records. The hearing shall not be less than five days from the date the notice is mailed. At the hearing the licensee or permittee shall have the right to be represented by counsel or by himself and to present evidence and testimony in his behalf. If the city commission determines that the license or permit should be revoked, it shall order revocation thereof. The city clerk shall record the order in the minutes of the hearing. 
(c)  The city commission, in its discretion, may revoke a license or permit by default if the license or permit holder fails to appear at such hearing. 
(d)  No license or permit fee or tax or any portion thereof shall be refunded if such license or permit is revoked or suspended. 
(Code 1986, § 14-2; Code 2002, § 8-2) 
Sec. 8-3. - Reports of pawnbrokers, auction houses, salvage shops and junk dealers. 
    Every pawnbroker, auction house, salvage shop and junk dealer shall furnish the chief of police or his designated representative a full and complete list every day of every article taken in pawn or bought by such dealer in a manner prescribed by the chief of police, giving a full description of the article and the brand name, model numbers, serial numbers, engravings or any other identifying mark or feature on the article so pawned or bought by such dealer. Such dealer shall also keep accounts giving descriptions [of those] from whom such articles are received. Each description shall include the full name, address, date of birth, sex, race, height, hair and eye color. Such dealer shall have the goods arranged in stock so as to be inspected by the police department. When it becomes necessary to visit such dealer, the chief of police or his designated representative shall perform such duty, and no such business shall refuse to admit such officer to his place of business for the purpose of such a visit. Such dealer shall freely and fully permit the officer to make examinations as are necessary to acquire the desired information. The conviction of any such pawnbroker or other dealer of a violation of this section shall result in an immediate revocation of the license of the offender. 
(Code 1986, § 14-9; Code 2002, § 8-3; Ord. No. 2224NS, § 1, 11-21-2005) 
Secs. 8-4-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 8-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm industry means the sale, installation, alteration, repair, replacement, service, inspection or maintenance of alarm systems or service, as provided in 59 O.S. § 1800.2 et seq., involving receipt of alarm signals for the purpose of employee response and investigation of such signals or any combination of such activities, except inspections on one- and two-family dwellings are exempt. 
    Alarm system means one or more devices designed either to detect and signal an unauthorized intrusion or entry or to signal a fire or other emergency condition, which signals are responded to by public law enforcement officers, fire department personnel, private guards or security officers. 
(Code 1986, § 18-111; Code 2002, § 8-31) 
Sec. 8-32. - Alarm permits required. 
(a)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated an alarm system designed to activate upon a break-in, vandalism, or robbery or to detect or draw attention to the presence of a fire or any residential dwelling or premises, business, or storage structure without first having obtained a permit. Failure to have a permit upon an alarm activation followed by a response by the police or fire department shall constitute an offense. 
(b)  No person or company in the business of installing alarm systems shall install or cause to be installed any alarm system designed to activate upon a break-in, vandalism or robbery of any residential dwelling or premises, business, or storage structure without first having obtained a state license as required by 59 O.S. § 1800.1 et seq. Failure to have a state license for alarm installation shall constitute an offense. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall be an offense punishable by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs, upon first conviction and by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs for each subsequent conviction. Each day that this section is violated shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 2002, § 8-32; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 1, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-33. - Requirements for alarm permit. 
    The application for an alarm permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The full name, address and telephone number of both the owner or lessee on whose premises the system will be installed, operated, connected or maintained. 
(2)  The name of the person or state-licensed alarm system business installing, maintaining or servicing the system, as well as the type (fire, burglar, etc.) of system to be installed, operated or maintained. 
(3)  The applicant will identify by name, address and telephone number (for day and night) two contact individuals or representatives that are able to physically respond to any such alarmed location in a reasonable time (30 minutes or less). 
(4)  Such application shall also contain additional information as the chief of police or fire chief shall reasonably deem necessary for the evaluation and proper processing of the application. 
(5)  Whenever a change occurs relating to the written information required on the permit application, listing requirements, or other documents filed with the city pursuant to this article, the applicant or permittee shall give written notice of said change to the police department within ten days. 
(6)  Any changes of ownership at a location formerly or currently utilizing an alarm system shall be construed as a new installation and shall require the necessary permit and fee. 
(Code 2002, § 8-33; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 2, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 8-34. - Alarm fees required. 
(a)  The initial registration and application administrative processing fee shall be set by resolution of the commission. 
(b)  A renewal license may be applied for any time within one year from the issuance of the initial permit. A renewal license application shall have an administrative fee set by resolution of the commission. 
(c)  The fee for reinstatement after an alarm permit revocation or suspension shall be set by resolution of the commission. 
(Code 2002, § 8-34; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 3, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-35. - False alarms. 
(a)  Any owner that allows excessive false alarms to occur at any location shall be deemed to have committed an offense, which may be punishable, upon first conviction, by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs. Each subsequent offense shall be punishable by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs. Each day any violation of the article continues constitutes a separate offense. Excessive alarms within a short period of time as determined by the police department, or more than three alarm activations through mechanical failure, malfunction, the negligence of the owner or user of the alarm or otherwise which elicits a response by a law enforcement agency or the fire department within a calendar year will constitute an offense. 
(b)  Exceptions. An alarm will not be considered a false alarm if it is determined that the alarm was the result of: 
(1)  A natural or manmade catastrophe, or an act of God. Such events include tornadoes, floods, utility line mishaps, thunderstorms, earthquakes or other similarly violent conditions, clearly beyond the control of the alarm manufacturer, installer, owner or user. 
(2)  Vandalism causing physical damage to the premises. 
(3)  Attempted entry of a location causing visible, physical or other evidence of damage to such location. 
(4)  Severe weather causing physical damages to the premises. 
This section shall not apply to testing during installation and regular maintenance when the user notifies the police in advance and receives permission for the test. 
(Code 2002, § 8-35; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 4, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-36. - Revocation or suspension of permits; excessive alarms. 
(a)  In addition to any penalties which may be imposed for the violation of certain provisions of this article, permits issued pursuant to this article may be revoked or suspended by the city manager and/or his designee after notice by mail to the last known address, for any, but not limited to the following reasons: 
(1)  Willful failure of the owner or operator of the alarm system to respond to a verbal or otherwise request to appear at the destination of the activated or previously activated alarm upon a request from the police or fire department. 
(2)  Failure to have the alarm serviced or checked by an alarm company having a state license as required by 59 O.S. § 1800.1 et seq., or failure to correct deficiencies in equipment or operation after a verbal, written or otherwise request from the police chief and/or his designee. 
(3)  Excessive alarms within a short period of time as determined by the police department, or more than six alarm activations through mechanical failure, malfunction, the negligence of the owner or user of the alarm or otherwise which elicits a response by a law enforcement agency or the fire department within a calendar year. 
(4)  Tendering a false or bogus check with request to obtain an alarm system permit. 
(5)  Failure to comply with the regulations and requirements of this article or as otherwise established in the Code. 
(b)  Any owner or operator of a premises with a revoked permit at which an alarm is activated and the police or fire department respond shall be deemed the same as a person with no alarm permit. 
(Code 2002, § 8-36; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 5, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 8-37. - Appeal from the denial, suspension or revocation of alarm permit and user fees. 
(a)  An appeal may be made to the city manager or their designee for the denial, suspension or revocation of an alarm permit. 
(b)  Any permit holder may petition the city manager for a hearing on user fees based on a change in circumstances or repairs made to an alarm system. 
(c)  Appeals shall be made to the city commission. 
(Code 2002, § 8-37; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 6, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 3, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-38. - Confidentiality of records. 
    The names, addresses, alarm descriptions and other information required of those individuals having secured a permit under this section shall remain confidential and shall not be released to the public. 
(Code 2002, § 8-38; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 7, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 8-39. - Governmental entities. 
    Alarms in buildings owned and operated by governmental entities are required to be registered pursuant to this article. However, governmental entities are exempt from fees required pursuant to this article. 
(Code 2002, § 8-39; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 8, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 8-40. - Enforcement. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs for a first offense. Each second and subsequent offence shall be punished by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs. Each day a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 2002, § 8-40; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 9, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-41. - Effective date. 
    Commencing on October 1, 2010, citizens will be allowed to register with the city code enforcement office for alarm permits. The penalty provisions of this article shall become effective for nonresidential alarms on January 1, 2011, and for residential alarms on July 1, 2011. 
(Code 2002, § 8-41; Ord. No. 2445NS, § 10, 9-7-2010) 
Secs. 8-42-8-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal license tax on hawkers, peddlers and merchants, 11 O.S. § 22-106; itinerant merchants, 47 O.S. § 421 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-191. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coupon book seller means any individual traveling by foot or any means whatsoever from place to place, from building to building, from house to house or from street to street or contacting persons by telephone, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of coupon books which are to be used for discounts or free goods, wares, merchandise, personal property of every nature whatsoever for future delivery, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes a sample of the coupon book for sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
    Itinerant merchant/transient street vendor means any person engaged in the business or occupation of selling any merchandise, products or services from a temporary indoor or outdoor location obtained from an owner or leaseholder or obtained by occupying the location without permission or by occupying a location on a street right-of-way as provided in 47 O.S. § 421(7). Itinerant merchant/transient street vendors will not include the following: 
(1)  Participants in wholesale trade shows or convention-sponsored events, trade fairs or flea markets. 
(2)  Sellers of Bibles, agricultural goods, including Christmas trees and firewood, or crafts or items made by hand. 
(3)  Participants in fairs and convention center activities conducted primarily for amusement or entertainment. 
(4)  Participants in residential garage sales. 
(5)  Civic, church and educational groups that are located in the local trade area. 
    Peddler includes the terms "hawker" and "huckster" and means any person who travels by foot or by any type of conveyance from place to place or from street to street carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares or merchandise of whatever nature, offering and exposing the goods, wares or merchandise for sale; or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the goods, wares or merchandise for sale from any vehicle or conveyance. 
    Solicitor or canvasser means any individual traveling by foot or any means whatsoever from place to place, from building to building, from house to house or from street to street or contacting persons by telephone, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise or personal property of every nature whatsoever for future delivery or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample or the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
(Code 1986, § 14-61; Code 2002, § 8-191) 
Sec. 8-192. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall violate any section of this article, either by doing anything that is prohibited or by failure or refusal to do anything that is commanded, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall pay a fine set by resolution of the commission plus costs, provided that each transaction shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 14-74; Code 2002, § 8-192; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-193. - Exemptions for farmers' products and disabled veterans. 
(a)  The term "ex-service person" as used in this section shall be construed to mean such honorably discharged persons as served in any branch of the military service of the United States during the period of any war in which the United States participated as a belligerent. 
(b)  The hawking and peddling of farm products sold by farmers are exempted from the sections of this article pertaining to produce raised and grown exclusively by such farmers. 
(c)  Any needy, disabled ex-service person who has been a citizen and resident of this state for one year may engage in what is known as hawking and peddling, to give illustrated lectures and such other like entertainment without paying a city license or tax for the privilege of so doing. Before any ex-service person shall be entitled to any of the privileges set out in this section, he shall make an affidavit in writing, before some officer authorized by law to administer oaths, that he is a citizen and resident of this state and has been for one year previous, that he served in the military of the United States as provided in subsection (e) of this section and was honorably discharged therefrom and that he is in genuine financial need of the privileges conferred by this section. 
(d)  A certificate of the judge of the district court of the county that he is in entitled to the benefits and privileges set out in this section shall be sufficient proof of the need or disability of such ex-service person and of such ex-service person's service in the military of the United States. Such certificate shall be of public record in the office of the city clerk and shall also be of record in the police department. No single certificate shall be effective for a period in excess of 60 days. 
(e)  The privileges granted by this section shall not be assignable or transferable to or used by any other person except those persons to whom certificates have been issued as provided. 
(Code 1986, § 14-62; Code 2002, § 8-193) 
State Law reference- Hawking and peddling by ex-service persons, 72 O.S. § 1 et seq. 
Sec. 8-194. - Fraud and other offenses. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any solicitor, peddler, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor or coupon book seller to: 
(1)  Harass, threaten, coerce or otherwise unreasonably apply duress to any citizen or otherwise breach the peace while attempting to perform the services of a solicitor or coupon book seller. 
(2)  Fail to provide any goods or services that have been paid for in full or in part. 
(3)  Defraud, trick, cheat or otherwise mislead any person into subscribing for or purchasing any goods or service when the solicitor, peddler, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor or coupon book seller knows or should know that the goods or service will not be provided or delivered. 
(Code 1986, § 14-63; Code 2002, § 8-194) 
Secs. 8-195-8-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 8-221. - Required; appeal of denial. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of solicitor, peddler, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor or coupon book seller without first having obtained a license, except persons soliciting on behalf of newspapers of general circulation; public schools; or educational, religious, disabled veterans', farmers' or eleemosynary institutions located or affiliated within the city. 
(b)  Any person denied a license may appeal to the city commission by filing notice thereof with the city clerk within five days of the denial. The city commission shall render a decision at its next regular meeting. 
(Code 1986, § 14-64; Code 2002, § 8-221) 
Sec. 8-222. - Exception for interstate commerce. 
    If any individual, whether a solicitor, peddler, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor or coupon book seller, is engaged in interstate commerce, the individual must bring in proof of the interstate commerce nature of his business to the city clerk. The city clerk will make a determination of whether or not the business does involve interstate commerce. If it does, a license will be issued, and the fee will be waived. If not, the individual can be licensed pursuant to this division. A denial of the interstate commerce exemption of the fee process may be appealed to the city commission pursuant to the procedures established in section 8-221(b). 
    (Code 1986, § 14-73) 
Sec. 8-223. - Application. 
    An application for a solicitor's, peddler's, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor's or coupon book seller's license shall be sworn to and filed with the city clerk. It shall contain the following: 
(1)  Full name, description, birth date and social security number of each individual applicant. 
(2)  Addresses, both permanent and local. 
(3)  Nature of the business and kinds of goods to be sold and, if the applicant is a farmer or truck gardener, whether such goods are produced by him on land he owns, cultivates and controls. 
(4)  If employed by another, the name and address of the applicant's employer, together with a brief description of credentials showing the exact relationship. 
(5)  Fingerprints of the applicant. 
(6)  Description and license number or other identification of any vehicle to be used. 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(8)  Verification of payment of sales tax to the state tax commission, providing the sales tax number. 
(9)  Whether the merchandise or goods are tax exempt and exemption from the state sales tax claimed. 
(10)  The names of at least two reliable property owners in the city; provided, however, for the itinerant merchants/transient street vendors, two reliable property owners from within the state who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility or other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant will suffice. 
(11)  For coupon book sellers, a copy of all contracts with merchants for the delivery of goods and services. For solicitors and coupon book sellers, a copy of the sales pitch shall be furnished the city if one is to be made over the telephone. 
(12)  Itinerant merchants shall supply a document from the county clerk's office that establishes that the business has complied with state law, in particular the requirement of posting bond pursuant to 19 O.S. § 1608. This subsection is to apply only to itinerant merchants/transient street vendors. 
(Code 1986, § 14-65; Code 2002, § 8-223) 
Sec. 8-224. - Fee. 
    No person shall be issued a solicitor's, peddler's, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor's or a coupon book seller's license until he pays a license fee set by resolution of the commission to the city clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 14-67; Code 2002, § 8-224; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-225. - Bond. 
(a)  Every person applying for a license to engage in the business of peddling goods, wares or merchandise or canvassing for the sale of such shall, before such license is issued, enter into a bond with the city with approved sureties in the penal sum set by resolution of the commission. The bond shall be conditioned that such applicant: 
(1)  Will strictly and faithfully observe all city ordinances, regulations and requirements in relation to peddlers, solicitors, canvassers, itinerant merchants and itinerant vendors, coupon book sellers or to such applicant's business and will pay all costs, fines or penalties incurred on account of his failure or neglect in that behalf; 
(2)  Will at all times do all work and perform all services relating to or arising from such canvassing, soliciting and peddling in a good and workmanlike manner; 
(3)  Shall fully indemnify and hold whole and harmless the city from any expenses or damages to real or personal property or personal injury done to any person or property in the performance of such work or the performance of such services that may arise out of or be occasioned in the performance of such work or services and that he will cause all property damaged by him to be repaired and put in the same condition as it was before the work was done; and 
(4)  The applicant will pay all costs, expenses or damages arising from any misrepresentation to any person to whom such applicant shall make any sale. 
(b)  Licenses issued and bonds filed under this division shall cover the applicant and all of his agents, servants, employees and representatives. 
(Code 1986, § 14-68; Code 2002, § 8-225; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-226. - Investigation and issuance or denial. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the application for a solicitor, peddler, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor or coupon book seller license, the chief of police shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business background to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public. 
(b)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall so endorse on the application and return it to the city clerk's office, and no license shall be issued. 
(c)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's business responsibility is found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall so endorse on the application and return it to the city clerk's office who shall then issue the license upon payment of the required fee. 
(Code 1986, § 14-66; Code 2002, § 8-226) 
Sec. 8-227. - Term. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this division shall expire one year from the date of its issuance, except itinerant merchant/transient street vendor licenses. An itinerant merchant/transient street vendor licenses is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of its issuance. Such licenses may be renewed for an additional 90-day period. 
(Code 1986, § 14-70; Code 2002, § 8-227) 
State Law reference- Duration of municipal licenses, 11 O.S. § 22-107. 
Sec. 8-228. - Display. 
    Every solicitor, peddler, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor and coupon book seller and any employee of a solicitor, peddler, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor and coupon book seller shall exhibit the license issued at the request of any person. 
(Code 1986, § 14-71; Code 2002, § 8-228) 
Sec. 8-229. - Transferability. 
    No license issued under this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1986, § 14-72; Code 2002, § 8-229) 
Sec. 8-230. - Grounds for suspension or revocation; liability of employer for acts of employee. 
    For purposes of the suspension or revocation of a solicitor's, peddler's, itinerant merchant/transient street vendor's or coupon book seller's license, it shall be sufficient to show that any solicitor or seller in the employ of such license holder has violated any section of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 14-69; Code 2002, § 8-230) 
Secs. 8-231-8-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SNOW CONE MERCHANTS 

Sec. 8-256. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall violate any section of this division, either by doing anything that is prohibited or by failure or refusal to do anything that is commanded, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall pay a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs, provided that each transaction shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 14-75(g); Code 2002, § 8-256; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-257. - License required; appeal of denial of license. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of selling snow cones from either a temporary or permanent structure without first having obtained a special license. 
(b)  Any person denied a license may appeal to the city commission by filing notice thereof with the city clerk within five days of the denial. The city commission shall render a decision at its next regular meeting. 
(Code 1986, § 14-75(a); Code 2002, § 8-257) 
Sec. 8-258. - Application for license. 
    An application for a snow cone merchant's license shall be sworn to and filed with the city clerk. It shall contain the following: 
(1)  Full name, description, birth date and social security number of each individual applicant. 
(2)  Addresses, both permanent and local. 
(3)  Verification of payment of sales tax to the state tax commission, providing the sales taxes number. 
(4)  The names of at least two reliable property owners in the city who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility or other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant. 
(5)  A valid zoning clearance permit. 
(Code 1986, § 14-75(b); Code 2002, § 8-258) 
Sec. 8-259. - License fee and term; compliance of licensee. 
    No person shall be issued a snow cone merchant's license until he pays a license fee set by resolution of the commission to the city clerk. Any license issued pursuant to this division shall expire 150 days from the date of its issuance. The licensee shall at all times conform to all relevant state health code regulations. 
(Code 1986, § 14-75(c); Code 2002, § 8-259; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-260. - Removal of structure after expiration of license. 
    Once the snow cone merchant's license has expired, if the licensee is operating from a portable structure, the structure is to be removed promptly from its location and stored privately by its owner. For purposes of this section, a portable structure is any structure not attached to a permanent foundation. 
(Code 1986, § 14-75(d); Code 2002, § 8-260) 
Sec. 8-261. - Display of license. 
    A snow cone merchant shall exhibit his license at the request of any person. 
(Code 1986, § 14-75(e); Code 2002, § 8-261) 
Sec. 8-262. - Transferability of license. 
    No license issued under this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1986, § 14-75(f); Code 2002, § 8-262) 
Secs. 8-263-8-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Solicitation of charitable contributions, 18 O.S. § 552.1 et seq. 

Sec. 8-291. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall violate any section of this division, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs. Each day of such violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 14-81; Code 2002, § 8-291; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-292. - License required. 
    Any person who wishes to engage in or do public charitable work within the city and who desires to solicit donations of money or other assistance for such purposes shall procure from the city clerk a license authorizing such person to solicit for money or other assistance for charitable purposes. 
(Code 1986, § 14-82; Code 2002, § 8-292) 
Sec. 8-293. - License prerequisites and issuance. 
    No license required under this division shall be issued by the city clerk until the applicant has made application to and procured from an officer of the chamber of commerce of the city a letter of credit and endorsement, in which letter the names of the solicitors shall be given, and it shall be stated therein the purpose for which such solicitor is authorized to solicit donations. The letter of credit shall be filed with the city clerk for the approval of the city manager. If so approved the city clerk is authorized to issue to such person a license as provided in this article. Such license shall be issued without any charge. 
(Code 1986, § 14-83; Code 2002, § 8-293) 
Sec. 8-294. - Weekly reports. 
    All associations doing public charitable work in the city may be requested to file a report each week, on Monday, showing the amounts and character of all donations collected during the previous week; how such donations were disbursed; and the number, names and residences of all persons so aided and assisted. 
(Code 1986, § 14-84; Code 2002, § 8-294) 
Sec. 8-295. - False representation of charitable purposes. 
    No person shall collect or receive any money or property by falsely representing that such money or property is being collected for charitable or church purposes. 
(Code 1986, § 14-85; Code 2002, § 8-295) 
State Law reference- False representations, 18 O.S. § 552.18. 
Sec. 8-296. - Telephone solicitation. 
    No person may solicit contributions by telephone for a charitable nonprofit organization unless that organization has complied with the provisions of the Oklahoma Solicitation of Charitable Contributions Act, 18 O.S. § 552.1 et seq. Such person may charge a reasonable fee for his services, which shall not exceed ten percent of the net receipts of the solicitation; provided, however, that if the fee charged is based upon a predetermined flat fee, this shall not apply. All sums shall be paid directly to the nonprofit organization. 
(Code 1986, § 14-86; Code 2002, § 8-296) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1861. 
Secs. 8-297-8-324. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes:

IV, §§ 8-325-8-339, pertained to pawnbrokers and derived from §§ 14-101-14-108 of the 1986 Code; §§ 8-325-8-339 of the 2002 Code; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, adopted April 7, 2014; Ord. No. 2569NS, §§ 1-11, adopted June 15, 2015; and Ord. No. 2582NS, §§ 1-11, adopted June 20, 2016.

ARTICLE V. - AUCTIONEERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal license tax on auctioneers, 11 O.S. § 22-106; Oklahoma Public Auction Law, 59 O.S. § 990 et seq. 

Sec. 8-361. - Applicability of article. 
    No section of this article shall be considered to apply to sales made pursuant to 59 O.S. § 990. 
(Code 1986, § 14-126; Code 2002, § 8-361) 
Sec. 8-362. - License required; compliance by licensee. 
    No person shall engage in the business or occupation of auctioneering of any goods, wares and merchandise in the city unless he first procures a license therefor and complies with all the sections of this Code and any other city ordinances relating thereto. 
(Code 1986, § 14-127; Code 2002, § 8-362) 
Sec. 8-363. - Fees. 
    All auctioneers regulated by this article shall pay a license fee set by resolution of the commission per annum. Such auctioneers may pay, in lieu of the annual fee, set by resolution of the commission per day, per week or per month. 
(Code 1986, § 14-128; Code 2002, § 8-363; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-364. - Bond. 
    A license required under this article shall not be issued to any auctioneer until he has given a good and sufficient bond to the city in the sum set by resolution of the commission, to be approved by the city manager or designee, conditioned upon such auctioneer observing the laws of the state and the city relating to such occupation and that he shall pay any damages which result from any misrepresentation made by him in the auctioneering of any goods, wares or merchandise of a material nature and upon which the purchaser of the goods, wares or merchandise relied as being true. 
(Code 1986, § 14-129; Code 2002, § 8-364; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-365. - Bids by agents. 
    No auctioneer shall authorize any person to act as his agent, servant or co-principal and in such capacity to make any bid on any goods, wares and merchandise offered at public auction by such auctioneer. In addition to being subject to the penalties provided by this Code for violations, the license of any auctioneer violating this section shall be revoked and no other license shall be issued within one year. 
(Code 1986, § 14-130; Code 2002, § 8-365) 
Sec. 8-366. - Reservation of power to refuse bids. 
    No auctioneer shall reserve any power to refuse any bid made for any goods, wares and merchandise put up by him to be sold to the highest and best bidder, unless a public announcement of such reserved right is made expressly at the time such goods, wares and merchandise are first offered for sale and before any bid is made on the goods, wares and merchandise. 
(Code 1986, § 14-131; Code 2002, § 8-366) 
Secs. 8-367-8-395. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RESIDENTIAL SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-396. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Residential sale means any sale of what is held out to be or is commonly known as a garage, porch, room, yard or patio sale; estate sale not conducted pursuant to an order of a court of competent jurisdiction; or any other type of general sale conducted from or on any premises not located in a zoning district which permits such sales where goods or articles of any type are held out for sale to the public. The term "residential sale" does not include a situation where specific items are held out for sale and all advertisements of such sale specifically name the items to be sold. 
(Code 1986, § 14-166) 
Sec. 8-397. - Enforcement. 
    The police department will have the authority to enforce the sign and permit requirements under this article. 
(Code 1986, § 14-172; Code 2002, § 8-397) 
Sec. 8-398. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the sections of this article shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine set by resolution of the commission, plus costs, for each offense. Every article sold and every day a sale is conducted in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 14-167; Code 2002, § 8-398; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-399. - Exempted persons. 
    This article shall not apply to or affect the following: 
(1)  Persons acting pursuant to an order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Duly licensed auctioneers selling at auctions. 
(Code 1986, § 14-168; Code 2002, § 8-399) 
Sec. 8-400. - Interval between sales. 
    No person shall hold, conduct, engage in or participate in any manner or allow a residential sale to be held or conducted on premises under his control or ownership more than three times in any calendar year, subject, however, to the exceptions allowed in sections 8-431 and 8-433. 
(Code 1986, § 14-169; Code 2002, § 8-400) 
Sec. 8-401. - Signs. 
(a)  One advertising sign per sale. Not more than one sign or other device used for the purpose of advertising or otherwise calling attention to a residential sale shall be allowed for each residential sale licensed under this article. 
(b)  Signs must be removed within 24 hours of the completion of the residential sale. Signs may not be placed closer than 13 feet of the curbline. Only the sign approved and issued by the city may be used. Signs may not be placed in the right-of-way, on any utility poles or street signs or on any private property without the permission of the property owner. 
(Code 1986, § 14-170; Code 2002, § 8-401) 
Sec. 8-402. - Display of goods. 
    The sale area of any residential sale shall be confined to the premises for which the license has been issued. 
(Code 1986, § 14-171; Code 2002, § 8-402) 
Secs. 8-403-8-430. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 8-431. - Required; compliance; limitations on number issued. 
(a)  No person shall hold, conduct, engage in or participate in any manner in a residential sale without obtaining a license as provided in this division. 
(b)  The issuance of a license under this division shall not exempt such person from the terms and provisions of other applicable sections of this Code or other ordinances. 
(c)  A separate license shall be required for each location at which a residential sale is to be held. No location shall be eligible for more than three licenses in any calendar year, unless there has been a change in the ownership of such location or unless licenses for such locations have been issued to nonprofit organizations, associations or corporations. No nonprofit organization, association or corporation may be issued more than three such licenses in any calendar year. 
(Code 1986, § 14-186; Code 2002, § 8-431) 
Sec. 8-432. - Application. 
    An applicant for a license for a residential sale shall furnish the city clerk with the following information: 
(1)  The full name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The location at which the proposed residential sale is to be held; 
(3)  The serial or identification number of each article to be sold, if it is obtainable; 
(4)  The date upon which the sale shall be held; and 
(5)  An affidavit from the applicant to the effect that all goods to be sold at the residential sale are owned by the applicant and have not been obtained for the purpose of reselling them at the sale. 
(Code 1986, § 14-187; Code 2002, § 8-432) 
Sec. 8-433. - Issuance; term; investigation. 
(a)  The city clerk is authorized to grant a license for a residential sale for a period not to exceed two consecutive days to any person applying who otherwise complies with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  If a residential sale is not held on one or both of the dates for which the license is issued, the city clerk may issue another license to the applicant for a residential sale to be conducted at the same location within 30 days from the date when the first sale was to be held, for no additional fee. 
(c)  Before issuing a residential sale license, the city clerk may conduct such investigation as may reasonably be necessary to determine if there is compliance with this article. 
(Code 1986, § 14-188; Code 2002, § 8-433) 
Sec. 8-434. - Fees. 
    The fee for a residential sale license shall be set by resolution of the commission, which shall include three signs which shall be in compliance with section 8-401. 
(Code 1986, § 14-189; Code 2002, § 8-434; Ord. No. 2542NS, § 2, 4-7-2014) 
Sec. 8-435. - Revocation; refusal. 
(a)  Any license issued under this division may be revoked or any application for issuance of a license may be refused by the city clerk if the application submitted by the applicant or license holder contains any false, fraudulent or misleading statement. 
(b)  If any person is convicted of an offense under this article, the city clerk is instructed to cancel any existing residential sale license held by the person convicted and not to issue such person another residential sale license for a period of two years from the time of conviction. 
(Code 1986, § 14-190; Code 2002, § 8-435) 
Secs. 8-436-8-460. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) ---
