(Code 2002, § 9-112; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 27, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-113. - Change of control of grantee. 
    Prior approval of the city commission, which shall not be unreasonably withheld, shall be required where ownership or control of more than 30 percent of the right of control of the grantee under this article is acquired by a person or group of persons acting in concert, none of whom already own or control 30 percent or more of such right of control, singularly or collectively. By its execution of the permit agreement, the grantee specifically grants and agrees that any such acquisition occurring without prior approval of the city commission shall constitute a violation of this article by the grantee. 
(Code 2002, § 9-113; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 28, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-114. - Filings and communications with regulatory agencies. 
    Copies of all petitions, applications and communications submitted by the grantee to the Federal Communications Commission, Securities and Exchange Commission, or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matter affecting, directly or indirectly, the cable television system operations authorized pursuant to the nonexclusive permit issued under this article shall also be submitted simultaneously to the mayor or designee. 
(Code 2002, § 9-114; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 29, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-115. - City rights in nonexclusive permit. 
(a)  The right is reserved to the city or the city commission to adopt, in addition to the sections contained in this article and in existing applicable sections of this Code or other city ordinances, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of its lawful powers. However, such regulations, by ordinance or otherwise, shall be reasonable and not in conflict with the rights granted in this article. 
(b)  The grantee shall make available at its local offices, upon 30 days' written notice by the city, financial information from its corporate offices as may be needed by the city in order to determine that correct permit fees have been paid and that other financial reporting to the city has been properly performed. The mayor or designee shall have the right to inspect the books, records, maps, plans, federal and state income tax returns and other like materials pertaining directly to the nonexclusive permit granted under this article at any time during normal business hours. 
(c)  The city shall have the right, during the life of the nonexclusive permit, to install and maintain free of charge upon the poles of the grantee any wire and pole fixtures that do not interfere with the cable television system operations of the grantee. 
(d)  The city shall have the right to supervise all construction or installation work performed subject to the provisions of the nonexclusive permit and other pertinent provisions of the state and local law. If such inspection reveals that the grantee has failed, in the city's judgment, to fulfill its obligation under the terms of the nonexclusive permit, the city shall notify the grantee, in writing, of its specific deficiencies. Absent commencement of corrective action by the grantee within 48 hours of receipt of such notification, the city, upon the direction of the city commission, may undertake the necessary repairs or restoration at the grantee's sole expense. 
(e)  Upon cancellation, as provided in this article, the city commission may require the grantee to continue operations for a period not to exceed 12 months from the date of the city commission's decision. If such nonrenewal occurs, the grantee shall have two years from the date it ceases operations to remove, at its own expense, all portions of its system from all public ways within the city and to restore the public ways to a condition reasonably satisfactory to the city. 
(f)  Upon cancellation, as provided for in this article, the city, at its option and upon the payment of a sum equal to the fair market value to the grantee, shall have the right to purchase and take over the cable television system in its entirety. Upon the exercise of this option, the payment of such sum by the city and service of an official notice of such action by the city upon the grantee, the grantee shall immediately transfer to the city possession and title to all facilities and property, real and personal, of the cable television system, free from any and all liens and encumbrances not agreed to be assumed by the city in lieu of some portion of the purchase price set forth, and the grantee shall execute such warranty deeds or other instruments of conveyance to the city as shall be necessary for this purpose. The grantee shall make it a condition of each contract entered into by the grantee, with reference to its operation under the nonexclusive permit, that any such contract shall be subject to the exercise of this option by the city and that the city shall have the right to succeed to all privileges and obligations thereof upon the exercise of such option. 
(g)  Upon the exercise of the option by the city to purchase and take over the cable television system in its entirety, the fair market value to the grantee of the cable television system shall be determined by three disinterested parties: one of such parties to be selected by the mayor, another to be selected by the grantee and the two parties so selected shall mutually agree upon a third party. When all three parties have been selected, they shall proceed to appraise the cable television system and determine the fair market value to the grantee; such determination shall be binding upon the city and the grantee. If the two parties selected by the city and the grantee are unable to agree upon a third party, upon petition by either party, the district judge of the county or his designee shall serve as the third party. The party selected by the mayor shall be with the approval of the city commission. However, if the city no longer desires to acquire the cable television system after its value is determined, the city may, without penalty or waiver of future rights to acquire the cable television system, abandon its intention to acquire the cable television system. The cost of the appraisal shall be shared equally between the city and the grantee. 
(Code 2002, § 9-115; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 30, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-116. - Maps, plats and reports. 
(a)  Under this article, the grantee shall file with the city engineer true and accurate maps or plats of all existing and proposed installations. The grantee shall, simultaneously with the execution of the permit agreement, file a map of the city showing the proposed construction schedule of the grantee. 
(b)  The grantee shall file annually with the city clerk, not later than 90 days after the end of the grantee's fiscal year, a copy of its report to its principals (if it prepares such a report), an income statement applicable to its operations during the preceding 12-month period, a balance sheet and a statement of its properties devoted to cable television system operations. These reports shall be prepared or approved by a certified public accountant, and there shall be submitted along with them such other reasonable information as the city commission shall request with respect to the grantee's properties and expenses related to its cable television system operations within the city. Such report can be given to the city on a pro rata basis in accordance with Federal Communications Commission regulations. 
(c)  The grantee, in order to ensure full disclosure, shall keep on file with the city clerk a current list of all owners, officers and operators of the proposed cable television system together with the manager for this nonexclusive permit, whether it be individual, association of individuals, general or limited partnership, or corporation, and such list shall reflect the extent or percentage of ownership of each such person, including all stockholdings of two percent or more. 
(Code 2002, § 9-116; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 31, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-117. - Payment to city. 
    The grantee shall pay to the city monthly on or before the 15th day of each month, an amount equal to three percent of the gross revenue from cable television system operations within the city, from monthly or other recurring charges for basic subscriber services, other leased channel services, advertising and program production services. If the amount of any payment of the grantee to the city shall not comply with applicable Federal Communications Commission standards, the amount otherwise due to the city shall be computed on the basis of such percentages and annual gross revenue amounts as the Federal Communications Commission might approve. This payment shall be in addition to any other fees or payments made to the city by the grantee. 
(Code 2002, § 9-117; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 32, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-118. - Forfeiture of nonexclusive permit; notice of violations and opportunity to cure. 
(a)  In addition to all other rights and powers pertaining to the city by virtue of the nonexclusive permit issued under this article or otherwise, the city reserves the right to terminate and cancel the nonexclusive permit and all rights and privileges of the grantee under this article if the grantee substantially breaches the material terms of its permit and fails to cure such breach following written notification by the city, in that the grantee: 
(1)  Violates any section of this article or any rule, order or determination of the city commission made pursuant to the nonexclusive permit, except where such violation is without fault or through excusable neglect. 
(2)  Becomes insolvent or unable to pay its lawful debts or is adjudged bankrupt. 
(3)  Violates or attempts to evade any of the provisions of the nonexclusive permit or practices any fraud or deceit or gross negligence upon the city or its citizens. 
(4)  Attempts to dispose of any of the facilities or property of its cable television system to prevent the city from purchasing such as provided for in this article. 
(5)  Fails to make timely reports or payments required in this article. 
(b)  Such termination or cancellation shall be by ordinance duly adopted after 30 days' notice via certified mail, return receipt requested, to the grantee before final reading of the ordinance and shall in no way affect any of the city's rights under the nonexclusive permit or any provision of law. If such termination or cancellation depends upon a finding of fact, such finding of fact as made by the city commission or its representative shall be conclusive; provided, however, that before this nonexclusive permit may be terminated and cancelled under this section, the grantee must be provided with an opportunity to be heard in a due process hearing or proceeding before the city commission. 
(c)  Prior to commencing any action to terminate the permit, the city commission shall notify the grantee in writing of any alleged violation of its permit or failure to meet any of the terms or conditions of the permit or other applicable law or regulation. The grantee shall be given 30 days from the date of receipt of such notice to respond in writing, stating its explanation for the alleged violations or what actions, if any, have been taken to cure the alleged violation. Upon receipt of the grantee's response, the city commission may accept the grantee's explanation and/or remedy proposed. Alternatively, if the city commission believes the alleged violation will not be properly cured within a reasonable period of time, it shall notify the grantee of its intent to seek termination of the permit. 
(d)  The city commission shall thereafter hold a hearing providing due process at which testimony and evidence shall be taken concerning the alleged breach. Representatives of the city and the grantee shall be permitted to address the alleged violation and related issues at the hearing. The grantee may submit evidence to the city commission showing that it is taking action to cure the alleged violation or may provide evidence showing that the alleged violation is due to circumstances beyond the grantee's control (force majeure), which prevent the grantee from curing the alleged breach until some future date. Such showings, if adequate in the determination of the city commission, shall be sufficient to relieve the grantee of penalties or termination of its permit. The city commission may require the grantee to provide periodic reports to update the city commission of progress being made to cure any unresolved problem. 
(e)  If, following the evidentiary hearing, the city commission believes that the grantee has substantially violated the material terms of the permit and has failed to cure the violation, it may issue a notice of intent to take action as determined by Federal Communications Commission regulations or terminate its permit. The grantee shall be given a period of 15 days from the date of the issuance of the notice to cure the alleged violation. If the alleged violation is not cured within the specified period, the city commission may then take the appropriate steps necessary to penalize the grantee or terminate the permit; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall limit or restrict the grantee's right to appeal the city's actions in federal or state court. 
(Code 2002, § 9-118; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 33, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-119. - City's right of intervention. 
    The grantee under this article agrees not to oppose intervention by the city in any suit or proceeding to which the grantee is a party. 
(Code 2002, § 9-119; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 34, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-120. - Further agreement and waiver by grantee. 
    The grantee under this article agrees to abide by all sections of this article and further agrees that it will not at any future time set up, as against the city or the city commission, the claim that the sections of this article are unreasonable, arbitrary or void. 
(Code 2002, § 9-120; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 35, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 9-121. - Protection of privacy. 
    Except as provided by law, the grantee shall not, under penalty of forfeiture of its nonexclusive permit rights and privileges granted under this article, without the express prior approval of the city commission, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, give, sell or exchange to any person any information concerning subscribers, except with the subscriber's consent, subscriber viewing habits or preferences. The purpose of this section is to ensure that the right of privacy of each subscriber shall be fully protected. 
(Code 2002, § 9-121; Ord. No. 1708NS, § 36, 12-19-1994) 
Chapter 10 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Cemeteries generally, 8 O.S. § 1 et seq.; deposit of funds with county, 8 O.S. § 111 et seq.; municipal cemeteries, 11 O.S. § 26-101 et seq.; violating sepulture and remains of the dead, 21 O.S. § 1151 et seq.; location of cemeteries, 50 O.S. § 42 et seq.; dead bodies, 63 O.S. § 91 et seq.; vital statistics, 63 O.S. § 1-301 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1. - Violations. 
    Any person who will violate any section of this chapter, either by doing that which is prohibited or by failing or refusing to do that which is commanded, upon conviction, will be punished by a fine in the amount provided in the city fine schedule, plus costs. Each day of such violation will be a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 8-1; Code 2002, § 10-1; Ord. No. 2527NS, § 1, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 10-2. - Supervision of cemetery. 
    The city manager will appoint an individual to exercise supervision of the cemetery, insuring that all rules, regulations and ordinances are enforced and maintaining the cemetery premises in good conditions. Wherever the term "cemetery sexton" appears in this Code, it will mean that individual or his designee. 
(Code 1986, § 8-2; Code 2002, § 10-2; Ord. No. 2527NS, § 2, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 10-3. - Cemetery register. 
    The city clerk shall keep and maintain a cemetery register in which shall be entered, in a systematic method, the number of every lot and the block in which it is located. The cemetery register shall show the name of the owner of every lot, by whom purchased, the date of purchase, the amount charged for the lot and the amount paid. The city clerk shall attest all deeds to lots in the cemetery and record the deeds in the cemetery register. 
(Code 1986, § 2-126(6); Code 2002, § 10-3) 
Sec. 10-4. - Records and reports. 
    The cemetery sexton shall keep a record of the facts relating to any burial, deposit in a tomb or vault or cremation in the municipal cemetery, and weekly he shall file with the city clerk such record of all burials that have taken place in the cemetery during the preceding week, together with all permits that he has received from the city clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 8-4; Code 2002, § 10-4) 
Sec. 10-5. - Authority of employees. 
    The cemetery sexton or any employee under him shall not authorize or permit any matter or thing to be done in or about the municipal cemetery that will conflict with the sections of this chapter or any rule or regulation approved and adopted by the city for the management of the municipal cemetery. 
(Code 1986, § 8-14; Code 2002, § 10-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - False statements or reports. 
    No person charged with the duty of reporting or making any report required in relation to the municipal cemetery, affecting any health requirement, shall write or make any false or misleading statement therein calculated to conceal any fact relative to any of such requirement. 
(Code 1986, § 8-15; Code 2002, § 10-6) 
State Law reference- Cemetery care fund, 11 O.S. § 26-108. 
Sec. 10-7. - Care of grounds and property generally. 
(a)  The city shall perpetually care for and maintain all roads, walks, pathways, grass, grounds, shrubbery and improvements belonging to the municipal cemetery. 
(b)  All lot or grave section owners shall care for and maintain all monuments, mausoleums and markers erected on their respective lots or grave sections and existing shrubs, flowers, trees and other plants which require special maintenance. 
(c)  All work and special care other than that which is done by the owner will be performed by the city and paid for at the rates set out the city's fee schedule. No city employee will receive any money or other fee or consideration for any services performed in or upon the municipal cemetery; all fees and considerations for special services will be paid to the city at the business office of the cemetery. 
(Code 1986, § 8-3; Code 2002, § 10-7; Ord. No. 2209NS, § 1, 6-20-2005; Ord. No. 2527NS, § 3, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 10-8. - Landscape plan; rules. 
(a)  The Landscape Plan of Fairview Municipal Cemetery, prepared by Christian Jensen, architect, and approved by the city and on file in the office of the city clerk, is approved and adopted as the official plan for the landscape in the municipal cemetery. The landscape plan shall govern all landscaping, ornamentation, beautification, care and maintenance of lots and premises in the cemetery insofar as its provisions may apply. 
(b)  All deeds to lots in the cemetery shall contain the following clause: "Subject to the rules and regulations of Fairview Cemetery". 
(c)  The city manager is authorized and directed to compile rules and regulations governing the operation, management and control of the cemetery. A printed copy of such rules shall be at all times kept on file in the office of the city clerk, and the rules shall be the official rules and regulations for the operation of the cemetery and shall be available to the public at all times for inspection. 
(Code 1986, § 8-5; Code 2002, § 10-8) 
Sec. 10-9. - Sale of lots. 
    The business office of the cemetery will keep a file of all lots in the cemetery showing the lots by plat, together with the cost for which each lot will be sold. The price for lots will be as set forth in the city fee schedule. Such lots will be sold on the same equal terms to applicants upon request to the business office of the cemetery and upon payment of the price fixed for the lots without discrimination. Lots and grave plots in the municipal cemetery will be conveyed to the purchaser by proper conveyance subject to the rules and regulations of the city in reference to such cemetery and the laws of the state. All lots and plots in the municipal cemetery will be held in accordance with and subject to the rules and regulations of the city and state. 
(Code 1986, § 8-6; Code 2002, § 10-9; Ord. No. 2435NS, § 1, 5-17-2010; Ord. No. 2527NS, § 4, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 10-10. - Interments generally. 
(a)  Before interments in the municipal cemetery are made, a deed for the lot shall have been obtained from the city clerk and placed upon the city clerk's records, and a permit issued by the city clerk for opening the grave shall be delivered to the sexton. The permit shall show the lot number to be used for the grave, the name of the person and the age and sex. No permit shall be issued until the cost of preparing the grave is first deposited with the city clerk. 
(b)  A schedule of charges shall be prepared by the city manager and kept on file with the city clerk for the sale of lots and preparation of graves in Fairview Cemetery. Such charges shall include the price for which lots shall be sold and the charges sufficient to cover the cost of opening and closing the graves and other miscellaneous charges including special care, overtime charges and other details. Such charges shall be based on the size and location of such graves and such other factors that have any bearing on the cost. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the cemetery sexton or his authorized representative to attend every funeral and exercise supervisory control over the funeral insofar as is necessary to preserve proper decorum, respect and order appropriate to the occasion and to enforce the rules of the city governing the cemetery. 
(d)  Two interments in one grave will not be permitted, except for a mother and infant child, twin children or two children under ten years of age buried at the same time. 
(Code 1986, § 8-7; Code 2002, § 10-10) 
State Law reference- Issuance of burial transit permit by local registrar of vital statistics, 63 O.S. § 1-319. 
Sec. 10-11. - Preparation and closing of graves; fees. 
    Only those persons with whom the city contracts will open and close graves in a municipal cemetery. However, the city may open and close graves and provide chapel or graveside services when the city deems it expedient to do so. If the city elects to provide such services, it will charge applicable fees in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 8-8; Code 2002, § 10-11; Ord. No. 2164NS, § 1, 6-7-2004; Ord. No. 2435NS, § 2, 5-17-2010; Ord. No. 2527NS, § 5, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 10-12. - Disinterments. 
    No undertaker or other person shall open or permit to be opened any grave, tomb or vault for the purpose of exhuming or removing any body which has been placed in the municipal cemetery for interment without a permit from the state commissioner of health. 
(Code 1986, § 8-9; Code 2002, § 10-12) 
State Law reference- Removal of remains from unmarked grave, 11 O.S. § 26-112; interference with places of burial, 21 O.S. § 1161 et seq.; permit for disinterment, 63 O.S. § 1-319; exhuming of bodies buried without proper certification of death, 63 O.S. § 946. 
Sec. 10-13. - Personal conduct. 
(a)  All cemetery employees and other persons, when engaged on the cemetery grounds, shall at all times when meeting and conversing with people show the utmost courtesy, respect and accommodation. 
(b)  No person shall engage in any profane language, loud talking or smoking while in the cemetery. 
(c)  No person shall visit or enter the cemetery at any time, except the hours which are prescribed for visit or entrance, except by special permission of the cemetery sexton. 
(d)  No person shall pick any flowers or cut any branches from shrubs or trees or injure or destroy any article, plant or mounting in the cemetery. 
(Code 1986, § 8-13; Code 2002, § 10-13) 
State Law reference- Disturbing funerals, 21 O.S. § 1166. 
Chapter 11 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 11-1-11-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 11-26. - Intent, purpose and authority. 
(a)  Intent and purpose. The purpose of this article is to create a department of emergency management for the city to aid in mitigation and preparedness before a disaster and to alleviate injury or damage through a coordinated response and recovery from damages resulting from disaster, nuclear or conventional weapons attack, sabotage or other hostile action, or by other disaster or major emergency as defined herein, and to protect the lives and health of the citizens of Shawnee, their property and property rights, whether public or private, in any emergency or disaster event endangering the lives and property of the people of the city. 
(b)  Authority. Nothing in this article shall be construed as power or authority to abridge or lessen the legislative and administrative powers of the mayor and city commission, unless such is specifically granted herein. 
(Code 2002, § 11-26; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized persons means all state, county and municipal police and fire personnel; hospital and ambulance crews; National Guard, and civil defense personnel ordered into a disaster area by proper authority; federal civil and military personnel on official business; persons who enter a disaster area to maintain or restore facilities for the provision of water, electricity, communications or transportation to the public; and such other officials as have valid reason to enter a disaster area. 
    Civil defense means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions pertaining to enemy attack or sabotage, other than functions for which the military services are primarily responsible. Those functions included without limitation: air raid warning service, radiological, chemical and other special weapons of defense, evacuations of persons from stricken areas, and emergency welfare services. 
    Civil emergency means a riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence of any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three or more persons acting together. All powers, duties and regulations relating to a disaster shall also apply to a civil emergency. 
    Curfew means a prohibition against any person or persons walking, running, loitering, standing, or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property, or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the city, except persons officially designated to duty with reference to the civil emergency. 
    Disaster means and includes, but is not limited to, actual or threatened enemy attack, sabotage, any manmade or natural fire, flood, severe storm, epidemic, earthquake or explosion within the city limits resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measure must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Disaster area means the scene or location of any disaster or civil emergency. 
    Emergency management means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions of the emergency management department and other city departments through a coordinated use of existing organized governmental functions and to provide other necessary governmental and non-governmental functions, as listed herein, to mitigate, prepare, respond, and otherwise aid the citizens of the city to recover from injury and damages caused by the effects of unusual natural or manmade disaster caused by fire, flood, tornado, earthquake, or other "acts of God"; the effects of a technological accident; the effects of any acts of war; and the effects of any riot or insurrection developing to such an extent as to cause an extreme emergency situation to arise which by declaration of the mayor jeopardizes the welfare of the citizens of the city. 
    Emergency management director ("director") means the individual appointed by the city manager to carry out the functions set out in this article. 
    Emergency management forces means the employees, equipment and facilities of all city institutions and commissions; and, in addition, it shall include all volunteer personnel, equipment and facilities contributed by, or obtained from, volunteer persons or agencies. 
    Emergency management volunteer means any person duly registered, trained, identified and appointed by the director and assigned to participate in the disaster activity. 
    Enemy attack means a direct or indirect assault against the city, its government, its environs, or of the nation, by the forces of a hostile nation or the agents thereof, including assault by bombing, radiological, chemical or biological warfare, sabotage or terrorism. 
    Oklahoma Department of Emergency Management (OEM) means the department of emergency management, as created in 63 O.S. § 683.4. 
    Public shelter managers means those persons appointed by the emergency management director to supervise public shelters. 
    Regulations means and includes plans, programs, and other emergency procedures deemed essential to emergency management. 
    Volunteer means the contribution of a service, equipment or facilities to the emergency management system and assigned for use in a disaster/exercise activity. 
(Code 2002, § 11-27; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-28. - Organization and appointments. 
    The city manager is authorized and directed to create an organization for emergency management utilizing to the fullest extent the existing agencies within the city. The city manager, as executive head of the municipal government, shall be the supervisor of the emergency management forces of this city and shall be responsible for their organization, administration and operations. The organization shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The city manager shall appoint an emergency management director to be a head of the emergency management department and such assistants and other employees as are deemed necessary for the property functioning of the organization. The director shall be a person trained in planning operations involving the activities of many different agencies which will operate to protect the public health, safety and welfare in the event of danger from enemy action or disaster as defined in this article. The director shall meet the qualifications promulgated by the state department of emergency management (OEM). 
(2)  The employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments, boards, institutions and commissions will participate in emergency management/civil defense activity as needed. Duties assigned to a city department shall be the same or similar to the normal duties of the department. 
(3)  Volunteer persons and agencies offering services to, and accepted by, the city. 
(Code 2002, § 11-28; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
State Law reference- Appointment of director, 63 O.S. § 683.11. 
Sec. 11-29. - Emergency powers and duties of city manager. 
(a)  The city manager may exercise the emergency power and authority necessary to fulfill his general powers and duties as defined in article V of the City Charter. When in the judgment of the city manager it is necessary to invoke the emergency powers provided herein, he shall immediately seek the concurrence of the mayor, who shall make the decision whether or not to declare an emergency. If the mayor is not available, the decision shall be made by the vice mayor; if he is not available, the decision shall be made by the senior commissioner available. In the event the mayor and city commission are not available to act, then the city manager shall be the sole criteria necessary to invoke the powers provided herein. In the absence of the city manager as the final judge of an emergency declaration, the emergency management director shall make the determination. Whether the mayor, the deputy mayor, a commissioner, the city manager or the director declares an emergency, such action shall not be construed as abridging or curtailing the powers or restrictions of the mayor and city commission as defined in the Charter of the city. Thereafter the mayor and city commission may convene to perform their legislative and administrative powers, and shall receive reports relative to emergency management activities. 
(b)  During any period when disaster threatens or when the city has been struck by disaster or major emergency, within the definition of this article, the city manager may promulgate such regulations as he deems necessary to protect life and property and preserve critical resources. Such regulations may include, but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Regulations prohibiting or restricting the movement of vehicles to facilitate the work of emergency forces or the mass movement of persons from critical areas within or without the city. 
(2)  Regulations pertaining to the movement of persons from areas deemed to be hazardous or vulnerable to disaster. 
(3)  Regulations restricting the movement of persons upon the streets at particular times of days and in particular areas. 
(4)  Such other regulations necessary to preserve public peace, health and safety. 
(5)  Regulations promulgated in accordance with the authority above will be given widespread circulation by proclamations published and uttered by newspaper, television and radio. These regulations will have the force of ordinance when duly filed with the city clerk and violations will be subject to the penalties provided in this article. 
(6)  The city manager shall order emergency forces to the aid of other communities when required in accordance with the statutes of the state, and he may request the state, as a political subdivision of the state, to send aid to the city in case of disaster or emergency when conditions in the city are beyond the control of the local emergency forces. 
(7)  The city manager may obtain vital supplies and equipment needed for the protection of health, life and property of the people. When obtaining formal approval would result in delay of attack-relief activity, the city manager may, until the mayor and city commission convene, waive procedures and formalities otherwise required pertaining to the performance of public works, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of temporary workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase and distribution of supplies, materials, facilities, and expenditures of existing funds. The mayor and city commission are also empowered to waive any such procedures and formalities. 
(8)  Whenever the city manager finds that any condition in the city has attained, or threatens to attain, the proportions of a disaster or emergency, he may assemble and utilize emergency management forces and may prescribe the manner and conditions of their use. When he deems it in the public interest, may send defense emergency forces of the city to the aid of other communities stricken by disaster or emergency when such disaster or emergency is affecting the health, welfare or security of the stricken community; however, after the mayor and city commission convene, the further continuance of any such relief and the period thereof shall be subject to their action and approval. 
(9)  After proclamation of an emergency, the city manager may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the city or to the city as a whole, as he deems advisable, and the curfew shall be applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of the public safety and welfare. After the mayor and city commission convene, such order is subject to their approval. 
(10)  After the proclamation of an emergency, the city manager may also, in the interest of public safety and welfare, make any or all of orders he deems necessary, including without limitation the following orders: 
a.  Any person being on the public streets, or in the public parks or at any other public place during the hours declared by the city manager to be a period of curfew; 
b.  A designated number of persons, as designated by the city manager, from assembling or gathering on the public streets, parks, or other open areas of this state, either public or private; 
c.  The manufacture, transfer, use, possession or transportation of a molotov cocktail or any other device, instrument or object designed to explode or produce uncontained combustion; 
d.  The transporting, possessing or using of gasoline, kerosene or combustible, flammable or explosive liquids or materials in a glass or uncapped container of any kind except in connection with the normal operation of motor vehicles, normal home use or legitimate commercial use; 
e.  The sale, purchase or dispensing of alcoholic beverages; 
f.  The sale, purchase or dispensing of other commodities or goods, as the city manager reasonably believes should be prohibited to help preserve and maintain life, health, property or the public peace; 
g.  The use of certain streets, highways or public ways by the public; 
h.  Impersonation of a city official or emergency management volunteer; 
i.  Unauthorized use of any insignia of the city; 
j.  Unauthorized entry into any disaster area; 
k.  Following an emergency or disaster vehicle, or purposely driving to any location on or near a roadway where a disaster or emergency area exists; 
l.  Proceeding to or remaining at a disaster area for the purpose of being a bystander, spectator, sightseer, or souvenir hunter, or disturbing any material objects, equipment, or thing directly or indirectly relating to or pertaining to the disaster; 
m.  Obstructing, hindering, or delaying any public official, shelter manager, or other authorized individual in the enforcement of any rules, regulations or executive orders issued pursuant to the authority contained in this chapter; 
n.  Failing to obey rules, regulations or official orders within a shelter; 
o.  Failing to obey any executive order issued under this chapter; 
p.  Unauthorized use of a siren or other devices so as to simulate any alert or take-cover signal or the termination of an alert or take-cover signal; and 
q.  Such other activities as the city manager reasonably believes should be prohibited to help preserve and maintain life, health, property or the public peace. 
(11)  The closing of any establishment engaged in the above activities. 
(12)  After the mayor and city commission convene, all orders are subject to their approval. 
(13)  The city manager may require emergency services of any city officer or employees. If regular city forces are determined inadequate, the city manager may require the services of such other personnel as he can obtain that are available, including citizen volunteers. All duly authorized persons rendering emergency services shall be entitled to the privileges and immunities as are provided by state law, the city Charter and ordinances for regular city employees and other registered and identified emergency management and disaster workers and, upon demand, may receive appropriate compensation for their emergency employment. 
(14)  The city manager will cause to be prepared by the emergency management director a basic emergency and disaster operations plan herein referred to and to exercise his ordinary powers as city manager, all of the special powers conferred upon him by the city Charter and this Code, all powers conferred upon him by any statute, or any other lawful authority. 
(15)  The city manager shall be empowered to accept any gifts, grants and loans from the federal government, from the state, or from any person, firm or corporation, as set out in the Oklahoma Civil Defense and Emergency Resources Management Act of 1967, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(16)  In the event the city manager is unable to assume emergency duties for any reason, the normal succession as designated in the emergency and disaster plan by the city manager shall take effect. In the event those individuals are unable to assume the city manager duties, the mayor and city commission shall designate an acting city manager. 
(Code 2002, § 11-29; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 2577NS, § 1, 10-19-2015) 
Sec. 11-30. - Firearms and ammunition. 
(a)  Notwithstanding this section or any other law of this state, neither the city manager nor any official of a municipal or state entity shall prohibit or suspend the sale, ownership, possession, transportation, carrying, transfer and storage of firearms, ammunition and ammunition accessories during a declared state of emergency, that are otherwise legal under state law. 
(b)  Any individual aggrieved by a violation of subsection (a) of this section may seek relief in an action at law or in equity for redress against any person who subjects such individual or causes such individual to be subjected to an action prohibited by subsection (a) of this section. In addition to any other remedy at law or in equity, an individual aggrieved by the seizure or confiscation of a firearm or ammunition in violation of subsection (a) of this section may bring an action for the return of such firearm or ammunition in the district court of the county in which that individual resides or in which such firearm or ammunition is located. In any action or proceeding to enforce the provisions of this section, the court shall award the prevailing plaintiff costs and reasonable attorney fees. 
(Code 2002, § 11-29.1; Ord. No. 2577NS, § 2, 10-19-2015) 
Sec. 11-31. - Duties and emergency powers of the emergency management director. 
    The emergency management director shall be responsible to the city manager in regard to all phases of emergency management or disaster activity. Under the supervision of the city manager, he shall be responsible for the planning, coordination and operation of emergency management/civil defense activity (disaster services) in the city. Under the supervision of the city manager, he shall maintain liaison with the state and federal authorities and the authorities of other nearby political subdivisions as to insure the most effective operations of the emergency management program. His duties shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Coordinate the recruitment of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment the personnel and facilities of the city for disaster purposes; 
(2)  Development and coordination of plans for the immediate use of all of the facilities, equipment, manpower and other resources of the city for the purpose of minimizing or preventing damage to persons and property; protecting and restoring to usefulness governmental services and public utilities necessary for public health, safety and welfare; 
(3)  Coordinate the recruitment of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment the personnel and facilities of the city for disaster purposes; 
(4)  Negotiating and concluding agreements with owners or persons in control of buildings or other property for the use of such buildings or other property for emergency purposes and designating suitable buildings as public shelters; 
(5)  Through public informational programs, educating the civilian population as to actions necessary and required for the protection of their persons and property in case of enemy attack, or disaster, as defined herein, either impending or present; 
(6)  Conducting practice exercises to insure the efficient operation of emergency and disaster forces and to familiarize disaster workers and residents with disaster regulations, procedures and operations; 
(7)  Coordinating the activity of all other public and private agencies engaged in any disaster activity, real or implied; and 
(8)  Assuming such authority and conducting such activity as the city manager may direct to promote and execute the emergency and disaster plan. 
(Code 2002, § 11-30; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
State Law reference- Responsibility of director, 63 O.S. § 683.11. 
Sec. 11-32. - Emergency and disaster operations plan. 
(a)  A comprehensive emergency and disaster operations plan shall be adopted and maintained by resolution of the city commission upon the recommendations of the city manager. In the preparation of this plan as it pertains to city organization, it is the intent that the services, equipment, facilities and personnel of all existing departments and agencies shall be utilized to the fullest extent. When approved, it shall be the duty of all municipal departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. The emergency and disaster plan shall be considered supplementary as to this chapter and have the effect of law whenever a disaster, as defined in this article, has been proclaimed. 
(b)  The emergency management director shall prescribe in the plan those positions within the disaster organization, in addition to his own, for which lines of succession are necessary. In each instance, the responsible person will designate and keep on file with the emergency manager a current list of three persons as successors to their position. The list will be in order of succession and will as nearly as possible designate persons capable of carrying out all assigned duties and functions. 
(c)  Each service chief and department head assigned responsibility in the plan shall be responsible for carrying out all duties and functions assigned therein. Duties will include the organization and training of assigned city employees and volunteers. Each chief or department head shall formulate the standard operating procedures and guidelines necessary to carry out the assigned duties and functions. 
(Code 2002, § 11-31; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-33. - Authority of shelter managers during emergencies. 
    In time of emergency or when an emergency is threatened as determined by the emergency management director, the director shall appoint public shelter managers, who shall: 
(1)  Open public shelters; 
(2)  Take charge of all stocks of food, water and other supplies stored in such shelters; 
(3)  Admit the public according to the city's shelter use plan; and 
(4)  Take whatever control measures are necessary for the protection and safety of the occupants. Shelter managers are authorized to use reasonable restraint against those who refuse to cooperate with the routine of shelter living under emergency conditions. No person shall refuse to carry out the orders of the shelter manager and his appointed staff. 
(Code 2002, § 11-32; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-34. - Amendments to emergency and disaster operations plan. 
    Amendments to the emergency and disaster operations plan shall be submitted to the city manager. If approved, the city manager will submit the amendments to the city commission with his recommendation for their approval. Following city commission approval, such amendments shall take effect 30 days from the date of approval unless an emergency exists and declared at which time the approved amendments shall become effective immediately. If action is taken by the city commission's disapproving a part of the city manager's submission or in the event an amendment is pending at the time a disaster is proclaimed under provisions of this article, and the terms of the amendment are critical to that specific disaster operations by the city manager, the amendment may be considered immediately and will remain effective until specifically revoked by the city commission until termination of the disaster declaration. Further consideration by the city commission of the amendment would then occur through normal process of law. 
(Code 2002, § 11-33; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-35. - Assistance of persons outside city government. 
    When a required competency or skill for a disaster function is not available within the city government, the appropriate department head in consultation with the city manager is authorized to seek assistance from persons outside of government. The assignment of duties, when of a supervisory nature, shall also grant authority for the persons so assigned to carry out such duties prior to, during and after the occurrence of a disaster until revoked by the city manager. Such services from persons outside of government may be accepted by the city on a volunteer basis or through charges agreeable to the city and contractor. Volunteers obtained to fill said needs shall be enrolled as emergency management volunteers in cooperation with the heads of city departments affected. 
(Code 2002, § 11-34; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-36. - No municipal or private liability. 
(a)  This article is an exercise by the city through its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health and safety and neither the city, nor its agents and representatives or any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, or any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this article, shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons or property as the result of said activity. 
(b)  Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants the city the right to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack or disaster shall not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any persons on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission, or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Code 2002, § 11-35; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-37. - Violation of regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this article or of the regulations or plans issued pursuant to the authority contained herein, or to willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency management organization as herein defined, in the enforcement of the provisions of this article or any regulation or plan issued thereunder. 
(Code 2002, § 11-36; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-38. - Penalty. 
    Violation of any section of this article is a Class C offense. 
(Code 2002, § 11-37; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014; Ord. No. 2577NS, § 3, 10-19-2015) 
Sec. 11-39. - Violation of Emergency Price Stabilization Act. 
    The city manager, upon the concurrence of a majority of the city commission, shall bring an action against any person, firm or individual that violates the Emergency Price Stabilization Act, as outlined in 15 O.S. § 777.1 et seq. 
(Code 2002, § 11-38; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Sec. 11-40. - Emergency management advisory committee. 
    There is hereby created an emergency management advisory committee, composed of the emergency management director, the fire chief, the police chief, the city attorney, the community development director, the utilities director and the floodplain administrator for the city. The purpose for the emergency management advisory committee shall be to provide advice and guidance to the emergency management director and city manager on emergency management issues and to facilitate coordination of programs and policies concerning emergency management. 
(Code 2002, § 11-39; Ord. No. 2528NS, 1-21-2014) 
Secs. 11-41-11-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - 911 EMERGENCY NUMBER 

Sec. 11-126. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency telephone service means a telephone system utilizing a three-digit number, 911, for reporting to the appropriate public agency in police, fire, medical or other emergency situations. 
    Emergency telephone tax means a tax to finance the operation of emergency telephone service. 
    Local exchange telephone company means any company providing exchange telephone services to any service user in this city. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, copartnership, joint venture, association, cooperative organization, private corporation, whether organized for profit or not, fraternal organization, nonprofit organization, estate, trust, business or common law trust, receiver, assignee for the benefit of creditors, trustee or trustee in bankruptcy, the state and any political subdivision of the state, state agency, department, commission, board, bureau or any other service user. 
    Public agency means any city, town, county, municipal corporation, public district or public authority located within this state which provides or has authority to provide firefighting, law enforcement, ambulance, emergency medical or other emergency services. 
    Service user means any person not otherwise exempt from taxation, who is provided exchange telephone service in this city. 
    Tariff rate means the rate billed by the local exchange telephone company stated in tariffs applicable for such company, as approved by the state corporation commission, which represents the recurring charges of such local exchange telephone company for exchange telephone service or its equivalent, exclusive of all taxes, fees, licenses or similar charges whatsoever. 
(Code 1986, § 18-124; Code 2002, § 11-126) 
Sec. 11-127. - Established. 
    There is established in the city a 911 emergency number service. 
(Code 1986, § 18-121; Code 2002, § 11-127) 
Sec. 11-128. - Purpose; findings. 
    It is the purpose of this article to establish the number 911 as the primary emergency telephone number for use throughout the city in order to expedite the response of police, fire, medical rescue and other emergency services to any person calling the telephone number 911. The city commission finds and declares that: 
(1)  It is in the public interest to shorten the time required for a citizen to request and receive emergency aid. 
(2)  Numerous different emergency telephone numbers currently exist throughout the city. 
(3)  Provision of a single, primary three-digit emergency number through which emergency services can be quickly and efficiently obtained would provide a significant contribution to law enforcement and other public safety efforts by making it less difficult to quickly notify public safety personnel. 
(Code 1986, § 18-123; Code 2002, § 11-128) 
Sec. 11-129. - Amendments. 
    This article may be amended as the city commission deems necessary for the purpose of improving emergency service or administration or for the purpose of bringing the article into conformance with amendments made by the state legislature to the Nine-One-One (911) Emergency Number Act. 
(Code 1986, § 18-129; Code 2002, § 11-129) 
Sec. 11-130. - Emergency telephone service and tax. 
(a)  The city commission provides for the operation of an emergency telephone service within the city and levies an emergency telephone tax for such service in areas within the city for which emergency telephone service has been contracted. The city commission levies such tax in an amount not to exceed three percent of the tariff rate in areas within the city for which emergency telephone service has been contracted. The exact rate of the tax to be levied for each calendar year shall be established by the city commission as provided for by section 11-132. The tax imposed shall be for a period of three years, after which the city commission may renew the levy of such tax for no longer than three years at a time. This article shall not take immediate effect, but shall become effective only upon approval thereof by a majority of the votes cast at an election called by the city commission for submission of such question to city voters. 
(b)  The proceeds of the tax shall be utilized to pay for the operation of emergency telephone service as specified in this article and may be collected at any time subsequent to execution of a contract with the provider of such service at the discretion of the city commission. Collection of such tax shall not begin prior to 90 days before operation of the emergency telephone service. 
(c)  The emergency telephone tax shall be imposed only upon the amount received from the tariff for exchange telephone service or its equivalent within the city. No such tax shall be imposed upon more than 100 exchange access lines or their equivalent per person per location. 
(d)  Every billed service user shall be liable for any tax imposed pursuant to this article until it has been paid to the local exchange telephone company. 
(e)  The duty to collect any tax imposed pursuant to the authority of this article from a service user shall commence 90 days before operation of the emergency telephone service; provided, however, no such tax shall ever be levied against any service user within any area of the city for which such service has not been contracted as anticipated in subsection (b) of this section. Taxes imposed pursuant to the authority of this article and that are required to be collected by the local exchange telephone company shall be added to and may be stated separately in the billings to the service user. 
(f)  The local exchange telephone company shall have no obligation to take any legal action to enforce the collection of any tax imposed pursuant to authority of this article. The local exchange telephone company shall annually provide the city commission with a list of amounts uncollected along with the names and addresses of those service users who carry a balance that can be determined by the local exchange telephone company to be nonpayment of any tax imposed pursuant to the authority of this article. 
(g)  Any tax imposed pursuant to this article shall be collected insofar as practicable at the same time as and along with the charges for exchange telephone service in accordance with the regular billing practice of the local exchange telephone service. The tariff rates determined by or stated in the billing of the local exchange telephone company shall be presumed to be correct if such charges are made in accordance with the business practices of the local exchange telephone company. The presumption may be rebutted by evidence which establishes that an incorrect tariff rate was charged. 
(Code 1986, § 18-125; Code 2002, § 11-130) 
Sec. 11-131. - Collection of emergency tax, establishment of rate of tax. 
(a)  The tax imposed pursuant to authority of this article and the amounts required to be collected are due monthly. The amount of tax collected in one month by the local exchange telephone company shall be remitted to the city commission no later than 30 days after the close of the month in which such taxes were collected. On or before the last day of each month, a return for the preceding month shall be filed with the city commission in such form as the city commission and local exchange telephone company shall agree. The local exchange telephone company required to file the return shall deliver the return together with a remittance of the amount of the tax payable to the city treasurer-finance director for deposit into a special revenue fund. The local exchange telephone company shall maintain records of the amount of any tax collected in accordance with this article. Such records shall be maintained for a period of one year from the time the tax is collected. 
(b)  From every remittance to the city commission made on or before the date when such becomes due, the local exchange telephone company required to remit the tax shall be entitled to deduct and retain, as an administrative fee, an amount not exceeding three percent thereof. 
(c)  At least once each calendar year, the city commission shall establish a tax rate not to exceed the amount authorized by section 11-130 that, together with any surplus revenues, will produce sufficient revenues to fund the expenditures authorized by this article. Amounts collected in excess of those necessary within a given year shall be carried forward to subsequent years. The city commission shall make its determination of such tax rate each year no later than September 1 and shall fix the new rate to take effect commencing with the first billing period of each service user on or following the next January 1. Immediately upon making its determination and fixing the rate, the city commission shall publish in its minutes the new rate, and it shall, at least 90 days before such new rate will become effective, notify by certified mail every local exchange telephone company providing emergency telephone service to areas within the jurisdiction of the city commission. The city commission may at its own expense require an annual audit of the books and records of the local exchange telephone company concerning the collection and remittance of the tax authorized by this article. 
(Code 1986, § 18-126; Code 2002, § 11-131) 
Sec. 11-132. - Rate of emergency telephone tax for calendar year. 
    The rate of the emergency telephone tax for each calendar year to be established as provided for by section 11-131 shall be set by separate resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 18-127; Code 2002, § 11-132) 
Sec. 11-133. - False alarm, complaint or information. 
    No person shall call the number 911 for the purpose of making a false alarm or complaint or reporting false information which could result in the dispatch of emergency services from any public agency as defined in section 11-126. Any person violating this section, upon conviction, shall be guilty of an offense punishable by a fine not to exceed an amount as established in the city fee schedule, plus costs. 
(Code 1986, § 18-128; Code 2002, § 11-133) 
Chapter 12 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Constitution reference- Jurisdiction of municipal courts, OK Const. Art. 7, § 1; removal of officers, etc., for excessive use of alcoholic liquors, OK Const. Art. 2, § 11. 
State Law reference- Creation of municipal court not of record, 11 O.S. § 27-101 et seq.; warrant of arrest, 22 O.S. § 171 et seq.; removal of officers, 22 O.S. § 1181; official misconduct defined, 51 O.S. § 93. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, will have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief of police means the peace officer in charge of the city police force. 
    Clerk means the clerk of the court, including any deputy or member of the office staff of the clerk while performing duties of the clerk's office. 
    Court means the municipal court of this city. 
    Judge means the judge of the municipal court, including any acting judge or alternate judge thereof as provided for by state statutes and this chapter. 
    This judicial district means the district court judicial district of the state wherein the government of this city is situated. 
(Code 2002, § 12-1; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 2, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-2. - Scope of chapter. 
    This chapter will govern the organization and operation of the municipal court, as continued by 11 O.S. § 27-101 et seq. To the extent of conflict between any section of this chapter and any other section of this Code or the provisions of any other city ordinance, this chapter will control. 
(Code 2002, § 12-2; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 3, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-3. - Jurisdiction. 
    The municipal court will have original jurisdiction to hear and determine all prosecutions wherein a violation of any ordinance of the city is charged, and will exercise all jurisdiction, powers, duties and functions as provided by 11 O.S. § 27-101 et seq. Nothing in this Code will be construed to limit or impair in any manner the status, jurisdiction, powers, rights or functions of such court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-3; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 4, 10-21-2013) 
State Constitution reference- Jurisdiction of municipal court, OK Const. Art. 7, § 1. 
Secs. 12-4-12-12. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-13. - Failure to appear before the court. 
(a)  Any person who is charged with a violation of this Code and who, having been duly issued a summons or citation or having been arraigned and released on recognizance or having made a promise to appear and violates such recognizance or fails to answer the summons or citation or fails to honor a promise to appear and does not voluntarily appear before the court on the appointed date and time, regardless of the disposition of the charge for which the summons or citation was originally issued, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate this section by failing to appear in the municipal court shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding $500.00 and costs. 
(Ord. No. 2613NS, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
Secs. 12-14-12-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MEMBERS OF THE COURT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Judges of municipal court, 11 O.S. § 27-104. 

Sec. 12-25. - Judges. 
(a)  The number of judges for municipal court will be determined by the commission. In addition to a chief judge, the commission may appoint such associate judges as it determines. In this chapter, the term "judge" will include "associate judge," unless the context shows otherwise. The judge will be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the commission. The name of the proposed appointee will be submitted in writing to the board at the next to the last regularly scheduled meeting prior to the day upon which the appointment is to take effect, and will be acted upon at the next regularly scheduled meeting. The judge will be licensed to practice law in the state. He will serve for a term of two years, said term expiring on June 30 of even years, and until his successor is appointed and qualified, unless removed by the vote of a majority of all members of the commission as provided in this article. Any appointment to fill a vacancy will be for the unexpired term. Nothing in the provisions of this section will be construed to prevent the judge from engaging in the practice of law in any other court during his tenure of office, but he will not accept employment inconsistent with his duties as judge or arising out of facts which give rise to or are connected with cases within the jurisdiction of the court pending in the court or that might become the subject of proceedings in the court. He must be a resident of this city. He may serve as judge of other municipal courts, if such service may be accomplished consistently with his duties as judge of this court, with the consent of the city commission. 
(b)  The judge will be paid a salary to be fixed by the commission. The commission may, in its discretion, provide the judge with benefits offered to city employees. 
(Code 2002, § 12-25; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 5, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Salary of judges, 11 O.S. §§ 27-104, 27-106. 
Sec. 12-26. - Removal from office. 
(a)  Municipal judges will be subject to removal from office, by the city commission, for the causes prescribed by the constitution and laws of this state for the removal of public officers. Proceedings for removal will be instituted by the filing of a verified written petition, setting forth facts sufficient to constitute one or more legal grounds for removal. Petitions may be signed and filed by the following: 
(1)  The mayor; or 
(2)  Twenty-five or more qualified electors of this city. 
(b)  If the petition is signed by 25 or more qualified electors as provided in subsection (a)(2) of this section, verification may be executed by one or more of the petitioners. The city commission will set a date for hearing the matter and will cause notice thereof, together with a copy of the petition, to be served personally upon the judge at least ten days before the hearing. 
(c)  At the hearing, the judge will be entitled to: 
(1)  Representation by counsel; 
(2)  Present testimony and cross examine the witnesses against him; and 
(3)  Have all evidence against him presented in open hearing. 
(d)  So far as they can be made applicable, the provisions of the Oklahoma Administrative Procedure Act governing individual proceedings (75 O.S. §§ 309-317 and any amendments or additions thereto in effect at the time of the hearing) will govern removal proceedings under this section. Judgment of removal will be entered only upon individual votes, by a majority of all members of the city commission, in favor of such removal. 
(Code 2002, § 12-26; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 6, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Grounds for removal of judges, 20 O.S. § 1404; removal of officers generally, 22 O.S. § 1181 et seq. 
Sec. 12-27. - Prohibition on change of venue; disqualification of judge. 
(a)  No change of venue will be allowed from any municipal court, but the judge of the municipal court may be disqualified under the same terms and conditions as are now provided by law for courts of record. 
(b)  In the event of an ethical disqualification by a municipal judge, the chief judge may assign the case to an associate or alternate judge, or, if all of them are disqualified, he may appoint, on a case-by-case basis, a sitting municipal judge in another municipality within Pottawatomie County or an adjacent county to act as a special judge for the purposes of hearing the case. 
(Code 2002, § 12-27; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 7, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 11 O.S. § 27-105. 
Sec. 12-28. - Acting judge; alternate judge; compensation. 
    In the event of disqualification of the chief judge in a particular case, or his absence or inability to act, should there be no associate judge available, the mayor of the municipality may appoint some person, qualified as provided in this chapter, as acting municipal judge of the court in the place of the judge during his absence or inability to act or in a case wherein the judge is disqualified; or, in its discretion, the municipal governing body may provide by ordinance for the appointment of an alternate judge of the court, in the same manner and for the same term as the judge and possessing the qualifications prescribed by section 12-25, who will sit as acting judge of the court in case of the absence, inability or disqualification of the judge. If both the judge and the alternate judge are unable to sit, the mayor may appoint an acting judge as provided in this section. The commission, by resolution, will provide for the compensation of an acting judge of the court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-28; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 8, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Acting or alternate judge, 11 O.S. § 27-106. 
Sec. 12-29. - Vacancies in office of judge. 
    Vacancies in the office of the judge will be filled in the same manner as provided for the appointment of the judge in the first instance. 
(Code 2002, § 12-29; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 9, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 11 O.S. § 27-107. 
Sec. 12-30. - Municipal attorney as prosecuting attorney. 
    The city attorney, or some other attorney licensed to practice law in the state as he may appoint, will be the prosecutor. The prosecutor will have full power to prosecute for the violations of any ordinance of Shawnee and will have the power to prosecute and resist appeals and proceedings in error and review from the court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-30; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 10, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 11 O.S. § 27-108. 
Sec. 12-31. - Clerk of court; duties. 
(a)  The municipal clerk of any municipality where a municipal court is established, or a designated deputy will be the clerk of the municipal court unless the governing body establishes or authorizes a position of chief municipal court officer to serve as court clerk. 
(b)  The court clerk will have authority to carry out the duties of the position as required by law; provided, that the person who serves as court clerk may separately perform other duties for the municipality. The clerk of the court will: 
(1)  Assist the judge in recording the proceedings of the court, preparation of writs, processes or other papers; 
(2)  Administer oaths required in judicial or other proceedings before the court; 
(3)  Be responsible for the entry of all pleadings, processes and proceedings in the dockets of the court; 
(4)  Perform such other clerical duties in relation to the proceedings of the court as the judge will direct; 
(5)  Receive and give receipt for and disburse or deliver to the municipal treasurer all fines, forfeitures, fees, deposits, and sums of money properly payable to the municipal court. Such funds and sums of money while in the custody of the clerk will be deposited and disbursed upon vouchers as directed by the municipal governing body; and 
(6)  The records of the court may be maintained electronically, including citations and complaints, pleas, judgments, endorsements and all signatures. If a notice requires a mailing by certified mail, the electronic method of certification in use by the United States Postal Service will be sufficient to prove such mailing and receipt. When a party provides an e-mail address, notifications not requiring certification may be delivered electronically. 
(Code 2002, § 12-31; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 11, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Clerk of court generally, 11 O.S. § 27-109. 
Sec. 12-32. - Court marshal; duties. 
    The municipal governing body, upon the recommendation of the judge of the municipal court, may designate any appropriate person who is a resident of the municipality to serve as marshal, and in the absence of such a designation, the chief of police or corresponding officer of the municipality will be ex officio marshal of the court. The marshal will execute any writs and other process directed to him, except as herein otherwise provided, and such duty may be performed by any deputy marshal or by any members of the police force of the municipality, as the case may be. 
(Code 2002, § 12-32; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 12, 10-21-2013) 
Secs. 12-33-12-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOND OF CLERK AND JUDGE; FEES, FINES AND FORFEITURES 

Sec. 12-53. - Bond of clerk and judge; form. 
(a)  The clerk and all deputy clerks and marshals, will give a bond, in an amount fixed by the commission by resolution, to the city. The bond will be approved by the commission and will be in substance as follows: 
I, ____________ , ____________ of the Municipal Court of the City of Shawnee, State of Oklahoma, and ____________ and ____________ , sureties, do jointly and severally agree to pay on demand each and every person who may be entitled thereto, all such sums of money as the ____________ may become liable to pay, on account of any moneys which may come into his hands, by virtue of his office. 
Dated at ____________ , this ____________ / ____________ / ____________ day of ____________ , 20 ____________ . 
____________ (Signed) 
(b)  The commission may provide that all judges, alternate judges, and an acting judge, or any of them, will give a bond to the city. If a bond is required, it will be in an amount to be fixed by resolution of the commission. It will be conditioned in the same manner as the bond that is required of the clerk of the court, and it will be approved by the governing body. 
(Code 2002, § 12-53; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 13, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-54. - Fees, fines and forfeitures; dispositions. 
    All of the fees, fines and forfeitures which come into the court will be paid by the clerk of the court to the city treasurer. The treasurer will credit such deposits to the fund designated by the commission. The court clerk will make duplicate receipts for the fees, fines and forfeitures collected by him, one copy of which will be retained by the municipal treasurer together with a detailed statement of all costs, the style of the case in which they were paid, and the name of the party paying the same. 
(Code 2002, § 12-54; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 14, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-55. - Procedure; judicial notice of statutes and ordinances; writs and process; service of arrest warrant. 
    Except as otherwise provided for by law, the code of procedure in the municipal court will be the same as is provided for by law for the trial of misdemeanors. The court will take judicial notice of state statutes and the ordinances of the city. Writs and processes of the court may be issued by the judge or clerk thereof to any proper officer. All writs and processes of the court in which a violation of a municipal ordinance is charged will be directed to the chief of police, a county sheriff, or to some other appropriate peace officer. A law enforcement officer of the city or county sheriff may serve an arrest warrant issued by the municipal court any place within this state. If the warrant is served by a county sheriff, the city will pay the sheriffs service fee account a fee as described in the city fee schedule, unless such fee is waived by the sheriff. 
(Code 2002, § 12-55; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 15, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 11 O.S. §§ 27-113, 27-115, 22 O.S. § 172. 
Sec. 12-56. - Issuance of summons. 
(a)  Upon the filing of a complaint charging violation of an ordinance, the municipal judge, unless he determines to issue a warrant of arrest or unless the defendant previously has been issued a citation or has been arrested and has given bond for appearance, will issue a summons, naming the person charged, specifying his address or place of residence if known, stating the offense with which he is charged and giving him notice to answer the charge in the court on a day certain, containing a provision for the official return of the summons and including such other pertinent information as may be necessary. 
(b)  The summons will be served by delivering a copy to the defendant personally. If he fails to appear and to answer the summons within the prescribed period, a warrant will be issued for his arrest, as provided by this article. 
(Code 2002, § 12-56; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 16, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-57. - Issuance of warrant; summons. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this Code or other city ordinances, upon the filing of a complaint approved by endorsement by the city attorney or by the municipal judge, there will be issued a warrant of arrest, in substantially the following form: 
"The City of Shawnee, Oklahoma, to the Marshal of the Municipal Court of Shawnee, Oklahoma.
