Complaint upon oath having this day been made by (naming complainant) that the offense of (naming the offense in particular but in general terms) has been committed and accusing (name of defendant) thereof, you are commanded therefore forthwith to arrest the above-named (name of defendant) and bring ____________ (insert him, her or them as appropriate) before me, at ____________ (naming the place). Witness my hand this ____________ / ____________ / ____________ day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , ____________ . 
____________ 
Judge of the Municipal Court of Shawnee, Oklahoma" 
(b)  It will be the duty of the marshal, personally or through a duly constituted member of the police force or through any other persons lawfully authorized to so act, to execute such warrant as promptly as possible. 
(Code 2002, § 12-57; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 17, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-58. - Rules of conduct for court business. 
    The judge of the court may prescribe rules, consistent with the provisions of this article, for the proper conduct of the business of the court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-58; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 18, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-59. - Prosecutions by verified complaint; style. 
    All prosecutions commenced in the court will be by complaint which will be subscribed by the person making the complaint and will be verified before a judge, the court clerk, a deputy court clerk, or a police officer. No warrant for arrest will be issued until the complaint has been approved by the judge of the court. All prosecutions for the violation of municipal ordinances will be styled, "The City of Shawnee vs. ____________ (naming the person or persons charged)". 
(Code 2002, § 12-59; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 19, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-60. - Properly verified citation or ticket. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions of law, when a law enforcement officer issues a citation or ticket as the basis for a complaint or information, for an offense against a municipal ordinance which is declared to be a misdemeanor, the citation or ticket will be properly verified if: 
(1)  The issuing officer subscribes the officer's signature on the citation, ticket or complaint to the following statement: 
"I, the undersigned issuing officer, hereby certify and swear that I have read the foregoing information and know the facts and contents thereof and that the facts supporting the criminal charge stated therein are true." 
Such a subscription by an issuing officer, in all respects, will constitute a sworn statement, as if sworn to upon an oath administered by an official authorized by law to administer oaths; and 
(2)  The citation or ticket states the specific facts supporting the criminal charge and the ordinance or statute alleged to be violated; or 
(3)  A complainant verifies by oath, subscribed on the citation, ticket or complaint, that he has read the information, knows the facts and contents thereof and that the facts supporting the criminal charge stated therein are true. For purposes of such an oath and subscription, any law enforcement officer of the state, county or municipality of the state issuing the citation, ticket or complaint will be authorized to administer the oath to the complainant. 
(Code 2002, § 12-60; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 20, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-61. - Arraignment; fines in lieu of appearance. 
    The arraignment will be made by the court. The judge or the prosecuting attorney will read the complaint to the defendant, inform him of his legal rights and of the consequences of conviction, and ask him whether he pleads guilty or not guilty. The commission, by ordinance or public resolution, may prescribe a schedule of fines which the defendant may pay in lieu of his appearance before the municipal court and such payment will constitute a final determination of the cause against the defendant. 
(Code 2002, § 12-61; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 21, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Arraignment, 11 O.S. § 27-116. 
Sec. 12-62. - Pleas. 
    There will be four kinds of pleas to a complaint in the municipal court: 
(1)  Guilty. 
(2)  Not guilty. 
(3)  Nolo contendere, subject to the approval of the court. The legal effect of such plea will be the same as that of a plea of guilty, but the plea may not be used against the defendant as an admission in any civil suit based upon or growing out of the act upon which the criminal prosecution is based. 
(4)  A former judgment of conviction or acquittal of the offense charged, which must be specially pleaded, either with or without the plea of not guilty. 
(Code 2002, § 12-62; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 22, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 22 O.S. § 513. 
Sec. 12-63. - Postponement of trial. 
    Before trial commences in the municipal court, either party, upon good cause shown, may obtain a reasonable postponement thereof. 
(Code 2002, § 12-63; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 23, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-64. - Presence of defendant. 
    The defendant must be present in person at the trial in the municipal court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-64; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 24, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-65. - Guilty plea; conviction. 
    If the defendant pleads guilty or is convicted after trial, the municipal court must render judgment thereon, fixing the penalty within the limits prescribed by the applicable ordinance and imposing sentence accordingly. 
(Code 2002, § 12-65; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 25, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-66. - Bail; amount and conditions; temporary cash bond. 
(a)  If a resident of the city is arrested by a law enforcement officer for the violation of any traffic ordinance for which section 12-67 does not apply, or is arrested for the violation of a non-traffic ordinance, the officer will immediately release said person if the person acknowledges receipt of a citation by signing it. Provided, however, the arresting officer need not release said person if it reasonably appears to the officer that the person may cause injury to himself or others or damage to property if released, that the person will not appear in response to the citation, or the person is arrested for an offense against a person or property. If said person fails to appear in response to the citation, a warrant will be issued for his arrest and his appearance will be compelled. 
(b)  If the arrested resident is not released by being permitted to sign a citation as provided for in this subsection, he will be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment, or will be released on personal recognizance. The city may prescribe a fine for up to the maximum amount authorized by law for failure of a person to have a valid driver's license when charged with a traffic violation. 
(c)  If a nonresident of a municipality served by a municipal court is arrested by a law enforcement officer for a violation of any ordinance for which section 12-67 does not apply, the defendant will be eligible to be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment. 
(d)  The amount and conditions of bail granted pursuant to the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section will be determined by the judge who will prescribe rules for the receipt of bail and for the release on personal recognizance. The amount of bail for each offense will not exceed the maximum fine plus court costs, unless the defendant has a previous history of failing to appear according to the terms or conditions of a bond, in which case the amount of bail will not exceed an amount as described in the city fee schedule. In the event of arrests at night, emergencies, or when the judge is not available, a court official, the chief of police or his designated representative may be authorized by the judge, subject to such conditions as will be prescribed by the judge, to accept a temporary cash bond in a sufficient amount to secure the appearance of the accused. The cash bond will not exceed the maximum fine provided for by ordinance for each offense charged, unless the defendant has a previous history of failing to appear according to the terms or conditions of a bond, in which case the amount of the cash bond will not exceed an amount as described in the city fee schedule. The court official, chief of police, or his designated representative is authorized, subject to such conditions as will be prescribed by the judge, to release a resident of the municipality on personal recognizance. 
(Code 2002, § 12-66; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 26, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Arrest, signing citation, bail, 11 O.S. § 27-117. 
Sec. 12-67. - Release on personal recognizance. 
    If a resident or nonresident of the city is arrested by a law enforcement officer solely for a misdemeanor violation of a traffic ordinance, other than an ordinance pertaining to a parking or standing traffic violation, and the arrested person is eligible to sign a written promise to appear and be released upon personal recognizance, as provided for in 22 O.S. § 1115.1, then the procedures provided for in the State and Municipal Traffic Bail Bond Procedure Act as applied to municipalities, will govern. A municipality, by ordinance, may prescribe a bail bond schedule for this purpose and may provide for bail to be used as payment of the fine and costs upon a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, as provided for in 22 O.S. § 1115.1. Absent such ordinance, the municipal court may prescribe a bail bond schedule for traffic offenses. The amount of bail will not exceed the maximum fine and costs provided by ordinance for each offense, unless the defendant has a previous history of failing to appear according to the terms or conditions of a bond, in which case the amount of bail will not exceed an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2002, § 12-67; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 27, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-68. - Failure to appear according to terms of bond; forfeiture. 
(a)  If, without sufficient excuse, a defendant fails to appear according to the terms or conditions of a bond, given by a bail bondsman as defined in 59 O.S. § 1301, either for hearing, arraignment, trial or judgment, or upon any other occasion when the presence of the defendant in court or before the judge may be lawfully required: 
(1)  The court will perform the procedures set forth in 59 O.S. § 1332, whereby the court clerk will issue the required notices; or 
(2)  a.  The judge will issue an order declaring the bond to be forfeited on the day the defendant failed to appear and stating the reasons therefor; and 
b.  Within five days of the order of forfeiture, the court clerk will file a certified copy of the order with the district court in the county. The district court clerk will treat the certified order of forfeiture as a foreign judgment and proceed in accordance with the provisions of 59 O.S. § 1332. A surety will have all remedies available under the provisions of 22 O.S. § 1108 and 59 O.S. §§ 1301-1340. 
(b)  Court costs will be collectible from the proceeds of a forfeited bond. 
(Code 2002, § 12-68; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 28, 10-21-2013) 
Secs. 12-69-12-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JURY 

Sec. 12-89. - Jury trials; qualifications of jurors. 
    In all prosecutions in the municipal court for any offense for which the city, with the concurrence of the court, seeks imposition of a fine of more than the amount as described in the city fee schedule, excluding court costs, or imprisonment, or both such fine and imprisonment, a jury trial will be had unless waived by the defendant and the municipality, provided that the municipality has compiled its penal ordinances in accordance with the provisions of 11 O.S. §§ 14-109 and 14-110. If the municipality has not compiled its ordinances as provided by law, the fine will not exceed an amount as described in the city fee schedule. In prosecutions for all other offenses, or in cases when a jury trial is waived by the defendant and the municipality, trial will be to the court. A jury in the municipal court will consist of six jurors, five of whom may return a verdict. Jurors will be good and lawful men or women, citizens of the county in which the court sits, having the qualifications of jurors in the district court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-89; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 29, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Jury trials, 11 O.S. § 27-119. 
Sec. 12-90. - Selection and summons of jurors. 
    Jurors in the municipal court will be selected pursuant to this section under the same terms and conditions as are provided for by law for the district courts, or in the alternative, pursuant to 38 O.S. § 18.1. Upon written request of the judge of the municipal court for a stated number of jurors to the chief judge of the appropriate district court, it will be the duty of the clerk of the district court to draw from the jury wheel a requested number of jurors in the same manner as is provided by law for the district court until the number requested, who from their addresses appear to reside within the corporate limits of the city, is drawn, and to prepare a list of names drawn and certify such list to the judge of the municipal court. On completion of the draw, the clerk will immediately return to the jury wheel all names drawn which are not placed on the certified list. The judge of the municipal court will make written request to the chief judge of the district court for a stated number of additional jurors if, after allowance of claimed statutory exemptions, the listed number is found to be insufficient. Summons of the prospective jurors will be issued as set out by ordinance, and may be served in person by the chief of police or any member of the police force of the city, or may be served by the court clerk by mail. 
(Code 2002, § 12-90; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 30, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Selection and summons of jurors, 11 O.S. § 27-120. 
Sec. 12-91. - Fees and mileage of jurors and witnesses. 
    The municipal governing body will determine by ordinance or public resolution the fees and mileage that will be paid to jurors and witnesses in municipal court. However, no witness fee will be paid to any police or peace officer. The jury fee and mileage due jurors and witnesses will be paid as costs taxed to the party issuing the subpoena for the witnesses or requesting the jury trial. The court may require that such fees be paid in advance. 
(Code 2002, § 12-91; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 31, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Fees and mileage of witnesses, 11 O.S. § 27-121. 
Sec. 12-92. - Misconduct of jurors. 
    Every juror or person drawn or summoned as a juror is guilty of a misdemeanor if the juror or person: 
(1)  Makes any promise or agreement to give a verdict for or against any party; or 
(2)  Willfully permits any communication to be made to him or receives any book, paper, instrument or information relative to any cause pending before him, except according to the regular course of proceeding upon the trial of such cause. 
(Code 2002, § 12-92; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 32, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Misconduct of jurors, 21 O.S. § 385; grounds for new trial, 22 O.S. § 952. 
Sec. 12-93. - Misconduct of officer in charge of jury. 
    Every officer to whose charge any juror or jury is committed by the municipal court or municipal judge is guilty of a misdemeanor if the officer negligently or willfully permits the jury or any one of the jury to: 
(1)  Receive any communication from any person; 
(2)  Make any communication to any person; 
(3)  Obtain or receive any book or paper or refreshment; or 
(4)  Leave the jury room, the jury box or his immediate custody or control, without the leave of such court or judge first obtained. 
(Code 2002, § 12-93; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 33, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 390. 
Sec. 12-94. - Attempt to influence juror. 
    Every person is guilty of a misdemeanor if the person attempts to influence a juror or any person summoned or drawn as a juror, in respect to his verdict or decision on any cause or matter pending or about to be brought before him: 
(1)  By means of any oral or written communication had with him, except in the regular course of proceedings upon the trial of the cause; 
(2)  By means of any book, paper or instrument exhibited otherwise than in the regular course of proceedings upon the trial of the cause; 
(3)  By means of any threat or intimidation; 
(4)  By means of any assurance or promise of any pecuniary or other advantage; or 
(5)  By publishing any statement, argument or observation relating to the cause. 
(Code 2002, § 12-94; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 34, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 388. 
Sec. 12-95. - Influencing false testimony by witnesses. 
    No person will attempt to influence or will influence a witness to testify falsely in the municipal court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-95; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 35, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-96. - Judgment; costs. 
(a)  At the close of trial, judgment must be rendered by the municipal judge, who will cause it to be entered in his docket. 
(b)  If the judgment is of acquittal and the defendant is not to be detained for any other legal cause, he must be discharged at once. 
(c)  After conviction and sentence, the judge may suspend sentence, in accordance with the provisions of and subject to the conditions and procedures imposed by 11 O.S. §§ 27-123 and 27-124. 
(d)  If a judgment of conviction is entered, the clerk of the court will tax the costs to the defendant in a sum set by resolution of the city commission, plus the fees and mileage of jurors and witnesses, all of which the defendant will pay, in addition to any fine that may be imposed. 
(Code 2002, § 12-96; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 36, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Costs, 11 O.S. § 27-126. 
Secs. 12-97-12-116. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - IMPRISONMENT; JUDGMENTS AND SENTENCES 

Sec. 12-117. - Delivery of copy of judgment of imprisonment. 
    If, after conviction in the municipal court, judgment of imprisonment is entered, a copy thereof, certified by the clerk, will be delivered to the chief of police, the county sheriff or other appropriate police officer. Such copy will be a sufficient warrant for execution of the sentence. 
(Code 2002, § 12-117; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 37, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-118. - Enforcement of payment of fines or costs by imprisonment; persons unable to pay. 
(a)  If a defendant who is financially able refuses or neglects to pay a fine or costs or both, payment may be enforced: 
(1)  By imprisonment until the same will be satisfied at the rate in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per day; or 
(2)  In the same manner as is prescribed in subsection (c) of this section for a defendant who is without means to make such payment. 
(b)  If the judge determines, after due inquiry, that the defendant is without immediate funds to pay the fine or costs, but may be able to pay over a period of time, he may order the total to be paid in installments. Failure of the defendant to make payments as ordered without showing sufficient cause why he could not pay, will result in a warrant for arrest of the defendant. 
(c)  If the judge determines, after due inquiry, that the defendant is without means to pay the fine or costs, the judge may direct the total amount due to be entered upon the court minutes and to be certified to the district court in the county where the situs of the municipal government is located, where it will be entered upon the district court judgment docket and will have the full force and effect of a district court judgment. The same remedies will be available for the enforcement of the judgment as are available to any other judgment creditor. 
(Code 2002, § 12-118; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 38, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-119. - Municipal court judgments and sentences; execution. 
(a)  All sentences of imprisonment will be executed by the chief of police, and any person convicted of a violation of any ordinance of the city and sentenced to imprisonment will be confined in the jail, farm or workhouse designated by the city, in the discretion of the court, for the time specified in the sentence; provided, however, the court may, in lieu of imprisonment, order the defendant to engage in a term of community service without compensation. If the defendant fails to perform the required community service or if the conditions of community service are violated, the judge may impose a sentence of imprisonment, not to exceed the maximum sentence allowable for the violation for which the defendant was convicted. 
(b)  The judge imposing a judgment and sentence, at the judge's discretion, is empowered to modify, reduce, suspend or defer the imposition of a sentence or any part thereof and to authorize probation for a period not to exceed six months from the date of sentence under terms or conditions as the judge may specify. Procedures relating to suspension of the judgment or costs or both will be as provided in section 12-67. Upon completion of the terms of probation, the defendant will be discharged without a court judgment of guilt, and the verdict, judgment of guilty, or plea of guilty will be expunged from the record and the charge dismissed with prejudice to any further action. Upon a finding of the court that the conditions of probation have been violated, the municipal judge may enter a judgment of guilty. 
(c)  The judge may continue or delay imposing a judgment and sentence for a period of time not to exceed six months from the date of sentence. At the expiration of this period of time the judge may allow the city attorney to amend the charge to a lesser offense. 
(d)  If a deferred sentence is imposed, an administrative fee not to exceed an amount as described in the city fee schedule may be imposed as costs in the case, in addition to any deferral fee otherwise authorized by law. 
(Code 2002, § 12-119; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 39, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-120. - Community service or remedial action in lieu of fine or in conjunction with imprisonment. 
    Whenever any person is convicted in municipal court for violation of a municipal ordinance, the court may order the defendant to a term of community service or remedial action in lieu of fine or in conjunction with imprisonment. If the defendant fails to perform the required community service or if the conditions of community service are violated, the judge may impose a sentence of imprisonment, not to exceed the maximum sentence allowable for the violation for which the defendant was convicted. 
(Code 2002, § 12-120; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 40, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-121. - Suspension of judgment or costs; reconfinement. 
    Whenever any person will be convicted in the municipal court of violating a municipal ordinance, the judge trying the cause, after sentence, may suspend the judgment or costs or both and allow the person so convicted to be released upon his own recognizance. Any person so released will be required to report at such times and to such person or officer as the judge will direct. The judge may cause a warrant to be issued for any person so released if it will be made to appear to the judge that such person: 
(1)  Has been guilty of the violation of any law after his release; 
(2)  Is habitually associating with lewd or vicious persons; or 
(3)  Is indulging in vicious habits. Upon the issuance of the warrant by the judge, the person will be delivered forthwith to the place of confinement to which he was originally sentenced and will serve out the full term for which he was originally sentenced. 
(Code 2002, § 12-121; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 41, 10-21-2013) 
Secs. 12-122-12-141. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 12-142. - Traffic violation by juveniles. 
(a)  The municipal court will have and possess the original jurisdiction to hear and determine all offenses against the city traffic regulations, without previous proceedings in juvenile court, when the person informed against has attained the age of 16 years or when the person informed against is between the age of 16 and 151/2 years of age and is the holder of an operator's or restricted operator's license issued by the state department of public safety authorizing such person to operate a motor vehicle. 
(b)  All such actions will be heard and determined in the manner provided by law for the trial of all other offenses against the city ordinances in such court, and the penalty for such offenses will be the same as provided for the violation of city traffic regulations. 
(Code 2002, § 12-142; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 42, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Children charged with violating ordinances, 10 O.S. § 2-2-403; driving by minors, 47 O.S. §§ 6-103, 6-105. 
Sec. 12-143. - Supervision of juveniles on parole or probation. 
    In addition to the duties otherwise provided by law, the judge, or some other person designated by the commission, will be required to supervise all juveniles who are either on parole or serving probation terms or suspended sentences pronounced and adjudged by the municipal court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-143; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 43, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-144. - Contempt of court. 
    The judge will have power to enforce due obedience to orders, rules and judgments made by him and may fine or imprison for contempt offered to the judge while holding his court or to process issued by him in the same manner and to the same extent as the district courts of the state. 
(Code 2002, § 12-144; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 44, 10-21-2013) 
State Law reference- Contempt of court generally, 21 O.S. § 565 et seq. 
Sec. 12-145. - Court costs and fees. 
    Except as provided in 11 O.S. § 14-111, and subject to other limitations or exceptions imposed by law, the commission will determine by ordinance or public resolution the court costs and fees that may be charged and collected by the clerk of the court. Court costs will not exceed an amount as described in the city fee schedule plus the fees and mileage of jurors and witnesses. The clerk of the court is authorized to charge and collect the fees as determined by the municipal body. 
(Code 2002, § 12-145; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 45, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-146. - Costs of imprisonment. 
    The judge will have the power to order the defendant to pay costs associated with imprisonment, or to waive such costs. 
(Code 2002, § 12-146; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 46, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-147. - Prosecution for same offense of another court prohibited. 
    When a defendant has been in jeopardy for the same or any lesser included offense in a municipal court or district court, he will not be prosecuted in another court for the same or a lesser included offense. 
(Code 2002, § 12-147; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 47, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-148. - Writs of mandamus, prohibition and certiorari. 
    The district court in each county wherein a municipal court is established will have the same jurisdiction to issue to the municipal court writs of mandamus, prohibition and certiorari as the supreme court now has to issue such writs to courts of record. 
(Code 2002, § 12-148; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 48, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-149. - Appeals. 
(a)  An appeal may be taken from a final judgment of the municipal court by the defendant by filing in the county district court, within ten days from the date of the final judgment, a notice of appeal and by filing a copy of the notice with the municipal court in case of an appeal, a trial de novo will be had, and there will be a right to a jury trial if the sentence imposed for the offense was a fine of more than an amount as described in the city fee schedule and costs. 
(b)  Upon conviction, at the request of the defendant, or upon notice of appeal being filed, the judge of the municipal court will enter an order on the docket fixing an amount in which bond may be given by the defendant, in cash or sureties for cash in an amount of not less than an amount as described in the city fee schedule nor more than twice the amount of such fine. Bond will be taken by the court clerk. Any pledge of sureties must be approved by a judge of the court. 
(c)  Upon appeal being filed the judge will within ten days thereafter certify to the clerk of the appellate court the original papers in the case. If the papers have not been certified to the appellate court, the prosecuting attorney will take the necessary steps to have the papers certified to the appellate court within 20 days of the filing of the notice of appeal, and failure to do so, except for good cause shown, will be grounds for dismissal of the charge by the appellate court, the cost to be taxed to the municipality. The certificate will state whether or not the municipal judge hearing the case was a licensed attorney in the state. 
(d)  All proceedings necessary to carry the judgment into effect will be had in the appellate court. 
(Code 2002, § 12-149; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 49, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-150. - Orders relative to procedures and practices by supreme court. 
    The supreme court is authorized to issue orders of state-wide application relative to procedures in and practices before municipal courts and appeals therefrom, subject to the provisions of 11 O.S. §§ 27-101-27-132, and under its general superintending control of all inferior courts, will have the power and authority by and through the chief justice of the supreme court, to call annual conferences of the judges of the municipal courts of the state to consider matters calculated to bring about a speedier and more efficient administration of justice. 
(Code 2002, § 12-150; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 50, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-151. - Appeal to court of criminal appeals. 
    An appeal may be taken to the court of criminal appeals from the final judgment or order of a district court in an appeal from a final judgment of the municipal court in the same manner and to the same extent that appeals are taken from a district court to the court of criminal appeals. 
(Code 2002, § 12-151; Ord. No. 2520NS, § 51, 10-21-2013) 
Sec. 12-152. - Penalty for exceeding the posted speed limit. 
    The penalty for exceeding the posted speed limit by no more than ten miles per hour upon any portion of the national system of interstate and defense highways, federal-aid primary highways, and the state highway system, which are located on the outskirts of the city, as determined by 47 O.S. § 2-117, is set at a fine of not more than an amount as described in the city fee schedule, nor court costs of more than an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2002, § 12-152; Ord. No. 2532NS, § 3, 3-3-2014) 
Sec. 12-153. - Community service allowed as a condition of probation. 
    Whenever any person receives probation for a municipal offense or is granted a deferred prosecution, a period of community service shall be allowed to be a condition of that probation or period of deferred prosecution. The number of days of community service for any person shall not exceed the maximum number of days that person could have been sentenced to serve in jail for the offense committed. 
(Code 2002, § 12-153; Ord. No. 2532NS, § 3, 3-3-2014) 
Sec. 12-154. - Costs of incarceration. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this section, the municipal attorney shall ask the court to require a person confined in any jail, for any municipal offense to pay the costs of incarceration, both before and after conviction, upon conviction or receiving a deferred sentence. The clerk of the court shall collect the costs of incarceration. The costs of incarceration shall include booking, receiving and processing out, housing, food, clothing, medical care, dental care and psychiatric services. The costs for incarceration shall be an amount equal to or less than the actual costs of the services and shall be determined by the municipal court. The costs of incarceration shall be paid to the municipality for which the person is being held before and after conviction. Except for medical costs, incarceration costs shall not be assessed if, in the judgment of the court, such costs would impose a manifest hardship on the person, or if, in the opinion of the court, the property of the person is needed for the maintenance and support of his immediate family. 
(Code 2002, § 12-154; Ord. No. 2532NS, § 3, 3-3-2014) 
Chapter 13 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Adoption of fire prevention code by reference, 11 O.S. § 14-107; regulation of fireworks, 11 O.S. § 22-110; fire hazards, 11 O.S. § 22-113; fire departments, 11 O.S. § 29-101 et seq.; volunteer fire departments, 11 O.S. § 29-201 et seq.; firefighters' pensions, 11 O.S. § 49-100.1 et seq.; contract with fire protection district, 19 O.S. § 901.25; liquefied petroleum gases, 52 O.S. § 420.1 et seq.; transportation and use of nitroglycerine, 63 O.S. § 127 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Fire limits established. 
    The city fire limits are established as follows: Commencing at the intersection of the north and south alley in block 21, with the north line of Main Street; thence north to the intersection of the east and west alley in block 21, amended plat; thence running east along the east and west alley, in blocks 21 and 22, amended plat, to the curbline on Market Street; thence north to Ninth Street; thence east to the east side of Beard Street; thence north to the north side of lot 21, block 15, amended plat; thence east along such north side of such lot 21 to the north and south alley in block 15, amended plat; thence north along such alley to 11th Street; thence east along 11th Street to Broadway; thence south along Broadway to Tenth Street; thence east along Tenth Street to a point opposite the north and south alley in block eight, Choctaw Addition; thence north along such alley through block eight and the north projection thereof to the centerline of Santa Fe right-of-way; thence in a southeasterly direction along the centerline of such right-of-way to a point opposite the east and west alley in block 11, Beard's Addition; thence east along such alley through block 12 to Harrison Street; thence south on Harrison Street to a point 150 feet south of Main Street; thence west along alley to Santa Fe Railroad; thence west along such alley through blocks 21, 22, 23 and 24, Choctaw Addition, to the intersection of the north and south alley in block 25, Choctaw Addition; thence south along such alley to the south line of block 26; thence south across block five, Choctaw Addition, to the right-of-way of the C. R. I. & P. Railroad Company; thence in a southeasterly direction along such right-of-way to Philadelphia Street; thence south on Philadelphia Avenue to the centerline of Rock Island right-of-way; thence along Rock Island spur track on Oakland Street to the intersection of such spur with O. C. A. & A. right-of-way; thence along the centerline of O. C. A. & A. right-of-way to the intersection of such centerline of the right-of-way with South Broadway; thence south on Broadway to Oakland; thence west on Oakland to Beard; thence south on Beard to the south line of lot 20, block 102, amended plat, of the southwest quarter; thence west along the south line of such lot 20 and along the south line of lot four, block 102, amended plat, of the southwest quarter, to South Market Street; thence north on South Market to south right-of-way line of O. C. A. & A. Railroad Company; thence east along such right-of-way line to South Beard; thence north on South Beard to the centerline of Rock Island right-of-way; thence in a northwesterly direction along such centerline of Rock Island right-of-way to a point opposite the north and south alley of block 21 and north to such point of beginning. 
(Code 1986, § 7-4; Code 2002, § 13-2) 
State Law reference- Power of city to establish fire limits, 11 O.S. § 22-113. 
Sec. 13-2. - Permit inspection and revocation. 
(a)  Permit inspections. Permits shall at all times be kept on the premises designated therein and shall at all times be subject to inspection by the fire code official. The fire code official or the fire code official's designated representative shall make or cause to be made such inspection or test as necessary to assure that the use and activities for which the permit is issued complies with the International Fire Code. 
(b)  Permit revocations. The fire code official shall revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this code if, upon inspection, any violation of the code exists or if conditions of a permit have been violated or if there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to material fact in the application, data or plans on which the permit or approval was based. 
(Code 1986, § 10-22; Code 2002, § 13-3; Ord. No. 2133NS, § 3, 2-2-2004) 
Sec. 13-3. - Permits required; application; fees. 
(a)  Permits required. It shall be unlawful to engage in any business activity involving the handling, storage or use of hazardous materials, substances or devices; or to maintain, store or handle materials; or to conduct processes producing conditions hazardous to life or property; or to install equipment utilized in connection with such activities without first notifying the fire code official and securing a permit as herein required. 
(b)  Application for permit. Application for a permit required by this section shall be made to the fire code official in such form and detail as prescribed by the fire code official. Applications for permits shall be accompanied by such plans as prescribed by the fire code official. 
(c)  Payment of fees. Permit fees, if any, shall be paid prior to issuance of the permit. Issued permits shall be kept on the premises designated therein at all times and shall be readily available for inspection by the fire code official. 
(d)  Authority of permit; fees. A permit shall constitute permission to maintain, store or handle materials; or to conduct processes which produce conditions hazardous to life or property; or to install equipment utilized in connection with such activities; or to install or modify any fire protection system or equipment or any other construction, equipment installation or modification in accordance with the provisions of the International Fire Code. Such permission shall not be construed as authority to violate, cancel or set aside any of the provisions of this Code or other applicable regulations or laws of the jurisdiction. Said permit shall remain in effect until revoked, or for such period of time as specified on the permit. Permits are not transferable and any change in occupancy, operation, tenancy or ownership shall require that a new permit be issued at the rates as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 10-21; Code 2002, § 13-4; Ord. No. 2133NS, § 4, 2-2-2004) 
Sec. 13-4. - Assistance and cooperation of persons at fires. 
    Every person at or near a fire who shall conduct himself in a disorderly manner or neglect or refuse to obey promptly any order of the fire chief or assistants or who shall resist, obstruct, hinder or cause any officer of the fire department or any firefighter, in the proper discharge of his duty, shall be in violation of this Code. Any of such officers or any police officer may forthwith arrest, without warrant, and take to the police station any person so offending a member of the fire department. It shall be the duty of every police officer at a fire to keep idle and suspicious persons from the immediate vicinity of the fire and to keep back all persons who are in the way of or impeding the work of the fire department, to aid so far as possible in protecting all property placed at risk from theft or needless injury and to cooperate with the fire department in every way possible while at such fire under the direction of the chief or firefighter in charge. 
(Code 1986, § 10-50; Code 2002, § 13-5) 
State Law reference- Obstructing officer, 21 O.S. § 540; interference at fire, 21 O.S. § 1198; arrest without warrant by officer, 22 O.S. § 196. 
Sec. 13-5. - Removal of or injury to fire apparatus and equipment. 
    No person shall willfully and without proper authority remove, take away or conceal any tool, appliance or other article belonging to any fire apparatus or fire department station or anything used in any way by the fire department. No person shall willfully injure in any manner any hose, fire engine or other apparatus or any building containing such belonging to the city. 
(Code 1986, § 10-52; Code 2002, § 13-6) 
Sec. 13-6. - Right-of-way of apparatus; emergency signals. 
(a)  All drivers, engineers or conductors of railway locomotives or cars, when in the vicinity of any fire department vehicle or apparatus, when the vehicle or apparatus is on its way to or on duty at a fire, shall so manage and control such car and the motive power which moves the car as not to obstruct or delay the fire department vehicle or apparatus or any part of it in the discharge of its duties. 
(b)  All pedestrians shall clear the street in use or to be used by fire department apparatus. All such pedestrians shall remain off the right-of-way until the fire department apparatus has passed and has no further immediate use of the right-of-way for the purpose of reaching the fire. 
(c)  The drivers of all fire department vehicles and apparatus, when answering alarms of fire, shall cause the gongs or sirens upon the apparatus to be sounded upon leaving their several stations and when approaching all cross streets and street crossings and shall continue the sounding of the gongs or sirens while en route to the fire as continuously as the public safety may require. 
(Code 1986, § 10-53; Code 2002, § 13-7) 
State Law reference- Operation of vehicles on approach of authorized emergency vehicles, 47 O.S. § 11-405; warning devices, 47 O.S. § 12-401. 
Sec. 13-7. - Interference with fire alarm system. 
    No person shall cut or sever or cause to be cut or severed or interfere with in any manner any wire of the fire alarm system or other wires or apparatus established for the purpose of dispatching fire alarms to the fire department. No person shall cut or injure any pole, crossarm, bracket or other support upon which such wires rest or in which such wires are enclosed or set up any obstruction to any instrument or means for reporting any fire alarm to the city fire department. 
(Code 1986, § 10-55; Code 2002, § 13-8) 
Sec. 13-8. - False alarm. 
(a)  No person shall willfully give or cause to be given any alarm of fire, by any means, knowing the alarm to be false. 
(b)  Whoever in this city shall give or sound a false alarm of fire, without reasonable or probable cause, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount as set in the city fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city commission from time to time, plus costs. Each day of such violation is a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 10-56; Code 2002, § 13-9; Ord. No. 2534NS, § 1, 3-3-2014) 
State Law reference- False reporting of fire, 21 O.S. § 1851 et seq. 
Sec. 13-9. - Woodburning stoves. 
(a)  Permits and inspections. Pursuant to applicable laws, every person installing woodburning (solid fuel) stoves within the city shall be required to obtain a permit for the installation. A fee in an amount as set in the city fee schedule adopted by resolution of the city commission from time to time shall be charged for the permit. The permit application request shall include a diagram of the proposed location for installation along with a copy of the manufacturer's installation instructions. Permits will be issued by the bureau of fire prevention upon meeting the required safety regulations according to the manufacturer's specifications and the specifications of the Building Officials and Code Administrators International, Inc. (BOCA) and National Fire Protection Association (NFPA), with final discretion given to the recommendations of the fire marshal. All inspections will be performed by the bureau of fire prevention. 
(b)  Installation requirements. Requirements for installation shall be as follows: 
(1)  All installations must comply with manufacturing instructions. 
(2)  Installations are not permitted in hallways or closets. 
(3)  A minimum of 36 inches is to remain between the stove and flammable building structure materials. 
(4)  A minimum of 60 inches must separate the stove and any combustible materials such as home furnishings. 
(5)  For installation next to a wall, the wall must be fireproofed, and the stove is to be installed at least 18 inches or more away from the wall. 
(6)  Wall fireproofing may be accomplished by use of a one-fourth-inch stoveboard if 11/2 inches of air space is maintained between the shield. 
(7)  Flue pipe that extends more than six feet in height must be supported, and a maximum of two bends are permissible. 
(8)  The horizontal rise of the flue pipe must be at least one-fourth inch per foot. 
(9)  Any single pipe bend must not exceed a 45-degree angle. 
(10)  A minimum of at least one damper must be installed in the flue pipe. 
(11)  Flue pipe should be a minimum of 24-gauge thickness and must be accessible for inspection and cleaning procedures. 
(12)  Flue piping may be connected to the chimney with either a cement, tile or metal collar per the BOCA Mechanical Code. 
(13)  The stove must be at least 18 inches above the floor and have a fireproof pad underneath. The pad shall extend at least 12 inches around all sides of the stove and 18 inches beyond the fire door. The pad will be a minimum of four inches thick, constructed of an approved fireproof material: concrete, mortar, brick, stone or covered with a 24-gauge sheet metal and stoveboard. 
(14)  The location of smoke termination or chimney vent openings shall be located a minimum of ten feet from the lot line unless otherwise approved. All manufactured vent systems shall bear the label of an approved agency. 
(15)  A chimney for a factory-built fireplace shall conform to UL 127 unless it is freestanding, in which case it must conform to UL 737. 
(16)  All spaces between the chimney and floor and ceiling through which a chimney passes shall be firestopped with noncombustible material. 
(17)  Chimney height shall be at least three feet above the highest point that the chimney penetrates the roof and at least two feet higher than any portion of the building within ten feet of the chimney. Chimneys can be made of masonry or stainless steel. 
(18)  A masonry chimney must have five-eighths inch in tile lining. A stainless steel chimney must be double-walled with air insulation between. 
(Code 1986, § 10-27; Code 2002, § 13-10; Ord. No. 2534NS, § 1, 3-3-2014) 
Secs. 13-10-13-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Adoption of fire prevention code by reference, 11 O.S. § 14-107; regulation of fireworks, 11 O.S. § 22-110; fire hazards, 11 O.S. § 22-113; fire departments, 11 O.S. § 29-101 et seq.; volunteer fire departments, 11 O.S. § 29-201 et seq.; firefighters' pensions, 11 O.S. § 49-100.1 et seq.; contract with fire protection district, 19 O.S. § 901.25; liquefied petroleum gases, 52 O.S. § 420.1 et seq.; transportation and use of nitroglycerine, 63 O.S. § 127 et seq. 

Sec. 13-36. - Adopted. 
    A certain document, one copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Fire Code, 2015 edition, as published by the International Code Council, as it is amended and modified from time to time, be and is hereby adopted as the fire code of the city, regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said fire code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this ordinance, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in Section 13-37. 
(Code 1986, § 10-16; Code 2002, § 13-36; Ord. No. 2133NS, § 1, 2-2-2004; Ord. No. 2499NS, § 33, 3-18-2013; Ord. No. 2600NS, § 13, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 13-37. - Amendments. 
    The fire prevention code adopted in section 13-36, the same being the International Fire Code, 2015 edition, as it is amended and modified from time to time, is hereby amended as follows: 
Section 101.1 insert: City of Shawnee, Oklahoma. 
Section 109.3. Violation penalties. Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than an amount as described in the city fee schedule or by imprisonment not exceeding 60 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense.. 
Section 111.4 is amended by inserting the following: 
111.4 Failure to comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine established in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 10-17; Code 2002, § 13-37; Ord. No. 2133NS, § 2, 2-2-2004; Ord. No. 2499NS, § 34, 3-18-2013; Ord. No. 2534NS, § 1, 3-3-2014; Ord. No. 2600NS, § 14, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 13-38. - Modifications. 
    The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code adopted by this article upon application, in writing, by the owner or lessee or his duly authorized agent when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modifications when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention thereon shall be entered upon the records of the fire department, and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1986, § 10-20; Code 2002, § 13-38) 
Sec. 13-39. - Violations. 
(a)  Under this article, no person shall: 
(1)  Violate any of the provisions of the fire prevention code adopted by this article or fail to comply therewith; 
(2)  Violate or fail to comply with any order made under the fire prevention code; 
(3)  Build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved under such code or any certificate or permit issued thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken; or 
(4)  Fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the chief of the bureau of fire prevention or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed therein. 
(b)  The application of a penalty for the violation of this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1986, § 10-18; Code 2002, § 13-39) 
Sec. 13-40. - Enforcement; bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The fire prevention code adopted by this article shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department, which is established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  The chief in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed by the city manager on the basis of examination to determine his qualifications. His appointment shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service, and he shall not be removed from office except for cause after public trial. 
(c)  The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The chief of the fire department shall recommend to the city manager the employment of technical inspectors who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department, and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term with removal only for cause. 
(d)  A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made annually and transmitted to the city manager. It shall contain all proceedings under the fire prevention code, with such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein. The chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to such code which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. 
(Code 1986, § 10-19; Code 2002, § 13-40) 
Secs. 13-41-13-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Constitution reference- Firefighters' pensions, OK Const. Art. 5, § 41. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-66. - Composition; bureaus. 
    The fire department shall consist of a chief, battalion chiefs and such captains, drivers, firefighters and mechanics as, in the opinion of the city manager and the city commission, may be required to properly man the fire department. The department shall be divided into two bureaus: a bureau of fire suppression and a bureau of fire prevention. 
(Code 1986, § 10-41; Code 2002, § 13-66) 
Sec. 13-67. - Membership generally; dues. 
(a)  The employment process for the fire department shall be the same as for any other department of the city. Requirements for admission to the Oklahoma State Firefighters Pension System shall be applied in addition to other tests and requirements. 
(b)  The city will pay the annual dues of each member of the fire department which are payable to the State Firefighter's Association, provided that no such dues shall be paid without the recommendation of the fire chief and the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 10-44; Code 2002, § 13-67; Ord. No. 2534, § 2, 3-3-2014) 
State Law reference- Appointment of firefighters, 11 O.S. § 29-103. 
Sec. 13-68. - Training program. 
    A training program shall be maintained which shall instruct all recruits and members of the fire department in the various branches of firefighting and fire prevention technique, acquainting them with the regulations of the department, the laws and ordinances of the state and city affecting their official duties and familiarizing them with fire department practices, methods and the use of equipment. 
(Code 1986, § 10-46; Code 2002, § 13-68) 
State Law reference- Fire service training at Oklahoma State University, 70 O.S. § 628.9. 
Sec. 13-69. - Firefighters' pension and retirement system. 
(a)  The city adopts the state statutes with regard to the firefighters' pension and retirement system. 
(b)  The city clerk shall file on or before January 15 of each year his certificate with the state insurance department showing the following: 
(1)  The existence of the fire department; 
(2)  The number of fire engines, fire apparatus and other equipment owned and used by the fire department and the value thereof; 
(3)  The system of water supply in use in such department; and 
(4)  The number of members, with their names, dates of appointment and the dates of expiration of terms of service. 
(Code 1986, § 10-58; Code 2002, § 13-69) 
State Law reference- Firefighters' pension and retirement system, 11 O.S. § 49-100.1 et seq.; report by clerk of statistics as to fire department, 11 O.S. § 49-124. 
Sec. 13-70. - Police power; arrest authority. 
    The fire chief and members of the fire department are vested with all authority of city police officers insofar as is necessary in the exercise of their duties, and they are authorized to make arrests for interference with firefighters in the discharge of the duties of their office or for any interference or obstruction of the operations of the fire department. 
(Code 1986, § 10-47; Code 2002, § 13-70) 
Sec. 13-71. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The fire department shall be charged with the prevention of fires within the city; with the detecting, combating and extinguishing of fires when such occur; and with the protection of property and persons against damage and accident incident to such fires. The department shall aid in the preservation of order within the city and the suppression of riots when so directed by the city manager, who may grant police powers to members of the fire department. 
(Code 1986, § 10-42; Code 2002, § 13-71) 
State Law reference- Power of governing body to regulate or prohibit riots, 11 O.S. § 22-110. 
Sec. 13-72. - Response to alarms outside corporate limits. 
    The fire department may respond to fire alarms outside the corporate limits upon the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The fire department is authorized and directed to answer all outside calls within a distance of ten miles from the nearest fire station, unless such calls are from within the corporate limits of another city or town and unless, in the opinion of the fire chief, it is inexpedient to do so on account of another fire in the city, broken apparatus, impassable or dangerous highways or other physical conditions. However, the fire department may respond to calls within the corporate limits of other cities or towns if, in the opinion of the fire chief, response to particular calls could be accomplished within a reasonable length of time and no problems would arise with regard to fire departments of other cities and towns. In accepting the firefighting services of the city, the owners of the individual properties where such firefighting activity is conducted shall be contractually liable to the city for the reasonable value of the services performed by the city in furnishing such firefighting services. The reasonable value of such services is established to be an amount as described in the city fee schedule per hour for each firefighting vehicle used in connection with answering such alarms. Such contractual liability shall be and is imposed upon the owners of individual properties whether they, any of them, members of their families, fire departments of other municipalities or any other persons request such firefighting services, the acceptance of the benefits of the fire department being sufficient to establish such contractual liability. 
(2)  The city may enter into contractual agreements with other cities and towns or private organizations to give or receive fire protection, and the city may provide fire protection jointly with one or more municipalities or private organizations. However, any contract for fire protection entered into by the city shall expressly stipulate the terms and conditions upon and in compliance with which each party thereof is to cooperate in furnishing, maintaining and operating fire equipment for outside aid or mutual aid or making payment for such service. 
(3)  In answering such fire alarms by the fire department, the city shall not be liable in damages for any act of commission, omission or negligence while answering or returning from any fire or reported fire or doing or performing any such fire prevention work or rescue, resuscitation, first aid, inspection or any other official work. 
(Code 1986, § 10-54; Code 2002, § 13-72) 
Secs. 13-73-13-101. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE CHIEF[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Duties of fire chief, 11 O.S. § 29-102. 

Sec. 13-102. - Control of firefighters. 
    The chief of the fire department, subject to the approval of the city manager, shall have exclusive control of the stationing and transferring of all firefighters and other officers and employees in the fire department. He shall be vested with the necessary disciplinary powers for effective subordination to authority, faithful discharge of duty and efficient performance of responsibilities with which each member stands charged. 
(Code 1986, § 10-43(a); Code 2002, § 13-101) 
Sec. 13-103. - Law enforcement. 
    The fire chief shall be charged with the administration of all sections of this Code or any other city ordinances relating to the inspection of fire risks or to the protection and safety of life and property from fire hazards. He shall control the director of fire prevention in the discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1986, § 10-43(b); Code 2002, § 13-102) 
Sec. 13-104. - Reports of fires. 
    The chief of the fire department shall make a monthly report to the city manager of all fires occurring in the city, the causes of each fire, the name of the occupant and owner of every building endangered by fire and such other facts as may be required by the city manager. The report shall show the work performed in each case by his department and the amount of insurance carried on each building damaged or destroyed by fire. It shall be the duty of the fire chief to maintain a register, in which shall be entered the date of every fire, the street number where it happened, the cause or apparent cause, the amount of damage and delays if any in reaching the fire, together with the obstructions or interferences which occasioned the delay. The fire chief shall make special reports on any particular fire or for any particular period of time as may be required by the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 10-43(d); Code 2002, § 13-104) 
Sec. 13-105. - Inventory of property. 
    The fire chief shall keep and maintain a duplicate inventory of all property in his department, with its value and condition. He shall keep a memorandum of all the purchases and reports and shall report the information to the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 10-43(e); Code 2002, § 13-105) 
Sec. 13-106. - Working hours. 
    The chief of the fire department shall so arrange the working hours of the employees of the fire department that each employee shall work, as near as practicable, an equal number of hours per month. The chief of the fire department or his aid or assistant may, in his discretion, in an emergency or great conflagrations, require such employees for a greater period to continue on duty during such conflagration or emergency. 
(Code 1986, § 10-45; Code 2002, § 13-106) 
Sec. 13-107. - Removal or destruction of combustibles; right of entry. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department or any person specially authorized by him shall be authorized to order the removal of fences, lumber or other combustibles and the pulling down of houses, buildings or other structures at fires when, in his opinion, the public safety may require it. 
(b)  The fire chief or his authorized deputy shall have the right of ingress and egress on and into any real property within the city during reasonable hours for the purpose of discharging the duties imposed upon him. 
(Code 1986, § 10-48; Code 2002, § 13-107) 
Sec. 13-108. - Safety zones around fires; protection of private property. 
    The fire chief or his deputy in charge of any fire shall have the authority to lay off fire zones around any fire for the purpose of public safety and effective firefighting. No person shall be allowed to enter such fire zone, except under direction of the fire chief. It shall be the duty of the police to give such assistance as is necessary in maintaining such zone clear of all traffic and persons and to render such further assistance as may be necessary for the preservation of the public safety. It shall be the duty of the fire chief to establish guards around any property removed from any building on account of fire and to safely protect the property from theft or other damage until properly and lawfully disposed of. 
(Code 1986, § 10-49; Code 2002, § 13-108) 
Sec. 13-109. - Maintenance, inspection and control of equipment and apparatus. 
(a)  All necessary equipment and property for effective firefighting shall be maintained and distributed according to fire hazards. The chief shall be charged with the control of all buildings, quarters, motor vehicles and equipment used by the department. 
(b)  The fire chief shall safely and securely keep all fire apparatus, hoses and other appliances used by the fire department in extinguishing fires in the city. He shall be the legal custodian of all property purchased and assigned to the fire department for the use of the department and shall have full authority in the use of the property. He shall not permit any equipment, apparatus, tools, paraphernalia or instruments belonging to his department to be taken therefrom without a written order from the city manager. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the fire chief or some member of the fire department authorized by him to make periodical examination of all fire apparatus, including hoses and all equipment, with the view to keeping the apparatus in good working order. He shall keep a record of each examination, showing the date of the examination or tests, the equipment so examined, the character of the test or examination and whether or not the condition of such equipment is in need of any repair in the immediate or remote future. 
(Code 1986, § 10-51; Code 2002, § 13-109) 
Sec. 13-110. - Fire hydrant obstruction. 
    No person shall place or cause to be placed upon or about any fire hydrant any rubbish, building material, fence or other obstruction of any character whatsoever, nor shall any person hitch or cause to be hitched to any fire hydrant any animal or fasten to the fire hydrant any guy rope, cable or brace or back or stand any vehicle nearer than 15 feet from a fire hydrant. Any fence or other obstruction standing in violation of this subsection shall be removed by the owner or the occupant of the premises to a proper distance from such fire hydrant to admit free access to the fire hydrant. 
(Code 1986, § 10-57; Code 2002, § 13-110; Ord. No. 2534NS, § 4, 3-3-2014) 
State Law reference- Parking near fire hydrant, 47 O.S. § 11-1003. 
Secs. 13-111-13-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS OR PYROTECHNICS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Fireworks generally, 68 O.S. § 1621 et seq. 

Sec. 13-136. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Pyrotechnics means any sparkler, squib, rocket, firecracker, Roman candle, fire balloon, signal light, railroad track torpedo, flashlight composition, firework or other device or composition used to obtain visible or audible pyrotechnic display. 
(Code 1986, § 10-23; Code 2002, § 13-136) 
Sec. 13-137. - Possession, manufacturing, selling or transporting. 
(a)  No person shall have, keep, store, use, manufacture, sell, handle or transport any pyrotechnics; provided, however, that nothing in this section or section 13-138 shall be held to apply to the possession or use of signaling devices for current daily consumption by railroads or other common carriers requiring them. 
(b)  The bureau of fire prevention may, upon due application, issue a permit to a properly qualified person for giving pyrotechnic display of fireworks in the public parks or other open places. Such permits shall impose such restrictions as, in the opinion of the director of the bureau of fire prevention, may be necessary to properly safeguard life and property in each case. 
(c)  Nothing in this section or section 13-138 shall be held to apply to the possession, sale or use of normal stocks of flashlight compositions by photographers or dealers in photographic supplies. 
(Code 1986, § 10-24; Code 2002, § 13-137) 
Sec. 13-138. - Discharge; firing; sale. 
(a)  The discharge, firing or use of any firecrackers, rockets, torpedoes, Roman candles or other fireworks or substances designed and intended for pyrotechnic display and of pistols, canes, cannons or other appliances using blank cartridges or caps containing chlorate of potash mixture is prohibited. However, the city commission may permit the public display of such when they shall be of such character and so located, discharged or fired as, in the opinion of the chief of police and fire chief, shall not be hazardous to surrounding property or endanger any person or property. Any violation of any subsection of this section shall be an offense. 
(b)  The sale of fireworks at retail is prohibited. The chief of police may, at his discretion, remove, at the owner's expense, all stocks of fireworks or other combustibles exposed for sale. 
(Code 1986, § 10-25; Code 2002, § 13-138) 
Sec. 13-139. - Fee and insurance for permit and display. 
    An application for a permit for a fireworks display must be submitted to the fire code official with a permit fee in an amount as set in the schedule adopted by resolution of the city commission from time to time. Prior to issuing permits for fireworks display, plans for the display, inspections of the display site, and demonstrations of the display operations shall be approved by the fire code official. Every display shall be handled by an approved competent operator, and the person or organization making application for a permit must present a general liability insurance policy in the amount as described in the city fee schedule. The fire code official is to inspect the site prior to the event for the purpose of determining if it has appropriate access for fire trucks and equipment. 
(Code 1986, § 10-26; Code 2002, § 13-139; Ord. No. 2135NS, § 1, 2-2-2004, Ord. No. 2534NS, § 1, 3-3-2014) 
Secs. 13-140-13-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS CLEANUP AND RECOVERY OF COST 

Sec. 13-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hazardous substance or waste means any material, whether solid, liquid or gaseous in form, that, because of its quantity, concentration or physical or chemical characteristics, poses a significant present or potential hazard to human health and safety or to the environment. 
(Code 1986, § 10-91(b); Code 2002, § 13-201) 
Sec. 13-202. - Authority to abate. 
    The fire chief is authorized to clean up or abate the effects of any hazardous substance or waste unlawfully, accidentally, willfully or negligently released, discharged or deposited upon or into any property or facilities within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 10-91(a); Code 2002, § 13-202) 
Sec. 13-203. - Responsibility for costs. 
(a)  The following persons shall be jointly and severally liable to the city for the payment of all costs incurred by the city as a result of hazardous materials cleanup or abatement activity: 
(1)  The person whose unlawful, accidental, willful or negligent act or omission proximately caused such release, discharge or deposit of the hazardous substance or waste; 
(2)  The person who owned or had custody or control of the hazardous substance or waste at the time of such release, discharge or deposit without regard to fault or proximate cause; and 
(3)  The person who owned or had custody or control of the container which held the hazardous substance or waste at the time or immediately prior to such release, discharge or deposit without regard to fault or proximate cause. 
(b)  If any person undertakes, either voluntarily or upon order of the fire chief or other city official, to clean up or abate the effects of any hazardous substance or waste unlawfully, accidentally, willfully or negligently released, discharged or deposited upon or into any property or facilities within the city, the fire chief may take such action as is necessary to supervise or verify the adequacy of the cleanup or abatement. The persons described in subsection (a) of this section shall be liable to the city for all costs incurred as a result of such supervision or verification. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, costs incurred by the city shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Actual labor costs of city personnel, including benefits and administrative overhead; 
(2)  Cost of equipment operation; 
(3)  Cost of any contract labor and materials; and 
(4)  Cost of any independent contractor. 
(d)  The remedies provided by this section shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law or equity. 
(e)  The authority to recover costs under this section shall not include actual fire suppression services which are normally or usually provided by the fire department. 
(Code 1986, § 10-92; Code 2002, § 13-203) 
Sec. 13-204. - Compliance with guidelines. 
    Any person who undertakes, either voluntarily or upon order of the fire chief or other city official, to clean up or abate the effects of any hazardous substance shall do so in accordance with all local, state and federal guidelines. 
(Code 1986, § 10-93; Code 2002, § 13-204) 
Chapter 14 - FLOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Floodplain management, 82 O.S. § 1601 et seq.; application of act, 82 O.S. § 1618. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-26. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance of the City of Shawnee, Oklahoma. 
(Code 2002, § 14-26; Ord. No. 2437NS, §§ 1, 2, 8-2-2010) 
Sec. 14-27. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined in this section, words or phrases used in this article shall be interpreted to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most reasonable application. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory structure means a structure which is on the same parcel of property as the principal structure and the use of which is incidental to the use of the principal structure. Examples of accessory structures include, but not be limited to, garages and storage sheds. 
    Area of special flood hazard means the land in the floodplain within the city subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Base flood elevation means the elevation in feet above mean sea level of the base flood or one percent chance flood. 
    Basement means any area of the building having its floor subgrade (below ground level) on all sides. 
    BFE means base flood elevation. 
    Critical feature means an integral and readily identifiable part of a flood protection system, without which the flood protection provided by the entire system would be compromised. 
    Development means any manmade change in improved and unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations or storage of equipment or materials. 
    Development permit means a permit issued by the city floodplain administrator which authorizes development in a special flood hazard area in accordance with this article. 
    Elevated building means a nonbasement building built, for a building in zones AE, A and X, to have the top of the elevated floor adequately anchored so as not to impair the structural integrity of the building during a flood up to the magnitude of the base flood. In the case of zones AE, A and X, the term "elevated building" also includes a building elevated by means of fill or solid foundation perimeter walls with openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movement of floodwaters. 
    Existing construction means, for the purposes of determining rates, structures for which the start of construction commenced before the effective date of the FIRM or before January 1, 1975, for FIRMs effective before that date. The term "existing construction" may also be referred to as "existing structures". 
    Existing manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed, including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads, is completed before August 4, 1972. 
    Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision means the preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed, including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads. 
    FEMA means the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
    FIRM means flood insurance rate map. 
    Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(1)  The overflow of inland or tidal waters. 
(2)  The unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means an official map of a community, on which the Federal Emergency Management Agency has delineated both the areas of special flood hazards and the risk premium zones applicable to the city. 
    Flood insurance study means the official report provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency for the city which contains floodway profiles, water surface elevation of the base flood, as well as floodway width, section area and mean velocity. 
    Flood protection system means those physical structural works for which funds have been authorized, appropriated and expended and which have been constructed specifically to modify flooding in order to reduce the extent of the areas within a community subject to a special flood hazard and the extent of the depths of associated flooding. Such a system typically includes hurricane tidal barriers, dams, reservoirs, levees or dikes. These specialized flood-modifying works are those constructed in conformance with sound engineering standards. 
    Floodplain or floodprone area means any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source (see Flood or flooding ). 
    Floodplain administrator means a person accredited by the OWRB and designated by the city commission to administer and implement laws, ordinances and regulations relating to the management of floodplains. 
    Floodplain management means the operation of an overall program of corrective and preventive measures for reducing flood damage, including, but not limited to, emergency preparedness plans, flood control works and floodplain management regulations. 
    Floodplain management regulations means zoning codes and ordinances, subdivision regulations, building codes, health regulations, special purpose ordinances such as a floodplain ordinance, grading ordinance and erosion control ordinance and other applications of police power. The term "floodplain management regulations" describes such state or local regulations, in any combination thereof, which provide standards for the purpose of flood damage prevention and reduction.
