State Law reference- Fishing and recreation on municipal lakes, 11 O.S. § 33-201 et seq.; municipal reservoirs, 11 O.S. § 37-102. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TWIN LAKES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-26. - Designation of city-owned lakes and reservoirs. 
    The reservoirs and lakes constructed by the city on South Deer Creek are designated and named "Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1" and "Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 2," and the city's police power is extended to cover such lakes. The lake constructed in 1935-1936 situated south of the lake dam is designated as "Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1," and the lake constructed in 1960-1961 situated northwest of such dam is designated as "Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 2." 
(Code 1986, § 13-1; Code 2002, § 16-26) 
Secs. 16-27-16-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SANITATION 

Sec. 16-56. - Depositing items in lakes. 
(a)  No person shall throw into or permit to enter Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 or place, throw or deposit upon the lands and premises surrounding such waters any unused bait, worms, flesh of animals or other matters subject to putrefaction or any human or animal excreta or other debris or any other unsanitary or unsightly thing. No glass containers shall be permitted on the swimming beaches, in the swimming areas or in park and picnic areas of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. 
(b)  The police department shall be the primary enforcing agency of all ordinances, rules and regulations relating to Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. The police department, police officers shall have full power and authority to enforce such ordinances, rules and regulations, with full power of arrest. 
(Code 1986, § 13-2; Code 2002, § 16-56; Ord. No. 2361NS, § 1, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-57. - Collection and disposal of refuse. 
(a)  No person shall throw or place garbage upon the ground or the property comprising the watershed of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, and all garbage or trash shall be placed in containers and removed from the premises when the container becomes full. 
(b)  The city or its agents and servants shall cause garbage cans to be placed in all picnic grounds used by the public, and all persons using such picnic grounds shall place all garbage and refuse in such can. The garbage and refuse shall be removed and disposed of by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 13-3; Code 2002, § 16-57) 
Sec. 16-58. - Burning of trash, brush or refuse. 
(a)  No person shall burn any trash or refuse upon the property comprising the watershed of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 and owned by the city, unless it is burned in an incinerator or container to be approved by the fire chief or his designee. 
(b)  No person shall burn grass, brush or refuse upon the Twin Lakes property belonging to the city without first obtaining permission to do so from the fire chief or his designee. No person shall burn grass or other rubbish around any cabin site or upon any property under lease by the city to such person without first notifying the fire chief or his designee of his intention to do so and obtaining permission from the fire chief or his designee. Any person desiring to burn grass or brush shall notify the fire chief or his designee. It shall be the duty of the fire chief or his designee to supervise such burning, and no fire shall be started except under the supervision of the fire chief or designee. 
(Code 1986, § 13-4; Code 2002, § 16-58; Ord. No. 2361NS, § 2, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-59. - Sewage disposal facilities. 
(a)  Individual sewage disposal systems may be constructed upon such premises, but shall be constructed to conform to and meet all requirements set forth in the most recently adopted building code and all applicable state health/environmental rules. 
(b)  Functional privies are prohibited on all leased property comprising the watersheds of Shawnee Twin Lakes. 
(c)  All approved septic tanks must be pumped or inspected by a state-licensed installer or sanitarian every five years for conventional systems and every two years for aerobic systems. A copy of the certificate or work receipt or service maintenance contract along with an accurately scaled map showing the exact location of the sewage disposal system in relation to the high water mark must be provided to the city. 
(d)  Any corrective measures identified during inspection must be completed within 60 days of written notice of the violation. 
(e)  All new or replaced septic/aeration systems shall be installed 150 feet from the high water mark, or as far as practically possible, as determined by the director of community development and acknowledged by the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 13-5; Code 2002, § 16-59; Ord. No. 2302NS, § 2, 2-20-2007; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
Secs. 16-60-16-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SWIMMING, WADING AND SCUBA DIVING 

Sec. 16-86. - Swimming and wading. 
    Swimming and wading will be permitted in designated areas on Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, in accordance with the following rules and requirements: 
(1)  Swimming will be permitted only in those areas of the lake designated as swimming areas. Such areas will be marked by buoy lines, and swimming will be allowed on the beach side of buoys. Swimming on the lake side of the buoys is prohibited. 
(2)  Swimming will also be permitted by a lessee and his guests immediately in front of the lot leased not more than 100 feet from the shore. 
(3)  Swimming will be permitted only during the hours from sunrise to one-half hour after sunset. 
(4)  Swimming from a boat or entering the water from a boat, except for the purpose of skiing, sailing, windsurfing or scuba diving, is prohibited. 
(5)  Public nudity is prohibited. No person shall appear nude or shall disrobe while in any area of the lake, except in authorized areas of buildings set aside for changing clothes. 
(6)  Diving or jumping from bridges, land or other structures that cross or are adjacent to Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 is prohibited. 
(7)  All swimming shall be at the swimmer's own risk. 
(8)  All children 12 years and younger must be accompanied by a parent or other responsible adult before entering the swimming area. All children eight years old and younger must wear a regulation life preserver when in the water. 
(9)  No dogs or other animals will be allowed on the swimming beaches, in the swimming areas, picnic areas, parks or in other waters of Shawnee Twin Lakes, except as permitted by section 16-152(d). 
(Code 1986, § 13-6; Code 2002, § 16-86; Ord. No. 2097NS, § 1, 7-7-2003) 
Sec. 16-87. - Scuba diving. 
    Scuba diving will be permitted in designated areas on Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, in accordance with the following rules and requirements: 
(1)  Scuba diving will be allowed only in designated areas. 
(2)  Any person diving or submerging with the aid of any mechanical diving or breathing device or suit must place a buoy with a flag in the water at or near the point of submergence or fly a flag from a boat indicating divers are present. The flag shall be red in color not less than 20 inches by 24 inches with a white stripe four inches wide running from one upper corner to a diagonal lower corner. When flown from a boat, it must be flown from the highest point and be visible from a 360-degree circle. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor-driven boat within 150 feet of a diver's buoy, except while engaged in the rescue of a person in such area. 
(4)  Scuba divers shall not be permitted to fish or use spear guns. 
(Code 1986, § 13-7; Code 2002, § 16-87) 
Secs. 16-88-16-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FISHING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for hunting, fishing privileges, 11 O.S. § 33-201 et seq. 

Sec. 16-116. - State license required. 
    Any person wishing to fish in Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 shall possess a current state fishing license unless otherwise exempt. 
(Code 1986, § 13-56; Code 2002, § 16-116) 
State Law reference- Fishing licenses, 29 O.S. § 4-110. 
Sec. 16-117. - City license. 
(a)  Annual and daily fees. No person shall fish in the water of Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 without first obtaining a license to fish in the waters of the lakes, upon application to the person as may be designated by the city manager to issue the license and upon the payment of an annual license fee. Daily fishing licenses may be obtained upon payment of a daily license fee. A portion of the license fees may be kept by retail outlets other than the city for handling and processing the sales of such licenses, as allowed by the city manager. The amounts of the fees and the portion to be retained by retail outlets shall be set from time to time by resolution of the mayor and city commissioners. No person shall go upon such lakes or upon the land owned by the city surrounding the lakes for the purpose of fishing without first having obtained a license to fish. 
(b)  Scope of license. The issuance of such fishing licenses enumerated in this section shall entitle the holders thereof to fish at such time and in such parts of the lakes as may be designated by the order of the city manager from time to time and provided that such applicants shall possess at such times valid state fishing licenses. 
(c)  Expiration of annual licenses. All licenses issued pursuant to this division shall bear the date of issuance and the date of expiration. All annual licenses shall expire on December 31 of each calendar year. 
(d)  Form; transferability. All licenses shall be issued on forms provided by the city and approved by the city manager and shall be nontransferable. 
(e)  Immediate possession. Each person holding a license for fishing upon Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, shall have his license therefor in his immediate possession when so fishing and shall produce the license for inspection upon demand of any officer, chief of police or his designee. 
(f)  Exemption. No city fishing license or fees required in this section shall be required of anyone under the age of 16, or 65 years and older. 
(g)  Handling fee. A $1.00 portion of license fees may be kept by retail outlets other than the city for handling and processing the sales of such license fees, as allowed by the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 13-63; Code 2002, § 16-117; Ord. No. 2361NS, § 3, 6-16-2008; Ord. No. 2469NS, § 1, 1-17-2012) 
Sec. 16-118. - Kind of fish taken. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to take, kill or catch from Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 any game fish smaller than legal size, which is as follows: Any smallmouth black bass or spotted black bass shall not be smaller than ten inches in total length, nor shall any species of trout or rock bass be smaller than six inches in total length. It shall be unlawful for any person to take, kill or catch from either of such lakes any largemouth black bass smaller than 14 inches in total length. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by the imposition of a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. 
(Code 1986, § 13-57; Code 2002, § 16-118) 
State Law reference- "Game fish" defined, 29 O.S. § 2-115; bag limits generally, 29 O.S. § 6-302. 
Sec. 16-119. - Means of taking fish. 
    No person shall fish in Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 except with a hook and line with plugs, artificial bait, minnows, flies or similar devices. Trotlines and jug-lines shall be marked and maintained and have no more hooks than that provided by state law. Juglines shall be permitted in Twin Lakes No. 2, only. Trotlines are allowed in both lakes No. 1 and No. 2 in nonswimming areas and no-wake areas. Only one trotline shall be used by each person, and no net, seine, minnow seine, gun, trap or any kind of snare shall be used to take fish from such waters. No person shall take or attempt to take fish from such waters by means of a net, seine, trap, gun or any explosive, poison, chemical or other substance placed therein, Juglines shall be prohibited in Twin Lake No. 1. 
(Code 1986, § 13-58; Code 2002, § 16-119; Ord. No. 2361NS, § 4, 6-16-2008) 
State Law reference- Prohibited means of taking fish, 29 O.S. § 6-301. 
Sec. 16-120. - Use of certain bait. 
    No game fish, as defined by the laws of the state or this article, and no carp or buffalo shall be used as bait to fish in Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, and no person shall release any minnows or other bait fish in such waters. No person shall keep, place or maintain in such waters any live box or other receptacle for keeping minnows or other fish alive, except while actually fishing. 
(Code 1986, § 13-59; Code 2002, § 16-120) 
Sec. 16-121. - Fishing in connecting channel; number of fish taken. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fish in the channel which connects Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. Any person who shall violate this subsection shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs, or shall be imprisoned in the city jail not exceeding 60 days or shall be punished by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Persons fishing on Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 shall not, on any day from 12:00 midnight to 12:00 midnight, take, kill or catch more than six black bass, 15 channel or blue catfish or 25 crappie. However, the state wildlife conservation commission may raise or lower the limits provided in this subsection by an amount not to exceed 50 percent, and such limits established by the state wildlife conservation commission from time to time are adopted in this subsection. Any person violating shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by the imposition of a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. 
(Code 1986, § 13-60; Code 2002, § 16-121) 
Sec. 16-122. - Fishing from floating wharf. 
(a)  No child under the age of 14 years shall fish upon the floating fishing wharf unless such child is accompanied by his parent or other responsible adult person. 
(b)  All persons who fish from the floating fishing wharf shall abide by all rules and regulations and shall observe hours of operation as promulgated by the city commission. No more than three total fishing lines or fishing poles, or combinations thereof, will be allowed per person, for fishing from the floating wharf. 
(Code 1986, § 13-61; Code 2002, § 16-122; Ord. No. 2361NS, § 5, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-123. - Float fishing. 
    Any person who fishes upon the waters of Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 from inflated tubes and similar articles, commonly known as float fishing, shall be permitted only from 30 minutes before sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset and no farther than 50 feet from shoreline in either lake. 
(Code 1986, § 13-62; Code 2002, § 16-123; Ord. No. 2361NS, § 6, 6-16-2008) 
Secs. 16-124-16-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - HUNTING 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 16-151. - Game refuge established. 
(a)  A game refuge is established on and around Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, and the hunting and shooting of animals, fowl or birds or the discharge or shooting of any firearm, long bow, bow, arrow, crossbow, pistol, rifle or shotgun upon the lakes or upon such land surrounding the lakes which is owned by the city is prohibited, except as provided in this article. 
(b)  The hunting and shooting of migratory water fowl, including ducks and geese, shall be permitted upon Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 and upon the city property surrounding the lakes by those persons first obtaining a city permit. However, nothing contained in this subsection shall prohibit the city from designating areas as archery, pistol and rifle ranges and authorizing the use of firearms and archery equipment thereon. 
(c)  The use of any motor-driven vehicle in the game refuge at Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 is prohibited without receiving the permission of the lake ranger prior to the use of the vehicle. Violation of this section is punishable by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 13-76; Code 2002, § 16-151) 
Sec. 16-152. - Prohibitions and restrictions. 
(a)  The holder of a hunting license issued under this division shall have the privilege, upon Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 and the land surrounding the lakes, of hunting for and shooting ducks, geese and other waterfowl in such places and at such times as the city commission shall from time to time direct. Such areas of such waters or the lands surrounding the lakes as may at any time be restricted against hunting or shooting shall be designated by signs thereon or adjacent thereto. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no holder of a hunting license or any other person shall at any time hunt or shoot any game of any kind upon such waters or the land surrounding the lakes except ducks, geese and other waterfowl, and no holder of a hunting license or any other person shall use, shoot or discharge upon such waters or the lands surrounding the lakes any long bow, bow, arrow, crossbow, pistol, rifle or any other firearm, other than a shotgun. Shot used with or fired from such shotgun shall not be a size larger than number 2. However, nothing contained in this subsection shall prohibit the city from designating areas as archery, pistol and rifle ranges and authorizing the use of firearms and archery equipment thereon. 
(c)  The hunting, killing, shooting or taking of Canada geese on Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 and the land surrounding the lakes is specifically prohibited. 
(d)  The use of hunting dogs to retrieve ducks, geese and other waterfowl is permitted during the hunting season for such fowl. 
(Code 1986, § 13-77; Code 2002, § 16-152) 
Sec. 16-153. - Doves, quail, squirrels and rabbits. 
(a)  The hunting of doves, quail, squirrels and rabbits with a shotgun is permitted on city-owned land surrounding Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. 
(b)  All persons who hunt doves, quail, squirrels and rabbits pursuant to this section shall abide by all state laws applicable to the hunting of doves, quail, squirrels and rabbits. 
(c)  No person shall hunt doves, quail, squirrels or rabbits upon city-owned lands surrounding such lakes without having first obtained a license from the city. 
(d)  The license fee for hunting doves, quail, squirrels and rabbits pursuant to this section shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per hunting season. Daily license fees shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 13-78; Code 2002, § 16-153) 
Sec. 16-154. - Frogs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take, kill or capture more than 15 bullfrogs in any one day upon Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. It shall also be unlawful to take, kill or capture bullfrogs upon the lakes at any time which is not during open season for bullfrogs as declared by the state wildlife conservation commission. Notwithstanding any other section of this Code to the contrary, bullfrogs may be taken, killed or captured by bows and arrows, gigs or spears. Such gigs or spears shall not have more than three points with not more than two barbs on each point. No person shall hunt bullfrogs upon Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 without having first complied with the sections of this article relating to fishing permits. 
(Code 1986, § 13-79; Code 2002, § 16-154) 
Sec. 16-155. - Use of blinds. 
    Each person obtaining a license to hunt under this division shall be entitled to a site near the Twin Lakes for the purpose of constructing a blind, and all such blind sites shall be issued and designated by the lake ranger. Such blinds shall not be closer together than approximately 400 feet. Each blind so designated and set apart shall be used only by the person in whose name the blind is issued or his invited guests. All hunting and shooting shall be from blinds. However, if any person has a license to hunt upon such lakes by the day and has no blind available, he may shoot or hunt from without a blind, and he shall not hunt or shoot closer than 400 feet to a blind. Such blinds may be constructed in the water of either lake where the location of a blind on the shoreline is not feasible, as may be determined by the lake ranger. If the lake ranger approves a site for the construction of a blind within the water of either lake, such blind must be attainable by persons wearing waders. A location shall not be in any area where the depth of the water requires a boat or ramp to reach the blind. If a change in the water level necessitates removal of the blind, the blind shall be removed by the owner thereof upon notice from the lake ranger. Boats or other movable objects shall not be used as blinds. All blinds located in the water shall be of a semipermanent nature, stationary and incapable of being moved about. It shall be the responsibility of the lake ranger to approve sites for all blinds and the construction of blinds located in the water of either lake, and he shall not approve the construction of such blinds unless they are constructed in accordance with this section and in such a manner that they shall be reasonably safe for the users of the blinds. 
(Code 1986, § 13-80; Code 2002, § 16-155) 
Secs. 16-156-16-180. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - License 

Sec. 16-181. - Required. 
    No person shall hunt or shoot upon any waters of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 or in any tributary or arm thereof or on the lands owned and controlled by the city surrounding such waters without first obtaining a license from the city, and then only in conformity with this division. However, no such license shall be required of retired city employees or of persons who have served as members of the city commission and who have completed their terms of office. 
(Code 1986, § 13-91; Code 2002, § 16-181) 
State Law reference- Hunting licenses, 29 O.S. § 4-112. 
Sec. 16-182. - Residents 65 years of age. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, all bona fide residents of the state who have attained the age of 65 years shall not be required to purchase a license under this subdivision from the city to hunt in Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. 
(b)  Any such person shall make application to the city clerk for a permanent license to hunt in the lakes, and, upon furnishing to the city clerk written evidence of being over 65 years of age, shall be granted a permanent license to hunt in the lakes. 
(Code 1986, § 13-92; Code 2002, § 16-182) 
Sec. 16-183. - Fees. 
(a)  Any bona fide resident of the state may obtain a license to hunt upon the waters or the land owned and controlled by the city surrounding Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, unless such hunting is otherwise restricted, upon payment of an annual license fee. Such persons in like manner may obtain a license to hunt for one day upon payment of a fee, except migratory fowl, but not excluding doves, provided that no person shall go upon such lakes or upon the land owned by the city surrounding the lakes for the purpose of hunting without first having obtained a permit to hunt. The amount of the fees shall be set from time to time by resolution of the mayor and city commissioners. 
(b)  The issuance of such a license as stated in subsection (a) of this section shall entitle the holder thereof to hunt at such times and in such parts of the lakes as may be designated by the order of the city commission from time to time, provided that the applicant shall possess at that time a state hunting license. 
(Code 1986, § 13-93; Code 2002, § 16-183; Ord. No. 2470NS, § 1, 1-17-2012) 
Sec. 16-184. - Issuance; terms, conditions. 
(a)  All licenses issued pursuant to this subdivision shall bear the date of issuance and the date of expiration. All annual licenses shall expire on December 31 of each calendar year. 
(b)  All licenses shall be issued on forms provided by the city clerk and approved by the city manager and shall be nontransferable. 
(c)  Each person holding a license for hunting upon Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 shall have his license in his immediate possession when so hunting and shall produce the license for inspection upon demand of any officer, custodian, patrol officer or city representative. 
(Code 1986, § 13-94; Code 2002, § 16-184) 
Sec. 16-185. - Expiration of daily licenses. 
    A daily hunting license issued pursuant to this subdivision shall be good for a period of 24 hours from the time of issuance of the license. 
(Code 1986, § 13-95; Code 2002, § 16-185) 
Sec. 16-186. - Authority granted generally. 
    The issuance of a hunting license pursuant to this subdivision shall entitle the holder thereof to hunt at such times and in such parts of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 and the land owned or controlled by the city surrounding such lakes as may be designated from time to time by the city commission, provided that such person shall possess at such time a state hunting license. 
(Code 1986, § 13-96; Code 2002, § 16-186) 
Sec. 16-187. - Revocation. 
(a)  All licenses issued pursuant to this subdivision shall be conditioned upon the strict observance by the holders and users thereof of the terms of this article and any other ordinances, rules or regulations promulgated by the city commission for the protection of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 from pollution or contamination; all state sanitary laws; and all state and federal game and fish laws while upon such waters or the premises occupied thereby. 
(b)  A violation of any such condition shall constitute a violation of the terms of this division, and the city commission, upon conviction of any such holder or user of such license of such violation, in addition to other penalties for violation of this Code, may revoke and cancel the license of such holder. Such convicted holder or user shall not be eligible for another license until the city commission shall so order. 
(Code 1986, § 13-97; Code 2002, § 16-187) 
Secs. 16-188-16-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - WATERCRAFT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- State boating safety generally, 63 O.S. § 4200 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 16-216. - Operation generally. 
(a)  No watercraft shall be operated or permitted to be used upon Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, except in accordance with the rules in this division, which are in addition to and supplement the state boat and water rules, regulations and safety laws, which are in force and which are incorporated in and made a part of this section. All watercraft used upon such lakes shall be subject to inspection by the chief of police or his designee. 
(b)  No person under the age of 16 years shall row, sail or operate any watercraft upon such lakes, unless accompanied by a person of the age of 18 or over. 
(c)  No person shall at any time leave any child under the age of eight years in any watercraft on the waters of such lakes, except when such child is at all times within the custody and care of some person over the age of 16 years. 
(d)  No watercraft propelled by motor on Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 shall pass, with the motor in operation, by where any person is fishing at a speed greater than leaving a visible wake, nor shall motorboats be operated in any part of the lakes that may be set apart and reserved therefrom, from time to time, by order of the police department. Such restricted areas shall be designated by notice posted thereon or adjacent thereto. 
(e)  Watercraft or other vessels may be operated on Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, except in prohibited or restricted areas, in accordance with posted restrictions, including buoys, signs or markers, as regulated by enforcement personnel of the Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. Speed limits at night or under adverse weather conditions shall not exceed 15 miles per hour. 
(f)  Owners of private watercraft of all types shall not be permitted to rent their watercraft for use on the Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, or to collect fares or to take donations for the use of the watercraft. 
(g)  Any person taking part in the operation of a watercraft, in any manner, must waive in writing all rights of claims for damages or injuries sustained or claimed to be sustained against the city or against any city commissioner, city official or city employee, either elected or appointed. 
(Code 1986, § 13-21(a)-(c), (g), (h); Code 2002, § 16-216; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 1, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-217. - Procedure upon collision, accident or other casualty. 
(a)  In Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, the operator and/or passenger of a vessel involved in a collision, accident or other casualty shall render to other persons involved in the collision, accident or other casualty reasonable assistance as may be necessary and practicable and shall immediately, by the quickest means of communication, give notice of such accident to the police department after complying with the requirements of this section. The operator of a vessel involved in a collision, accident or other casualty shall give his name, address and identification of his vessel, in writing, to any person injured in the collision, accident or other casualty and to the owner of any property damaged in the collision, accident or other casualty. 
(b)  If a collision, accident or other casualty results in death or injury to a person or damage to property in excess of $500.00, the operator of the vessel involved in the collision, accident or other casualty shall file with the state department of public safety a full description of the collision, accident or other casualty and such information as the department may require. 
(c)  Whenever a person is halted by any duly authorized peace officer of this state for any violation of 63 O.S. § 4002 et seq., which shall be punishable as a misdemeanor, and is not taken before a magistrate as required or permitted, the officer shall prepare in quadruplicate, using the Oklahoma Uniform Violations Complaint, a written notice to appear in court. Such notices to appear shall be serially numbered, containing the name and address of the person, the state registration number of his vessel if any, the offense charged, the time and place when and where the person shall appear in court and such other pertinent information as may be necessary. 
(d)  The time specified in the notice to appear must be at least five calendar days after the alleged violation unless the person charged with the violation shall demand an earlier hearing. 
(e)  The person charged with the violation may give his written promise to appear in court by signing the written notice to appear prepared by the officer, in which event the officer shall deliver a copy of the notice to appear to the person, and thereupon the officer shall not take the person into physical custody for the violation. 
(f)  If the person charged with the violation is a minor, the citing officer shall ascertain from the minor the name and address of his parents or legal guardian, and the officer shall cause a copy of the violation to be mailed to the address of the parents or legal guardian within three calendar days after the date of the violation. 
(g)  Except for felony violations, any duly authorized peace officer of this state at the scene of a boating accident may issue a written notice to appear to the operator of a vessel involved in the accident when, based upon personal investigation, the officer has reasonable and probable grounds to believe that the person has committed any offense in connection with the accident. 
(h)  Any city employee or officer shall make a written report to the department of public safety if an occurrence involving a vessel or its equipment results in one or more of the following: 
(1)  A person dies; 
(2)  A person is injured and requires medical treatment beyond first aid; 
(3)  Damage to the vessel and other property totals more than $500.00 or there is a complete loss of the vessel; 
(4)  A person disappears from the vessel under circumstances that indicate death or injury; 
(5)  A person drowns in swimming to retrieve a vessel that is adrift from its mooring or dock, having departed from a position of inherent safety such as a shore or pier; 
(6)  A person drowns while swimming from a vessel for pleasure and the vessel does not contribute to the drowning; 
(7)  A person drowns after falling from a vessel that is moored or anchored for use as a swimming platform or other purpose; 
(8)  A person dies or is injured while in the act of launching a vessel into a body of water; 
(9)  A person drowns or is injured while surfing; 
(10)  A fatality or injury occurs to an operator or a crew member while participating in an organized/sanctioned race or warm-up in a vessel uniquely designed for racing; or 
(11)  Damage, injury or death on a docked, moored or anchored vessel resulting from unusual wake or wave conditions. 
(Code 1986, § 13-21(f); Code 2002, § 16-217) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 63 O.S. § 4214. 
Sec. 16-218. - Sizes and types. 
(a)  No watercraft shall be operated or permitted to be used upon Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 in excess of eight feet wide and 30 feet in length, nor under 40 inches wide and 12 feet in length, unless such watercraft is coast guard-approved and bears a certification plate. All watercraft shall be subject to inspection by law enforcement officers or any other person designated by the chief of police. 
(b)  No houseboat shall be operated or permitted to be used upon such lakes, and no license shall be issued for a houseboat, and no boat of any kind or character shall be operated or permitted upon the lakes if the boat is equipped with bunks, beds or other living quarters. No person shall be permitted to live in any boat operated upon the waters of the lakes. 
(c)  Motorized racing boats less than 12 feet in length may be permitted to be used upon the lakes if such boats are equipped with a coast guard-approved personal flotation device for each passenger and a standby boat is used in connection with the operation of the raceboat. No raceboat shall be permitted upon the lakes except under the direct supervision and permission of the chief of police or the designee. 
(d)  Speedboats may be operated upon the lakes, and they shall operate within a general area designated by the chief of police or designee. When such speedboats are operating upon the lakes, they shall remain a distance of 300 feet from the bank and 100 feet from any other boat. 
(e)  Parasailing is prohibited on the waters of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. 
(f)  Paddle boats are prohibited from the waters of Twin Lakes No. 2. Paddle boats are permitted on Twin Lakes No. 1, in areas where waterskiing is prohibited. 
(Code 1986, § 13-22; Code 2002, § 16-218; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 2, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-219. - Rules of right-of-way; speed; paddles. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, no watercraft shall be propelled upon the waters of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 at a rate of speed greater than 45 miles per hour. All watercraft are subject to existing rules of the road. All power boats shall be required to carry at least one paddle or oar. The following rules of right-of-way apply to all watercraft operating on Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2: 
(1)  When two watercraft are approaching each other head on or nearly so, so as to involve risk of collision, each watercraft shall bear to the right and pass the other watercraft on its left side. 
(2)  When two watercraft approach each other obliquely or at right angles, the watercraft approaching on the right has the right-of-way. 
(3)  When a watercraft may overtake another on either side, the passing watercraft shall grant right-of-way to the overtaken watercraft. The watercraft being overtaken shall hold its course and speed. 
(4)  When a motorboat and a sailing vessel are proceeding in such direction as to involve risk of collision, the motorized watercraft shall keep out of the way of the sailing vessel. 
(5)  When a watercraft which is underway passes a watercraft which is at anchor, the watercraft moving shall maintain a minimum distance of 100 feet and exercise due care with regard to the wake being created. 
(Code 1986, § 13-23; Code 2002, § 16-219) 
Sec. 16-220. - Safety equipment. 
(a)  Compliance with state law. All watercraft shall comply with the Oklahoma Boat and Water Safety Act, 63 O.S. § 4200 et seq., and any revisions thereto. 
(b)  Fire extinguishers. Every motorboat or motor vessel must carry at least the minimum number of hand portable fire extinguishers for its class in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Class A and Class I motorboats without a fixed fire extinguisher system are not required to have a fire extinguisher if the construction of such motorboat will not permit the entrapment of explosive vapors or flammable gases or vapors. 
(2)  Fire extinguishers must be carried in all motorboats that have one or more of the following: 
a.  Closed compartments under thwarts and seats wherein portable tanks may be stored. 
b.  A double bottom not sealed to the hull or which is not completely filled with flotation material. 
c.  Closed living spaces. 
d.  Closed stowage compartments in which combustible or flammable material is stored. 
e.  Permanently installed fuel tanks. 
(c)  Whistle and horn. Each motorboat 16 feet in length or over shall have one hand-, mouth- or power-operated whistle or horn capable of producing several blasts of two or more seconds in duration and audible for at least one-half mile. No watercraft shall be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a watercraft any siren, except authorized emergency vessels. 
(d)  Lighting. Every watercraft in all weather, from sunset to sunrise, shall carry and exhibit the following lights when underway and during the prescribed times the lights shall be exhibited as provided: 
(1)  From sunset to sunrise, all watercraft of classes A and I, as described by the Oklahoma Boat and Water Safety Act, shall carry the following lights: 
a.  A bright white light aft to show all around the horizon; and 
b.  A combined lantern in the fore part of the watercraft and lower than the white light aft, showing green to the starboard and red to port, so fixed as to throw the light, from right ahead of two points of the compass aft, the beam on their respective sides. 
(2)  From sunset to sunrise, all watercraft manually propelled or propelled by the water current shall have at hand a lantern capable of showing a white light, which shall be capable of being displayed in sufficient time to prevent collision with other watercraft. 
(e)  Life-saving devices. The following requirements for personal flotation devices (PFDs) shall apply to all motorboats, watercraft and vessels that are propelled or controlled by machinery, sails, oars, paddles or poles or any other vessel: 
(1)  No person shall use a watercraft less than 16 feet in length or a canoe or kayak unless at least one coast-guard approved personal flotation device (PFD) of the following types is on board for each person: type I, II, III or IV. 
(2)  No person shall use a watercraft 16 feet or more in length unless at least one coast-guard approved personal flotation device (PFD) of the following types is on board for each person: type I, II, III and at least one type IV PFD in addition to the PFDs required. 
(3)  No person may operate or give permission to operate any personal watercraft without a coast-guard approved personal flotation device of proper size and type, either a type I, II, III or IV, preferably a type III with an impact rating of at least 35 miles per hour, which shall be worn while such craft is in operation. 
(4)  No person shall be engaged in skiing, surfboarding or similar activity unless wearing a coast-guard approved personal flotation device (PFD) of type I, II, III or IV. Ski belts are not coast-guard approved. 
(5)  A personal flotation device (PFD) type V or type V hybrid may be used in lieu of any PFD required if that type V PFD is approved by the coast guard for the activity in which the recreation watercraft is being used or is used within the limitation of its approval. 
(6)  Children who have not attained the age of 12 years shall wear a U.S. Coast Guard approved personal flotation device of proper size at all times when they are in or on any watercraft which is upon the waters of the Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2. 
(7)  All coast guard approved personal flotation devices (PFDs) must be serviceable, readily accessible and of the appropriate size for the intended user. A serviceable PFD is free of rot, tears, punctures and waterlogging, and all straps and buckles must be attached and functional. The term "readily accessible" means that the PFD can be immediately reached in an emergency situation. 
(Code 1986, § 13-24; Code 2002, § 16-220) 
Sec. 16-221. - Reckless or negligent operation. 
(a)  Reckless operation of a watercraft includes operating the watercraft in a manner which unnecessarily interferes with the free and proper use of the navigable waters or unnecessarily endangers other watercraft therein or the life and limb of any person. Reckless and negligent operation of a watercraft on Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 is strictly prohibited. 
(b)  Every operator of a watercraft shall at all times operate the watercraft in a careful and prudent manner and at such rate of speed as not to endanger the life, limb or property of any other person and shall obey all posted speed limits. 
(c)  No person shall operate any watercraft at a rate of speed greater than will permit him in the exercise of proper care to bring the watercraft to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead. 
(d)  The operator shall keep a proper lookout at all times while underway. 
(e)  A person shall not operate a watercraft or ski within a lawfully authorized restricted area clearly marked by buoys, beacons or distinguishing devices as being prohibited to watercraft or skiing. 
(Code 1986, § 13-26; Code 2002, § 16-221) 
Sec. 16-222. - Operation or control of vessel under influence of alcohol or other intoxicating substance. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "other intoxicating substance" shall mean any controlled dangerous substance as defined in the Uniform Controlled Dangerous Substances Act or any other substance, other than alcohol, which is capable of being ingested, inhaled, injected or absorbed into the human body and is capable of adversely affecting the central nervous system, vision, hearing or other sensory or motor functions. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or be in actual physical control of a vessel upon the waters of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 and of the city, except privately owned waters, who: 
(1)  Has a blood or breath alcohol concentration of 0.10 or more at the time of a test of the person's blood or breath; 
(2)  Is under the influence of any other intoxicating substance to a degree which renders such person incapable of safely operating a vessel upon the waters of the lakes and of the city; or 
(3)  Is under the influence of alcohol and any other intoxicating substance to a degree which renders such person incapable of safely operating a vessel upon the waters of the lakes and of the city. 
(c)  Any person operating a vessel upon the waters of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 and of the city, except privately owned waters, shall be deemed to have given consent to a test of such person's blood, breath, saliva or urine for the purpose of determining the presence and concentration of alcohol or any other intoxicating substance. Such test shall be performed within two hours of an arrest and in the same manner as provided for in 47 O.S. § 752. 
(d)  Evidence that the person has refused to submit to a test as required by this section shall be admissible upon the trial of any criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed in violation of this section. 
(e)  Any person refusing to submit to such test shall be in violation of this section and subject to a fine. 
(Code 1986, § 13-27; Code 2002, § 16-222) 
Sec. 16-223. - Manner of riding in or on. 
(a)  In Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, no person shall sit or ride on the sides of a watercraft or stand in a covered bow or on the back of any seat of a watercraft or stand in a watercraft while underway, at any speed greater than idle or trolling speed; provided, however, the operator of such watercraft may stand if such watercraft is specifically designed to be operated from a standing position. 
(b)  No operator shall allow any person to occupy the front or back deck of any watercraft, while underway at any speed greater than idle or trolling speed, or any structure above the main deck without adequate safety rails or lines so constructed as to prevent such person from slipping or falling overboard. 
(Code 1986, § 13-28; Code 2002, § 16-223) 
Sec. 16-224. - Water skiing. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the term "water skiing" shall mean the activity of being propelled along the water upon devices known as skis and being, at the same time, towed by some type of watercraft and shall include the use of surfboards, ski bikes or any other device which may be used to sustain any person upon the water while being towed by a watercraft. 
(b)  Water skiing and similar activities will be permitted in designated areas on Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, in accordance with the following rules and requirements: 
(1)  Water skiing shall be prohibited between November 15 and February 1. 
(2)  Any person taking part in water skiing, in any manner, must waive in writing all rights or claims for damages or injuries sustained or claimed to be sustained, against the city or against any city commissioner, city official or city employee, either elected or appointed. 
(3)  A person inexperienced in watercraft operations or a person under the age of 18 years shall not operate a watercraft which is engaged in skiing activity upon the Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, unless accompanied by an adult experienced in watercraft operations. 
(4)  No person shall operate a watercraft on any waters of the Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1 for towing a person on water skis or a surfboard or similar device, unless there is in such watercraft a person, in addition to the operator, in a position to observe the progress of the person being towed or unless a rearview mirror has been installed on the watercraft in such manner as to permit the person operating the watercraft to face the direction of travel and be in a position to observe the progress of the person being towed. The person observing must be at least eight years of age. 
(5)  No person shall operate a watercraft on the waters of the Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, towing a person on water skis, a surfboard or similar device, nor shall any person engage in water skiing, surfboarding or similar activities at any time between the hours from one-half hour after sunset to sunrise. 
(6)  No person shall operate or manipulate any watercraft, tow rope or other device by which the direction or location of water skis, a surfboard or similar device may be affected or controlled in such a way as to cause the water skis, surfboard or similar device or any person thereon to collide with or strike against any object or person. 
(7)  No person shall operate a watercraft on the waters of Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1 while towing a person on water skis, a surfboard or similar device and leave the skier unattended in the waters in such a manner as to endanger the skier or unnecessarily interfere with the free and proper use of the navigable waters of other watercraft therein. 
(8)  While being towed by a watercraft or motor vehicle, no person shall have any airfoil or balloon device in hand or affixed to a person for the purpose of becoming airborne over the lands or waters of the lake unless written permission has first been obtained from the chief of police or his designee 30 days in advance. 
(Code 1986, § 13-29; Code 2002, § 16-224; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 3, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-225. - Personal watercraft, jet skis, ski bikes and similar devices. 
    In addition to those rules and regulations established by this division and state law concerning the operation of watercraft on the waters of the Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, operators of personal watercraft shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  All personal watercraft, jet skis, ski bikes or similar devices must be registered with the state and licensed by the city. All operators of such devices must wear United States Coast Guard approved life preservers at all times, and operators of such equipment must conform to the water rules, regulations and safety laws as apply to the operation of watercraft in the Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1. 
(2)  A person may not operate a personal watercraft, jet ski or similar device on the waters of the Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, except in those areas specifically restricted for such use. Personal watercraft are not permitted on Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 2. 
(3)  A person may not operate or give permission to operate any personal watercraft in a reckless, negligent or careless manner so as to endanger life, limb or property of any person, including the operator of such watercraft. 
(4)  A person may not operate or give permission to operate any personal watercraft without a U.S. Coast Guard approved lifesaving device (PFD) of the proper size and type, either a type I, II, III or V, preferably a type III with an impact rating of at least 35 miles per hour, which shall be worn while such craft is in operation. 
(5)  A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal watercraft within 150 feet of any person, other watercraft, dock, buoy, bridge or any other prohibitive structure at a speed greater than idle or slow steerageway speed. 
(6)  A person may not operate a personal watercraft on the waters of the Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1, unless it is equipped with a self-deactivating device or a lanyard-type engine cutoff switch. 
(7)  A person may not operate a personal watercraft equipped by the manufacturer with a lanyard-type engine cutoff switch, unless the lanyard is operational and attached to the operator, operator's clothing or a personal flotation device worn by the operator. 
(8)  A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal watercraft equipped by the manufacturer with a self-deactivating device if the self-activating device or engine throttle has been altered in any way that would prohibit the self-deactivating device from operating in its intended manner. 
(9)  A person may not operate or give permission to operate a personal watercraft between one-half hour after sunset and sunrise. For the purpose of this subsection, times of sunrise and sunset for a given day shall be the same as those officially designated by the national weather service. 
(10)  Personal watercraft, jet skis, ski bikes or similar devices operated in areas designated "no wake" shall not exceed ten miles per hour. 
(11)  No personal watercraft will exceed 20 miles per hour in areas outside the designated ski area. 
(Code 1986, § 13-30; Code 2002, § 16-225; Ord. No. 2013NS, § 1, 7-16-2001) 
Secs. 16-226-16-250. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. License to Operate 

Sec. 16-251. - Required. 
    No person shall operate any watercraft in or upon any of the waters of Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 or any tributary or arm thereof without first obtaining required licensing from the state and city and then only in conformity with this division. 
(Code 1986, § 13-36; Code 2002, § 16-251) 
Sec. 16-252. - Issuance by agents. 
    Licenses issued by the city for boating on Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 may be issued by agents of the city duly appointed by the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 13-37; Code 2002, § 16-252) 
Sec. 16-253. - Fees; special licenses. 
(a)  Any person may obtain a license for the use of a watercraft on Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, upon application to any person as may be designated by the city manager to issue the license and upon the payment in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for an annual license. Persons may also obtain daily licenses upon the payment of a fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per day. 
(b)  Persons who are watercraft dealers duly licensed by the state may obtain a special license to permit the operation of watercraft on Shawnee Twin Lake No. 1 for the purpose of testing watercraft and motors and not for pleasure or any other purpose. The annual fee for such license shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, which shall be paid upon issuance of the license. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other section of this Code to the contrary, the holder of a special license shall not operate watercraft during testing operations at a speed greater than 45 miles per hour, provided that no such testing shall be commenced until the chief of police or his designee has approved such testing. 
(d)  No fee required by this subdivision shall be prorated. 
(Code 1986, § 13-38; Code 2002, § 16-253; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 4, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-254. - Issuance; terms, conditions. 
(a)  All licenses issued pursuant to this subdivision shall bear the date of issuance and the date of expiration. All annual licenses shall expire on December 31 of each calendar year. 
(b)  All licenses shall be issued on city forms and approved by the city manager and shall be nontransferable. 
(c)  Each person holding a license for boating upon Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 shall have his license therefor in his immediate possession, when so boating and shall produce the license for inspection upon demand by the chief of police or designee. 
(Code 1986, § 13-39; Code 2002, § 16-254; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 5, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-255. - Numbering of watercraft; renewal. 
(a)  All watercraft for which a license has been issued to operate on Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, shall be numbered in the order in which the license is granted, with numbers beginning at 1 and running numerically for the full number of watercraft for which licenses have been issued, and all watercraft shall be subject to inspection by the chief of police or designee. 
(b)  Any person owning an annual watercraft license for any calendar year who obtains a new annual license for the ensuing year on or before January 10 of any calendar year, may retain the same number on his watercraft as of the previous year. However, unless such new annual license is obtained on or before January 10, such number shall be forfeited and a new number obtained. 
(c)  The annual watercraft license shall be designated by the proper tag on the port side near the bow and of the watercraft, which must be plainly visible for a distance of at least 100 feet from the watercraft. Such tag shall be furnished with the license by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 13-40; Code 2002, § 16-255; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 6, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-256. - Revocation. 
(a)  All licenses issued pursuant to this subdivision shall be conditioned upon the strict observance by the holders and users thereof of the terms of this article and any other ordinances, rules or regulations promulgated by the city commission for the protection of Shawnee Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 from pollution or contamination, all state sanitary laws and all state and federal game and fish laws while upon such waters or the premises occupied thereby. 
(b)  A violation of such condition shall constitute a violation of this article, and the city manager, upon conviction of any such holder or user of the license of such violation, in addition to other penalties for violation of this Code, may revoke and cancel the license of such holder, and such convicted holder or user shall not be eligible for another license until the city manager shall so order. 
(Code 1986, § 13-41; Code 2002, § 16-256) 
Secs. 16-257-16-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - CAMPING 

Sec. 16-286. - Campsites designated. 
    At Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, camping is allowed at 15 designated campsites at Isaac Walton Park, only. Primitive camping by scout groups may be permitted at designated sites by special permit. 
(Code 1986, § 13-130; Code 2002, § 16-286) 
Sec. 16-287. - Permit required. 
    At Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, no person shall occupy a site for camping unless such person shall possess a current and valid camping permit issued by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 13-131; Code 2002, § 16-287) 
Sec. 16-288. - Fees. 
(a)  Daily fees. Daily fees for camping at Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per campsite. The daily fee covers use of the facilities from 5:00 p.m. on the day of payment until 5:00 p.m. the following day. 
(b)  Receipts nontransferable. Camping fee permit receipts are nontransferable. 
(c)  Maintenance of receipts. Camping fee receipts shall be maintained at the campsite and available for review upon request by the chief of police or his designee. 
(Code 1986, § 13-132; Code 2002, § 16-288; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 7, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-289. - Prohibitions. 
    The following are prohibited in the designated camping area at Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2: 
(1)  Digging or leveling the ground at a campsite. 
(2)  Hanging a propane or gas-operated lantern on any tree or plant. 
(3)  Leaving refuse or human waste after departing a campsite. 
(4)  Parking a vehicle in, occupying or otherwise blocking in any manner, any campsite. 
(5)  The installation of permanent camping facilities. This does not prohibit the erection of a tent in designated areas. 
(6)  Firearms or hunting. 
(7)  Alcoholic beverages. 
(8)  Climbing, cutting or damaging trees, shrubs or greenery. 
(9)  Leaving a camping area without cleanup. Dumpsters in the area may be used for disposal. 
(10)  Subleasing a campsite. 
(11)  Parking in other than designated areas. 
(12)  Dumping sewage or effluent from sinks upon or into the surfaces of the ground or water in the campsite or park. 
(Code 1986, §§ 13-135(b), 13-137; Code 2002, § 16-289) 
Sec. 16-290. - Length of stay. 
    Camping at one or more campsites at Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 is limited to a period no longer than seven consecutive days. The chief of police or his designee may grant extensions to the seven-day limit based upon the degree of park use, anticipated weekend or holiday occupancy and recreation season. 
(Code 1986, § 13-133; Code 2002, § 16-290; Ord. No. 2362NS, § 8, 6-16-2008) 
Sec. 16-291. - Reservations. 
    Camping facilities at Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2 are available on a first-come basis. Reservations are not accepted except for special events, festivals, etc., by special permit. 
(Code 1986, § 13-134; Code 2002, § 16-291) 
Sec. 16-292. - Campsite use. 
(a)  Limits. At Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, camping is limited to no more than ten persons per campsite. Only one pop-up trailer, travel trailer or motorhome is permitted per campsite. Two tents are permitted per campsite. 
(b)  Dogs. It is unlawful for any person to allow or permit a dog to be within any camping area unless such dog is on a leash at all times. 
(Code 1986, § 13-135(a), (c); Code 2002, § 16-292) 
Sec. 16-293. - Juvenile campers. 
    At Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, no person who is under the age of 18 years shall camp, except when accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(Code 1986, § 13-136; Code 2002, § 16-293) 
Sec. 16-294. - Quiet hours. 
    In designated campsites at Twin Lakes Nos. 1 and 2, quiet hours will be enforced from 10:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. Loud noises that may disturb the peace are prohibited during these hours. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorcycle, television, boom box, radio or phonographic equipment after 10:00 p.m. within the camping area. It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb other persons in the camping areas by any loud or unusual noise, loud language or by any other improper behavior. 
(Code 1986, § 13-138; Code 2002, § 16-294) 
Secs. 16-295-16-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - LOT RENTALS 

Sec. 16-321. - Rental fee; renewal of lease. 
    There is established an initial annual lease fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for the year 2010, for each lot at Shawnee Twin Lakes No. 1 leased by the city. All persons entering into or renewing leases after the effective date of this section shall comply with all applicable city rules and regulations and all terms of the lease and shall pay the applicable rate at time of lease renewal or lease transfer. Lease fees shall increase annually on the anniversary of each lease at a rate of two percent per year, rounded up to the nearest whole dollar, in accordance with the published lease schedule. Such leases shall be for a term of 30 years. The lessee shall have the right and option to renew such lease for an additional 30-year period, under the terms and conditions set forth in this Code and said lease, provided that the city retains the right to adjust the lease rate schedule at the termination of the original 30-year lease or at such time that a transfer is approved. There is no limit to the number of times a lease can be renewed. 
(Code 2002, § 16-321; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 2, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 16-322. - Assignment of lease; sale of improvements. 
(a)  No lease entered into under this division shall be assigned or sublet, but the lessee may at any time during the term of his lease sell and transfer to other persons the improvements on the lot leased by him. 
(b)  If improvements are sold by the lessee, the transfer shall not become effective until approved by the city commission at a regular or adjourned meeting held for that purpose. The city as lessor reserves the right to reject and disapprove any transfer when, in its opinion, it would be to the best interests of the city and its inhabitants to do so. If the transfer is approved, a new full-term lease shall be entered into between the purchaser and the city, and a transfer charge in an amount as described in the city fee schedule shall be paid to the city prior to such transfer. No transfer fee shall be charged in cases where the transfer is made as a result of a trust or will or in cases where a lease has joint owners and one owner obtains full ownership rights. 
(Code 2002, § 16-322; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 3, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 16-323. - Removal of improvements; reversion to city of unremoved improvements. 
    Any individual leasing from the city shall be the owner of all improvements which are purchased or placed by him. Such improvements, including cabins, other buildings and boathouses, shall constitute personal property, and the lessee shall have the right to remove the property from the lot at the termination of the lease. However, whenever a lease has been canceled by the city, as provided by this division or such lease, the lessee or owner of such improvements shall remove the improvements within 60 days of the date of such cancellation of the lease. Upon failure to do so, the improvements shall revert to and become the property of the city. The city shall have the right, without further notice or demand, to take immediate possession of all such improvements and may enter upon the premises of the lessee with or without process of law, and such improvements shall belong to the first party or its assigns as liquidated damages for the nonfulfillment of the lease by the lessee and the use and rental thereof. 
(Code 2002, § 16-323; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 4, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 16-324. - Use of property. 
    All lots leased by the city pursuant to this division and the cabins or buildings constructed thereon, may be used for recreational or residential purposes when in total compliance with all city codes and ordinances. Premises shall at all times be kept clean and maintained in a sanitary condition by the lessee. 
(Code 2002, § 16-324; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 5, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 16-325. - Boathouse, dock facilities; liability of city. 
(a)  In addition to the possession of the property leased, every lessee under this division or under a lease from the State of Oklahoma, shall have the right and privilege of a site for a boathouse and boat dock on the land owned by the city adjoining and immediately in front of the lot leased. The boathouse shall be erected and maintained by and at the cost of the lessee and shall not exceed 30 feet by 30 feet. The boathouse shall never be used as a place of human habitation and shall be the private property of the lessee, who shall have the right of ingress and egress to and from the boathouse, subject to the rights of the public as set forth in this division. Boathouses and docks shall be maintained in good working order and shall not present a hazard to the general public or create a nuisance. 
(b)  All docks and boathouses located on arms or coves of Twin Lakes No. 1, shall not extend from the high water line (elevation 1073.5) into the lake more than 100 feet. Docks and boathouses on Lake No. 1 lease lots, which are adjacent to skiing and watercraft areas, shall not extend from the high water line (1073.5) into the lake more than 75 feet. 
(c)  Flotation devices for docks and/or boathouses shall be constructed of materials that are not corrosive and are environmentally safe for Lake No. 1. 
(d)  Docks and/or boathouses shall not be anchored to or cross over side lot lines of abutting lots. The connections of the dock or boathouse to the shore shall be constructed in such a way as to allow the dock and/or boathouse to float level on the lake during the lake's fluctuating water elevations. 
(e)  Any person wishing to construct and/or alter a dock and/or boathouse on Lake No. 1, exclusive of routine maintenance, must obtain a building permit from the city. Failure to obtain a building permit will be considered grounds for the city to terminate the lease. 
(f)  The lessee shall agree to keep such lot and boathouse and dock in a clean and sanitary condition and to maintain the lot and boathouse in a safe condition. The city as lessor shall in no manner be liable to the lessee for any damages suffered by the lessee to such lot or boathouse or dock or the improvements thereon on account of the rise and fall of the water line of the lake or for the enlargement or decrease by the city of the size of the lake or on account of any rule or regulation that may be adopted by the lessor governing the regulations of the lake. 
(g)  The lessee shall agree to hold the lessor free and harmless from all damages suffered by him or by any other person on account of personal injuries or loss of property that may incur upon such lot, boathouse or boat dock. 
(Code 2002, § 16-325; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 6, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 16-326. - Cancellation of lease. 
    The city commission may upon a showing of intentional disregard for the terms of the lease and this division or other city ordinance pertaining to the lake, cancel the city lease upon 30 days notice to the lessee by mailing a copy of such notice to the lessee at his last known address. If a lease is cancelled either by the city or the lessee of a city-owned lot prior to the expiration of the lease term, the lessee shall pay the city an early termination fee of in an amount as described in the city fee schedule in exchange for a release of liability from the remaining term. 
(Code 2002, § 16-326; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 7, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 16-327. - Renewal of lease after cancellation. 
    No lease for a cabin site at Twin Lakes No. 1, shall be renewed in the name of the original owner after such lease has been canceled for nonpayment of rentals or for any other cause, without the original lessee paying to the city a renewal fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule in addition to the standard yearly lease fee. Such sum shall be paid to the city clerk, and no renewal of the lease shall be made to the original lessee without the payment of the renewal fee. 
(Code 2002, § 16-327; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 8, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 16-328. - Inspection of lake lot septic/waste disposal systems. 
    Each septic system or waste disposal system on all leased lake lots at Twin Lakes No. 1, shall be inspected by city staff once every five years. city staff will determine whether such system is safe and in good working order in accordance with section 16-59. The inspection fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. If the city staff determines that such system is defective, the city will notify the leaseholder that the system requires an inspection by representatives of the state department of environmental quality and/or a certified sanitarian or septic installer, to be paid for by the leaseholder. The leaseholder shall have 60 days to have the department of environmental quality inspect and correct any defects found in the system. The leaseholder must then supply the city with a certificate of compliance from the department of environmental quality. Failure to correct the defects in the system within the allotted time shall be grounds for the city to cancel the lease of the leaseholder. 
(Code 2002, § 16-328; Ord. No. 2441NS, § 9, 9-7-2010) 
Chapter 17 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Police departments generally, 11 O.S. § 34-101 et seq.; police pensions, 11 O.S. § 50-101 et seq.; arrest, style of process, 12 O.S. § 51 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17-1-17-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Police departments, 11 O.S. § 34-101 et seq. 

Sec. 17-31. - Composition; powers and duties. 
(a)  The police department shall consist of a chief of police and such other personnel as may be designated by the city manager. The number of personnel of the police department may be enlarged or diminished by order of the city manager. 
(b)  The police department shall have such powers and shall perform such duties as shall be prescribed by the city manager. All police officers shall have powers of arrest as provided by law. 
(Code 1986, § 21-21; Code 2002, § 17-31) 
State Law reference- Arrest, 22 O.S. § 171 et seq. 
Sec. 17-32. - Pension and retirement system. 
    The city adopts the state statutes with regard to the police pension and retirement system, except tit. 11, art. XLIX(L) (11 O.S. § 50-101 et seq.). 
(Code 1986, § 21-26; Code 2002, § 17-32) 
Sec. 17-33. - Disposal of unclaimed personal property. 
    The chief of police is authorized to dispose of personal property, money or legal tender that has come into the possession of the chief of police in any manner, if the owner of the personal property or money or legal tender is unknown or has not claimed the property, the property, money or legal tender has been in the custody of the chief of police for at least 90 days, and the property, money or legal tender or any part thereof is no longer needed to be held as evidence or for any other purpose in connection with any litigation. Disposal of property, money or legal tender under this section must be in accordance with the provisions of 11 O.S. § 34-104. 
(Code 1986, § 21-22; Code 2002, § 17-33; Ord. No. 2375NS, § 1, 11-3-2008; Ord. No. 2535NS, § 2, 3-3-2014) 
State Law reference- Police disposal generally, 11 O.S. § 34-104; uniform unclaimed property generally, 60 O.S. § 651 et seq. 
Sec. 17-34. - Unclaimed personal property found by person other than public official. 
    Any personal property found by a person other than a public official which is delivered to any police officer for identification and which is not claimed or identified within 60 days shall, within ten additional days thereafter, if requested by the finder, be returned to the finder, and a record of such disposal shall be made. If any such property shall be sold as provided and the owner thereof shall take and recover possession of the property from the purchaser, the amount paid therefor shall be returned to the purchaser upon verified claim being submitted, approved and allowed by the proper officers. 
(Code 1986, § 21-23; Code 2002, § 17-34) 
Sec. 17-35. - Personal property of deceased person. 
    The personal property of a deceased person shall be delivered only to the next of kin of such person or to the legally appointed representative of his estate. If the personal property is claimed by the legally appointed representative of the estate of the deceased, a certified copy of the order of the court appointing such person shall be deemed sufficient authority to support the claim. If the personal property is claimed by the next of kin, the claimant shall furnish an affidavit to the effect that he is the person entitled to possession of such property; the affidavit shall be deemed sufficient authority to support the claim. If personal property of a deceased person remains unclaimed for a period of 90 days, it shall be disposed of in the appropriate manner provided in sections 17-33 and 17-34. 
(Code 1986, § 21-24; Code 2002, § 17-35) 
Sec. 17-36. - Disposition of exhibits. 
(a)  All exhibits which have been introduced, filed or held in custody in any criminal action or proceeding may be disposed of as provided for in this section. 
(b)  The court may, on application of the party entitled thereto or an agent designated in writing by the owner, order all such exhibits, other than documentary exhibits, as may be released from the custody of the court or the city, without prejudice to the city, delivered to such party at any time after the final determination of the action or proceedings; provided, however, where the action or proceeding has resulted in an order granting probation, such delivery may be made any time after the final determination of an appeal of such order or after the time for such appeal has elapsed. If the owner of such exhibit is the victim of the offense for which such exhibit is held, such owner may make application to the court at any time prior to the final disposition of the action or proceeding for the return of the exhibit. The applicant shall notify the last person in possession of such exhibit prior to such exhibit being seized by the city of the hearing by mailing a copy of the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the last known address of such person, unless such person has signed a nonownership affidavit pursuant to 22 O.S. § 1321 disclaiming any ownership rights to such exhibit. If the last person in possession of the property is unable to be served notice by such certified mail, notice shall be provided by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the property is held in custody. The applicant shall notify the city attorney and the court when notice has been served to the last person in possession of such property or published pursuant to this section. The hearing shall be held not less than ten days or more than 20 days after the court has been notified that the notice has been served or published. If the court orders the release of the exhibit to the owner, the city attorney shall photograph or mark the exhibit with an identification number and return the exhibit to the owner within ten days of the court order. The court may authorize ten days' additional time for the return of such exhibit if the city attorney shows cause that additional time is needed to photograph or mark such exhibit. Such photograph or marked exhibit may be presented as the exhibit in any further action or proceeding. If the party entitled to such exhibits is unknown or fails to apply for the return of such exhibits, the procedure for their disposition shall be as follows: 
(1)  After the expiration of six months from the time the conviction becomes final, or if the action or proceeding has not resulted in a conviction, at any time after the judgment has become final, the court in which the case was tried shall make an order specifying what exhibits may be released from the custody of the court without prejudice to the city. Upon receipt of such an order, the property shall be transferred to the chief of police or other proper governmental agency for sale to the public. At least ten days prior to such sale, notice of the sale shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last person in possession of such exhibit prior to such exhibit being seized by the city at the last known address of such person. Upon satisfactory proof being provided to the chief of police or other proper governmental agency holding the transferred exhibit that the last person in possession of such exhibit was a lawful possessor, the exhibit shall be released to the last person in possession of such exhibit; 
(2)  At any time prior to the time fixed for the transfer, the owner or any person entitled to the possession of any of such exhibits may obtain from the court an order returning them to him; 
(3)  Articles not returned to their owners or to persons entitled to their possession at or prior to the time set for the transfer shall be sold by the proper receiving agency for cash. The articles shall be sold singly or in combinations. The money received from such sales shall be placed in the appropriate fund of the governmental agency responsible for the sale; 
(4)  Where the exhibit consists of money or currency and is unclaimed at the time of the transfer, it shall not be transferred but shall be immediately deposited in the appropriate fund of the governmental agency in possession of such property; and 
(5)  If any property is transferred to the chief of police or other governmental agency pursuant to this section, it may be sold in the manner provided by law for the sale of surplus personal property. If the chief of police or other proper governmental agency determines that any such property transferred to it for sale is needed for a public use, such property may be retained by the agency and need not be sold. 
(c)  The court may, on application of the party entitled thereto or an agent designated in writing by the owner, order such documentary exhibits as may be released from the custody of the court without prejudice to the city delivered to such party any time after the final determination of the action or proceeding; provided, however, where the action or proceeding has resulted in an order granting probation, such delivery may be made any time after the final determination of an appeal of such order or after the time for such appeal has elapsed. If the owner of such exhibit is the victim of the offense for which such exhibit is held, the owner may make application to the court at any time prior to the final disposition of the action or proceeding for the return of the exhibit. The applicant shall notify the last person in possession of such exhibit prior to such exhibit being seized by the city of the hearing by mailing a copy of the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the last known address of such person, unless such person has signed a nonownership affidavit pursuant to 22 O.S. § 1321 disclaiming any ownership rights to such exhibit. If the last person in possession of the property is unable to be served notice by certified mail, notice shall be provided by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the property is held in custody. The applicant shall notify the city attorney and the court when notice has been served to the last person in possession of such property or published pursuant to this section.
