The hearing shall be held not less than ten days or more than 20 days after the court has been notified that the notice has been served or published. If the court orders the release of the exhibit to the owner, the city attorney shall photograph or mark the exhibit with an identification number and return the exhibit to the owner within ten days of the court order. The court may authorize ten days' additional time for the return of such exhibit if the city attorney shows cause that additional time is needed to photograph or mark such exhibit. Such photograph or marked exhibit may be presented as the exhibit in any further action or proceeding. If the person entitled to such documentary exhibits is unknown or fails to apply for the return of such exhibits, the procedure for their disposition shall be as follows: 
(1)  After the expiration of six months from the time the conviction becomes final or, if the action or proceeding has not resulted in a conviction, at any time after the judgment has become final, the court in which the case was tried shall make an order requiring such exhibits to be destroyed, provided that no such order shall be made authorizing the destruction of any documentary exhibit if the destruction of such exhibit would prejudice the city. 
(2)  No exhibit shall be destroyed or otherwise disposed of until 60 days after the clerk of the court has posted a notice conspicuously in three public places in the city, referring to the order for the disposition, describing briefly the exhibit and indicating the date after which the exhibit will be destroyed or otherwise disposed of. 
(d)  Subsection (b) of this section shall not apply to any dangerous or deadly weapons, narcotic or poisonous drugs, explosives or any property of any kind or character whatsoever the possession of which is prohibited by law. Any such property filed as an exhibit or held by the city shall be, by order of the trial court, destroyed or sold or otherwise disposed of under the conditions prescribed in such order. This section shall not be interpreted to authorize the return of any property, the possession of which is prohibited by law. 
(Code 1986, § 21-25; Code 2002, § 17-36) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 22 O.S. § 1327. 
Chapter 18 - MANUFACTURED HOMES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dependent mobile/manufactured home means a mobile/manufactured home which does not have a flush toilet and a bath or shower. For the purposes of regulation under this chapter, a dependent mobile/manufactured home shall be considered to be the same as a travel trailer/recreational vehicle, unless otherwise specified. 
    Freestanding mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle means any mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle not located in a mobile/manufactured home park or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park, respectively, licensed by the city or in an approved mobile/manufactured home subdivision. 
    Independent mobile/manufactured home means a mobile/manufactured home which meets the minimum gross floor area or habitable space requirement as provided in section 18-553 and which has a flush toilet and a bath or shower. 
    Inspection officer means the city inspector or authorized agent. 
    Licensee means any person licensed to operate and maintain a mobile/manufactured home park under this chapter. 
    Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, covers 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained thereon. The term "manufactured home" does not include any structure or vehicle which is owned by a religious corporation or society and is used exclusively for religious purposes. The term "mobile home" means a manufactured home transportable in one section. The term "sectional home" means a manufactured home transportable in two or more sections. These terms shall not include any travel trailer/recreational vehicle or any self-propelled vehicle used as living quarters, whether referred to as a "motor home" or by any other name. Trailers or semitrailers used for the transportation of goods or property other than the personal belongings of the owner of the vehicle shall not be included in this definition. 
    Mobile home means a single-family dwelling designed for transportation on streets and highways on its own wheels or on flatbed or other trailers, both highway and rail, and arriving at the site where it is to be occupied as a dwelling complete and ready for occupancy, except for minor and incidental unpacking and assembly operations, location on jacks or permanent foundation, connection to utilities and similar operations. The term "mobile home" shall not include modular homes or prefabricated homes that meet all city codes. Unless otherwise indicated in the text of this chapter, the term "mobile home" refers to an independent mobile/manufactured home as defined in this section. See also the definition of Manufactured home. 
    Mobile/manufactured home park means any plot of ground upon which two or more mobile/manufactured homes, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodations. 
    Mobile/manufactured home space means a plot of ground within a mobile/manufactured home park designed for the accommodation of one mobile/manufactured home, and not located on a mobile/manufactured home sales lot. 
    Mobile/manufactured home subdivision means a subdivision designed and intended for residential use where residence is in mobile/manufactured homes, exclusively, and mobile/manufactured home lots are sold for occupancy. 
    Nonresidential mobile trailer means any vehicle having the basic characteristics of either a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle, but which is used for purposes other than residential and is not being offered for sale, as indicated by a clearly displayed sign on or near the trailer. 
    Park means a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park. 
    Public water system or public sewer system means any such system built and owned by or dedicated to and accepted by the city; all other such systems are private. 
    Recreational vehicle means a class D motor vehicle, provided such vehicle is a self-propelled or towed vehicle that is equipped to serve as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel purposes and is used solely as a family or personal conveyance. 
    Rural means any area that is zoned agriculturally. 
    Service building means a building housing toilet and bathing facilities for men or women, and may also include buildings containing laundry facilities and other facilities as required by this chapter or desired by the park operator. 
    Subdivision means a mobile/manufactured home subdivision, unless otherwise indicated. 
    Travel trailer/recreational vehicle means a vehicle or portable structure built on a chassis, designed as a temporary or permanent dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation use not included in the definition of an independent mobile/manufactured home. 
    Travel trailer/recreational vehicle park means any plot of ground upon which two or more travel trailers/recreational vehicles, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodations. 
    Travel trailer/recreational vehicle space means a plot of ground within a travel trailer/recreational vehicle park designed for accommodation of one travel trailer/recreational vehicle. 
    Urban means any area not zoned agriculturally. 
(Code 1986, § 15-1; Code 2002, § 18-1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this chapter shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs, for each offense. Each day shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1986, § 15-2; Code 2002, § 18-2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Freestanding mobile/manufactured home. 
(a)  Location in urban area. No freestanding mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle shall be permitted in the urban area unless it is being offered for sale or parked for storage. Except for mobile/manufactured homes or travel trailers/recreational vehicles within regular commercial mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle sales lots, each such freestanding mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle offered for sale must be clearly marked as such, shall not be occupied for either living or sleeping purposes and must be removed from the premises if not sold within 120 days. Freestanding mobile/manufactured homes or travel trailers/recreational vehicles located within regular commercial mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle sales lots need be neither individually marked for sale nor removed within 120 days if not sold. A property owner shall not store or permit to be stored more than one mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle on a residential lot. Such mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle may be stored on a hard surface but shall not be stored in any required front yard, in an unscreened side yard, or public utility easement, nor shall such mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle project beyond the front of any building. 
(b)  Location in rural area. Freestanding mobile/manufactured homes shall be permitted in the rural area (only in agricultural zoning districts). Permits for such freestanding mobile/manufactured homes shall be issued by the inspection officer, but only when the applicant agrees in writing to remove such mobile/manufactured home within 120 days after either the mobile/manufactured home site is rezoned to a district other than agricultural or is abutted within 660 feet by a district other than agricultural. Such freestanding mobile/manufactured homes must comply with all normal city regulations, except the specific qualifications to the housing code outlined for mobile/manufactured homes in article VI of this chapter. No mobile/manufactured home parks shall be permitted in the areas within the city limits lying west of State Highway No. 102, notwithstanding the fact that such areas may be in agricultural zoning districts. 
(c)  Location on lake lots. The following shall apply to mobile/manufactured homes located on lake lots: 
(1)  All mobile/manufactured homes placed on lake lease lots must be skirted and tied down or anchored. 
(2)  The lessee must submit an approved septic system certificate of approval before a permit will be issued to place the mobile/manufactured home on a lake lease lot. 
(3)  The mobile/manufactured home lake lease lot owner will be required to submit to the city code enforcement department a certified inspection of its septic system not less than every five years and upon all lake lease lot transfers. 
(4)  Any mobile/manufactured home placed on a lake lease lot must have all required permits and have all inspections with a certificate of occupancy prior to occupying the mobile/manufactured home. 
(5)  All septic systems must be installed and maintained in accordance with the state department of environmental quality bulletin no. 600 and the city codes. 
(Code 1986, §§ 15-3-15-5; Code 2002, § 18-3; Ord. No. 2111NS, § 1, 11-3-2003) 
Secs. 18-4-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOTICES, HEARINGS AND ORDERS 

Sec. 18-31. - Notice of violations. 
    Whenever the inspection officer determines that a violation of pertinent sections under this chapter exists, he shall notify the licensee or permittee of such alleged violation. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance; 
(3)  Contain an outline of remedial action, which, if taken, will effect compliance with this chapter and other pertinent regulations; 
(4)  Allow a reasonable time, not to exceed 90 days, for the performance of any act it requires; and 
(5)  Be served upon the owner or his agent, as the case may require. However, such notice or order shall be deemed as properly served upon the owner or agent when a copy thereof has been sent by certified mail to his last known address. 
(Code 1986, § 15-21; Code 2002, § 18-31) 
Sec. 18-32. - Hearing before board of housing appeals. 
    Any person affected by any notice issued under this chapter or other regulation may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the board of housing appeals, provided that such person shall file with the inspection officer a written request for such hearing setting forth briefly the grounds for such request within ten days after the day the notice was served. The filing of such request shall stay notice of suspension of permits and licenses, except for orders issued under section 18-35. The hearing shall be held at the next board of housing appeals meeting for which the agenda has not been completed or at a later meeting if so requested by the petitioner, if the inspection officer determines sufficient cause for such delay exists. 
(Code 1986, § 15-22; Code 2002, § 18-32) 
Sec. 18-33. - Findings of board of housing appeals; issuance of order. 
    After hearing held pursuant to section 18-32, the inspection officer shall compile the findings of the board of housing appeals as to compliance with this chapter and regulations and shall issue an order in writing sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the prior notice, which shall be served as provided in section 18-31. Upon failure to comply with such order, the permit of the mobile/manufactured home park or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be revoked. 
(Code 1986, § 15-23; Code 2002, § 18-33) 
Sec. 18-34. - Appeals to city commission. 
    Appeals from decisions of the board of housing appeals made pursuant to this chapter shall be to the city commission. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city commission may seek relief in the district court. 
(Code 1986, § 15-24; Code 2002, § 18-34) 
Sec. 18-35. - Emergency procedure. 
    Whenever the inspection officer finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he may deem necessary to meet the emergency, including the suspension of the permit. Notwithstanding any other section of this chapter, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately but, upon petition to the city commission, shall be afforded a hearing at the next regular meeting as an item of new business, even if the agenda has been completed. Sections 18-33 and 18-34 shall be applicable to such hearing and the order issued thereafter. 
(Code 1986, § 15-25; Code 2002, § 18-35) 
Secs. 18-36-18-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL PERMITS 

Sec. 18-61. - Application; hearing; action by commission. 
(a)  Any person who has a special or hardship case and who desires to park a mobile/manufactured home upon property located within the corporate limits of the city may make written application to the planning commission for a hearing to determine the facts relating to his case. Upon filing such application, the applicant shall pay a fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule to cover the cost of processing the application. The planning commission is authorized to hear such application after public notice has been given by publishing notice of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation which is printed within the city, not less than 15 days prior to the hearing. The planning commission shall consider such application and review such matters as the nature of the applicant's special or hardship case and shall consider the proposed location of such mobile/manufactured home with regard to the type of buildings or dwellings within the general area of such proposed location and the relationship of such mobile/manufactured homes to the neighborhood. The planning commission may require written consent of adjacent property owners when, in its judgment, it is deemed necessary or advisable. 
(b)  Upon hearing the planning commission shall make its recommendation to approve or disapprove such application, which recommendation shall be forwarded to the city commission for its consideration. The city commission shall review the application, the recommendations of the planning commission and any other evidence it deems necessary or advisable. The city commission may accept or reject the recommendation of the planning commission. 
(Code 1986, § 15-346; Code 2002, § 18-61) 
Sec. 18-62. - Issuance. 
    If the application made under this article is approved by the city commission, the city commission shall authorize the issuance of a special permit by the city clerk for a mobile/manufactured home to be parked upon the property, subject to such application. 
(Code 1986, § 15-347; Code 2002, § 18-62) 
Sec. 18-63. - Transfer; expiration; use of home. 
    A special permit issued under this article shall be personal and shall not be transferable. The special permit shall expire upon the termination of the special or hardship situation set forth in the application. The mobile/manufactured home under such special permit shall be used and occupied by the persons so authorized and shall not be transferred, rented or leased for use by any other person at such approved location. However, any mobile/manufactured home which has been located within the corporate limits under a special or hardship permit for a period of seven years or longer may remain at such location as a nonconforming use, which use shall be controlled by the provisions of the city zoning code relating to nonconformities, as amended from time to time, and after the period of seven years it will no longer be necessary to make annual reports to the city as provided in section 18-64. 
(Code 1986, § 15-348; Code 2002, § 18-63) 
Sec. 18-64. - Annual report. 
    A person issued a permit under this article shall make an annual report to the city clerk showing that the hardship or special situation still exists. However, if such mobile/manufactured home is allowed by the city to remain at such location for a period of seven years or longer, no annual report is necessary after the seventh year. 
(Code 1986, § 15-349; Code 2002, § 18-64) 
Sec. 18-65. - Inspection fee. 
    The holder of the special permit issued under this article shall pay a fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule annually to cover the costs of inspection of the mobile/manufactured home. 
(Code 1986, § 15-350; Code 2002, § 18-65) 
Secs. 18-66-18-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NONRESIDENTIAL MOBILE TRAILERS 

Sec. 18-91. - License required. 
    No nonresidential mobile trailer shall be permitted in the city unless a license for its operation is issued by the city clerk after inspection by the inspection officer. Such license shall specify the permitted use of the nonresidential mobile trailer, the location of such operation and the termination date of the permit. No license shall be issued for a use which would violate any city, state or federal ordinance, law or regulation. 
(Code 1986, § 15-41; Code 2002, § 18-91) 
Sec. 18-92. - License fee. 
    An annual fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule shall be charged for each nonresidential mobile trailer license. However, no governmental or nonprofit agency shall be charged such a fee. 
(Code 1986, § 15-42; Code 2002, § 18-92) 
Sec. 18-93. - Use on construction projects. 
    Operation of a nonresidential mobile trailer by a contractor on a construction project for which building permits have been issued or which is otherwise approved by governmental units is permitted during the term of such construction project without issuance of a license. 
(Code 1986, § 15-43; Code 2002, § 18-93) 
Sec. 18-94. - Permanent location. 
    This article is not to be construed as permitting or authorizing the permanent location of any nonresidential mobile trailer in the city. 
(Code 1986, § 15-44; Code 2002, § 18-94) 
Secs. 18-95-18-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOBILE/MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS AND TRAVEL TRAILER/RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-121. - Supervision. 
    Under this article, the licensee or permittee or a duly authorized attendant or caretaker shall be in charge at all times to keep a mobile/manufactured home park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition. The attendant or caretaker shall be answerable, with the licensee or permittee, for the violation of any section of this chapter to which the licensee or permittee is subject. 
(Code 1986, § 15-61; Code 2002, § 18-121) 
Sec. 18-122. - Existing parks; expansions. 
    Mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks in existence upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived which have concrete pads indicating the location of mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces need not comply with those sections of this chapter which would require the moving of concrete pads. Any park expansion shall be in full compliance with this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 15-76; Code 2002, § 18-122) 
Sec. 18-123. - Fuel piping and storage. 
    All piping from outside fuel storage tanks or cylinders to mobile/manufactured homes shall be of acceptable material as determined by the inspection officer and shall be permanently installed and securely fastened in place. All fuel storage tanks or cylinders shall be securely fastened in place and shall not be located inside or beneath the mobile/manufactured home or less than five feet from any mobile/manufactured home exit. 
(Code 1986, § 15-62; Code 2002, § 18-123) 
Secs. 18-124-18-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-151. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, maintain or operate any mobile/manufactured home park or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park within the city limits unless he holds a valid license issued annually by the city clerk in the name of such person for the specific mobile/manufactured home park. 
(b)  An application shall be made to the city clerk who, acting jointly with the inspection officer, shall issue a license upon compliance by the applicant with all pertinent sections of this chapter and other city ordinances and regulations. Every person holding such a license shall notify the city clerk in writing within 24 hours after having sold, transferred, given away or otherwise disposed of interest in or control of any mobile/manufactured home park. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such mobile/manufactured home park or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-77; Code 2002, § 18-151) 
Sec. 18-152. - Application for original and renewal licenses. 
(a)  An application for an original license required under this division shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, and accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the application and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The interest of the applicant in and the location and legal description of the park; 
(3)  A complete plan of the park showing compliance with all applicable sections of this chapter and regulations promulgated under this chapter; and 
(4)  Such further information as may be requested by the inspection officer. 
(b)  Application for a renewal of the license shall be made in writing by the holder of the license and shall contain the following: 
(1)  Any change in the information submitted since the time the original license was issued or the latest renewal granted; and 
(2)  Other information requested by the inspection officer. 
(Code 1986, § 15-78; Code 2002, § 18-152) 
Sec. 18-153. - Plan of park. 
    A complete plan, for the purpose of obtaining a license to be issued under this division, shall show the following: 
(1)  The area and dimensions of the tract of land; 
(2)  The number, location and size of all mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces; 
(3)  The location and width of roadways, walkways, buffer strips and recreational areas; 
(4)  The location of service buildings and other proposed structures; 
(5)  The location and size of utility lines and treatment facilities; and 
(6)  Plans and specifications of all buildings and other improvements constructed or to be constructed within the park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-79; Code 2002, § 18-153) 
Sec. 18-154. - Fees. 
    The city clerk shall charge and collect for each mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park an initial license fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for up to 30 spaces and a fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per space for all over 30 spaces. The initial license shall expire one year from the date of issue, unless renewed upon such conditions as the city commission may by ordinance direct. The annual renewal fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per space. 
(Code 1986, § 15-82; Code 2002, § 18-154) 
Sec. 18-155. - Posting. 
    The license certificate issued under this division shall be conspicuously posted in the office or on the premises of the mobile/manufactured home park or the travel trailer/recreational vehicle park at all times. 
(Code 1986, § 15-83; Code 2002, § 18-155) 
Sec. 18-156. - Notice of violation; compliance. 
    Whenever the inspection officer finds conditions existing in violation of this chapter or of any regulation adopted pursuant to this chapter, he shall give notice in writing to the person to whom the license was issued that, unless such conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in the notice, the license will be suspended. At the end of such period, not to exceed 90 days, the inspection officer shall reinspect the park and, if such conditions or practices have not been corrected, he shall suspend the license and give notice in writing of such suspension to the person to whom the license was issued. Upon receipt of notice of suspension, such person shall cease operation of such park except as provided in section 18-32. 
(Code 1986, § 15-80; Code 2002, § 18-156) 
Sec. 18-157. - Hearing following denial or suspension or receipt of notice to correct violation. 
    Any person whose license issued under this division has been denied or suspended or who has received notice from the inspection officer that his license will be suspended unless certain conditions or practices at the park are corrected may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city commission. However, when no petition for such hearing shall have been filed within ten days following the day on which notice of suspension was served, such license shall be deemed to have been automatically revoked at the expiration of the ten-day period. 
(Code 1986, § 15-81; Code 2002, § 18-157) 
Secs. 18-158-18-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 18-186. - Purpose. 
    The inspection officer is authorized and directed to make inspections to determine the condition of mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks located within the city, in order to perform his duty of safeguarding the health and safety of occupants of mobile/manufactured home parks and of the general public. 
(Code 1986, § 15-96; Code 2002, § 18-186) 
Sec. 18-187. - Outside premises of private or public property. 
    The inspection officer shall have the power to inspect the outside premises of private or public property for the purposes of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this chapter or of regulations promulgated under this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 15-97; Code 2002, § 18-187) 
Sec. 18-188. - Register of mobile/manufactured homes and occupants. 
    The inspection officer shall have the power to inspect the register containing a record of all mobile/manufactured homes and occupants using the park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-98; Code 2002, § 18-188) 
Sec. 18-189. - Access of owner for repairs. 
    It shall be the duty of every occupant of a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park to give the owner thereof or his agent or employee access to any part of such park or its premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this chapter or with any lawful order issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 15-99; Code 2002, § 18-189) 
Secs. 18-190-18-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REGISTRATION OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS OF MOBILE/MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAVEL TRAILERS/RECREATIONAL VEHICLES 

Sec. 18-216. - Information in register. 
    Each licensee under this article shall keep a register containing a record of all mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle owners and occupants located within the park. The register shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or occupant of each mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle and motor vehicle by which it is towed; 
(2)  The make, model, year and license of each mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle and motor vehicle; 
(3)  The state, territory or country issuing such license; 
(4)  The date of arrival and of departure of each mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle; and 
(5)  Whether or not each mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle is a dependent or independent mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 15-111; Code 2002, § 18-216) 
Sec. 18-217. - Inspection of register. 
    The mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall keep the register available for inspection at all times by law enforcement officers, inspection officers and other officials whose duties necessitate acquisition of the information contained in the register. The register record of each occupant registered shall not be destroyed for a period of one year following the date of departure of the registrant from the park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-112; Code 2002, § 18-217) 
Secs. 18-218-18-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LOCATION, SPACE AND GENERAL LAYOUT 

Sec. 18-246. - Types of parks. 
(a)  Under this article, parks shall be of three types as follows: 
(1)  Mobile/manufactured home parks; 
(2)  Travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks; and 
(3)  Mixed mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks. 
(b)  No travel trailer/recreational vehicle shall be located in a mobile/manufactured home park. No mobile/manufactured home shall be located in a travel trailer/recreational vehicle park. In a mixed park, separate areas shall be reserved for mobile/manufactured homes and for travel trailers/recreational vehicles; no mobile/manufactured home shall be permitted in the travel sector; no travel trailer/recreational vehicle shall be permitted in the mobile/manufactured home sector. 
(Code 1986, § 15-126; Code 2002, § 18-246) 
Sec. 18-247. - Drainage of site. 
    Every mobile/manufactured home park shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded to ensure rapid drainage and free from stagnant pools of water. Drainage shall not endanger any water supply. 
(Code 1986, § 15-127; Code 2002, § 18-247) 
Sec. 18-248. - Minimum area. 
    The minimum area of any mobile/manufactured home park shall be five acres. However, parks in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may continue to operate with less than five acres. However, if the park is to be expanded, it must at that time have a minimum of five acres. 
(Code 1986, § 15-128; Code 2002, § 18-248) 
Sec. 18-249. - Intensity of development. 
    Intensity of development for a mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be limited to no more than ten mobile/manufactured homes per gross acre for a mobile/manufactured home park and no more than 15 travel trailers/recreational vehicles per gross acre for a travel trailer/recreational vehicle park. The area used for sewage treatment facilities shall not be included in density computations. Mobile/manufactured home spaces shall be at least 30 feet wide where pads are closest to driveways. Travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces shall be at least 25 feet wide where travel trailers/recreational vehicles are located closest to the driveway. 
(Code 1986, § 15-129; Code 2002, § 18-249) 
Sec. 18-250. - Spaces generally. 
    Every mobile/manufactured home space and travel trailer/recreational vehicle space shall be clearly defined. Mobile/manufactured homes and travel trailers/recreational vehicles shall be parked in such spaces that, at the nearest point, they shall be ten feet from the service road, five feet from the rear lot line and at least ten feet from any other mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 15-130; Code 2002, § 18-250) 
Sec. 18-251. - Distance of mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle from street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to locate a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle less than 25 feet from any public street or highway right-of-way or so that any part of such mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle will obstruct any roadway or walkway of such park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-131; Code 2002, § 18-251) 
Sec. 18-252. - Occupancy of designated spaces. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a mobile/manufactured home to occupy a travel trailer/recreational vehicle space, a travel trailer/recreational vehicle to occupy a mobile/manufactured home space and for any mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle to be located in a park unless in a designated mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle space. 
(Code 1986, § 15-132; Code 2002, § 18-252) 
Sec. 18-253. - Abutting driveway to mobile/manufactured home space. 
    All mobile/manufactured home spaces shall abut upon a sealed-surface driveway of not less than 20 feet in width if on-street parking is prohibited and 26 feet in width if on-street parking is permitted on one side of the street only. Driveways must have unobstructed access to a public street or highway. 
(Code 1986, § 15-133; Code 2002, § 18-253) 
Sec. 18-254. - Parking. 
(a)  In a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park existing at the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, parking on or adjacent to the street within the park is permissible as long as it does not obstruct free movement of traffic. Whether or not a safety hazard exists is a question to be determined by the inspection officer with final appeal to the city commission. If, upon final appeal before the city commission, it is determined by the commission that a safety hazard does in fact exist, the mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park concerned will be required to comply with subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  In new mobile/manufactured home parks, at least two clearly defined parking spaces will be provided for each space either on or adjacent to the space. In new travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks, at least one parking space shall be provided for each space either on or adjacent to the space. 
(Code 1986, § 15-134; Code 2002, § 18-254) 
Sec. 18-255. - Clothes drying facilities. 
    Outside drying spaces or other clothes drying facilities shall be provided in every mobile/manufactured home park or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park. Mobile/manufactured home parks shall have at least 100 linear feet of clothes drying line or one mechanical clothes drying unit in good condition; mechanical units shall be located in a service building. Travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks and mixed parks shall have at least 25 linear feet of outdoor clothes drying line for each travel trailer/recreational vehicle space or one mechanical clothes drying unit for the first ten travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces or any fraction thereof and an additional unit for each ten additional travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces or any fraction thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 15-135; Code 2002, § 18-255) 
Sec. 18-256. - Composition of driveways, walkways. 
    All driveways and walkways within a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be at least asphalt-oil-rock sealed surface. 
(Code 1986, § 15-136; Code 2002, § 18-256) 
Sec. 18-257. - Ingress and egress. 
    In the urban area, new mobile/manufactured home parks should abut and have their major means of ingress and egress on at least a minor arterial street. Travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks and mixed parks in the urban area shall abut and have their major means of ingress and egress on at least a principal arterial street. 
(Code 1986, § 15-137; Code 2002, § 18-257) 
Sec. 18-258. - Buffer planting strip along certain boundaries. 
    All mobile/manufactured home parks shall have and maintain a buffer planting strip, not less than three feet in width, along all park boundaries not bordering a street. Such strip shall consist of not less than one row of shrubs, spaced not more than eight feet apart, which grow to a height of five feet or more in one full growing season and which will eventually grow to a height of not less than 12 feet. 
(Code 1986, § 15-138; Code 2002, § 18-258) 
Secs. 18-259-18-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SERVICE BUILDINGS FOR TRAVEL TRAILER/RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS 

Sec. 18-286. - Required. 
(a)  Each travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be provided with at least one service building adequately equipped with flush-type toilet fixtures and other sanitary facilities as required in this chapter. No service building shall contain less than one toilet for females, one toilet for males, one lavatory and shower or bathtub for each sex and one laundry tray. 
(b)  All sanitary facilities required by section 18-288 shall be located in service buildings. 
(Code 1986, § 15-151; Code 2002, § 18-286) 
Sec. 18-287. - Requirements. 
    Service buildings in a travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall: 
(1)  Be located 25 feet or more from any travel trailer/recreational vehicle space; 
(2)  Be of permanent construction and adequately lighted; 
(3)  Be of moisture-resistant material, to permit frequent washing and cleansing; 
(4)  Have adequate heating facilities to maintain a temperature of 70 degrees Fahrenheit during cold weather and to supply adequate hot water during times of peak demands; and 
(5)  Have all rooms well ventilated, with all openings effectively screened. 
(Code 1986, § 15-154; Code 2002, § 18-287) 
Sec. 18-288. - Sanitary facilities. 
    Each park accommodating travel trailers/recreational vehicles shall provide the following: 
(1)  Toilet facilities for males shall consist of not less than two flush toilets and one urinal for the first ten travel trailers/recreational vehicles or fraction thereof and, for travel trailers/recreational vehicles in excess of ten, not less than one additional flush toilet and one additional urinal for every ten additional travel trailers/recreational vehicles or fractional number thereof. 
(2)  Toilet facilities for females shall consist of not less than two flush toilets for the first six travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces or any less number thereof and, for travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces in excess of six, not less than one additional flush toilet for every ten additional travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces in excess of six or fractional number thereof. 
(3)  Each sex shall be provided with not less than two lavatories and two showers or bathtubs with individual dressing accommodations for the first ten travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces or any less number thereof and, for travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces in excess of ten, not less than one additional lavatory and one additional shower or bathtub with individual dressing accommodations for every ten additional travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces or fractional number thereof. 
(4)  Each toilet for females and each shower or bathtub with individual dressing accommodations for females shall be in a private compartment or stall. 
(5)  The toilet and other sanitation facilities for males and females shall be either separate buildings or shall be separated, if in the same building, by a soundproof wall. 
(6)  There shall be provided in a separate compartment or stall not less than one flush toilet bowl receptacle for emptying bedpans and other containers of human excreta or a slop sink with at least a three-inch trap and an adequate supply of hot running water for cleaning such bedpans or containers. 
(Code 1986, § 15-152; Code 2002, § 18-288) 
Sec. 18-289. - Maximum distance from trailer spaces. 
    Travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces in a travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall not be more than 200 feet from a service building. 
(Code 1986, § 15-153; Code 2002, § 18-289) 
Sec. 18-290. - Laundry facilities. 
    Laundry facilities in a travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be provided in the ratio of one laundry unit to every 30 travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces and shall be in a separate soundproof room of a service building or in a separate building. A laundry shall consist of not less than one laundry tub and one clothes washing machine. 
(Code 1986, § 15-155; Code 2002, § 18-290) 
Sec. 18-291. - Maintenance of service buildings and grounds. 
    All service buildings and the grounds of the travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be maintained in a clean, sightly condition and kept free of any condition that will menace the health of any occupant or the public. 
(Code 1986, § 15-156; Code 2002, § 18-291) 
Secs. 18-292-18-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 18-321. - Discharge of waste from service and other buildings. 
    Waste from showers, bathtubs, flush toilets, urinals, lavatories, slop sinks and laundries in service and other buildings within the mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be discharged into a public sewer and disposal plant, septic tank system or private sewer and lagoon system of such construction and in such manner as approved by the state health department and in accordance with all applicable sections of this Code and other city ordinances. 
(Code 1986, § 15-171; Code 2002, § 18-321) 
Sec. 18-322. - Sewer connection at each space. 
    Each mobile/manufactured home space shall be provided with at least a three-inch sewer connection at least four inches above the surface of the ground. The sewer connection should be protected by a concrete collar at least four inches thick and with a minimum outside diameter of 24 inches. The sewer connection shall be fitted with a standard ferrule and close nipple and provided with a screw cap. The connection between the mobile/manufactured home drain and the sewer must be watertight and self-draining. Mobile/manufactured homes with fixtures from which backsiphonage may occur shall not be connected to the park's water system until the defect has been corrected. 
(Code 1986, § 15-172; Code 2002, § 18-322) 
Sec. 18-323. - Connection to public sewer system. 
    If a public sewer system is or becomes available within 300 feet of a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park, a connection must be made to the public system within 180 days. 
(Code 1986, § 15-173; Code 2002, § 18-323) 
Sec. 18-324. - Sewage treatment facilities. 
    The design of private sewage treatment facilities shall be based on the maximum capacity of the mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park. Effluents from sewage treatment facilities shall not be discharged into the watershed of the Shawnee Twin Lakes or into any other waters of the state. The disposal facilities shall be located where they will not create a nuisance or health hazard to the mobile/manufactured home park or to the owner or occupant or any adjacent property. The state health department must approve the type of treatment proposed and the design of any disposal facilities and sewer systems prior to construction. 
(Code 1986, § 15-174; Code 2002, § 18-324) 
Sec. 18-325. - Dumping of accumulated waste. 
    Every mobile/manufactured home occupying a mobile/manufactured home park space shall tie into the park sewer system and shall dump any accumulated waste into the system. Every travel trailer/recreational vehicle shall dump any accumulated waste into a receptacle provided in the travel trailer/recreational vehicle park upon entering and upon leaving the park. Such receptacles must be approved by the state health department. Any other dumping of accumulated waste within the city is prohibited. 
(Code 1986, § 15-175; Code 2002, § 18-325) 
Sec. 18-326. - Monthly sewerage charge. 
    The monthly sewerage charge shall be based on the maximum mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle capacity of the park. The park operator shall, by the tenth of each month, notify the city clerk of the maximum number of mobile/manufactured home spaces in use at any time during the previous month. The city clerk shall then adjust the sewerage fee to the actual use of the park. If the park operator fails to notify the city clerk of the prior month's actual usage of trailer or mobile/manufactured home spaces, the sewerage fee shall be levied on the maximum capacity of the park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-176; Code 2002, § 18-326) 
Sec. 18-327. - Condition of sewer connections. 
    Sewer connections in a mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park shall be watertight. The park licensee shall maintain trailer and mobile/manufactured home connections to sewer and water systems in good condition and shall be responsible that there is no sewage or water leakage on park premises. 
(Code 1986, § 15-177; Code 2002, § 18-327) 
Sec. 18-328. - Sewer connections to travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces. 
    No sewer connections shall be made to travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces. 
(Code 1986, § 15-178; Code 2002, § 18-328) 
Secs. 18-329-18-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - WATER SUPPLY FOR MOBILE/MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS 

Sec. 18-356. - Use of public or private source of water. 
    An accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of water shall be provided in each mobile/manufactured home park, capable of furnishing a maximum of 250 gallons per day per mobile/manufactured home space. Where a public supply of water of such quality is available within 300 feet or becomes available within 300 feet, a connection shall be made thereto, and its supply shall be used exclusively. Where private water supplies must be developed, the inspection officer must approve the location, construction and development of both the water well and pipe system and connections. No private source other than a water well shall be used. 
(Code 1986, § 15-191; Code 2002, § 18-356) 
Sec. 18-357. - Connections to buildings and spaces. 
    The water system of the mobile/manufactured home park shall be connected by pipes to all buildings and all mobile/manufactured home spaces, storage buildings excepted. Each mobile/manufactured home shall be provided with a cold water tap at least four inches above the ground. An adequate supply of hot water shall be provided at all times in the service buildings for all bathing, washing, cleansing and laundry facilities. 
(Code 1986, § 15-192; Code 2002, § 18-357) 
Sec. 18-358. - Construction and maintenance of water piping. 
    All water piping in a mobile/manufactured home park shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with state and local law. The water piping system shall not be connected with nonpotable or questionable water supplies, and the system shall be protected against the hazards of backflow or backsiphonage. All water connections shall be weathertight. 
(Code 1986, § 15-193; Code 2002, § 18-358) 
Sec. 18-359. - Drinking fountains. 
    Where drinking fountains are provided for public use in a mobile/manufactured home park, they shall be of a type and in locations approved by the inspection officer. 
(Code 1986, § 15-194; Code 2002, § 18-359) 
Sec. 18-360. - Individual water service connections. 
    Individual water service connections which are provided for direct use by mobile/manufactured homes or travel trailers/recreational vehicles shall be of such construction that they will not be damaged by the parking of such mobile/manufactured homes or travel trailers/recreational vehicles. The park system shall be adequate to provide 20 pounds per square inch of pressure at all mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle connections. 
(Code 1986, § 15-195; Code 2002, § 18-360) 
Sec. 18-361. - Water supply to travel trailer/recreational vehicle space. 
    Provision shall be made within 150 feet of each travel trailer/recreational vehicle space to supply water for travel trailer/recreational vehicle reservoirs. 
(Code 1986, § 15-196; Code 2002, § 18-361) 
Sec. 18-362. - Location of pumping machinery and pipes. 
    In a mobile/manufactured home park, no well casing, pumps, pumping machinery or suction pipes shall be located in any pit, room or space extending below ground level or in any room or space above ground which is walled in or otherwise enclosed, unless such room, whether above or below ground, has free drainage by gravity to the surface. All floors shall be watertight and sloped from the pump pedestal to the drain, and floors shall extend at least two feet from the well in all directions. The pedestal shall not be less than 12 inches above the floor. This shall not be construed as prohibiting submersible pumps. 
(Code 1986, § 15-197; Code 2002, § 18-362) 
Sec. 18-363. - Requirements for water storage reservoirs. 
    All water storage reservoirs in a mobile/manufactured home park shall be watertight and constructed of impervious material. All overflows and vents of such reservoirs shall be effectively screened. Open reservoirs are prohibited. Manholes shall be constructed with overlapping covers, so as to prevent the entrance of contaminated material. Overflow pipes from a reservoir shall not connect to any pipe in which sewage or polluted water may back up. 
(Code 1986, § 15-198; Code 2002, § 18-363) 
Sec. 18-364. - Installation of stopcocks and wastecocks. 
    Underground stopcocks and wastecocks shall not be installed on any connection in a mobile/manufactured home park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-199; Code 2002, § 18-364) 
Sec. 18-365. - Water wells drawing water from sands reserved to city. 
    Under this article, no water well shall draw water from any sands reserved to the city for its use, except as may be otherwise permitted by this Code or city ordinances. 
(Code 1986, § 15-200; Code 2002, § 18-365) 
Sec. 18-366. - Water connection to travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces. 
    No water connections shall be made to travel trailer/recreational vehicle spaces. 
(Code 1986, § 15-201; Code 2002, § 18-366) 
Secs. 18-367-18-395. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - REFUSE DISPOSAL FOR MOBILE/MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS 

Sec. 18-396. - Sanitary and safety conditions. 
    The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the mobile/manufactured home park shall be so managed as to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect-breeding areas, accident, fire hazards or air pollution. 
(Code 1986, § 15-226; Code 2002, § 18-396) 
Sec. 18-397. - Storage of refuse in proper containers. 
    All refuse shall be stored in flytight, watertight, rodentproof containers, which shall be located within 150 feet of any mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle space. Containers shall be provided in sufficient numbers and capacity to properly store all refuse. 
(Code 1986, § 15-227; Code 2002, § 18-397) 
Sec. 18-398. - Racks or holders for refuse containers. 
    In a mobile/manufactured home park, racks or holders shall be provided for all refuse containers. Such container racks or holders shall be so designed as to prevent containers from being tipped, to minimize spillage and container deterioration and to facilitate cleaning around them. Lids for containers shall be permanently connected to racks or holders with chains or other flexible materials. 
(Code 1986, § 15-228; Code 2002, § 18-398) 
Sec. 18-399. - Municipal or private collection. 
    Under this article, all refuse shall be collected at least once weekly or as otherwise required by the inspection officer. Where municipal garbage collection is not available, the mobile/manufactured home park operator shall either employ a private agency or provide this service. All refuse shall be collected and transported in covered vehicles or covered containers. 
(Code 1986, § 15-229; Code 2002, § 18-399) 
Sec. 18-400. - Burial or transporting of refuse. 
    Where a municipal or private disposal service is not available, the mobile/manufactured home park operator shall dispose of refuse by burial or by transporting to a site approved by the state health department. Refuse shall be buried only at locations and by methods approved by the state health department and in accordance with this code and city ordinances and state health department regulations. 
(Code 1986, § 15-230; Code 2002, § 18-400) 
Sec. 18-401. - Use of city disposal service. 
    When a municipal refuse disposal service is available for a mobile/manufactured home park, it must be used. 
(Code 1986, § 15-231; Code 2002, § 18-401) 
Secs. 18-402-18-430. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - INSECT AND RODENT CONTROL 

Sec. 18-431. - Measures for control generally. 
(a)  Insect and rodent control measures to safeguard public health, as required by the inspection officer, shall be applied in the mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle park. 
(b)  The inspection officer may require the park operator to take suitable measures to control other insects and obnoxious weeds. 
(Code 1986, § 15-246(a), (c); Code 2002, § 18-431) 
Sec. 18-432. - Larvicidal solutions. 
    Effective larvicidal solutions may be required by the inspection officer for fly or mosquito breeding areas in the mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park which cannot be controlled by other, more permanent measures. 
(Code 1986, § 15-246(b); Code 2002, § 18-432) 
Sec. 18-433. - Accumulations of debris. 
    Accumulations of debris which may provide harborage for rodents shall not be permitted in the mobile/manufactured home park. 
(Code 1986, § 15-247; Code 2002, § 18-433) 
Sec. 18-434. - Extermination of rodents. 
    When rats or other objectionable rodents are known to be in the mobile/manufactured home or travel trailer/recreational vehicle park, the park operator shall take definite action, as directed by the inspection officer, to exterminate them. 
(Code 1986, § 15-248; Code 2002, § 18-434) 
Secs. 18-435-18-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - ELECTRICITY AND EXTERIOR LIGHTING 

Sec. 18-461. - Electrical outlets and equipment. 
    An electrical outlet supplying at least 60 amperes shall be provided for each mobile/manufactured home space. The installation shall comply with all applicable state and local electrical codes and ordinances. Such electrical outlets and extension lines shall be grounded and weatherproofed. Plug receptacles shall also be grounded and weatherproofed. No power supply line shall be permitted to lie on the ground, and no main power line shall be suspended less than 18 feet above the ground, unless otherwise approved by the inspection officer. 
(Code 1986, § 15-261; Code 2002, § 18-461) 
Sec. 18-462. - Streetlights. 
    Streets and driveways within mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks shall be lighted with streetlights meeting the current standards of the Illuminating Engineering Society or one-half candlepower, whichever is higher. 
(Code 1986, § 15-262; Code 2002, § 18-462) 
Secs. 18-463-18-490. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - FIRE PROTECTION 

Sec. 18-491. - Flammable materials. 
    Mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle park areas shall be kept free of litter, rubbish and other flammable materials. 
(Code 1986, § 15-276; Code 2002, § 18-491) 
Sec. 18-492. - Water risers. 
    Where the water supply system does not provide at least six-inch water mains, there shall be provided a two-inch, frost-protected water riser within 300 feet of each mobile/manufactured home or building. 
(Code 1986, § 15-277; Code 2002, § 18-492) 
Sec. 18-493. - Fires generally. 
    Fires shall be made only in stoves and other cooking or heating equipment intended for such purposes in mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks. 
(Code 1986, § 15-278; Code 2002, § 18-493) 
Secs. 18-494-18-520. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - ALTERATIONS AND ADDITIONS 

Sec. 18-521. - Plumbing and electrical alterations or repairs. 
    All plumbing and electrical alterations or repairs in mobile/manufactured home and travel trailer/recreational vehicle parks shall be made in accordance with applicable local regulations. 
(Code 1986, § 15-291; Code 2002, § 18-521) 
Sec. 18-522. - Skirting of mobile/manufactured homes. 
    Skirting of mobile/manufactured homes is permissible, but areas enclosed by such skirting shall be maintained so as not to provide a harborage for rodents or create a fire hazard. 
(Code 1986, § 15-292; Code 2002, § 18-522) 
Sec. 18-523. - Permit for exterior construction. 
    A permit issued by the inspection officer shall be required before any construction on a mobile/manufactured home space or any structural addition or alteration to the exterior of a mobile/manufactured home takes place. No construction or addition or alteration to the exterior of a mobile/manufactured home located in a mobile/manufactured home park shall be permitted unless of the same type of construction or materials as the mobile/manufactured home affected. All such construction, additions or alterations shall be in compliance with applicable local and state laws. No permit shall be required for the addition of steps, canopies, awnings or antennas. 
(Code 1986, § 15-293; Code 2002, § 18-523) 
Sec. 18-524. - Additional structures on mobile/manufactured home space. 
    No structure other than a mobile/manufactured home shall be permitted on a mobile/manufactured home space, except that one structure of not to exceed 175 cubic feet may be used for storage on each such space. 
(Code 1986, § 15-294; Code 2002, § 18-524) 
Secs. 18-525-18-550. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MINIMUM HOUSING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 18-551. - Compliance with housing code generally. 
    Every mobile/manufactured home located in either a mobile/manufactured home park, a mobile/manufactured home subdivision or as a freestanding mobile/manufactured home shall meet the provisions of the city housing code, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 15-306; Code 2002, § 18-551) 
Sec. 18-552. - Applicability of housing code to travel trailers/recreational vehicles. 
    The housing code shall not apply to travel trailers/recreational vehicles insofar as floor area, flush toilet, bath or shower or ceiling height is concerned. 
(Code 1986, § 15-307; Code 2002, § 18-552) 
Sec. 18-553. - Minimum gross floor area or habitable space. 
(a)  Every mobile/manufactured home shall contain the following minimum gross floor area or habitable space: 
(1)  For one or two occupants, 150 square feet. 
(2)  For a third occupant, 100 additional square feet. 
(3)  For each additional occupant thereafter, 75 square feet additional. 
(b)  Habitable space in a mobile/manufactured home shall have a minimum ceiling height of seven feet over 50 percent of the floor area, and the floor area where the ceiling height is less than five feet shall not be considered in computing minimum gross floor area. 
(Code 1986, § 15-308; Code 2002, § 18-553) 
Sec. 18-554. - Primary and emergency exits. 
    A mobile/manufactured home shall have a safe and unobstructed primary exit and an emergency exit located remote from the primary exit. 
(Code 1986, § 15-309; Code 2002, § 18-554) 
Sec. 18-555. - Area of rooms occupied for sleeping purposes. 
    Rooms in a mobile/manufactured home occupied for sleeping purposes must contain at least 60 square feet of floor space if used by more than one person and at least 40 square feet if used by one person. 
(Code 1986, § 15-310; Code 2002, § 18-555) 
Sec. 18-556. - Sanitary facilities of dependent mobile/manufactured homes. 
    Dependent mobile/manufactured homes shall not be required to have a flush toilet or a bath or shower. 
(Code 1986, § 15-311; Code 2002, § 18-556) 
Secs. 18-557-18-585. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MOBILE/MANUFACTURED HOME SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 18-586. - Compliance with subdivision ordinance and zoning code. 
    Mobile/manufactured home subdivisions shall comply with the city subdivision ordinance and the zoning code, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 15-326; Code 2002, § 18-586) 
Sec. 18-587. - Minimum size. 
    The minimum size of a mobile/manufactured home subdivision shall be ten acres. 
(Code 1986, § 15-327; Code 2002, § 18-587) 
Sec. 18-588. - Residences permitted. 
    No residences except mobile/manufactured homes shall be permitted in a mobile/manufactured home subdivision. 
(Code 1986, § 15-328; Code 2002, § 18-588) 
Sec. 18-589. - Minimum lot widths and areas. 
    Minimum effective lot widths in a mobile/manufactured home subdivision shall be 40 feet measured at the front building line, and minimum lot areas shall be 4,000 square feet. At least a five-foot side yard shall be provided on each lot beyond any mobile/manufactured home and additions thereto. In areas not serviced by a public sewer, the minimum additional lot area shall be determined by the inspection officer on the basis of safe and sanitary sewer service. The effective lot width of a mobile/manufactured home lot shall be determined, for interior lots, by measuring at right angles across the lot from one diagonal sideline to the other, and for corner lots the measurement shall be made at right angles from the diagonal having the greatest divergence from perpendicular to the street, through the midpoint of the rear line of the required front yard, to the opposite lot line or an extension thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 15-329; Code 2002, § 18-589) 
Sec. 18-590. - Side lot lines. 
    Sidelines of lots in mobile/manufactured home subdivisions need not be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines. 
(Code 1986, § 15-330; Code 2002, § 18-590) 
Sec. 18-591. - Lots to abut public street for certain distance. 
    Regardless of the effective lot width, mobile/manufactured home subdivision lots must abut a public street for at least 25 feet. 
(Code 1986, § 15-331; Code 2002, § 18-591) 
Sec. 18-592. - Greenbelt planting strips. 
    All mobile/manufactured home subdivisions, except those developed under residential estate standards, shall have a greenbelt planting strip, not less than ten feet in width, along all subdivision boundaries. Such greenbelt shall be composed of not less than three rows of shrubs, spaced not more than eight feet apart and which grow to a height of five feet or more after one full growing season and which will eventually grow to a height of not less than 12 feet. 
(Code 1986, § 15-332; Code 2002, § 18-592) 
Chapter 19 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal traffic regulations, 11 O.S. § 22-117; motor vehicles, 47 O.S. § 101 et seq.; alteration of speed limits, 47 O.S. § 11-803; provisions uniform throughout state, 47 O.S. § 15-101; powers of local authorities, 47 O.S. § 15-102. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - State highway traffic safety code adopted. 
    The state highway traffic safety code, O.S. Title 47, as amended, is adopted and incorporated in this chapter to the extent applicable within the city as though set forth herein for the purposes of establishing locally appropriate rules and regulations for the control of traffic within the city. The adoption of the state traffic code is not intended to and does not repeal any provision of this chapter but shall be in addition thereto. 
(Code 2002, § 19-1; Ord. No. 2591NS, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 19-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a way or part of a way through a block for public use, but established for the purpose of specially serving adjoining owners or occupants and for which public use is limited. 
    Boulevards means streets or portions thereof designated officially as through streets, or streets, the traffic on which has the right-of-way over traffic traveling on the intersecting streets. 
    Bus zone means a parking place set aside for the exclusive use of bus parking and so marked with appropriate and adequate signs. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to and including a street when, within any 600 feet along such street, there are buildings in use for business or industrial purposes, including, but not limited to, hotels, banks or office buildings, railroad stations and public buildings which occupy at least 300 feet of frontage on one side or 300 feet collectively on both sides of the street. 
    Crosswalk means that portion of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the street measured from the curbs or in absence of curbs from the edges of the traversable roadway; or any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Daytime means any time between one hour before sunrise and one hour after sunset. 
    Double parking means parking a vehicle parallel with the curb at a point where cars are lawfully parked between it and the curb and adjacent to such parking. 
    Emergency vehicle means vehicles of fire departments, ambulances and police vehicles, including vehicles owned and operated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation or by any local organization for civil defense as defined by 63 O.S. § 683.3. 
    Fire route means any street so designated by rule of the traffic and transportation commission, as normally used by the fire department or apparatus in attending fires. 
    Intersection means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two streets or highways which join one another at or approximately at right angles or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets joining at any other angle may come in conflict. Where a street includes two roadways 30 or more feet apart, every crossing of each roadway of such divided street by an intersecting street shall be regarded as a separate intersection. If such intersecting street also includes two roadways 30 or more feet apart, every crossing of two roadways of such streets is a separate intersection. 
    Legal route means any street or avenue within the city which is so posted as a truck route, either through or to an industrial access. 
    Limit lines means lines marked on pavement, curbs or sidewalks for the protection and direction of traffic. 
    Loading zone means that part of a roadway officially set apart as a zone in which the loading and unloading of goods, wares and merchandise shall be the exclusive use thereof, and so marked or indicated by proper signs as to be plainly visible at all times while so set apart as a loading zone. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled, provided that such term does not include implements of husbandry as defined in 47 O.S. § 1-125. 
    Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor or a motorized bicycle. 
    Nighttime means any time between one hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise. 
    No parking zone means that part of a roadway officially set apart as a zone in which there shall be no parking, except as may be indicated, and so marked or indicated by proper signs as to be plainly visible at all times while so set apart as a "no parking zone." 
    One-way street means a street where one-way traffic is required. 
    One-way traffic means traffic restricted to move in one direction on any given street. 
    Operator means any person, other than a commercial chauffeur or chauffeur, who drives or is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon a street or who is exercising control over or steering a vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle. 
    Parking or standing means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, other than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
    Parking zone means a place marked off upon any roadway with lines within which vehicles may park. 
    Passenger zone means that portion of a roadway officially set apart for the use of common carriers in taking on or discharging passengers and so marked or indicated by proper signs as to be plainly visible at all times while so set apart as a passenger zone. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Private road or driveway means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
    Residence district means the territory contiguous to and inclusive of a street not comprising a business district when the property on such street for a distance of 300 feet or more is mainly improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
    Right-of-way means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and adjacent property lines, intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Stop or stopping, when required, means complete cessation from movement; when prohibited, any halting even momentarily of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Taxi zone means that portion of a roadway officially set apart for the use of taxis and the parking and standing of the taxis and so marked or indicated by proper signs as to be plainly visible at all times while so set apart as a taxi zone. 
    Through truck means any truck entering the city, proceeding through the city and leaving the city on any route; any truck entering the city and terminating therein or any truck having its point of origin within the city, proceeding through the city and leaving the city on any route. 
    Time zone means that part of a roadway officially set apart as a zone in which there shall be no parking during the hours of the day indicated thereon or where there shall be no parking for a longer time than may be indicated by proper signs so placed as to be plainly visible while such part shall be so set apart as a time zone. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any street for the purpose of travel. 
    Traffic control signs, devices, etc. means all authorized traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings for the control of traffic in the city. 
    Triple parking means parking a vehicle in any manner in such a way that two vehicles are parked in a line between it and the curb. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, provided that the term "vehicle" does not apply to implements of husbandry as defined in 47 O.S. § 1-125. 
(Code 1986, § 16-1; Code 2002, §§ 19-1, 19-2) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to motor vehicles, 47 O.S. § 1-101 et seq. 
Sec. 19-3. - Chapter extended to streets forming city boundary. 
    All ordinances in effect and part of the laws of the city regulating the operation of motor vehicles and other traffic on the city streets and alleys are extended to and enforced within and upon all streets, roads and highways that form the boundary line of the city and are not within the city limits. 
(Code 1986, § 16-24; Code 2002, § 19-2) 
Sec. 19-4. - Obedience to chapter. 
    It is unlawful for any person to do any act prohibited or to fail to perform any act required in this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 16-3; Code 2002, § 19-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-102. 
Sec. 19-5. - Valid license required. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon the city streets without having first procured either a chauffeur's or operator's license from the state, except as specifically exempted in this chapter or by law. Any violation of this subsection shall be punishable by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. 
(b)  Any person who drives a motor vehicle on any public street of the city at a time when his privilege to do so is cancelled, denied, suspended or revoked shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished on first offense by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs, and for a second offense or subsequent offense by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs and by imprisonment of not more than 60 days. Each act of driving on the streets of the city as prohibited shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  A record of conviction of any offense committed under this section shall be forwarded by the chief of police to the state department of public safety. 
(Code 1986, § 16-10; Code 2002, § 19-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 6-303. 
Sec. 19-6. - Compliance with driver's license restrictions. 
    No person shall drive or operate a motor vehicle on the public streets, highways and alleys in violation of the restrictions contained in the state driver's license of the operator thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 16-11; Code 2002, § 19-5) 
State Law reference- Restricted licenses, 47 O.S. § 6-113. 
Sec. 19-7. - Security verification form. 
(a)  The words, phrases and terms used in this section shall have the same meanings and definitions as those contained in 47 O.S. § 7-600, as amended from time to time. 
(b)  The owner of a motor vehicle registered in this state shall carry in such vehicle at all times a current owner's security verification form listing the vehicle or an equivalent form which has been issued by the state department of public safety and shall produce such form upon the request for inspection by any law enforcement officer or representative of the department of public safety. In case of a collision, the form shall be shown upon request to any person affected by the collision. 
(c)  An owner or operator shall not be required to carry an owner's or operator's security verification form or an equivalent form from the department of public safety during operation of any of the following vehicles and shall not be required to surrender such form for vehicle registration purposes: 
(1)  Any vehicle owned or leased by the federal or state government or any agency or political subdivision thereof; 
(2)  Any vehicle bearing the name, symbol or logo of a business, corporation or utility on the exterior and which is in compliance with the provisions of 47 O.S. §§ 7-600-7-607, according to the records of the department of public safety which reflect a deposit, bond, self-insurance or fleet policy; 
(3)  Any licensed taxicab; and 
(4)  Any vehicle owned by a licensed used motor vehicle dealer. 
(d)  Every operator of a motor vehicle registered in the state shall, while operating or using such vehicle, carry either an operator's or an owner's security verification form issued by a carrier, providing the operator is not excluded from coverage thereon, or an equivalent form issued by the department of public safety reflecting liability coverage. 
(Code 1986, § 16-12.1; Code 2002, § 19-7) 
Sec. 19-8. - Applicability to persons working on highways. 
    Unless specifically made applicable, the sections of this chapter, except those contained in sections 19-45 through 19-47, 19-176 through 19-178, 19-441 through 19-447, 19-449, 19-450, 19-452 through 19-454, 19-486, 19-487, 19-516, 19-546, 19-571, 19-572, 19-601 through 19-606 and 19-667 shall not apply to persons, motor vehicles and other equipment while actually engaged in work upon the surface of a street or to persons, motor vehicles and other equipment while actually engaged in construction, maintenance or repair of public utilities, provided that all street and public utility operations shall be protected by adequate warning signs, signals, devices or flagmen. However, the sections of this chapter shall apply to such persons and vehicles when traveling to or from such work. 
(Code 1986, § 16-7; Code 2002, § 19-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-105. 
Sec. 19-9. - Riding or driving on sidewalk.
