The warning shall advise the driver of the possible danger to children resulting from the failure to install or use a child passenger restraint system or seat belts in the motor vehicle. 
(f)  Any person convicted of violating subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule and shall pay an amount as described in the city fee schedule for court costs. This fine shall be suspended for a first offense upon proof of purchase or acquisition by loan of a child passenger restraint system. 
(Code 1986, § 16-121; Code 2002, § 19-183) 
Sec. 19-184. - License plate display. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle on the streets, roadways or thoroughfares unless such vehicle displays a current and appropriate identification number plate as required by the State of Oklahoma. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to display upon any vehicle owned by such person within Oklahoma, any license plate issued by any state or country other than Oklahoma, unless there shall be displayed upon such vehicle at all times a current license plate and decal assigned to it by the Oklahoma Tax Commission or the vehicle shall display evidence that the vehicle is registered as a nonresident vehicle pursuant to rules promulgated by the Oklahoma Tax Commission. A violation of this section shall be presumed to have occurred if a person who is the holder of an Oklahoma Driver's License operates a vehicle owned by such person and there is not displayed on the vehicle a current Oklahoma license plate and decal, unless the vehicle is owned by a member of the armed forces of the United States assigned to duty in Oklahoma in compliance with official military or naval orders or the spouse of such member of the armed forces. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to operate any vehicle registered as a commercial vehicle and displaying a commercial vehicle license plate issued by the Oklahoma Tax Commission, without the name of the commercial establishment or the words "Commercial Vehicle" permanently and prominently displayed upon the outside of the vehicle in letters not less two inches high and two inches wide. Such letters shall be in sharp contrast to the background and shall be of sufficient shape and color to be readily legible during daylight hours from a distance of 50 feet while the vehicle is not in motion. 
(d)  License plates shall be placed and fastened securely to the rear of the vehicle and the numbers and letters of such plate shall be upright reading from left to right and clearly visible at all times. 
(Code 2002, § 19-184; Ord. No. 2382NS, § 1, 12-1-2008) 
Sec. 19-185. - Texting while driving prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any street or highway within this city while using a hand-held electronic communication device to manually compose, send or read an electronic text message while the motor vehicle is in motion. 
(b)  Any person who violated the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply if the person is using a cellular telephone or electronic communication device for the sole purpose of communicating with any of the following regarding an imminent emergency situation: 
(1)  An emergency response operator; 
(2)  A hospital, clinic; physician's office or health [care provider]; 
(3)  A provider of ambulance services; 
(4)  A provider of firefighting services; or 
(5)  A law enforcement agency. 
(d)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cellular telephone means an analog or digital wireless telephone authorized by the Federal Communications Commission to operate in the frequency bandwidth reserved for cellular telephones. 
    Compose, send or read with respect to a text message means the manual entry, sending or retrieval of a text message to communicate with any person or device. 
    Electronic communication device means an electronic device that permits the user to manually transmit a communication of written text by means other than through an oral transfer or wire communication. The term "electronic communication device" does not include a device that is physically or electronically integrated into a motor vehicle or a voice-operated global positioning or navigation system that is affixed to a motor vehicle, or a hands-free device that allows the user to write, send or read a text message without the use of either hand except to activate, deactivate or initiate a feature or function. 
    Text message includes a text-based message, instant message, electronic message, photo, video or electronic mail. 
(e)  The ordinance from which this section derives shall become effective November 1, 2015. 
(Code 2002, § 19-185; Ord. No. 2576NS, § 1, 10-19-2015) 
Secs. 19-186-19-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 19-211. - Applicability of article. 
(a)  No person shall drive or move and no owner shall cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any street or highway any vehicle or combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any person or which does not contain those parts or is not at all times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and adjustment as required in this article or which is equipped in any manner in violation of this article. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prohibit the use of additional parts and accessories on any vehicle not inconsistent this article. 
(c)  The sections of this article with respect to equipment on vehicles shall not apply to implements of husbandry, road machinery, road rollers or farm tractors, except as made applicable in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 16-231; Code 2002, § 19-211) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-101. 
Sec. 19-212. - Use of lighted lamps. 
    Every vehicle upon a street or highway within the city at any time from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise and at any other time when, due to insufficient light or unfavorable atmospheric conditions, persons and vehicles on the highway are not clearly discernible at a distance of 500 feet ahead shall display lighted lamps and illuminating devices as required in this article, subject to exceptions with respect to parked vehicles. 
(Code 1986, § 16-232; Code 2002, § 19-212) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-201. 
Sec. 19-213. - Visibility distance of lamps; mounted height of lamps. 
(a)  Whenever a requirement is declared in this article as to distance from which certain lamps and devices shall render objects visible or within which such lamps or devices shall be visible, such requirement shall apply during the times stated in section 19-212 in respect to a vehicle without a load when upon a straight, level, unlighted highway, under normal atmospheric conditions, unless a different time or condition is expressly stated. 
(b)  Whenever a requirement is declared in this article as to the mounted height of lamps or devices, it shall mean from the center of such lamp or device to the level ground upon which the vehicle stands when the vehicle is without a load. 
(Code 1986, § 16-233; Code 2002, § 19-213) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-202. 
Sec. 19-214. - Headlights. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle other than a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with at least two headlamps with at least one on each side of the front of the motor vehicle, which headlamps shall comply with the requirements and limitations set forth in this article. 
(b)  Every headlamp upon every motor vehicle, including every motorcycle and motor-driven cycle, shall be located at a height measured from the center of the headlamp of not more than 54 inches and not less than 22 inches to be measured as set forth in section 19-213. 
(Code 1986, § 16-234(a), (c); Code 2002, § 19-214) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-203. 
Sec. 19-215. - Taillights. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer and pole trailer and any other vehicle which is being drawn at the end of a train of vehicles shall be equipped with at least one taillamp mounted on the rear, which, when lighted as required in this article, shall emit a red light plainly visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear, provided that for a train of vehicles only the taillamp on the rearmost vehicle need actually be seen from the distance specified. Every such vehicle, other than a truck tractor, registered in this state and manufactured or assembled after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, shall be equipped with at least two taillamps mounted on the rear, on the same level and as widely spaced laterally as practicable, which, when lighted as required in this article, shall comply with this section. 
(b)  Every taillamp upon every vehicle shall be located at a height of not more than 72 inches and not less than 20 inches. 
(c)  Either a taillamp or a separate lamp shall be so constructed and placed as to illuminate with a white light the rear registration plate and render it clearly legible from a distance of 50 feet to the rear. Any taillamp, together with any separate lamp for illuminating the rear registration plate, shall be so wired as to be lighted whenever the headlamps, clearance lamps or auxiliary driving lamps are lighted. 
(Code 1986, § 16-235; Code 2002, § 19-215) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-204. 
Sec. 19-216. - Lamps on parked vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever a vehicle is parked or stopped upon a roadway or shoulder adjacent thereto, whether attended or unattended, during the hours between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise, and there is not sufficient light to reveal any person or object within a distance of 500 feet upon such highway, such vehicle so parked or stopped shall be equipped with one or more lamps meeting the following requirements: At least one lamp shall display a white or amber light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle and the same lamp or at least one other lamp shall display a red light visible at a distance of 500 feet to the rear of the vehicle, and the location of such lamps shall always be such that at least one lamp or combination of lamps meeting the requirements of this section is installed as near as practicable to the side of the vehicle which is closest to passing traffic. The preceding requirements shall not apply to a motor-driven cycle. 
(b)  Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Code 1986, § 16-236; Code 2002, § 19-216) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-214. 
Sec. 19-217. - Brakes generally. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle, other than a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle, when operated upon a street or highway, shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and hold such vehicle, including two separate means of applying the brakes, each of which means shall be effective to apply the brakes to at least two wheels. If these two separate means of applying the brakes are connected in any way, they shall be so constructed that failure of any one part of the operating mechanism shall not leave the motor vehicle without brakes on at least two wheels. 
(b)  Every trailer, semitrailer and pole trailer of a gross weight of 3,000 pounds or more, when operated upon a street or highway, shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and to hold such vehicle and shall be so designed as to be applied by the driver of the towing motor vehicle from its cab, and such brakes shall be so designed and connected that in case of an accidental breakaway of the towed vehicle the brakes shall be automatically applied. 
(c)  Every singly driven motor vehicle and every combination of motor vehicles shall be equipped with parking brakes adequate to hold a vehicle or combination on any grade on which it is operated under any condition of loading, on a surface free from snow or ice. 
(Code 1986, § 16-237(a), (c), (d); Code 2002, § 19-217) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-301(a), (c), (e). 
Sec. 19-218. - Maintenance of brakes. 
    All brakes shall be maintained in good working order and shall be so adjusted as to operate as equally as practicable with respect to the wheels on opposite sides of the vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 16-238; Code 2002, § 19-218) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-303. 
Sec. 19-219. - Horns and warning devices. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle, when operated upon a street or highway, shall be equipped with a horn in good working order and capable of emitting sound audible under normal conditions from a distance of not less than 200 feet, but no horn or other warning device shall emit an unreasonably loud or harsh sound or a whistle. The driver of a motor vehicle shall, when reasonably necessary to ensure safe operation, give audible warning with his horn, but shall not otherwise use such horn when upon a street or highway. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a vehicle any siren, whistle or bell, except as otherwise permitted in this section. 
(c)  It is permissible but not required that any commercial vehicle be equipped with a theft alarm signal device which is so arranged that it cannot be used by the driver as an ordinary warning signal. 
(d)  Any authorized emergency vehicle may be equipped with a siren, whistle or bell, capable of emitting sound audible under normal conditions from a distance of not less than 500 feet and of a type approved by the state department of public safety, but such siren shall not be used except when such vehicle is operated in response to an emergency call or in the immediate pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, in which event the driver of such vehicle shall sound such siren when reasonably necessary to warn pedestrians and other drivers of the approach thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 16-239; Code 2002, § 19-219) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-401. 
Sec. 19-220. - Mufflers; exhaust system modifications. 
    Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke, and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass or similar device upon a motor vehicle on a highway. No person shall modify the exhaust system of a motor vehicle in any manner which will amplify or increase the noise or sound emitted louder than that emitted by the muffler originally installed on the vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 16-240; Code 2002, § 19-220) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-402. 
Sec. 19-221. - Glass coating materials or sunscreening devices on windshields and windows. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Glass coating material or sunscreening devices means materials, films, applications or devices which are used in conjunction with approved vehicle glazing materials for the purpose of reducing the effects of sun. 
    Light transmission means the percentage of total light which is allowed to pass through a window. 
    Luminous reflectance means the ratio of the amount of total light, expressed in percentages, which is reflected outward by the glass coating material or sunscreening device to the amount of total light falling on the glass coating materials. 
    Manufacturer means a person who: 
(1)  Engages in the manufacturing or assembling of sunscreening devices; or 
(2)  Fabricates, laminates or tempers glazing materials, incorporating the capacity to reflect or reduce the transmittance of light during the manufacturing process. 
    Multipurpose vehicle means any vehicle capable of carrying goods or persons and which is manufactured on a truck frame. 
    Window means the windshield, side or rear glass of a motor vehicle, including any glazing material, glass coating or sunscreen device. 
(b)  It is unlawful for a person to sell, install or to operate a motor vehicle with any object or material placed, displayed, installed, affixed or applied upon the windshield or side or rear windows or with any object or material so placed, displayed, installed, affixed or applied in or upon the motor vehicle so as to obstruct or reduce a driver's clear view through the windshield or side or rear windows, except as provided by this section. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to place, install, affix or apply any transparent material upon the windshield or side or rear windows of any motor vehicle if such material alters the color or reduces the light transmittance of such windshield or side or rear windows, except as provided in this section. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Side or back windows that have a substance or material in conjunction with glazing material that has a light transmission of at least 25 percent and a luminous reflectance of, at most, 25 percent; 
(2)  Front side wing vents and windows that have a substance or material not attached in conjunction with glazing material, which is used by a vehicle operator on a moving vehicle during daylight hours; 
(3)  Rearview mirrors; 
(4)  Adjustable nontransparent sun visors which are mounted forward of the side windows and are not attached to the glass; 
(5)  Signs, stickers or other materials which are displayed in a 49-square-inch area in the lower corner of the windshield farthest removed from the driver or signs, stickers or other materials which are displayed in a 49-square-inch area in the lower corner of the windshield nearest the driver; 
(6)  Direction, designation or termination signs on buses if the signs do not interfere with the driver's clear view of approaching traffic; 
(7)  Rear window wiper motors; 
(8)  Rear window defrosters or defoggers; 
(9)  Rear truck lid handle or hinges; 
(10)  Side windows to the rear of the driver or back windows that have a substance or material in conjunction with glazing material that has a light transmission of at least ten percent and luminous reflectance of, at most, 25 percent on all vehicles manufactured prior to 1996-year models, if the motor vehicle is equipped with outside mirrors on both lefthand and righthand sides of the vehicle that are so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the highway through each mirror for a distance of at least 200 feet to the rear of the motor vehicle; 
(11)  Transparent material which is installed, affixed or applied to the topmost portion of the windshield if: 
a.  It does not extend downward beyond the AS-1 line or more than five inches from the top of the windshield, whichever is closer to the top of the windshield; and 
b.  The material is not red or amber in color; 
(12)  All windows to the rear of the driver's seat in a vehicle licensed as a bus, as defined by 47 O.S. § 1-105, or a taxicab, as defined by 47 O.S. § 1-174; and 
(13)  Vehicles not subject to registration in the state. 
(e)  This section shall not prohibit the use and placement of federal, state or political subdivision certificates on any windows as are required by applicable laws. 
(f)  Louvered materials, when installed as designed, shall not reduce the area of the driver's visibility below 50 percent, as measured on a horizontal plane. When such materials are used in conjunction with the rear window, the measurement shall be made based upon the driver's view from inside the rearview mirror. 
(g)  The commissioner of public safety, upon application from a person required for medical reasons to be shielded from the direct rays of the sun, supported by written attestation of such fact from a physician licensed pursuant to 59 O.S. § 495, may issue an exemption from this section for a motor vehicle belonging to such person or in which such person is a habitual passenger. Any person may operate a vehicle or alter the color or reduce the light transmitted through the side or rear windows of a vehicle in accordance with an exemption issued by the commissioner. 
(h)  This section shall not apply to implements of husbandry, as defined in 47 O.S. § 1-125. 
(i)  This section shall not apply to automobile manufacturers that comply with Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 205 or to multipurpose vehicles with windows that are in compliance with Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 205, regardless of whether the glass coating or sunscreening device is added by the automobile manufacturer or a manufacturer as defined by this section. 
(j)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement vehicles which are owned by the state or a political subdivision thereof. 
(k)  Any person who violates this section, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 16-241; Code 2002, § 19-221) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-422. 
Secs. 19-222-19-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ACCIDENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Accidents and accident reports, 47 O.S. § 10-101 et seq. 

Sec. 19-251. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs, or imprisoned in the city jail not exceeding 30 days or punished by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1986, § 16-256; Code 2002, § 19-251) 
Sec. 19-252. - Police authority to investigate. 
    The police department is authorized to investigate accidents involving motor vehicles on private property where the public is invited or on public property. 
(Code 1986, § 16-257; Code 2002, § 19-252) 
Sec. 19-253. - Damage to vehicle. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of the accident or as close thereto as possible, but shall forthwith return to and in every event shall remain at the scene of the accident until he has fulfilled the requirements of section 19-254. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. 
(Code 1986, § 16-258; Code 2002, § 19-253) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 10-103. 
Sec. 19-254. - Duty to give information and render aid. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or damage to any vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall give his correct name, address and registration number of the vehicle he is driving and shall upon request and if available exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license and security verification form to the person struck or the driver or occupant of or person attending any vehicle collided with and shall render to any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance, including the carrying or the making of arrangements for the carrying of such person to a physician, surgeon or hospital for medical or surgical treatment if it is apparent that such treatment is necessary or if such carrying is requested by the injured person. 
(Code 1986, § 16-259; Code 2002, § 19-254) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 10-104A; accidents involving death, 47 O.S. § 10-102.1; nonfatal injury, 47 O.S. § 10-102. 
Sec. 19-255. - Duty upon striking unattended vehicle. 
    The driver of any vehicle which collides with any vehicle that is unattended shall immediately stop and shall then and there either locate and notify the operator or owner of such vehicle of the correct name and address of the driver and owner of the vehicle striking the unattended vehicle and provide the operator or owner with information from his security verification form, as defined in 47 O.S. § 7-600, or shall leave in a conspicuous place in the vehicle struck a written notice giving the name and address of the driver and of the owner of the vehicle doing the striking and providing information from his security verification form and a statement of the circumstances. 
(Code 1986, § 16-260; Code 2002, § 19-255) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 10-105. 
Sec. 19-256. - Duty upon striking fixtures upon highway. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to fixtures or other property legally upon or adjacent to a highway shall take reasonable steps to locate and notify the owner or person in charge of such property of such fact and of his name and address and of the registration number of the vehicle he is driving and shall upon request and if available exhibit his operator's or chauffeur's license and security verification form and shall make report of such accident when and as required in section 19-258. 
(Code 1986, § 16-261; Code 2002, § 19-256) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 10-106. 
Sec. 19-257. - Immediate notice of accident. 
    The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person shall immediately, by the quickest means of communication, give notice of such accident to the police department after complying with the requirements of 47 O.S. § 10-104. 
(Code 1986, § 16-262(a); Code 2002, § 19-257) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 10-107. 
Sec. 19-258. - Written report of accident; notice to other parties; ancillary proceedings. 
(a)  The operator of a motor vehicle which is in any manner involved in a collision upon any road, street, highway or elsewhere within this city resulting in bodily injury to or death of any person or in which it is apparent that damage to one vehicle or other property is in excess of $300.00 shall forward a written report of such collision to the department of public safety if settlement of the collision has not been made within six months after the date of the accident and provided that if a settlement has been made a report of such settlement must be made by the parties. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of 47 O.S. § 7-202, if any party involved in a collision files a report under this section, the department shall notify all other parties involved in the collision, as specified in the report, that a report has been filed, and all other parties shall then furnish the department, within ten days, such information as the department may request to determine whether the parties were in compliance with the requirements of 47 O.S. § 7-601 et seq. at the time of the collision. Upon a finding that an owner or driver was not in compliance with 47 O.S. § 7-601 et seq., the department shall then commence proceedings under the provisions of 47 O.S. §§ 7-201 and 7-301 et seq. 
(Code 1986, § 16-262(b); Code 2002, § 19-258) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 10-108; authority of city to require accident reports, 47 O.S. § 10-117. 
Secs. 19-259-19-285. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDESTRIANS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Pedestrians' rights and duties, 47 O.S. § 11-501 et seq. 

Sec. 19-286. - Obedience to traffic devices and signals; privileges and restrictions. 
(a)  A pedestrian shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device specifically applicable to him, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic and pedestrian control signals as provided in sections 19-108 and 19-110. 
(c)  At all other places pedestrians shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 16-211; Code 2002, § 19-286) 
State Law reference- Pedestrians subject to traffic regulations, 47 O.S. § 11-501. 
Sec. 19-287. - Right-of-way in crosswalks. 
(a)  When traffic control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(c)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the conditions stated in section 19-288(b). 
(d)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 16-212; Code 2002, § 19-287) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-502. 
Sec. 19-288. - Crossing at other than crosswalks. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(Code 1986, § 16-213; Code 2002, § 19-288) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-503. 
Sec. 19-289. - Due care of drivers. 
    Notwithstanding the sections of this chapter, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1986, § 16-214; Code 2002, § 19-289) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-504. 
Sec. 19-290. - Use of right half of crosswalks. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of a crosswalk. 
(Code 1986, § 16-215; Code 2002, § 19-290) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-505. 
Sec. 19-291. - Walking on roadways. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction and shall yield to approaching vehicles. 
(Code 1986, § 16-216; Code 2002, § 19-291) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-506(a), (b). 
Sec. 19-292. - Soliciting rides, donations, employment or business. 
    No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride, donation, employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 16-217; Code 2002, § 19-292) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-507. 
Secs. 19-293-19-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BICYCLES, MOTORCYCLES AND PLAY VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles and play vehicles generally, 47 O.S. § 11-1201 et seq. 

Sec. 19-321. - Responsibility of parent or guardian; applicability of article to bicycles. 
(a)  The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the sections of this article. 
(b)  The sections of this article applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or highway or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 16-191; Code 2002, § 19-321) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1201(b), (c). 
Sec. 19-322. - Rights and duties of persons riding bicycles generally. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this chapter, except as to special regulations in this article and except to those sections of this chapter which by their nature can have no application. 
(Code 1986, § 16-192; Code 2002, § 19-322) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1202. 
Sec. 19-323. - Manner of riding bicycle. 
(a)  A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
(b)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1986, § 16-193; Code 2002, § 19-323) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1203. 
Sec. 19-324. - Clinging to vehicles. 
    No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle or himself to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Code 1986, § 16-194; Code 2002, § 19-324) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1204. 
Sec. 19-325. - Use of bicycles upon roadways and bicycle paths. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(b)  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(c)  Wherever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
(Code 1986, § 16-195; Code 2002, § 19-325) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1205. 
Sec. 19-326. - Carrying articles while riding bicycle. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the driver from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1986, § 16-196; Code 2002, § 19-326) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1206. 
Sec. 19-327. - Lamp, rear reflector and brake on bicycle. 
(a)  Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type approved by the state department of public safety which shall be visible from all distances from 50 feet to 300 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(b)  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheels skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(Code 1986, § 16-197; Code 2002, § 19-327) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1207. 
Sec. 19-328. - Operation of minibikes, trail bikes, golf carts, go-carts and similar off the road vehicles. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the definitions of the terms "motor vehicle" and "motorcycle" contained in this chapter, self-propelled, motor-driven cycles, known and commonly referred to as "minibikes," "trail bikes" and other similar trade names, shall not be permitted to be operated upon the city streets, highways, alleys or any other city property. 
(b)  Minibikes used by regularly organized units of any Shrine temple shall be exempt from this section while being used in any parade or other function of such body. 
(c)  This section shall also apply to those motor-driven or operated vehicles known as golf carts, go-carts and power lawn mowers and other motor vehicles that are manufactured principally for use off the streets and highways. However, this shall not prohibit occasional necessary movement of such golf carts, go-carts, power lawn mowers and other such vehicles on streets. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as prohibiting farm vehicles from using the public highways. 
(Code 1986, § 16-17; Code 2002, § 19-328) 
Sec. 19-329. - Operation of motorcycles, motorscooters and motorbicycles. 
(a)  No person shall drive a motorcycle, a motorscooter or a motorbicycle while transporting more than one passenger, except a motorcycle, motorscooter or motorbicycle factory-designed for the purpose of carrying additional passengers. 
(b)  No person shall operate any motorcycle, motorscooter or motorbicycle at a speed greater than the speed limit legally posted; provided, however, in no event nor at any time may an operator under the age of 16 years operate a motorcycle, motorscooter or motorbicycle at a speed greater than 35 miles per hour. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate upon the streets, roads, highways or other public places within the city any motorcycle or motor-driven cycle unless the headlamps of such motorcycle or motor-driven cycle are fully lighted. 
(Code 1986, § 16-13; Code 2002, § 19-329) 
Sec. 19-330. - Safety equipment on motorcycles and motorscooters. 
(a)  Generally. The equipment in this section shall be required on all motorcycles and motorscooters, except when on actual trail rides conducted on other than public roads and highways. 
(b)  Rearview mirrors. Every motorcycle, motorscooter and similar motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with two mirrors, each containing a reflection surface of not less than three inches in diameter, mounted one on each side of the vehicle and positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the roadway for a distance of 200 feet to the rear of his vehicle. 
(c)  Windshield. Every motorcycle, motorscooter and similar motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with a windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to protect the operator from foreign objects. However, in lieu of such windshield the operator shall wear goggles or a face shield of such material and design as to protect him from foreign objects. 
(d)  Brakes. Every motorcycle, motorscooter and similar motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of such vehicle and to stop and hold such vehicle. Further, the required equipment for such vehicle shall include two separate means of applying the brakes: one means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the front wheel and one means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the rear wheel. Every such vehicle shall be equipped with a stoplamp, on the rear of the vehicle, which shall display a red or amber light or a light of any color between red and amber, visible from a distance of not less than 100 feet to the rear in normal sunlight, and actuated upon application of the service brake. 
(e)  Speedometer. Every motorcycle, motorscooter and similar motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with a properly operating speedometer capable of registering at least the maximum legal speed limit for such vehicle. 
(f)  Fenders. Every motorcycle, motorscooter and similar motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with a fender over each wheel. Such fenders shall be of the type provided by the manufacturer of such vehicle. 
(g)  Lights. Every motorcycle, motorscooter and similar motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with at least one and not more than two headlamps capable of showing a white light visible at least 300 feet in the direction in which such vehicle is proceeding. Every headlamp shall be located at a height measured from the center of the headlamp of not more than 54 inches and not less than 22 inches to be measured as set forth in section 19-213. The motorcycle, motorscooter and similar motor-driven cycle shall have one taillamp mounted on the rear which, when lighted, shall emit a red light plainly visible from at least 300 feet to the rear. 
(h)  Headgear. No person under 18 years of age shall operate or ride upon any motorcycle, motorscooter or similar motor-driven cycle unless such person is equipped with and wearing on his head a crash helmet of a type which complies with the standards established by the state department of public safety. Every crash helmet shall consist of lining, padding and a chin strap and shall be so designed as not to distort the view of the driver. 
(Code 1986, §§ 16-14, 16-234(b), (c), 16-237(d); Code 2002, § 19-330) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-608, 12-609. 
Secs. 19-331-19-355. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Abandonment of vehicles, 47 O.S. § 901 et seq.; removal of abandoned vehicle, 47 O.S. § 11-1002. 

Sec. 19-356. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Property means any real property within the city which is not a street or highway. 
    Vehicle means a machine propelled by power, other than human power, designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and transport persons or property or pull machinery and includes, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, tractors and wagons. 
(Code 1986, § 16-276; Code 2002, § 19-356) 
Sec. 19-357. - Prohibited; declaration of nuisance. 
(a)  No person shall abandon any vehicle within the city and no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the city for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. The circumstances mentioned in this subsection may consist of but shall not be limited to any one or more of the following conditions:. 
(1)  Weed and grass undergrowth indicating to a reasonable person that the vehicle has not been moved, thereby permitting such growth to occur. 
(2)  Tires flat or wheels or tires missing. 
(3)  Portions of the vehicle, needed for its legal operation and control on the street and highways, that are missing, including a current automobile license tag. 
(4)  Evidence offered by neighbors or other persons of the length of time the vehicle has been standing in one place without removal and evidence that parts are taken from or added to such vehicle which would indicate a salvage or garage operation. 
(5)  Evidence of violation of any of the sections of this Code or city ordinances pertaining to junk and salvage yards, including violations of the city zoning code. 
(b)  The abandonment of vehicles, as contemplated or defined in this section, on any street or private property within the city limits is declared to constitute a public nuisance, and, in addition to the penalties for violations of this chapter, the counsel to the city may, upon proper evidence submitted by city enforcement agents, institute any necessary action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the terms of this article and to abate such nuisance. 
(Code 1986, § 16-277; Code 2002, § 19-357; Ord. No. 1989NS, § 1, 11-20-2000; Ord. No. 2058NS, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Sec. 19-358. - Wrecked, dismantled or junked vehicles. 
(a)  Leaving on street. No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or junked vehicle on any street or highway within the city. 
(b)  Allowing to remain on property. No person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked or discarded vehicle to remain on such property longer than 48 hours. However, this article shall not apply with regard to a vehicle in an enclosed building; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the operation of such business enterprise; or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city. 
(Code 1986, §§ 16-278, 16-279; Code 2002, § 19-358) 
Sec. 19-359. - Impoundment. 
    The chief of police or other appropriate official or any member of his department designated by him is authorized to remove or have removed any vehicle left on any public way within the city which reasonably appears to be in violation of this article or is lost, stolen or unclaimed. Such vehicle shall be impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with 47 O.S. § 901 et seq. 
(Code 1986, § 16-280; Code 2002, § 19-359) 
Sec. 19-360. - Notice to owner. 
    An officer designated to enforce this article shall, when it appears to him that a vehicle is in violation of this article, give notice to the owner or possessor thereof as follows: 
(1)  He shall first securely attach to the vehicle, whether located on a public way or on private property, a written notice stating that: 
a.  The vehicle is in violation of this article which prohibits the abandonment of inoperable vehicles within the city; 
b.  The owner or possessor thereof has 48 hours within which to remove the vehicle to an authorized place of storage or salvage; and 
c.  Should the notice not be complied with, both criminal and civil actions will immediately be instituted to enforce this article. 
(2)  Notice shall also be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner or possessor if his whereabouts can be determined by due diligence informing him of those conditions contained in the notice attached to the vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 16-281; Code 2002, § 19-360) 
Secs. 19-361-19-385. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - RAILROADS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Constitution reference- City consent for street railroad required, OK Const. Art. 9, § 10. 
State Law reference- Annexation of territory separated by railway, 11 O.S. § 21-102; authority of city to regulate railways, 11 O.S. § 22-119; relocation, etc., of railroad property, 11 O.S. § 32-104; street and sidewalk improvements, 11 O.S. § 36-116 et seq.; use of streets by railroads, 66 O.S. § 63; street railroads in cities, 66 O.S. § 201 et seq. 

Sec. 19-386. - Boarding or alighting from train in motion. 
    No person, not an employee of a railway company, shall get upon, hold onto or board or alight from any railway car, tender or engine while the car, tender or engine is in motion within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 16-296; Code 2002, § 19-386) 
Sec. 19-387. - Trespass on railroad property. 
    No person, without lawful right, shall stand, walk, sit or recline upon any railroad track, depot, yard or right-of-way within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 16-297; Code 2002, § 19-387) 
Sec. 19-388. - Blocking streets. 
    No railroad company or its agent or employee shall obstruct any street, avenue or alley crossing within the city with any railway cars, engine or other equipment for a longer period of time than five minutes pursuant to 45 USC 421 et seq. 
(Code 1986, § 16-298); Code 2002, § 19-388 
Sec. 19-389. - Speed limit. 
    No engineer, fireman or other railroad employee shall run or operate any railway locomotive or car at any greater speed than 35 miles per hour within that portion of the city lying between Leo Street on the west, Harrison Street on the east, Independence on the north and Bluff Street on the south pursuant to 45 USC 421. 
(Code 1986, § 16-299; Code 2002, § 19-389) 
Sec. 19-390. - Obedience to warning or danger signals. 
    No person shall refuse to heed any danger signal established or posted by any railroad company within the city for the purpose of giving a warning of approaching trains or cars. Every watchman stationed by any railway company for the purpose of giving signals of danger to the public or of warning the public of approaching cars or trains shall be vested with police power insofar as necessary to prevent any person from not heeding and obeying the signals or warning, and he shall have power to arrest any person so violating such signal. 
(Code 1986, § 16-300; Code 2002, § 19-390) 
State Law reference- Arrest by private person, 22 O.S. § 202. 
Secs. 19-391-19-415. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - TRAFFIC SCHEDULES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 19-416-19-440. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, 47 O.S. § 11-1001 et seq.; authority of city to regulate the standing or parking of vehicles, 47 O.S. § 15-102. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 19-441. - Emergency and construction vehicles excepted. 
    This division shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles or to vehicles or machinery used in the construction or maintenance of streets, and such vehicles or machinery may be operated on any part of the road, whether the road is open to traffic or closed, when such operation is necessary in the maintenance or construction of the street, provided that all such operations shall be protected with adequate warnings, signs, signals, lights, devices or flagmen. 
(Code 1986, § 16-131; Code 2002, § 19-441) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1005. 
Sec. 19-442. - Manner of parking vehicles. 
    Except when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals, no operator of a vehicle shall stop, stand or park such vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within one foot of the edge of the roadway, except as follows: Upon those streets which have been marked or designated for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks or signs and wholly between the zone lines. 
(Code 1986, § 16-151; Code 2002, § 19-442) 
State Law reference- Parking near curb, 47 O.S. § 11-1004. 
Sec. 19-443. - Unattended motor vehicle. 
    The person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall not permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine and effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the street. 
(Code 1986, § 16-152; Code 2002, § 19-443) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1101. 
Sec. 19-444. - Restrictions on parking generally. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall park such vehicle for a longer period of time than is designated for the area by official signs, nor shall he park such vehicle at any place at any time in which parking is prohibited and for which official signs are placed. 
(Code 1986, § 16-133; Code 2002, § 19-444) 
Sec. 19-445. - Loading and unloading. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, nothing contained in this chapter or in any traffic rule or regulation of the city shall be deemed to prohibit a vehicle from parking at the curb of any street while taking on or discharging passengers, but a vehicle shall not stop on any crosswalk or between any safety zone and the curb nearest thereto in such manner as to obstruct free passage upon all parts of such crosswalk or between such safety zone and the nearest curb. 
(b)  So far as practicable, all persons shall alight from vehicles and board the vehicles upon the right side. 
(c)  When taking up or discharging freight or passengers, a vehicle shall, so far as practicable, be headed in the direction of the traffic, on the right side of the roadway. So far as practicable, all vehicles shall be loaded from the righthand side and shall be drawn in close to the curb when loading or unloading. 
(d)  When such handling is impracticable, the vehicle being loaded or unloaded or seeking a position for loading or unloading may back to the curb, but shall not stand at an angle which will interfere with the traffic on the street. No vehicle shall remain backed up to the curb, except when actually loading or unloading such vehicle and in such case for no longer time than the actual loading or unloading requires. 
(e)  Upon the request to the driver, a vehicle parking or waiting at the curb shall promptly give place to a vehicle about to take on or let off passengers or freight. 
(Code 1986, § 16-153; Code 2002, § 19-445) 
Sec. 19-446. - Blocking roadway. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. However, this section shall not apply to the operator of a vehicle stopped momentarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers, if such stopping does not actually impede traffic, nor shall it apply to a necessary stop in obedience to traffic regulations, traffic signs or signals of a police officer. 
(Code 1986, § 16-136; Code 2002, § 19-446) 
Sec. 19-447. - Standing in front of theater or entrance to building. 
    No vehicle shall be left standing in front of the entrance to any theater or within 15 feet of either side of the entrance to any building, except when taking on or discharging passengers or freight, and then only for such length of time as is necessary for such purpose. 
(Code 1986, § 16-150; Code 2002, § 19-447) 
Sec. 19-448. - Use of alley for loading or unloading. 
    No person shall load or unload any goods, wares or merchandise from any vehicle on the street or sidewalk in front of any place of business where such place of business has an alley entrance from which such merchandise may be loaded or unloaded. 
(Code 1986, § 16-175; Code 2002, § 19-448) 
Sec. 19-449. - Parking in alleys. 
    Vehicles shall not be parked in alleys except for loading and unloading purposes and then not longer than is necessary for such purpose. When so parked, the vehicle shall stand as close as possible to one side of the alley and in any case shall so stand as to permit other vehicles to pass. Vehicles in alleys shall comply with the directions and orders of police officers. 
(Code 1986, § 16-147; Code 2002, § 19-449) 
Sec. 19-450. - Handicapped parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or park a motor vehicle in any parking space on private property accessible to the public and where the public is invited or on public property that is designated and posted as a reserved area for parking of motor vehicles of a physically disabled person unless such person is eligible for a detachable insignia or reflective insignia or special license plate under 47 O.S. § 1136 as a physically disabled person under the provisions of 47 O.S. § 15-112 and such insignia or plate is displayed as provided in 47 O.S. § 1101 et seq. or regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be an offense, and, upon conviction, such person shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule and, in addition, such person shall pay any and all reasonable and necessary charges incurred by the landowner or other person in having any motor vehicle removed from the property and stored. 
(Code 1986, § 16-135; Code 2002, § 19-450; Ord. No. 2106NS, § 1, 10-6-2003) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1007. 
Sec. 19-451. - Parking on posted private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place or park a motor vehicle or trailer upon the posted private property of another without first obtaining permission from the landowner or the person in charge of such property, except where such placing or parking is casual or involuntary. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall be considered to be an offense, and, upon conviction, violators shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule and, in addition, shall pay any and all reasonable and necessary charges incurred by the landowner or other person in having any vehicle or trailer removed from his property and stored. 
(Code 1986, § 16-158; Code 2002, § 19-451) 
Sec. 19-452. - Use of street for storage of vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall use any street or alley for the parking and placing of any vehicles in the street or alley under such circumstances as to constitute an improper use thereof for purely storage purposes and in lieu of the use of private property. No proprietor or person in charge of any livery stable, blacksmith shop, garage, vehicle repair shop or any business establishment which performs any service for hire in reference to any vehicle shall use the streets, parkings, traverse driveways or other public places in the city for the storing of vehicles thereon. 
(b)  No work of any kind shall be done on any vehicle while it is parked upon the street, nor shall any vehicle on which work has been done be parked in front of such place after the work has been completed. 
(c)  Every such vehicle shall be parked inside the building or on private property from the time of delivery for such services until the vehicle is redelivered to the owner thereof or some person authorized by him to receive the vehicle. The streets and alleys around such places shall be open to public use on the same terms and conditions as all other streets. 
(Code 1986, § 16-154; Code 2002, § 19-452) 
Sec. 19-453. - Central business district. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the central business district of the city is defined as follows: all of that area between 11th Street on the north and Seventh Street on the south; Pennsylvania Street on the east and Market Street on the west. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle or allow a vehicle to remain parked in any parking space designated by signs as two-hour parking contrary to the provisions of this section. The parking of motor vehicles shall be allowed in two-hour parking places within the central business district of the city, but it shall be a violation to permit any vehicle to remain in such two-hour parking spaces for more than two hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on any day except Saturday, Sunday and legal holidays. The only exception to the two-hour parking rule in the central business district shall be the 15-minute parking on both sides of Ninth Street from Union Street to Bell Street. 
(c)  The city manager is authorized to designate two-hour parking spaces in the central business district and place lines or marks on the curb or on the street designating two-hour parking spaces within the central business district. No person shall park any vehicle across any such line or mark or park such vehicle in such a way that the vehicle shall not be within the area so designated by such lines or markings, whether the area is designated as parallel parking or diagonal parking. Any person who violates this subsection shall be subject to a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, and such violation shall be considered illegal parking. If any vehicle remains parked in any such parking space beyond a two-hour period, such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime. Any person causing a vehicle to be parked overtime as provided for in this subsection shall be subject to a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for each parking ticket placed on the vehicle as provided in this section. 
(d)  The city manager is authorized to designate police officers or other persons to patrol the central business district and use appropriate means of marking parked vehicles in order to identify vehicles that are parked overtime. Such persons shall patrol such areas in accordance with the schedules prepared by the city manager. Such vehicles and parking spaces shall be checked on the basis of not less than every two hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on all days except Sunday and legal holidays. Whenever the person patrolling such spaces and vehicles determines that a vehicle has been parked overtime, he shall place on the vehicle a ticket indicating a violation. If the vehicle remains parked in such place, the person patrolling the spaces and vehicles is authorized to place additional tickets on the vehicle, and each such ticket shall represent a separate violation. Any person violating this subsection shall be subject to a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for each such violation. If any such vehicle parked overtime bears a license tag issued by some state or sovereign other than this state, such person may cause to be placed thereon a courtesy or warning ticket, and no complaint for violation shall be issued pursuant to such courtesy or warning ticket. 
(Code 1986, § 16-148; Code 2002, § 19-453; Ord. No. 2029NS, § 1, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 19-454. - Moving vehicle to avoid two-hour limit in central business district. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, a block is defined as that part of a street between two intersecting streets. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move a motor vehicle to any location within the same block with the intent to avoid receiving a parking ticket in violation of the two-hour parking limit on any street within the central business district. However, it shall not be unlawful for a person to move a vehicle to the opposite side of the street within the same block. 
(c)  Any vehicle remaining in the same block as defined in subsection (a) of this section beyond the two-hour limit shall be regarded as parked overtime, and the person causing the vehicle to remain in the block beyond a two-hour period shall be subject to a fine for each such two-hour period. 
(Code 1986, § 16-149; Code 2002, § 19-454) 
Secs. 19-455-19-480. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Passenger, Bus and Loading Zones 

Sec. 19-481. - Designation of loading and unloading zones. 
(a)  That part of the north side of Ninth Street, described as beginning 20 feet west of the west curbline of Bell Street at the intersection of Ninth and Bell Streets, extending west to the alley between Bell and Broadway Streets is designated as a loading zone. No person shall permit a motor vehicle to remain parked in the designated area for more than 15 minutes. 
(b)  A portion of the east side of Eden Street beginning 150 feet south of the south curbline of Main Street and extending south a distance of 20 feet is designated as a loading and unloading zone. No person shall permit a motor vehicle to remain parked in such designated area for more than 15 minutes. 
(Code 1986, § 16-176(b), (c); Code 2002, § 19-481) 
Sec. 19-482. - Use of passenger zones. 
    No operator of any vehicle shall stop, stand or park any vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the actual loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger zone. 
(Code 1986, § 16-171; Code 2002, § 19-482) 
Sec. 19-483. - Use of loading zones. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall stop, stand or park any vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the actual loading or unloading of passengers or for the unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a loading zone. 
(Code 1986, § 16-172; Code 2002, § 19-483) 
Sec. 19-484. - Use of bus zones and taxi zones. 
    No operator of any vehicle other than a bus shall stand or park in an officially designated bus zone, and no operator of any vehicle other than an intracity vehicle for hire shall park in any taxi zone. 
(Code 1986, § 16-173; Code 2002, § 19-484) 
Sec. 19-485. - Parking or standing of buses and vehicles for hire. 
    No operator of any bus or vehicle for hire shall stand or park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a zone which is specially established or set aside for the particular vehicle. However, this section shall not prevent the operator of an intracity vehicle for hire from temporarily stopping in accordance with other parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Code 1986, § 16-174; Code 2002, § 19-485) 
Sec. 19-486. - Shipping entrances to buildings. 
(a)  Special no parking spaces in front of shipping entrances may be provided and established by compliance with the conditions of this section. 
(b)  Any owner or occupant of a building adjacent to a street or alley desiring a certain no parking space immediately in front of a shipping entrance to such building shall make application to the traffic and transportation commission, setting forth all relevant information and stating the number of feet desired for such purpose. The traffic and transportation commission may grant or refuse such application, in its discretion, or grant the application with restrictions or limitations as it may fix which are reasonable under the circumstances. 
(c)  If the application is granted, the chief of police shall issue to the applicant a permit or certificate setting forth the location of such no parking space, the number of feet frontage fixed and such other limitations as may be pertinent. The permit may at any time be withdrawn or further limited by the traffic and transportation commission. 
(d)  The holder of the permit shall have the right to place no parking signs on the sidewalk marking the limits of such no parking space. Such signs shall be of the exact size, character and description required by the traffic and transportation commission, but shall be provided at the expense of the holder of the permit and shall bear the number of the permit issued. 
(e)  No vehicle shall be allowed to stop or remain standing in any special no parking space, except for the purpose of taking on or discharging merchandise, freight or passengers. Except as provided in this section, no person shall place or exhibit a sign or standard similar to those used by the police department upon any street or in any public place or attempt by signs or written or printed instructions to regulate traffic or the parking of vehicles. 
(Code 1986, § 16-137; Code 2002, § 19-486) 
Sec. 19-487. - Parking and loading or unloading trucks and commercial vehicles. 
(a)  Parking and storage in residential areas. Commercial vehicles and trucks shall not be parked or stored within any residential area except in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Not more than one commercial vehicle or truck of a maximum of 11/2 tons rated capacity and two axles, per family living on the premises, shall be permitted. Off-street parking shall be provided for this commercial vehicle. 
(2)  In no case shall a commercial vehicle or truck used for hauling explosives, gasoline, hazardous materials or liquefied petroleum products be permitted within any residential area. 
(3)  No tractor trailer rigs (semitrailers) or tractors for semitrailers shall be parked or stored on the street, street right-of-way, yard or driveway within any residential area. 
(4)  No trailer used for hauling or boat shall be stored or parked in any residential front yard or unscreened side yard or public-utility easement; nor shall such trailer or boat project beyond the front of any building in a residential district. However, any boat that is tagged for the current year and is in working condition may be parked on a trailer in a residential, hard-surfaced (asphalt/concrete) driveway providing the boat is covered with a tarpaulin. 
(b)  Loading; unloading. All commercial trucks which exceed a gross vehicular weight of five tons (10,000 pounds GVW) are prohibited to load or unload between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 4:00 a.m. within the city limits, except as follows: 
(1)  Designated truck routes. 
(2)  Commercial and industrial zones. 
(c)  Parking of vehicles carrying explosives, hazardous or flammable materials. Vehicles carrying explosives, hazardous materials or flammable materials are prohibited from parking within the city limits, except as follows: 
(1)  For the explicit purpose of loading or unloading. 
(2)  In those zoning districts where such activities are permitted. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person who shall violate this section or who fails to comply with any of the requirements of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-10. Each day upon which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 16-134(a), (c)-(e); Code 2002, § 19-487; Ord. No. 1943NS, § 1, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 2099NS, § 1, 8-4-2003; Ord. No. 2102NS, § 1, 9-2-2003) 
Secs. 19-488-19-515. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Municipal Parking Lots 

Sec. 19-516. - Designated and restrictions. 
    Municipal parking lots of the city are designated and the restrictions of the parking lots shall be as follows: 
(1)  Parking Lot A. Municipal Parking Lot A, located in the southwest corner of the intersection of North Street and Union Avenue, is all-day, free parking. 
(2)  Parking Lot B. Municipal Parking Lot B, located in the southeast corner of Ninth Street and Broadway Avenue, is designated as the west half being two-hour parking and the east half being all-day, free parking. 
(3)  Parking Lot C. Municipal Parking Lot C, located in the northwest corner of Philadelphia Avenue and Seventh Street, is all-day, free parking. 
(4)  Parking Lot D. Municipal Parking Lot D, located in the northwest corner of Broadway Avenue and Seventh Street, is all-day, free parking. 
(5)  Parking Lot E. Municipal Parking Lot E, located in the northwest corner of Bell and Tenth Streets, is all-day, free parking. 
(6)  Parking Lot F. Municipal Parking Lot F, located in the northwest corner of Bell and Seventh Streets, is all-day, free parking. 
(7)  Parking Lot G. Municipal Parking Lot G, located in the southeast corner of Philadelphia Avenue and Ninth Street, has the north half of the parking lot designated as all-day, free parking, and the west half (50 parking spaces) of the south half as library parking only, and the east half of the south half as two-hour parking. 
(8)  Parking Lot H. Municipal Parking Lot H, the public parking area north of and adjacent to the city hall lying east of the north door of the city hall, is two-hour parking. 
(Code 1986, § 16-142; Code 2002, § 19-516) 
Secs. 19-517-19-545. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Prohibited 

Sec. 19-546. - Certain places. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(4)  Within an intersection. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
(7)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings. 
(8)  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
(9)  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of such entrance, when properly signposted. 
(10)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(11)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(12)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway underpass. 
(13)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1986, § 16-132; Code 2002, § 19-546; Ord. No. 2091NS, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1003. 
Secs. 19-547-19-570. - Reserved.

Sec. 19-604. - Two-hour parking. 
    Parking a motor vehicle or allowing a motor vehicle to remain parked on North Louisa Street between Wallace Street and Dill Street on the east side thereof between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, is restricted to two-hour parking, and any person who violates this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense.

Sec. 19-605. - Fifteen-minute parking. 
(a)  There is established a 15-minute parking limit for motor vehicles in all designated parking spaces at the following locations: 
(1)  In the block on all of the south side and all of the north side of Ninth Street between Bell Street and Union Avenue; 
(2)  On both the north side and south side of Ninth Street between Broadway Avenue and the alley between Broadway Avenue and Bell Street; 
(3)  At 116 North Beard in the north half of the block on the west side from the alley to Ninth Street; 
(4)  At 114 North Beard on the west side from Main Street north to the alley; and 
(5)  At 4 East Main on the north side of Main Street in front of the minimall. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a motor vehicle to remain parked in any such space for more than 15 minutes between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., except for Sundays and legal holidays. 
(Code 1986, § 16-141(4); Code 2002, § 19-605) 
Sec. 19-606. - Thirty-minute parking. 
(a)  There is established a 30-minute parking limit for motor vehicles in all designated parking spaces at the following locations: 
(1)  In the block on the north side of Ninth Street between Union and Philadelphia Avenues; and 
(2)  On both the north side and south side of Ninth Street from the alley east to Broadway Avenue. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a motor vehicle to remain parked in any such space for more than 30 minutes between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., except for Sundays and legal holidays. 
(Code 1986, § 16-141(5); Code 2002, § 19-606)

Subdivision VII. - Additional Parking Zones 

Sec. 19-636. - Established.

DIVISION 3. - TRUCK ROUTES 

Sec. 19-666. - Through truck routes established. 
(a)  There are established in the city through truck routes. 
(b)  All through trucks designed for or used in commercial usage and/or heavy hauling shall remain on state and federal route highways, unless an alternate route has been provided and signs installed to so indicate. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the city manager to cause to be placed and maintained conspicuous signs bearing appropriate words and markings designating such routes to conform with this section. The signs so placed shall be of a sufficient size to be easily readable at a distance of 100 feet by any person using, approaching or entering such truck routes. 
(d)  The following streets, avenues, public ways or portions thereof are designated and established as truck routes within the city: 
Street or Avenue From To Beard Farrall Gordon Cooper Drive Farrall Highway 177/270 Harrison 45th Kickapoo Harrison Gordon Cooper Drive Beard South city limits Harrison Farrall North city limits Kickapoo I-40 Farrall Kickapoo Spur Highway 177/170 Kickapoo MacArthur Harrison West city limits Highland Harrison East city limits Highway 177/270 North city limits South city limits  
(e)  Vehicles required by statute to be licensed for three-ton carrying capacity or over shall be prohibited from using any of the city's public streets and places for travel, except for the purpose of access to and exit from a location within the city which has not been legally designated as a truck route. Whenever it is necessary for vehicles of the class described in this subsection to travel to and from a location on any of the city's public streets and places for purposes of loading and/or unloading merchandise or material at such location, the route traveled shall be as short and direct as possible from and to the most available, legally designated truck routes. 
(f)  Unless otherwise legally posted by official signs in the city, any legally licensed truck shall be permitted the privilege of being parked on any of the public streets or places within the city legally designated as truck routes, if so parked in the manner prescribed by law, for a continuous period of time not to exceed two hours. 
(Code 1986, § 16-9; Code 2002, § 19-666) 
Sec. 19-667. - Use of streets by commercial trucks. 
(a)  All commercial trucks which exceed a gross vehicular weight of five tons (10,000 pounds GVW) are prohibited from using or traveling any streets and alleys within the city limits, except as follows: 
(1)  On a designated truck route. 
(2)  On section line roads, arterials. 
(3)  For the explicit purpose of loading or unloading. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate this section or who fails to comply with any of the requirements of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-10. Each day upon which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 16-134(b), (e); Code 2002, § 19-667) 
Secs. 19-668-19-695. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - HEAVY VEHICLES 

Sec. 19-696. - Load limits on bridges. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the term "gross weight" is defined as the weight of a vehicle without load, plus the weight of any load thereon. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a truck or other motor vehicle whose gross weight exceeds five tons on or across the following bridges located within the city: 
(1)  Six-tenths mile west of Highway 102 on Archery Range Road, also known as BPW Road. 
(2)  Three-tenths mile west of Highway 102 on Clear Pond Road. 
(3)  One-tenth mile east of Walker Road on Ingram Road, also known as By-Pass Road. 
(4)  One-fourth mile west of NS 332 on Ingram Road, also known as By-Pass Road. 
(5)  One-tenth mile west of Highway 102 on Rose Lane. 
(6)  One-half mile north of the Dam Road on Walker Road. 
(7)  Three-fourths mile south of the Dam Road on Walker Road. 
(8)  One-tenth mile west of Highway 102 on Wanda Drive. 
(c)  Any person who desires to cross one of the bridges described in subsection (b) of this section with a vehicle whose gross weight exceeds five tons may apply to the city manager for a special permit to cross a specific bridge. The city manager is authorized to investigate the circumstances relating to the application and cause appropriate studies to be made. If, after such studies are made, it appears to the city manager that the crossing of such bridge by such vehicle will not likely cause damage to it, the city manager may issue a special permit to the applicant to cross the bridge. However, no such permit shall be issued until the applicant has executed an indemnity agreement agreeing to indemnify and save harmless the city and all other persons from damages or injuries caused by such vehicle crossing or attempting to cross the bridge. 
(d)  Any person who violates this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs, or imprisonment in the city jail not exceeding 30 days or punishment by both such fine and imprisonment.
