    Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the authority and the commission, may appeal to the district court within 30 days after such decision as provided by the rules of the authority. 
(Code 2002, § 22-215.10; Ord. No. 2545NS, § 1(Exh. 1), 6-2-2014) 
Sec. 22-692. - Penalties. 
    Each violation of these regulations, the Aircraft Pilot and Passenger Protection Act, commission rulings, or of any regulation, order, or ruling promulgated hereunder, shall constitute a misdemeanor and be punishable by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, or imprisonment not more than 30 days, or both; and each day a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 2002, § 22-215.11; Ord. No. 2545NS, § 1(Exh. 1), 6-2-2014) 
Secs. 22-693-22-712. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 17. - LAKE PROTECTION ZONE (LPZ) 

Sec. 22-713. - Lake Protection Zone Overlay District. 
    The regulations governing the lake protection zone overlay district are codified in , article V of this chapter. 
(Code 2002, § 22-220; Ord. No. 2545NS, § 1(Exh. 1), 6-2-2014) 
Chapter 23 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Solid Waste Management Act, 27A O.S. § 2-10-101 et seq.; municipal solid waste management, 27A O.S. § 2-10-901; regional solid waste planning, 27A O.S. § 2-10-1101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage means vegetable or animal refuse accumulating from kitchens, pantries, dining rooms, hotels, restaurants, boardinghouses, dwellings, markets, stores and other establishments. 
    Refuse or rubbish means ashes, cinders, paper, broken ware, discarded shoes, plastic, tin cans and such other refuse as may be termed the natural accumulation of resident families and places of business. 
    Solid waste means all putrescible and nonputrescible refuse in solid or semisolid form, including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes or incinerator residue, street refuse, dead animals, demolition wastes, construction wastes, solid or semisolid commercial and industrial wastes including explosives, biomedical wastes, chemical wastes and herbicide and pesticide wastes. The term "solid waste" does not include the following: 
(1)  Scrap materials which are source separated for collection and processing as industrial raw materials, except when contained in the waste collected by or in behalf of a solid waste management system; or 
(2)  Used motor oil, which shall not be considered to be a solid waste, but shall be considered a deleterious substance, if the used motor oil is recycled for energy reclamation and is ultimately destroyed when recycled. 
    Yard waste means rubbish or trash consisting of leaves, grass clippings, brush and tree limbs not larger than one inch in diameter and cut into lengths not more than four feet long which are accumulated from property within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 22-1; Code 2002, § 23-1; Ord. No. 2312NS, § 1, 6-4-2007) 
State Law reference- Waste tires generally, 27A O.S. § 2-10-101 et seq. 
Sec. 23-2. - Reservation of authority of city. 
    The city reserves to itself the exclusive right and privilege to collect, remove and dispose of and to provide for the collection, removal and disposal of all garbage, rubbish, refuse, waste, trash and unwholesome and unsanitary matter within the city, either by contracting with some suitable person for the removal of such or by removing the garbage, rubbish, refuse, waste, trash and unwholesome and unsanitary matter by city employees, at its discretion. 
(Code 1986, § 22-2; Code 2002, § 23-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 27A O.S. § 2-10-102. 
Sec. 23-3. - Superintendent of sanitation department. 
    If the city does not elect to enter into a contract for the collection and removal of garbage, refuse and rubbish as contemplated in this chapter, the city manager shall designate an appropriate department to enforce this chapter and all other sections of this Code and city ordinances relating to sanitation. The person in charge thereof shall inspect the work of garbage and rubbish collection and observe premises in general, to see that all regulations which relate to the placing, keeping and removing of garbage and rubbish are strictly enforced. This section shall not take away any of the authority or lessen the duty of any other city officer to enforce this chapter or any other section of this Code or city ordinance relating to sanitation. 
(Code 1986, § 22-3; Code 2002, § 23-3) 
Sec. 23-4. - Standards for receptacles; placement of receptacles for collection. 
(a)  All owners, occupants or other persons in charge of any residence, apartment or any multifamily dwelling within the city shall place all garbage in either a 95-gallon or 65-gallon polycart to be supplied by the contractor for the city's waste pickup service. Each owner, occupant or person in charge shall clear between a 95-gallon or 65-gallon polycart for their residence. Each owner, occupant or person in charge of a residence shall have the option of requesting additional 95-gallon polycarts for a fee as set forth in section 23-38. Fifty-five-gallon drums and similar receptacles are specifically prohibited. 
(b)  Polycarts shall be placed curbside at least three feet from any mailbox, gas meter, fire hydrant or any other utility equipment or structure located above ground, and within two feet of the curb or road. Placement of the polycarts in alleys is specifically prohibited. 
(c)  No person shall park a vehicle between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. along a road where garbage is to be picked up that day. 
(Code 1986, § 22-4; Code 2002, § 23-4; Ord. No. 2312NS, § 2, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 2436NS, § 1, 6-21-2010) 
Sec. 23-5. - Turning over, misplacing or damaging receptacles. 
    No person shall turn over, misplace or damage any polycart or move the polycart from its position so as to permit the contents of the polycart to spill or fall out on any property within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 22-5; Code 2002, § 23-5; Ord. No. 2312NS, § 3, 6-4-2007) 
Sec. 23-6. - Dumping refuse. 
    No person shall dump any manure, garbage, offal, refuse or other waste matter on any public or private grounds within the city or within one-half mile of the city for the purpose of filling up any lot or piece of ground or disposing of the manure, garbage, offal, refuse or other waste matter without first getting permission from the county health department. 
(Code 1986, § 22-6; Code 2002, § 23-6) 
Secs. 23-7-23-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND REMOVAL 

Sec. 23-36. - Contract for removal; bond and insurance. 
    The city commission may contract with some suitable person for the removal of any garbage, waste, refuse or rubbish on such terms and conditions as it shall deem to the best interests of the city, including the requirement of a bond, the terms, conditions and limits of which are approved by the city commission and conditioned on the faithful performance of the contract entered into, and liability insurance in a sum fixed by the city commission and conditioned that the city will be saved harmless against any liability imposed by law against the city as the result of any negligence causing damage to any person or property on the part of the principal obligor. 
(Code 1986, § 22-21; Code 2002, § 23-36) 
Sec. 23-37. - Vehicles. 
(a)  All vehicles used in the removal, collection or transportation of garbage and refuse shall be constructed in such a manner that will prevent any portion of such garbage, waste, refuse and rubbish from leaking, spilling, falling or blowing out of such vehicle or onto any highways, streets, avenues, alleys or public or private places. 
(b)  All such vehicles, except when being loaded or unloaded, shall be kept completely and securely covered so that no part of the contents thereof shall at any time be exposed to view. 
(c)  Such vehicles shall not be loaded above a point that will not permit its being drawn or driven over the highways, alleys or streets without any portion of the contents being spilled or falling therefrom. 
(d)  All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall have upon them, in figures and letters at least three inches in height, the name of the owner or operator and the number given the vehicles. 
(e)  All such vehicles shall at all times be subject to inspection by the department in charge of sanitation. If any vehicle is defective or unfit for use, the department may prevent the use of the vehicle until put in proper condition to comply with this section. Any person aggrieved shall have a right to appeal to the city commission, which shall hear the appeal at its next regular meeting or at other times as ordered by it, and its decision thereon shall be final. 
(f)  No person shall transport or haul over the city streets any manure, sand, mud, dirt, clay or ashes, except in a vehicle so constructed as to prevent spilling or scattering of any of the substances therein contained upon the streets and in accordance with any regulations relating thereto. 
(Code 1986, § 22-23; Code 2002, § 23-37) 
Sec. 23-38. - Charges. 
(a)  Monthly charges shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, adopted and updated by the city commission from time to time. 
(b)  The rates in subsection (a) of this section are based on a combined once a week collection of solid waste and yard waste. 
(c)  For multifamily dwellings and manufactured home parks where garbage is collected in central locations for family units therein and placed in commercial solid waste containers, monthly rates shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per unit or manufactured home pad in a manufactured home park, notwithstanding the fact that some units or pads may not be occupied. 
(d)  Charges for garbage service shall be included on the water bills issued by the city, and it shall be the duty of all persons so billed to pay the charges on or before the due date of such water bills. If such sanitation bills are not paid as provided in this section, the service shall be discontinued along with the water service. 
(e)  If a charge is made for the collection and removal of garbage or rubbish from the owner or occupant of any premises in the city that does not have water service, a special bill for such removal shall be sent to such person and shall be paid as provided in this section on or before the due date shown on the bill. Failure to pay the charges shall be deemed a violation of this section, and such service shall be discontinued. 
(f)  The minimum deposit for garbage service from the city shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, which shall be made at the time application is made for such service. The deposit shall remain with the city to the credit of the person paying the deposit and shall be subject to any charge for garbage service that is unpaid. 
(Code 1986, § 22-24; Code 2002, § 23-38; Ord. No. 2145NS, § 1, 3-15-2004; Ord. No. 2272NS, § 1, 7-17-2006; Ord. No. 2312NS, § 4, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 2436NS, § 2, 6-21-2010) 
State Law reference- Fees and charges for collection of solid wastes, 27A O.S. § 2-10-901(B). 
Sec. 23-39. - Types of refuse collected by city; cleanup campaigns. 
    The city will pick up yard waste once a week, provided such items are placed in disposable bags, and further provided, that tree limbs are not larger than one inch in diameter and are cut into lengths not more than four feet long. A person desiring the city to pick up such items shall place them on the curb or roadside to be picked up on the same day of their solid waste pickup. No abandoned or discarded furniture, appliances, building materials, dirt, rocks and similar materials shall be picked up by the city except on the dates specified for bulk waste pickup. Such items shall be placed in the manner and location designated by the city. At no time will any person leave hazardous waste to be picked up by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 22-22; Code 2002, § 23-39; Ord. No. 2312NS, § 5, 6-4-2007; Ord. No. 2436NS, § 3, 6-21-2010) 
Sec. 23-40. - Disposal of household hazardous waste; rates. 
    Household hazardous waste (HHW) may be delivered by residents of the city (customers) to the Oklahoma City HHW Collection Facility at Southwest 15th and Portland. Customers must provide proof of Shawnee residency in the form of a valid drivers license and current city water bill. Charges for the disposal of HHW are as follows and will be billed by Oklahoma City to the city which will bill the customer through the standard utility billing process. All nonliquid HHW products will be converted through use of an equivalent rate unit (ERU) measurement scale: 
< = 7.5 gallons 0.5 ERU $39.50 > 7.5 gallons to 15 gallons 1.0 ERU $79.00 > 15 gallons to 22.5 gallons 1.5 ERU $118.50 > 22.5 gallons 2.0 ERU $158.00 Note: 
Minimum charge per vehicle per arrival = 0.5 ERU. 
Maximum charge per vehicle per arrival = 2.0 ERU.  
(Code 2002, § 23-40; Ord. No. 2333NS, § 1, 11-19-2007) 
Secs. 23-41-23-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY DUMP; SANITARY LANDFILL 

Sec. 23-66. - Use permitted; materials restricted. 
    All persons and their agents, whose residences or places of doing business are within the corporate limits of the city, shall be privileged to use the facilities of the area established by the city as a sanitary landfill for the depositing or dumping of empty cans or bottles, glass, wooden or paper boxes, crates, old metals or alloys, stone, ashes, brick, tires and the like originating in the city. Except as provided in this article, no person other than those designated in this section shall enter into or upon a sanitary landfill or use a sanitary landfill for any purpose whatsoever, and no refuse except refuse originating in the city shall be placed in a sanitary landfill. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any garbage, vegetable matter subject to decay, bodies of animals, grease, fats, oil or any similar material in a dump, but such items may be deposited in sanitary landfills. 
(Code 1986, § 22-41; Code 2002, § 23-66) 
Sec. 23-67. - Charges. 
(a)  No charge shall be made for the privilege of depositing or dumping materials in a city sanitary landfill, except for the following: 
(1)  Building or construction contractors; 
(2)  Commercial firms located outside the corporate limits that shall be permitted to use such facilities upon payment of fees as provided in this article; and 
(3)  Commercial firms located inside the corporate limits that deposit or dump more than one load of material per week. 
(b)  The fee to be collected from persons included in subsection (a) of this section using the city dump or sanitary landfill shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per cubic yard of material disposed therein. 
(Code 1986, §§ 22-42, 22-43; Code 2002, § 23-67) 
Sec. 23-68. - Records; monthly billing. 
    The caretaker at a city sanitary landfill shall keep complete records of all persons subject to the charges provided in this article who deposit or dump material in city dumps or sanitary landfills and shall regularly transmit to the city clerk information for billing as directed by the city manager. Billing for such depositing or dumping shall be done by the utility department on a monthly basis, unless special billing or collection is arranged with the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 22-44; Code 2002, § 23-68) 
Chapter 24 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Roads and streets, 11 O.S. § 36-101 et seq.; improvement districts, 11 O.S. § 39-101 et seq.; cooperation by state highway commission, 69 O.S. § 303; cooperation by department of highways, 69 O.S. § 317; bridges, 69 O.S. §§ 611, 612; appropriation of highway, 69 O.S. § 648. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Violations. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person who shall violate any section of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. Each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 23-1; Code 2002, § 24-1) 
Sec. 24-2. - Street paving or improvement work. 
(a)  Bond. Before any person shall engage in work of any kind within the city, which constitutes the paving, by cement, blacktop or gravel, or otherwise improving of any street, he shall execute and deliver to the city a bond in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, that he shall save the city harmless from any liabilities that may arise in the use of any of the streets or alleys where such work is performed and that he shall in all respects comply with all city ordinances, rules and regulations relating to the use of streets. 
(b)  Liability insurance. Before any person shall engage in work of any kind in the city constituting the paving, by cement, blacktop or gravel, or otherwise improving of any street, the person doing such work shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy for an indemnity fund as follows: 
(1)  The insurance policy shall be issued by a company licensed and authorized to do business in the state and shall provide public liability insurance coverage for each operation required in the conduct of such work. The insurance policy coverage, for injury or death of any one person, for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident and for property damage in any one accident growing out of the work, shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  The policy cannot be cancelled until ten days' notice of cancellation is given to the city clerk, and the policy shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city of any changes therein. 
(3)  The insurance policy shall be approved by the city manager or designee and endorsed thereon. The insurance policy shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(4)  The insurance policy shall be made for the use and benefit and protection of the city and for the use and benefit and protection of any person who may suffer injury either to his person or property because of an accident or omission or negligence of any person, his agents or servants engaged in such work. If the policy is approved by the city manager or designee, it shall remain in force and effect during the life of the policy. 
(c)  Manner of doing work. Any work of any kind in the city constituting the paving, by cement, blacktop or gravel, or any other improving of streets shall be done under the supervision and according to specifications of the city engineer and shall be inspected and approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1986, §§ 23-2-23-4; Code 2002, § 24-2) 
Sec. 24-3. - Playing games. 
    No person shall engage in any game of marbles, ball playing or other game upon any of the city streets, avenues, alleys, sidewalks or crosswalks. 
(Code 1986, § 23-5; Code 2002, § 24-3) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prohibit games on streets, sidewalks, etc., 11 O.S. § 22-117. 
Sec. 24-4. - Open doors or gratings in sidewalks. 
    No person shall keep open or leave open any cellar door or grating of any kind in or upon any sidewalk in the city or suffer or permit the door or grating to be left open, except when necessarily open during the use thereof, and during such time the door or grating shall be properly guarded and protected. 
(Code 1986, § 23-6; Code 2002, § 24-4) 
Sec. 24-5. - Damaging fresh concrete. 
    No person shall walk upon any fresh concrete that has been set in any sidewalk, pavement or curb or step upon, score, mark, deface, injure or throw any article of any kind whatever thereupon. 
(Code 1986, § 23-8; Code 2002, § 24-5) 
Sec. 24-6. - Driving over curbs. 
    No person shall recklessly or negligently drive any heavily loaded truck, tractor or wagon loaded in excess of one ton into, over or on the curbing or concrete guttering of any paved street. 
(Code 1986, § 23-9; Code 2002, § 24-6) 
Sec. 24-7. - Defacing or marking. 
    No person shall cut, carve, mark, write or advertise, engrave or inscribe upon any sidewalk, curbing, pavement or other public part of any street any sign, mark, advertisement or effigy, other than to show the sidewalk contractor's nameplate. 
(Code 1986, § 23-10; Code 2002, § 24-7) 
Sec. 24-8. - Responsibility for cleanliness. 
(a)  No property owner, occupant or agent of any property that abuts or adjoins any street or avenue in the city shall allow or permit any animal or vegetable substance; any tin, glass or piece of iron; or any trash, mud, snow, ice, dirt, slop, refuse matter or filth of any kind or description whatever to accumulate or remain on any part of the sidewalk abutting or adjacent to the premises owned or occupied by such person. 
(b)  No property owner, occupant or agent of such property shall fail or refuse to clean off the sidewalk abutting or adjacent to the property owned or occupied by him, as provided in this section, within 24 hours after notice is served on him by any police officer, the public works director or other city officer. 
(c)  No person shall sweep out or deposit on any of the city sidewalks or streets any dirt or trash of any kind or sweep from the sidewalk into the street any dirt or trash of any kind whatsoever. 
(d)  No property owner, occupant or agent of such property shall allow grass to grow over the edge of the curb and into the street or gutter of the street abutting or adjacent to the property owned or occupied by that person. 
(Code 1986, § 23-11; Code 2002, § 24-8; Ord. No. 2237NS, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Sec. 24-9. - Throwing or depositing harmful materials. 
(a)  No person shall throw any stone, trash, tack, nail, rubbish, brick or other missile in, on or onto or across any street or alley or in any public or other place. 
(b)  No person shall throw, drop or cast any bottle, jug, jar or other container which is breakable and suited to holding any liquids upon the city streets, alleys or sidewalks. No person shall commit such act in the presence of any peace officer who has apprehended or is about to apprehend and arrest the person doing the act for violation of this Code or any other city ordinances or the laws of the state or the United States. 
(c)  No person shall throw, place, leave, scatter or otherwise deposit any papers, boxes, cartons or rubbish of any kind, including, but not limited to, glass, plastic or metal containers or parts thereof, or any other object that might cause injury to persons or damage to property upon any street, alley, avenue or other public place within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 23-12; Code 2002, § 24-9) 
Sec. 24-10. - Refuse left on premises. 
    No person shall allow to remain in any alley or on any parking area or street adjoining, in front of, to the rear of or alongside of his premises any rubbish, waste, trash or other accumulations of discarded matter, except in a manner provided by law. 
(Code 1986, § 23-13; Code 2002, § 24-10) 
Sec. 24-11. - Escape of water or steam. 
    No person shall allow or permit water or steam to escape from any water main or service steam pipe or exhaust pipe into or upon any street, alley or sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1986, § 23-14; Code 2002, § 24-11) 
Sec. 24-12. - Draining of oil, grease or slop. 
    No person shall permit any oil, grease or slop to run onto or drain into any city street or alley. 
(Code 1986, § 23-15; Code 2002, § 24-12) 
Secs. 24-13-24-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to construct, repair and alter sidewalks, 11 O.S. § 36-101. 

Sec. 24-41. - Applicability of article. 
    All sidewalk construction and repair on any street, avenue or alley in the city shall be done subject to and shall strictly conform in all respects to all sections in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 23-31; Code 2002, § 24-41) 
Sec. 24-42. - Responsibility for damaged or unsafe sidewalks. 
    No person shall permit the sidewalk in front or on the side of his premises to be or continue in a broken or unsafe condition so as to endanger life and limb of any person traveling thereon. 
(Code 1986, § 23-32; Code 2002, § 24-42) 
Sec. 24-43. - Report of hazardous conditions. 
    Any city officer who discovers or receives a report from any citizen of any defect, hole, obstruction or any other condition in or upon or under any sidewalk in the city which constitutes a hazard to pedestrians or to public safety shall, at once, report such condition to the office of the community development director. 
(Code 1986, § 23-33; Code 2002, § 24-43; Ord. No. 2238NS, § 1, 2-21-2006) 
Sec. 24-44. - Notice to repair. 
(a)  Upon receiving a report prescribed by section 24-43 or upon receipt of equivalent information from any reliable source, the city community development director shall begin the process of causing the defective sidewalk to be repaired either by the owner of the property or by the city pursuant to the procedures set forth in section 7-582. 
(b)  If, on the date specified for the unsafe condition hearing, the community development director determines the sidewalk to be in such a condition as to be a hazard to pedestrians or public safety the community development director shall order the property owner to repair the sidewalk at the owner's expense within 30 days of the hearing. 
(c)  The service of all notices prescribed by this section shall be evidenced by the return of the officer making such service, certified in his official capacity, and filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 23-34; Code 2002, § 24-44; Ord. No. 2238NS, §§ 2, 3, 2-21-2006) 
Sec. 24-45. - Failure to repair. 
(a)  If the provisions of an order given by the community development director are not complied with, the city may proceed to construct or repair the sidewalk or let a contract therefor, without advertisement, and the cost of making such repairs shall be assessed against the abutting property as provided by state law. All such assessments which amount to $10.00 or less shall be paid in one installment at the next taxpaying period after the assessment is certified by the county treasurer, as provided by law. 
(b)  If the costs of the work performed under this section are not paid within 90 days from the date of the service of the notice prescribed by section 24-44, the city clerk shall forward a certified statement of the amount of such costs to the county treasurer to be levied upon the property and to be collected by the county treasurer in the manner prescribed by law. 
(c)  The property owner shall have the right of appeal to the city commission from any order of the community development director. Such appeal shall be taken by filing written notice of appeal, clearly stating all grounds upon which the appeal is based, with the city clerk within ten days after the administrative order is rendered. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from abating a defective sidewalk constituting a hazard to pedestrians or public safety as a nuisance or otherwise exercising its police power to protect the health, safety or welfare of the general public. 
(e)  The city officers, employees or agents shall not be liable for any damages or loss of property due to the repair of any defective sidewalk performed pursuant to this section, or any previous section, or as otherwise prescribed by law. 
(Code 1986, § 23-35; Code 2002, § 24-45; Ord. No. 2238NS, §§ 4, 5, 2-21-2006) 
Sec. 24-46. - Permit to construct or repair. 
(a)  Required. No person shall build, construct or repair any sidewalk on any street, avenue or alley in the city without first obtaining a written permit approved by the building inspector. The permit fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(b)  Contents. All permits issued pursuant to this section shall show the name of the property owner, the contractor or person who is to do the work, the lot and block numbers on which the work is to be done and the addition or part of the city in which it is to be located. 
(c)  Terms and conditions. All permits issued for sidewalk construction or repair shall be issued on the condition that the work will be done strictly in accordance with the city regulations relating to the construction or repair, and all persons having any part or interest in any sidewalk construction or repair are charged with and bound by this article, notwithstanding that the provisions may not be specially set forth in the permit. 
(Code 1986, §§ 23-36-23-38; Code 2002, § 24-46) 
Sec. 24-47. - Work to conform to established levels and grades. 
    All sidewalk construction and repair work shall be conformable to the levels and grades established for that purpose by the city and on file with the city engineer. It shall be the duty of the engineer to establish all grades and levels for all sidewalks constructed. 
(Code 1986, § 23-39; Code 2002, § 24-47) 
Sec. 24-48. - Requirements and specifications. 
(a)  Materials. Sidewalks constructed in any street, avenue, alley or public ground in the city shall be constructed either of concrete or other material, subject to the approval of the city engineer. Concrete shall invariably be used except in new construction where there is no concrete construction within the block. 
(b)  Specifications. All sidewalks shall be built according to the following specifications: 
(1)  Width. The width in residential sections shall be five feet or wider where required by the city engineer, provided that in residential sections where an adjoining concrete walk is less than five feet wide a lesser width may be allowed by the city engineer. In exercising his discretion in such cases, the city engineer shall be governed by the density of population in the immediate vicinity and the future demands to be made by the public on such walk. 
(2)  Base. All bases shall be four inches, except where the city engineer requires additional depths for driveways. 
(3)  Mixtures. All concrete mixtures shall be 1-2-4 proportion, well mixed. 
(4)  Concrete. Except as otherwise provided in this article, all walks shall be of concrete and nothing else, made in one course, properly troweled and tamped to bring a smooth mortar surface. 
(5)  Subbase. Places that are low and continuously damp or soaked shall have a five-inch subbase of gravel or cinders, with tiling added for drainage as specified by the city engineer. 
(6)  Blocking. All walks shall be cut into blocks not greater than five feet in the greatest dimension. Shallow marked grooves are not permissible. All cuts shall be made with one-eighth-inch to 3/16 -inch separation plates and cut to the cross section of the walk and shall be provided with a square lug on each end which fits into a notch in the forms. 
(7)  Expansion joints. Expansion joints one-half inch wide and filled with bituminous material shall be placed in all walks, and joints shall not be more than 50 feet apart. Expansion joints shall be placed on all sides of driveway crossing blocks. At all junctions of walks with the curbs, there shall be one-inch expansion joints filled with bituminous material. 
(8)  Slopes. All walks shall slope one way toward the curb with a fall of one-fourth inch to each foot. 
(9)  Grades and levels. The city engineer shall supply all grades and levels, and none other shall be used. 
(10)  Finish. Sidewalks shall have a wooden float finish, true to line and grade, and shall bear thereon the imprint of the person constructing the sidewalk. Such wooden float finish may be waived by the city engineer in the exercise of his discretion. 
(Code 1986, § 23-40; Code 2002, § 24-48) 
Sec. 24-49. - Certificates of approval. 
    All sidewalk construction and repair work shall be done under the direct supervision of the city engineer. It shall be the duty of the city engineer, when any construction or repair work has been completely finished in accordance with this article, to issue a certificate of approval. No right of action for work done or labor or materials supplied on any contract for sidewalk construction or repair shall arise, nor shall any materialman's or laborer's lien be held to be established until the city engineer has approved the work and issued and delivered his certificate of approval to the proper person. The certificate shall be issued only after the completion of the work and shall certify that the work and materials in all respects comply with the city regulations. 
(Code 1986, § 23-41; Code 2002, § 24-49) 
Sec. 24-50. - Repairs. 
    All sidewalks out of repair shall be repaired with good material of the same kind and dimensions and of a quality equal to that originally used in the construction of sidewalks and well laid so as to correspond with the rest of the sidewalk. Such of the sidewalk or part that has settled so as to make depressions or that has become raised above the grade of the sidewalk shall be replaced on the same grade as the rest of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1986, § 23-42; Code 2002, § 24-50) 
Sec. 24-51. - Covenant of indemnity. 
    Any person issued a permit for sidewalk construction or repair shall execute a covenant indemnifying the city against any and all claims for damages of any kind or nature and against any and all judgments predicated upon such claims which may arise by virtue of the construction or repairs of the sidewalk; the storage or emplacement of any equipment, tools or materials incident thereto; and the performance of any and all work incident to such construction or repairs. 
(Code 1986, § 23-43; Code 2002, § 24-51) 
Secs. 24-52-24-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION OF DRIVEWAY APPROACHES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Corner means the point of intersection of the outside lines of the traveled way of any public right-of-way. 
    Curb parking space means a length of curbing, equal to 22 feet, along the edge of any traveled way where any motor vehicle is authorized or permitted to park. 
    Curb return means that portion of the curbing along the edge or side of any driveway approach which connects the driveway approach with the curbing along the edge of any traveled way, including the radius of curvature. 
    Driveway approach means any area, between the right-of-way line of any public street and traveled portion of such street, used for the purpose of providing access for motor vehicles from the traveled way of the public street to any private property adjacent to such street. 
    Outside sidewalk line means a line contiguous with that edge of any public sidewalk which is next to the traveled way of any public street or, if there is no public sidewalk, a line in the street right-of-way which is parallel to and four feet from the street right-of-way line. 
    Parcel of land means any private tract of land in the city to which a proposed driveway approach is to be constructed or emplaced. 
    Specifications means the specifications prepared by the public works department and approved by the city commission. 
    Traveled way or street means that portion of any public right-of-way which has been improved for or which is designed or used by or for the travel or operation of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1986, § 23-56; Code 2002, § 24-81) 
Sec. 24-82. - Compliance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or emplace any driveway approach without first complying with this article. 
(Code 1986, § 23-57; Code 2002, § 24-82) 
Sec. 24-83. - Plans and specifications. 
    All driveway approaches shall be constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications for such work on file in the office of the building inspector. A copy of such typical plans and specifications is attached to Ordinance No. 531NS, on file in the city clerk's office, and the plans and specifications are by reference incorporated in this article and made a part of this article with the same force and effect as though completely set forth in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 23-58; Code 2002, § 24-83) 
Sec. 24-84. - Commencement and completion of work. 
    Upon commencement of the construction of any driveway approach, notice thereof shall be given to the building inspector, and such construction shall be completed within 30 days after its commencement, unless weather conditions or other forces of nature make such completion impossible. Failure to complete the construction within 30 days from its commencement shall be deemed an unlawful act. 
(Code 1986, § 23-59; Code 2002, § 24-84) 
Secs. 24-85-24-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 24-111. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct a driveway approach or to cut into, remove or destroy any part of any curb along the edge of any traveled way without first securing a permit. 
(Code 1986, § 23-71; Code 2002, § 24-111) 
Sec. 24-112. - Application. 
    Prior to the construction or emplacement of any driveway approach, any person having a vested interest in the parcel of land to which such approach will run or the person who is to perform the work incident to the construction or emplacement of such driveway approach shall file an application in the office of the building inspector, which application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name or legal description of every person having any vested interest in the parcel of land to which the proposed approach will run; 
(2)  The street address of the parcel of land or, if such parcel has no street address, the name of the street upon whose right-of-way such parcel abuts and the location of the parcel upon the street with reference to the nearest intersecting street; 
(3)  The legal description of the parcel of land; 
(4)  The width of the proposed driveway approach and, if such width is not uniform along the entire length of such approach, the location on the approach of each variance in width; 
(5)  The design of the approach and the type of materials to be used in the construction or emplacement thereof; 
(6)  The total estimated cost of the approach; 
(7)  The scheduled date for the commencement of the work on the approach; 
(8)  The name and address of the contractor or other person who is to undertake the work incident to the construction or emplacement of the approach; 
(9)  Attached to the application, a plat showing the dimensions of the parcel of land, the location and the nature of all improvements upon the land and the proposed location of the driveway approach, showing its proposed dimensions in the same scale as that of the parcel of land and its improvements; and 
(10)  Such other information as may be deemed necessary by the building inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 23-72; Code 2002, § 24-112) 
Sec. 24-113. - Preliminary inspection. 
    Within seven days from the filing of an application under this division, the building inspector or authorized representative shall conduct a preliminary inspection of the site of the proposed driveway approach and shall determine if the approach upon its completion will conform to and be in accordance with all specifications adopted under this article. 
(Code 1986, § 23-73; Code 2002, § 24-113) 
Sec. 24-114. - Issuance. 
(a)  Upon completion of the preliminary inspection, if it is determined that the proposed driveway approach will conform to and be in accordance with all specifications adopted under this article and otherwise will meet the requirements of all other laws and regulations, the building inspector shall issue a permit for such construction. The permit shall be issued in the name of the applicant. 
(b)  If it is determined that the proposed construction or emplacement will not be in conformity with this article or the provisions of any other law or regulation, the building inspector shall advise the applicant of any and all changes which will be necessary, and the applicant shall file with the building inspector such amendments to his application as may be necessary to incorporate such changes. 
(c)  If such amendments are sufficient to show the necessary changes, the building inspector shall issue such permit as provided in this section. 
(d)  No permit shall be issued if the proposed construction will be in violation of this article or of any other law or regulation. 
(e)  In order to defray the cost of administering this article, a fee of in an amount as described in the city fee schedule shall be charged for each permit issued. If a curb is cut into, a fee for cutting or removing a curbing exceeding 20 feet shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per foot for each additional foot in excess of 20 feet. Such distances measured in linear feet shall be measured at the outside sidewalk or property line as defined in this article. The fee shall be paid at the office of the building inspector, and no permit shall be issued until such charge has been paid. 
(Code 1986, § 23-74; Code 2002, § 24-114) 
Sec. 24-115. - Duration; renewal. 
    Each permit issued under this division shall be valid for a period of six months from the date of issuance, and the construction of any approach may be commenced under such permit within the six-month period from and after the date of the issuance of the permit. Any such permit may be renewed for an additional six-month period by the payment of an additional fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, to be paid to the building inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 23-81; Code 2002, § 24-115) 
Sec. 24-116. - Covenant of indemnity. 
    The person issued a permit under this division shall execute a covenant indemnifying the city against any and all claims for damages of any kind or nature and against any and all judgments predicated upon such claims which may arise by virtue of the construction of the driveway approach; the storage or emplacement of any equipment, tools or materials incident thereto; and the performance of any and all work incident to such construction. 
(Code 1986, § 23-75; Code 2002, § 24-116) 
Sec. 24-117. - Notice of completion. 
    Upon completion of the driveway approach construction, the permittee shall within seven days deliver to the building inspector written notice of such completion. 
(Code 1986, § 23-76; Code 2002, § 24-117) 
Sec. 24-118. - Certificate of approval. 
(a)  Final inspection. Upon receipt of the notice of completion as provided in section 24-117, the building inspector shall inspect the driveway approach and, if the work conforms to the application and any amendments thereto and to the plans and specifications adopted in this article and to all other laws and regulations, the building inspector shall issue a certificate of approval of the driveway approach. 
(b)  Notice of noncompliance. If the building inspector finds that a driveway approach, when completed, does not conform to the application, any amendments thereto, the plans and specifications adopted in this article or any other provisions of law, he shall give a written notice to the permittee, setting out each item or error of noncompliance, and the permittee shall within ten days remedy all such items or errors. No certificate of approval shall be issued until all items or errors set forth in the notice have been corrected. 
(Code 1986, §§ 23-77, 23-78; Code 2002, § 24-118) 
Sec. 24-119. - Unlawful construction. 
    It shall be unlawful for any permittee, his agent, servant, contractor or employee to construct any driveway approach in any manner not in conformity with the application for the permit, the plans and specifications in this article and the general provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 23-79; Code 2002, § 24-119) 
Sec. 24-120. - Removal of approach. 
    The granting of a permit for the construction of a driveway approach and the issuance of a certificate of approval upon completion thereof shall in no way vest any right in the permittee or in any person having any vested interest in the land to which such approach may run or in any person who may subsequently acquire any interest in such land to permanently retain such approach. The city specifically reserves the right and power to remove such approach or any part thereof if such removal: 
(1)  Is deemed necessary as a matter of public convenience, necessity or safety; 
(2)  Becomes necessary in order to facilitate drainage upon or along any street right-of-way or traveled way; or 
(3)  Becomes necessary in order to widen, change or otherwise improve the traveled way or the right-of-way of any street, alley or other public thoroughfare. 
(Code 1986, § 23-80; Code 2002, § 24-120) 
Secs. 24-121-24-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-146. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. Each day of such violation shall be a separate offense. The election by the city to file such charges shall not constitute a waiver on its part to proceed against a bond as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 23-96; Code 2002, § 24-146) 
Sec. 24-147. - Bond. 
    Any person performing any work under this article shall execute to the city a bond or cash in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for each cut, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties; to save the city harmless from any liabilities that may arise in the use of any of the city streets, avenues or alleys; and that he will in all respects comply with the provisions of any permit granted therefor and any regulations of the city relating thereto. 
(Code 1986, § 23-97; Code 2002, § 24-147) 
Sec. 24-148. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Before any permit shall be issued under this article to cut any street, curb, alley or thoroughfare, any person obtaining such permit shall file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance certifying the issuance of a policy of insurance as provided in this section. 
(b)  The insurance policy shall be issued by an insurance company licensed and authorized to do business in the state and shall provide public liability insurance coverage for each operation required in the cutting of such curb, street, alley or thoroughfare, for the injury or death of any one person, for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident and for property damage in any one accident arising out of such work. Such liability insurance coverage shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  The policy shall provide that it cannot be cancelled until ten days' written notice of cancellation has been given to the city clerk, and it shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city of any changes therein. 
(d)  The certificate shall be approved by the city manager or designee and endorsed thereon. It shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(e)  The policy shall be made for the use, benefit and protection of the city and for the use, benefit and protection of any person who may suffer injury either to his person or property because of any accident or omission or negligence of any person cutting any street, curb, alley or thoroughfare. If such certificate is approved by the city manager or designee, it shall remain in full force and effect during the life of any permit issued for such work. If, after the approval of the certificate and after the issuance of the permit, the policy is allowed to lapse or is not renewed by the payment of premiums, the city manager may suspend the permit, and the city commission may cancel any permit issued under this article after notice to the permittee and after an opportunity to be heard. The cancellation of any policy shall in no way affect or terminate any liability arising prior to the effective date of such cancellation. 
(Code 1986, § 23-98; Code 2002, § 24-148) 
Sec. 24-149. - Protection. 
    Every excavation upon the front or side of any lot adjoining any street, avenue or alley or under any sidewalk in the city shall be securely and properly guarded and protected by the person having charge of the excavation so as to prevent the excavation being or becoming dangerous to life or limb. An accident or injury to person or property resulting from any excavation shall be prima facie evidence of neglect to properly and effectively guard such excavation as provided in this section. 
(Code 1986, § 23-7; Code 2002, § 24-149) 
Secs. 24-150-24-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS 

Sec. 24-176. - Applicability of division. 
    No person shall cut any of the streets, avenues or alleys in the city for the purpose of laying pipes for water, gas or other connection or cut or otherwise injure the surface of any streets, avenues or alleys for any purpose whatever, except in strict compliance with the conditions of this division authorizing such cutting. 
(Code 1986, § 23-111; Code 2002, § 24-176) 
Sec. 24-177. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall cut or cause to be cut any street, avenue or alley within the city without first obtaining from the building inspector a permit authorizing such cut. The term "cut" shall include any type of cutting, digging or excavating which disturbs the surface of any street, avenue or alley within the city, whether such operations are for the purpose of laying pipes, conduits, wires or cables under such streets, avenues or alleys or for any other purpose. 
(b)  Fees. Any person desiring to make a cut, as defined in this section, shall make application to the building inspector for a permit. Before any such permit is issued, the applicant shall post with the city clerk a bond as provided in section 24-147 and shall also submit to the city clerk a certificate of insurance as required in section 24-148. The applicant shall pay to the building inspector a fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for the permit before it is issued. 
(Code 1986, §§ 23-112, 23-113; Code 2002, § 24-177) 
Sec. 24-178. - Specifications for cuts. 
    Every person who makes a cut in any street, avenue or alley, as provided in this article, shall make such cuts and permanently repair the cuts according to that certain specification entitled "Paving Cuts and Permanent Repairs" prepared by the city department of planning and engineering, dated October 12, 1982, a copy of which is attached to Ordinance No. 1133NS, on file in the city clerk's office, and made a part of this article by reference. The building inspector shall make periodic inspections of such cuts and repairs. All such cuts shall be permanently repaired according to the specifications with due diligence. When such permanent repairs have been made according to the specifications, the person holding the permit shall notify the building inspector, who shall make a final inspection. Upon his certification that such repairs have been made according to the specifications, the bond shall be released. 
(Code 1986, § 23-114; Code 2002, § 24-178) 
Sec. 24-179. - Delay; interruption. 
    All work in any excavation under this division shall be done without delay or interruption, save by an act of God or for cause satisfactory to the building inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 23-115; Code 2002, § 24-179) 
Secs. 24-180-24-205. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 24-206. - Enforcement. 
    The city manager shall designate such city official as in the exercise of his discretion he shall approve to assign all house and lot numbers. It shall be the duty of such officer to assign numbers to every lot, house or premises as provided in this article and to require the numbers to be established and maintained in a conspicuous place on the front of the lot, house or premises in a substantial and approved manner. 
(Code 1986, § 23-131; Code 2002, § 24-206) 
Sec. 24-207. - Required. 
    Every owner of a building fronting on any street, avenue or public way in the city, when notified by the duly authorized official of the proper number assigned to such building, shall cause such number to be placed in a conspicuous place in the front of such building in a desirable and substantial way. The number shall be not less than two inches high and shall be approved by the duly authorized city official in all respects. 
(Code 1986, § 23-133; Code 2002, § 24-207) 
Sec. 24-208. - Baseline streets. 
    For the purpose of this article, Main Street shall be considered a baseline street for the purpose of numbering all lots fronting on streets running north and south, and Broadway Avenue shall be considered a baseline street for the purpose of numbering all lots fronting on streets running east and west. 
(Code 1986, § 23-134; Code 2002, § 24-208) 
Sec. 24-209. - Block numbers. 
    All blocks shall be numbered by the hundred in consecutive order beginning from the baseline street, respectively, and shall also have the proper word attached to indicate the direction from the baseline street. All lots fronting south shall have even numbers, and all lots fronting north shall have odd numbers; all lots fronting east shall have even numbers, and all lots fronting west shall have odd numbers. 
(Code 1986, § 23-135; Code 2002, § 24-209) 
Sec. 24-210. - Lot numbers. 
(a)  For the greater convenience in locating residences, business houses and other real property and the occupants therein, all lots in the city containing 25-foot fronts and all lots containing more than 25-foot fronts shall be reckoned on a basis of 25 feet for the purpose of numbering. However, in each addition to the city where the front footage of the lots in such addition are in excess of 25 feet, with restrictions that only one house can be built on a lot, each house shall be numbered in consecutive order, regardless of the width of the lot. 
(b)  The numbering of buildings in each block shall be determined by beginning at the corner of the block nearest its baseline street and assigning to such corner lot the block number for the even-numbered lot and the block number increased by one for the odd-numbered lot. Each succeeding number in each respective block shall be the next highest successive number beginning from the corner nearest the baseline street, provided that all numbers in any block shall be either even or odd numbers according to the direction of frontage of the block. In this manner a system of alternating numbers, either even or odd as the case may be, shall be established for any respective block. For fractional lots or lots less than 25 feet, fractional numbers shall be employed on the number assigned for the entire 25 feet. 
(Code 1986, § 23-136; Code 2002, § 24-210) 
Sec. 24-211. - Removing or damaging numbers. 
    No person shall remove, injure, damage or in any manner commit any act to impair the usefulness of any duly established house, lot or premises number without the express direction and authority of the duly authorized city official. 
(Code 1986, § 23-132; Code 2002, § 24-211) 
Secs. 24-212-24-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OBSTRUCTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Encroachments and obstructions in streets, 11 O.S. § 36-107; obstructing roads generally, 69 O.S. § 1208 et seq. 

Sec. 24-241. - Prohibited generally. 
(a)  No person shall obstruct or encumber, by any fence, building, box, stand, structure or in any other manner, any of the highways, streets, alleys, roads or crosswalks within the city. 
(b)  No person shall deposit within the city any obstacle upon any sidewalk which will in any way obstruct the free passage of pedestrians and which will in any way interfere with the use of such sidewalk. 
(Code 1986, § 23-151; Code 2002, § 24-241) 
Sec. 24-242. - Drains, gutters and driveway crossings. 
    No person shall in any manner obstruct any drainage of any of the city streets or alleys. All gutters, curbs and driveway crossings shall be kept open in such a way that the watercourse shall in no way be obstructed. All driveways across drains or curblines shall be level and in line with the drainage. 
(Code 1986, § 23-152; Code 2002, § 24-242) 
Sec. 24-243. - Parades, demonstrations, concerts, exhibitions or assemblies. 
(a)  No person shall maintain or exhibit any parade, demonstration, circus, show or animal show or give any concert or show for profit or for advertising upon any city street, alley or avenue, unless permission is granted by the city manager and expressly authorizes such use of the streets, alleys or avenues or unless approved by the city commission. 
(b)  No person shall obstruct any sidewalk, passage, street, alley, walk or any public grounds in the city by congregating or in any way assembling therein or thereon. 
(Code 1986, § 23-153; Code 2002, § 24-243) 
Sec. 24-244. - Sale, advertisement or placement of merchandise. 
(a)  No person shall permit any merchandise, boxes or any other obstructions to remain in or on any of the city sidewalks for any length of time whatsoever or use any portion of the sidewalk for the sale and advertising of any merchandise of any character whatsoever; provided, however, this shall not apply during special events and celebrations in which a substantial number of businesses participate. This subsection does not apply to merchants receiving goods for the purpose of immediately unpacking the goods and placing such goods in buildings, and this subsection does not apply to the placing of objects on the sidewalks that are for the purpose of beautifying the downtown area, which placement of objects has been approved by the city commission. 
(b)  No person shall use any portion of the street for the sale or advertising of any merchandise of any kind or character whatsoever, except as provided by this Code or any other city ordinance. 
(Code 1986, § 23-154; Code 2002, § 24-244) 
Chapter 25 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Constitution reference- State constitution references: Revenue and taxation, OK Const. Art. 10. 
State Law reference- Tax exemption for new manufacturing establishments and public utilities, 11 O.S. § 17-112; municipal taxation generally, 68 O.S. § 2701 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 25-1-25-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SALES TAX[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 25-26. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Shawnee Sales Tax Ordinance." 
(Code 1986, § 24-16; Code 2002, § 25-26) 
Sec. 25-27. - Definitions. 
(a)  The definitions of words, terms and phrases contained in the state Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1352, as amended from time to time, are adopted by reference and made part of this article. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Tax collector means the department of the city government or the official agency of the state duly designated, according to law or according to contract authorized by law, to administer the collection of the tax levied by this article. 
(Code 1986, §§ 24-18, 24-19; Code 2002, § 25-27) 
Sec. 25-28. - Purpose. 
    It is declared to be the purpose of this article to provide revenues for the support of the functions of the city government. 
(Code 1986, § 24-17; Code 2002, § 25-28) 
Sec. 25-29. - Article cumulative. 
    The sections of this article shall be cumulative and in addition to all other taxing provisions of city ordinances. 
(Code 1986, § 24-21; Code 2002, § 25-29) 
Sec. 25-30. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this article are declared to be severable, and if any section, paragraph, sentence or clause of this article is for any reason held invalid or inoperative by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect any other section, paragraph, sentence or clause of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 24-83(b); Code 2002, § 25-30) 
Sec. 25-31. - Amendments. 
    The people of the city, by their approval of this article at the election described in the ordinance from which this section is derived, authorize the city commission, by ordinances duly enacted, to make such administrative and technical changes in or additions to the method and manner of the administration and enforcement of this article as may be necessary or proper to ensure efficiency and fairness, except that the rate of the tax provided in this article shall not be changed without the approval of the qualified city electors, as provided by law. 
(Code 1986, § 24-22; Code 2002, § 25-31) 
Sec. 25-32. - Ratification of state permits. 
    All valid and subsisting permits to do business issued by the state tax commission pursuant to the state Sales Tax Code are, for the purposes of this article, ratified, confirmed and adopted in lieu of any requirement for an additional city permit for the same purpose. 
(Code 1986, § 24-23; Code 2002, § 25-32) 
Sec. 25-33. - Priority of tax; collection by suit. 
    The taxes, penalties and interest due under this article shall at all times constitute a prior, superior and paramount claim as against the claims of unsecured creditors and may be collected by suit as is any other debt. 
(Code 1986, § 24-24; Code 2002, § 25-33) 
Sec. 25-34. - Classification of taxpayers. 
    For the purposes of this article, the classification of taxpayers shall be as prescribed by state law for the purposes of the state Sales Tax Code. 
(Code 1986, § 24-25; Code 2002, § 25-34) 
Sec. 25-35. - Failure or refusal to pay; fraudulent returns. 
    The willful failure or refusal of any taxpayer to make the reports and remittances required by this article or the making of any false and fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or escaping payment of any tax or portion thereof rightfully due under this article shall be an offense, and, upon conviction, the offending taxpayer shall be subject to a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs, in addition to all civil penalties provided by this article. 
(Code 1986, § 24-26; Code 2002, § 25-35) 
Sec. 25-36. - Confidentiality of records. 
    The confidential and privileged nature of the records and files concerning the administration of the city sales tax is legislatively recognized and declared and, to protect such confidentiality, the provisions of 68 O.S. § 205 and each subsection thereof is adopted by reference and made fully effective and applicable to the administration of the city sales tax, as if set forth in full in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 24-27; Code 2002, § 25-36) 
Secs. 25-37-25-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES; PROCEDURES 

Sec. 25-66. - Levied; enumeration of sales subject to tax. 
(a)  There is levied an excise tax of three percent upon the gross proceeds or gross receipts derived from all sales taxable under the sales tax law of the state, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Tangible personal property; 
(2)  Natural or artificial gas, electricity, ice, steam or any other utility or public service, except water; 
(3)  Transportation for hire of persons by common carriers, including railroads, both steam and electric, motor transportation companies, taxicab companies, Pullman car companies, airlines and all other means of transportation for hire; 
(4)  Service by telephone and telegraph companies to subscribers or users, including transmission of messages, whether local or long distance. This shall include all services and rental charges having any relation to the transmission of any message; 
(5)  Printing or printed matter of all kinds and the service of printing or overprinting; 
(6)  Service of furnishing rooms by hotels, apartment hotels, public roominghouses and public lodginghouses and tourist camps; 
(7)  Service of furnishing storage or parking privileges by auto hotels and parking lots; 
(8)  Foods, confections and all drinks sold or dispensed by hotels, restaurants or other dispensers for immediate consumption upon the premises or delivered or carried away from the premises for consumption elsewhere; 
(9)  Advertising of all kinds, including any device used for advertising purposes and the servicing of any advertising device used for advertising purposes and the servicing device, except as provided by section 25-96(15); and 
(10)  Dues or fees to clubs and the sale of tickets or admission to places of amusement and to athletic, entertainment and recreational events or dues or fees for the privilege of having access to or the use of amusement, entertainment, athletic or recreational facilities, including free or complimentary passes, tickets, dues or fees, which are declared to have a value equivalent to the sale price of tickets, passes, admissions, fees or dues of similar character. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, sales of service and tangible personal property made for the purpose of developing real estate, even when such real estate is intended for resale as real property, are declared to be sales to consumers or users. Sales of service and tangible personal property, including materials, supplies and equipment made to contractors who use such materials in the performance of any contract, are declared to be sales to consumers or users and not sales for resale. Sales of tangible personal property to persons who are primarily engaged in selling their services shall be deemed sales to consumers or users and, therefore, taxable. Sales of tangible personal property to peddlers, solicitors and other salespersons who do not have established places of business shall also be deemed to be sales to consumers or users and, therefore, taxable. 
(c)  A sale shall include the sale, preparation or service of ice or nonalcoholic beverages that are sold, prepared or served for the purpose of being mixed with alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises where such sale, preparation or service occurs. 
(Code 1986, § 24-41; Code 2002, § 25-66) 
Sec. 25-67. - Time and manner of payment. 
    The tax levied under this article shall be due and payable at the time and in the manner and form prescribed for payment of the state sales tax under the state sales tax law. 
(Code 1986, § 24-42; Code 2002, § 25-67) 
Sec. 25-68. - Payment to tax collector. 
    The tax levied by this article shall be paid to the tax collector at the time and in the form and manner provided for payment of the state sales tax under the state sales tax law. 
(Code 1986, § 24-43; Code 2002, § 25-68) 
Sec. 25-69. - Collection by vendor. 
(a)  Duty generally. The tax levied under this article shall be paid by the consumer or user to the vendor, and it shall be the duty of every vendor in the city to collect from the consumer or user the full amount of the tax levied by this article or an amount equal, as nearly as possible or practicable, to the average equivalent thereof. 
(b)  Computation and recoverability of debt. Vendors shall add the tax imposed under this article or the average equivalent thereof to the sales price or charge, and, when added, such tax shall constitute part of such price or charge, shall be a debt from the consumer or user to the vendor until paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as other debts. 
(c)  Violations. A vendor who willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to collect the full amount of the tax levied by this article or who willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to comply with this article or who remits or rebates to a consumer or user, directly or indirectly, by whatever means, all or any part of the tax levied by this article or who makes, in any form of advertising, verbally or otherwise, any statement which implies that he is absorbing the tax or paying the tax for the consumer or user by an adjustment of prices or at a price including the tax or in any manner whatever shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, plus costs. 
(Code 1986, § 24-44; Code 2002, § 25-69) 
State Law reference- Payment by consumer, 68 O.S. § 1361. 
Sec. 25-70. - Returns and remittances; discount. 
    Returns and remittances of the tax levied by this article and collected shall be made to the tax collector at the time and in the manner, form and amount as are prescribed for returns and remittances required by the state Sales Tax Code, and remittances of tax collected under this article shall be subject to the same discount as may be allowed by such code for the collection of state sales taxes. 
(Code 1986, § 24-45; Code 2002, § 25-70) 
State Law reference- Remittance of tax, 68 O.S. § 1362. 
Sec. 25-71. - Erroneous payments. 
    Refunds of erroneous payments of the city sales tax levied by this article may be made to any taxpayer making such erroneous payment, in the same manner and procedure and under the same limitations of time as are provided for the administration of the state sales tax, as set forth in 68 O.S. § 227 and, to accomplish the purposes of this section, the applicable provisions of 68 O.S. § 227 are adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 24-46; Code 2002, § 25-71) 
Secs. 25-72-25-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXEMPTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Exemptions, 68 O.S. § 1355 et seq. 

Sec. 25-96. - Enumeration. 
    There are specifically exempted from the tax levied by this article the gross receipts or gross proceeds exempted from the state sales tax law, derived from but not restricted to the following sources: 
(1)  Sales of such nonintoxicating beverages as are taxed by state law; 
(2)  Sales of cigarettes and such tobacco products as are taxed by state law; 
(3)  Sales of raw products from farms, orchards or gardens, where such sales are made by the producers of such raw products directly to the consumers or users; gross receipts or gross proceeds derived from the sale of livestock, poultry, poultry products and dairy products by the producers. Exemptions granted by this subsection shall not apply when such articles are sold, even by the producer thereof, at or from an established business place, not on a farm, neither shall this exemption apply unless such articles are produced or grown within the state. This subsection is intended to exempt the sale by livestock producers of livestock sold at special livestock sales. This subsection is further intended to exempt the sale of dairy products when sold by a dairyman or farmer who owns all of the cows from which the dairy products he sells are produced. This subsection shall not be construed to exempt sales of dairy products by any other business, neither shall this subsection be construed to exempt sales by florists, nurserymen and chicken hatcheries; 
(4)  Dues paid to fraternal, religious, civic, charitable or educational societies or organizations by regular members thereof, provided that such societies or organizations operate under what is commonly termed "the lodge plan or system" and provided that such societies or organizations do not operate for a profit which inures to the benefit of any member thereof, to the exclusion of other members; 
(5)  Sales of tangible personal property or services to or by churches, except where such organizations may be engaged in business for profit or savings competing with other persons engaged in the same or a similar business; 
(6)  Gross receipts and gross proceeds derived from the transportation of school children to and from schools in motor and other vehicles; 
(7)  Transportation of persons where the fare of each person does not exceed $0.15 or local transportation of persons within the corporate limits of cities and towns, except by taxicabs; 
(8)  Sales of food in public, common, high school or college cafeterias and lunchrooms, operated primarily for teachers and pupils, not for the public, and not operated for profit; 
(9)  Carrier sales made directly to consumers or users of newspapers or any other periodicals where any individual transaction does not exceed $0.25; 
(10)  Sales to the federal government, the state or any of its political subdivisions; 
(11)  Sales of gasoline or motor fuel on which the motor fuel tax, gasoline excise tax or special fuels tax has been paid to the state; 
(12)  Sales of crude petroleum or natural or casinghead gas and other products subject to gross production tax under the provisions of state laws. This exemption shall not apply when such products are sold to a consumer or user for consumption or use, except when used for injection into the earth for the purpose of promoting or facilitating the production of oil or gas. This subsection shall not be construed as increasing or repealing the gross production tax levied by state laws; 
(13)  Sales of motor vehicles and attached optional equipment and accessories, on which sales the state motor vehicle excise tax has been paid; 
(14)  Sales by county, district or state fairs; 
(15)  Sales of advertising space in newspapers and periodicals and billboard advertising service; 
(16)  Sales for resale to persons regularly engaged in the business of reselling the articles purchased, within or without the state, provided that such sales to residents of the state are made to persons to whom sales tax permits have been issued as provided by this article. This exemption shall not apply to the sales of articles made to persons holding permits when such persons purchase items for their use, which they are not regularly engaged in the business of reselling, neither shall this exemption apply to sales of tangible personal property to peddlers, solicitors and other salespersons who do not have sales tax permits or established places of business; 
(17)  Goods, wares, merchandise and property sold for use in manufacturing, compounding, processing, assembling or preparing for sale shall be classified as having been sold for the purposes of resale or the subject matter of resale only if: 
a.  Such goods, wares, merchandise or property is purchased for the purpose of being manufactured into a finished article and it becomes a recognizable, integral part of the manufactured, compounded, processed, assembled or prepared product; or 
b.  Such merchandise is consumed in the process of manufacturing, compounding, processing, assembling or preparing products for resale; 
(18)  Sales of machinery and equipment purchased and used by persons establishing new manufacturing or processing plants in the state and machinery and equipment purchased and used by persons in the operation of manufacturing plants already established in the state, provided that this exemption shall not apply unless such machinery and equipment is incorporated into and is directly used in the process of manufacturing property subject to taxation under this article. The term "manufacturing plants" shall mean those establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing or processing operations and generally recognized as such; 
(19)  Sales of tangible personal property manufactured in the state, when sold by the manufacturer to a person who transports it to another state for immediate and exclusive use in another state; 
(20)  Sale of interest in tangible personal property to a partner or other person who, after such sale, owns a joint interest in such tangible personal property, where the state sales or use tax has previously been paid on such tangible personal property; 
(21)  Sales of containers when sold to a person regularly engaged in the business of reselling empty or filled containers or when a person purchases such containers for the purpose of packaging raw products of farms, gardens or orchards for resale to the consumer or processor, provided that this exemption shall not apply to the sale of containers used more than once and which are ordinarily known as returnable containers, unless a tax under this article is collected and paid to the tax commission with respect to every transfer of title or possession of such returnable container if made to any consumer or user within the state, nor shall it apply to the sale of labels or other materials delivered along with items sold, but which are not absolutely essential to the sale of the sold merchandise; 
(22)  Sales of tangible personal property or services to the council organization or similar state supervisory organization of the Boy Scouts of America, Girls Scouts of U.S.A. and the Campfire Girls; 
(23)  The gross proceeds from the sale of baby chickens, turkey poults and starter pullets used in the commercial production of chickens, turkeys and eggs, provided that the purchaser certify, in writing, on the copy of the invoice or sales ticket to be retained by the seller, that the pullets will be used primarily for egg production; and 
(24)  Exemptions of poultry and livestock feed, agricultural fertilizers and farm machinery, as prescribed by the state sales tax code shall be equally applicable as exemptions from the tax levied in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 24-61; Code 2002, § 25-96) 
Sec. 25-97. - Corporate transfers. 
(a)  There is specifically exempted from the tax levied by this article the transfer of tangible personal property exempted from the state sales tax law, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  From one corporation to another, pursuant to a reorganization. As used in this subsection, the term "reorganization" means: 
a.  A statutory merger or consolidation; or 
b.  The acquisition, by a corporation, of substantially all the properties of another corporation when the consideration is solely all or part of the voting stock of the acquiring corporation or of its parent or a subsidiary corporation; 
(2)  In relation to the cessation, dissolution or liquidation of a corporation, only when there is a distribution in kind to the shareholders of the property of such corporation; 
(3)  To a corporation for the purpose of the organization of such corporation, where the former owners of the property transferred are, immediately after the transfer, in control of the corporation and the stock or securities received by each such former owner is substantially in proportion to this interest in the property prior to the transfer; 
(4)  To a partnership, in the organization of such partnership, if the former owners of the property transferred are, immediately after the transfer, members of such partnership and the interest in the property prior to the transfer; and 
(5)  From a partnership to the members thereof, when made in kind in the dissolution of such partnership. 
(b)  Sale of an interest in tangible personal property to a partner or other person who after such sale owns a joint interest in such tangible personal property where the state sales or use tax has previously been paid on such tangible personal property. 
(Code 1986, § 24-62; Code 2002, § 25-97)
