(Code 2002, § 26-71; Ord. No. 2260NS, § 1, 6-5-2006; Ord. No. 2279NS, § 1, 9-18-2006; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 5, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-72. - Fire hydrant meter for bulk water purchase; deposit. 
    There is hereby established a refundable deposit in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission, for the use of a city-owned water meter to be used on a fire hydrant for bulk water purchase for nonmunicipal purposes. Returning the meter in good working condition to the city will result in a refund of the entire amount of the deposit. Should the meter be lost or returned in a non-working condition, the deposit will be forfeited to the city in its entirety. 
(Code 2002, § 26-72; Ord. No. 2288NS, § 1, 11-6-2006; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 6, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-73. - Fire hydrant use, maintenance and control. 
(a)  Fire hydrants and plugs connected with the waterworks, mains and laterals and located in the public streets, avenues or alleys of the city shall be under the direct supervision and control of the utility department and the utility director. 
(b)  The utility director or authorized agent shall, not less than once in each month, examine every fire hydrant and see that it is always accessible and in a good serviceable condition. 
(c)  The fire hydrants shall be used only by members of the fire department and other authorized city employees and shall not be used by contractors as a source of water supply for construction purposes. The responsibility for the inspection and repair of the fire hydrants shall rest upon the utility director. 
(d)  No person shall use, molest or connect any hose or any apparatus with any fire hydrant or plug without first having secured from the utility director a permit in writing authorizing such use, which shall specify the length of time, purpose and condition under which such hydrant or plug may be used. 
(Code 2002, § 26-73; Ord. No. 2534, § 4, 3-3-2014) 
Secs. 26-74-26-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE CONNECTIONS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 26-96. - Application for service. 
(a)  When any person desires to connect with the city water system, he shall make application to the customer service division in the city clerk's office. The account will be placed in the name of the person who signs the application as the responsible party. The application shall contain at least the true name of the applicant; the applicant's date of birth, Social Security and/or student identification number, telephone number, employer and next of kin not residing at the same address; the service address and mailing address, if different; and such other information as the city may deem necessary in order to ensure the effective billing and collection of each account applied for. If the applicant is a corporation, the application must be completed in a person's name "doing business as" the corporation. 
(b)  Identification proving that the applicant is at least 18 years of age may be required. In addition, a legible, valid copy of an existing lease of a renter/tenant applying for service may be requested of the applicant. 
(c)  A single application for service cannot be made to apply to different locations nor to cover more than one point of delivery at the same location to be used by the same customer, unless the city determines that the physical characteristics of the facility served requires more than one point of delivery according to good engineering and operating practices. 
(d)  Before any connection is made for an applicant who applies for water service outside the city limits, the application shall be made in writing to the city manager. 
(Code 1986, § 25-35; Code 2002, § 26-96) 
Sec. 26-97. - Tapping fee. 
    When an application is made for water service and when the water system has not been tapped and connected to the premises, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to collect a water tap fee in the amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 25-40; Code 2002, § 26-97; Ord. No. 2289NS, § 1, 11-20-2006; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 7, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-98. - Prerequisites; conditions. 
(a)  No water connection shall be made to any premises on which the plumbing has not been approved and such approval is not on file with the chief code enforcement officer. 
(b)  Every person using water from the city water system shall be liable to the city for all water used, according to the established rates and minimum charges and according to the conditions of this article. Such rates as are authorized by the city commission shall be kept on file with the city clerk and shall be subject to the inspection of any person at any time. 
(Code 1986, § 25-41; Code 2002, § 26-98) 
Sec. 26-99. - Making of connection. 
    After payment of the tapping fee and the required water deposit and after a tapping pit at the water main has been excavated by a licensed plumber, it shall be the duty of the city to make the required tap, provided that the tap shall not be larger than one inch. A licensed plumber shall install a type K copper line from the main to the meter and shall provide all the necessary fittings to make the meter setting, including type K copper extending 36 inches out of the meter tile on the house side, except the tapping saddle and corporation shop, which the city will furnish for taps one inch and smaller. If the tap is larger than one inch, it shall be made by a licensed plumber and paid for by the customer. For all taps larger than two inches in diameter, a tapping sleeve and valve are required; provided, however, before any such tap is made, reasonable notice shall be given to the city in order for city personnel to be present during the tapping operations. It shall be the duty of the plumber to fill in the tapping pit to the satisfaction of the city. The line maintenance utility director shall cause the meter to be turned on and note the reading and date that water service is established. 
(Code 1986, § 25-42; Code 2002, § 26-99; Ord. No. 1945NS, § 1, 10-18-1999; Ord. No. 2530NS, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
Sec. 26-100. - Occupancy without application or deposit. 
    If the city leaves the water service connected to vacant premises, it shall not constitute consent by the city for any new occupant of such premises to use the service without making proper application for the service. An occupant using service without a deposit and/or an application shall be liable to the city for the deposit amount, as well as payment for all services received, which will be billed at the prevailing rates for all services available to the premises. The occupant will be required to show a lease or document specifying when occupancy began and will be billed back to the reading nearest to the date of the lease or, if such document is not available, back to the date of the last occupant terminating service. Failure to make an application and/or a deposit may result in immediate termination of service. 
(Code 1986, § 25-43; Code 2002, § 26-100) 
Sec. 26-101. - Transfer of service. 
(a)  An application and contract for water service is not transferable from one customer to another customer unless written authorization is obtained from the city clerk or designee. Service can be connected for the same customer moving from one address to another by the completion of a new application and by a new deposit except for a person who, prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, had on file with the city a lesser amount of deposit than set out in this article and who has been found by the city clerk or designee to have an established, acceptable credit record with the city. In that case the lesser amount of the deposit shall be applied to the request for transfer, and no new application or increased deposit will be required. However, the customer service division may request an update to the individual's account history, and such information may be acquired by telephone. 
(b)  For the purposes of what shall be ruled an unacceptable credit history for an individual, the city clerk or designee may, among other things, consider the frequency of a customer's account on the delinquency list for nonpayment of an account, instances of a meter having been disconnected for nonpayment of an account, insufficient checks for payment of an account and the use of an alias to avoid payment of an account. 
(c)  Transfer of service fee. When a customer requests to transfer his/her account from one location to another location within the city limits, or utilizing city utilities, the current deposit may be transferred to the new account. The transfer will not be allowed if there exists, or will exist, any past due balance from the prior account. The current balance may be transferred to the new location if that balance is not past due. If the deposit is being transferred to the new location, the transfer must not overlap more than ten calendar days. Any outstanding balance from a closed account may be transferred to an open account under the same customer or occupant's name. A transfer of service fee shall be set and imposed in an amount, per transfer, as described in the city fee schedule, which may be updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission; the transfer of service fee will be added to the customer's account at the time of the request. The city clerk or designee may request immediate payment before the transfer can occur if deemed necessary. 
(Code 1986, § 25-48; Code 2002, § 26-101; Ord. No. 2646NS, § 2, 12-17-2018) 
Sec. 26-102. - Responsibility for payment on failure to receive bills. 
    Every water customer, whether owner or tenant, shall keep the customer service division advised of the customer's correct mailing address. The failure of any customer to receive water bills shall not be a valid excuse for failure to pay bills when due. 
(Code 1986, § 25-49; Code 2002, § 26-102) 
Sec. 26-103. - Connection with new lines. 
    Where new lines are installed, all water service shall be furnished from such new lines, and the public works director is authorized to abandon and discontinue any old lines upon ten days' notice to all users of water from the old lines. Such notice shall inform such users that they shall connect with the new lines within ten days or water service will be discontinued until connection with the new line is made, unless written authorization otherwise is obtained from the city manager or designee. 
(Code 1986, § 25-52; Code 2002, § 26-103) 
Sec. 26-104. - Filling swimming pools. 
    When any city water customer fills such customer's swimming pool from the house hydrant, the customer will be charged the normal water rate. However, the sewer rate will be adjusted to allow for the filling of the swimming pool. If a customer has the swimming pool filled from a fire hydrant, the customer will be charged the bulk water rate. 
(Code 1986, § 25-51; Code 2002, § 26-104) 
Secs. 26-105-26-130. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Deposits 

Sec. 26-131. - Exemptions. 
    Federal, state, local governmental agencies, institutions of higher education and public schools shall be exempt from making water deposits with the city. 
(Code 1986, § 25-47; Code 2002, § 26-131) 
Sec. 26-132. - Residential service. 
(a)  Residential deposit. The cash deposit for residential water service from the city water system shall be in an amount described in the city fee schedule, will be assessed to each new residential water service account established. The fee will be due at the time the account is established. The deposit amount may be amended or updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section a homeowner may be defined as a person owning a home presently which is used as that individual's place of residency; one who is in the process of purchasing a home for residency; one who owns a piece of property but leases or rents it out to another individual; or one who is renting or leasing to purchase the property which is planned as his place of residency. The city clerk or designee may, for a question concerning a customer's exact designation as to whether or not the customer shall be termed a "homeowner" or "renter," review the particular circumstances of the customer's position and make a determination from those findings. Evidence of a customer's claim to home ownership may be required, if necessary, by the customer service division. 
(c)  Processing fee. A processing fee in an amount described in the city fee schedule, will be assessed to each new residential water service account. The fee will be due at time the account is established. The fee amount may be amended or updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 25-36; Code 2002, § 26-132; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 1, 3-20-2017; Ord. No. 2646NS, §§ 3, 4, 12-17-2018) 
Sec. 26-133. - Business or commercial service. 
(a)  The cash water deposit for a business or commercial establishment shall be based on the size of the meter and demand for service. The deposit shall be such sum as will at least cover three times the monthly bill of the consumer according to established rates and shall be determined by the city clerk or designee. The deposit shall in no case be less than the amount as described in the city fee schedule and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(b)  For business and commercial establishments, an irrevocable letter of credit may be furnished the city in lieu of a cash deposit. This letter of credit must designate the city as beneficiary and be in an amount double the deposit figure which has been determined by the city for purposes of guaranteeing payment of the monthly utility bills. Any letter of credit so given shall be renewed annually. Failure to keep such letter of credit current by such annual renewal shall be treated in the same manner as failure to pay a monthly utility bill and may result in disconnection of service. 
(c)  In addition, a business or commercial establishment may post a surety bond, signed by a good and sufficient corporate surety company licensed to do business in the state, in lieu of a cash deposit. The surety bond shall be in an amount double the deposit figure which has been determined by the city and must designate the city as beneficiary. 
(d)  Further, for business or commercial establishments, on or before the first day of the 13th month of utility service, but not before the end of 12 continuous months of service, the business or commercial establishment may request that the amount of deposit be reviewed and adjusted to an amount determined to be in line with the current deposit schedule for the previous 12-month period of utility service. Such adjustment may result in an increase or decrease to the existing deposit. This adjustment shall be determined by the city clerk or designee. 
(e)  Landlords of vacant premises, real estate agents, property management specialists or builders/renovators, among others, may be permitted to furnish a blanket bond to cover those accounts which are multiple in nature. The blanket bond and amount must be approved by the city manager or designee. If the blanket bond is furnished as other than cash, all requirements for surety bonds as set out in subsection (c) of this section shall also apply. 
(Code 1986, § 25-37; Code 2002, § 26-133; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 1, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-134. - Construction meter. 
    Construction water meters set during the construction phase may be authorized upon receipt of a cash deposit in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 25-38; Code 2002, § 26-134; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 8, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-135. - Temporary service. 
(a)  Upon approval by the city clerk or designee, the city may extend temporary water service without requiring a deposit for special circumstances. 
(b)  The customer is required to complete a temporary utility service agreement at the time of connection and to prepay a service charge in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. The normal minimum water, sewer and sanitation rates will apply where such services are on the account, and the service will be disconnected without further notice at the expiration of the temporary utility service agreement; at which time, a deposit will then be required. The city may decline to provide temporary service if the applicant has a delinquent account for services provided at any other premises. 
(Code 1986, § 25-39; Code 2002, § 26-135; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 9, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-136. - Credit of account; unclaimed deposits. 
(a)  The water meter deposit required by this section shall remain with the city to the credit of the person paying the deposit, so long as service is continued at such location, and shall be subject to any charge for water, sewer or sanitation service which is unpaid or for repairs done by the city to such person's water meter. All deposit amounts which have not been claimed by or refunded to a customer within one year following termination of the utility service to the customer shall be paid over to the city unless it is claimed by the customer within 90 days from the date a notice is mailed by the city advising the customer of such unclaimed deposit. 
(b)  When a charge is made against such deposit for meter repair or a water bill, it shall be the duty of such person to pay the city such amount as is necessary to maintain the meter deposit in full during all times for rendering water service. 
(Code 1986, § 25-44; Code 2002, § 26-136) 
Sec. 26-137. - Increase. 
(a)  The city reserves the right to require a higher water deposit amount if a customer has received service in the past and has had service suspended for nonpayment. An existing customer's deposit may be increased if any of the following conditions occur: 
(1)  Service is suspended for failure to pay; 
(2)  Insufficient check; or 
(3)  Use of service without proper authorization from the city. 
(b)  If the character or volume of a customer's service should change at any time so that a customer's deposit is inadequate to ensure payment of bills, the city clerk or designee may require the customer to increase his deposit to an amount satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1986, § 25-45; Code 2002, § 26-137) 
Sec. 26-138. - Refund. 
    If any person using water from the city water system shall desire to discontinue such service, he shall notify the customer service division, who shall immediately order the disconnection. The city clerk or designee shall at that time cause the meter to be read and the amount due the city to be determined by comparison with the next preceding meter reading for the premises. Upon payment of such amount and all other applicable charges, the meter deposit shall be refunded. However, if, after all authorized charges have been made, it is found that the meter deposit is in excess of the amount due, such balance shall only be refunded for a final disconnect. If service is transferred, any and all of the remaining credit amount shall be transferred to the new service address account, and under no circumstances shall a refund be made to the customer or shall a refund be used in lieu of placing a new deposit on the new service address account. 
(Code 1986, § 25-46; Code 2002, § 26-138) 
Secs. 26-139-26-165. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Meters 

Sec. 26-166. - Required. 
    No person shall obtain any water from the city water system unless the water passes through a properly installed and approved meter. All water meters shall be provided by the city where the service requires the use of a one-inch meter or less. All other meters shall be supplied by the owner or user of the premises on which the meter is located at such owner's or user's expense. Upon installation and approval of the meter, the meter shall become the property of the city. All meters installed on the city water system shall be of a type and brand as approved by the line maintenance utility director. The city shall repair and replace any meter at any time it deems advisable. 
(Code 1986, § 25-80; Code 2002, § 26-166; Ord. No. 1945NS, § 2, 10-18-1999; Ord. No. 2530NS, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
Sec. 26-167. - Location. 
    Water meters shall be placed as near as possible and convenient to the curb or the property line of the property served. Residential property meters shall be placed between the curb and sidewalk or between the property line and the street curb. Location of meters serving commercial and industrial properties shall be determined by the public works director. 
(Code 1986, § 25-81; Code 2002, § 26-167) 
Sec. 26-168. - Installation. 
(a)  All water meters installed on the city water system shall be of a type and brand as approved by the line maintenance utility director. 
(b)  Where two or more meters are supplied with one service line, the service line shall be not less than 11/4 inches in diameter, but in no case of less than adequate size to supply all meters at peak usage, and each meter shall be supplied with an individual cutoff. 
(c)  Meters shall be at least 18 inches and not more than 30 inches in the ground and, if a change in grade of the yard, parking or sidewalk is made, the service pipe and meter shall be changed to correspond with this requirement. 
(d)  All meters larger than two inches shall be installed with a bypass and appropriate valves. Bypasses may be required on two-inch meter installations where, in the judgment of the line maintenance utility director, uninterruptible service is important. 
(Code 1986, § 25-82; Code 2002, § 26-168; Ord. No. 1945NS, § 3, 10-18-1999; Ord. No. 2530NS, § 1, 2-18-2014) 
Sec. 26-169. - Reading. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk, at least once a month, to have read the water meters located at all premises in the city or wherever located and to have made a record of such meter reading in a book to be kept for that purpose. Such record shall show the monthly reading, in each month for the preceding month, and the present reading. The city clerk shall have determined for such meter reading the amount of water consumed in each month by each customer. 
(Code 1986, § 25-83; Code 2002, § 26-169) 
Sec. 26-170. - Responsibility for repairs. 
    Water meters shall be protected at all times from freezing or other injury. If an injury shall occur, the public works department shall make the necessary repairs of its own meters without cost to the occupant or user, when such was not caused by any neglect of care by the occupant or user. A failure to keep the water box covered shall be the responsibility of the user, and damages caused by freezing due to failure to cover the water box shall be the liability of the user and paid for by the user. A defect of installation in such a way as to resist freezing shall be cause for the city to make its own repairs. For privately owned meters, the owner or user shall make all repairs at his own cost or the city will make such repairs, upon request, at the cost of such user or owner. 
(Code 1986, § 25-84; Code 2002, § 26-170) 
Sec. 26-171. - Testing. 
(a)  Any person receiving water through a meter supplied by the city who desires to have the accuracy of the meter tested may do so by making a deposit in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission, with the customer service division. The public works director will then bring the meter in for testing. If after proper testing the meter is found to be incorrect by more than two percent in favor of the city, the deposit shall be returned to the customer and correction made only for that month for which a bill was last rendered. If the meter is found to be correct or within two percent of correct, the amount to be set in the city fee schedule shall become the property of the city and shall be deposited in the general fund. 
(b)  If a meter fails to register, the monthly water rent due the city shall be determined by an average of the three preceding months that the meter last registered. 
(Code 1986, § 25-85; Code 2002, § 26-171; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 10, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-172. - Two meters serving single premises. 
    When a water consumer's piping or plumbing is divided, necessitating the use of two or more meters, each meter shall be handled and regarded as for separate and distinct consumers, to each of which will apply the regular water rates and minimum charges, until such plumbing or piping is so arranged as to permit the use of but one meter. Under no circumstances shall the consumption shown by the two or more meters in use by the same consumer be added or lumped together in order to reduce the net sum due the city. 
(Code 1986, § 25-86; Code 2002, § 26-172) 
Sec. 26-173. - Meter maintenance fees. 
    The rate to be charged to each account for the maintenance of meters is as follows: 
    Residential: $6.00 per month per meter. 
    Commercial: 
Meter Size Rate Per Month 3/4" meter $ 6.00 ?" meter $ 6.00 1" meter $ 6.00 11/2" meter $ 7.00 2" meter $ 9.00 3" meter $13.00 4" meter $17.00 5" meter $21.00 6" meter $25.00 8" meter $34.00  
The amount to be charged for meter maintenance fees shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2646NS, § 5, 12-17-2018) 
Secs. 26-174-26-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BILLING AND BILLING ADJUSTMENTS 

Sec. 26-201. - Estimated bills. 
    The city's water meters shall be read on approximately 30-day intervals, and billing for service will normally be submitted at monthly intervals. Whenever it is not possible with reasonable diligence to read meters for each billing period, the city may submit an estimated bill to the customer, which will be based upon previous usage and other available information. As necessary, the amount of such estimated bill may be subsequently adjusted when the next actual reading is obtained. 
(Code 1986, § 25-60; Code 2002, § 26-201) 
Sec. 26-202. - Delinquency; late payment penalty. 
    All water bills are due and payable upon receipt. If the bill is not paid by the due date, water service shall be subject to being discontinued. If the bill is not paid in full on or before the due date, a late payment penalty, in an amount to be set in the city fee schedule adopted and updated by resolution of the city commission shall be assessed. 
(Code 1986, § 25-61; Code 2002, § 26-202; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 11, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-203. - Adjustment of bills. 
    When a water customer questions his billed usage for any time period because of gross discrepancies, the account shall be checked for clerical and technical accuracy. If it is reasonably determined that the city is not responsible for the unusual usage in question, the city manager or designee may, on a case-by-case basis, make adjustments to the account. 
(Code 1986, § 25-61.1; Code 2002, § 26-203) 
Secs. 26-204-26-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CREDIT AND COLLECTION POLICIES 

Sec. 26-231. - Discontinuance of service for nonpayment; reconnection charges; deposit increase. 
(a)  Applicability. Water service shall be discontinued for any person who owes a past-due and delinquent utility account who is a recipient, beneficiary or consumer of water, whether such account is offered by some other name or not. 
(b)  Amount due; increase of deposit. The gross amount due shall be the current utility bill plus the penalty and any arrears. If the utility bill, penalty and arrears are not paid in full by the past-due date, water service shall be subject to being discontinued. No water service shall be reestablished until all bills are paid. Furthermore, the amount required for the deposit will be doubled based on the current prevailing deposit rates. 
(c)  Resetting meter. In certain instances, if the city determines that a meter or any other related property should be removed from a customer's premises to prevent the unauthorized taking of city water services, a charge in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission will be assessed to the customer's account for resetting the meter. 
(d)  Administrative fee for process of disconnecting. Once the city water department begins the process of disconnecting water service to a customer due to late payment or failure to pay a water bill, an administrative fee, in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission, will automatically be assessed to that customer's bill, regardless of whether the customer pays the bill prior to actual disconnection of water service. 
(e)  Rescheduling fee. When a customer schedules a time for the service to be turned on, or reconnected, the customer, or adult occupant, must be present at the appointment time. If the customer, or adult occupant, is not present, and a time must be rescheduled, the customer's account will be assessed a fee in an amount described in the city fee schedule, which may be amended or updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(f)  Cutoff notice fee. If an account has not been paid in full by the due date, a cutoff notice may be sent to the account holder; if a cutoff notice is sent, a fee will be assessed to the customer's account in an amount described in the city fee schedule, which may be amended or updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(g)  After-hours connection service fee . If a customer requests to have utility services connected, or reconnected after the normal business hours of the customer service office, that customer shall pay, in advance of the reconnection, a fee in an amount described in the city fee schedule, which may be amended or updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission, together with the current utility bill, plus any penalty, and any arrears. The payment for the after-hours reconnect service must be paid 30 minutes prior to the end of the normal business hours for the customer service office. The allotted time for the reconnect service will be two hours given to the customer at the time of payment and the customer will be required to be at the location at the time the reconnection is made. 
(Code 1986, § 25-65; Code 2002, § 26-231; Ord. No. 2090NS, § 1, 2, 4-7-2003; Ord. No. 2189NS, § 1, 1-3-2005; Ord. No. 2239NS, §§ 2, 3, 2-21-2006; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 12, 3-20-2017; Ord. No. 2646NS, §§ 6-8, 12-17-2018) 
Sec. 26-232. - Extension of time to pay. 
    When the city clerk or designee determines the facts warrant an extension of time to pay a utility bill, such extension may be granted. Such an extension shall be allowed for a period not to exceed 60 days. Failure to comply with any extension agreement may result in disconnection of service without further notice, and no additional extension will be granted for one year from the date of the broken agreement. 
(Code 1986, § 25-66; Code 2002, § 26-232) 
Sec. 26-233. - Dishonored checks. 
    There is levied, for the purpose of defraying bookkeeping costs and expenses, a charge in an amount as described in the city fee schedule adopted and updated from time to time by resolution of the city commission, which shall become a part of the account of any customer in the city when any check given in payment of water, sewer, sanitation or other service charges is returned from the bank after payment is refused for any reason. A returned check is considered nonpayment of a bill. Further, failure to replace the returned check with cash or a certified/cashier's check before 11:00 a.m. on the next working day after notification that the check has been returned will result in immediate disconnection of utility service without further notice. If two such returned checks are made to the city for utility service within any last preceding 12-month period, payment of each monthly bill by such customer of the next 12-month period of ensuing service shall be made and accepted only when tendered by certified/cashier's check, cash or money order. 
(Code 1986, § 25-67; Code 2002, § 26-233; Ord. No. 2597NS, § 13, 3-20-2017) 
Sec. 26-234. - Collection remedies. 
    On utility accounts which are found to be in default, the city manager or designee may institute all collection remedies available to the city, including, but not limited to, collection agency services and garnishment or execution on property, if the city obtains a judgment against the customer in a suit to collect money owed. If such suit is filed, the court cost shall be included in the suit as money owed. 
(Code 1986, § 25-68; Code 2002, § 26-234) 
Sec. 26-235. - False information to avoid charges. 
    If the city clerk or designee receives sufficient evidence to indicate that a customer has provided false information to establish water service at a new location to avoid the payment of charges owing at a previous location, the city shall transfer the charges owed to the current account, and the charges shall become a part of the customer's utility bill, at which time the entire bill becomes subject to the city's payment policy. 
(Code 1986, § 25-69; Code 2002, § 26-235) 
Secs. 26-236-26-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Sewer improvements, 11 O.S. § 37-201 et seq.; sewage generally, 27A O.S. § 2-6-401 et seq.; state water and sewage laboratories, 27A O.S. § 2-4-701. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-261. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act or the Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. 
    Administrator means the person designated by the city to manage the implementation and enforcement of the industrial pretreatment program. The city may designate the public works director, the utility director or other qualified individual who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities under this article. 
    Approval authority means the administrator of Region VI of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or designee. 
    Authorized representative of the industrial user means the authorized representative of an industrial user, who may be: 
(1)  A principal executive officer of at least the level of vice-president if the industrial user is a corporation. 
(2)  A general partner or proprietor if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively. 
(3)  A duly authorized representative of the individual designated in subsection (1) or (2) of this definition if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the indirect discharge originates. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures, five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in terms of weight and concentration (milligrams per liter (mg/l)). 
    Building drain means the part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system that receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means a sewer conveying wastewater from the premises of a user to the publicly owned treatment works. 
    Categorical pretreatment standard or categorical standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 USC 1317) which apply to a specific category of industrial users and which appear in 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N, parts 405-471. 
    Chemical oxygen demand (COD) means the measure of the oxygen consuming capacity expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l), of inorganic and organic matter present in water or wastewater. It is expressed as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific test. It does not differentiate between stable and unstable matter, and thus does not necessarily correlate with biochemical oxygen demand. The laboratory determination of COD shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in Standard Analysis Methods. 
    Color means the optical density at the visual wave length of maximum absorption, relative to distilled water. One hundred percent transmittance is equivalent to zero optical density. 
    Composite sample means the sample resulting from the combination of individual wastewater samples taken at selected intervals based on an increment of either flow or time. 
    Control authority means the "approval authority" defined in this section or the utility director if the city has an approved pretreatment program under the provisions of 40 CFR 403.11. 
    Cooling water means the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    Direct discharge means the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the state. 
    Domestic wastewater means the wastewater normally discharged into the sanitary connections of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings, factories, and institutions, free from storm surface water and industrial wastes. 
    Environmental Protection Agency or EPA means the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or, where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the regional water management division director or other duly authorized official of such agency. 
    Existing source means any source of discharge, the construction or operation of which commenced prior to the publication of proposed categorical pretreatment standards which will be applicable to such source if the standard thereafter promulgated is in accordance with section 307 of the Act. 
    Grab sample means a sample which is taken from a wastestream on a one-time basis without regard to the flow in the wastestream and without consideration of time. 
    Indirect discharge means the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under section 307(b), (c) or (d) of the Act into the publicly owned treatment works, including holding tank waste discharged into the system. 
    Industrial user means any user of publicly owned treatment works, identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, as amended and supplemented. 
    Industrial waste means all waterborne solids, liquids, or gaseous wastes resulting from and discharged, permitted to flow, or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, or food processing operation or process, or from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of these with water or domestic wastewater, or distinct from normal domestic wastewater. 
    Inspector means the city code enforcement officer, or any duly authorized representative thereof. 
    Instantaneous maximum allowable discharge limit means the maximum concentration (or loading) of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of any discrete or composited sample collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and the duration of the sampling event. 
    Interference means a discharge which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge from other sources: 
(1)  Inhibits or disrupts the publicly owned treatment works, its treatment processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and 
(2)  Therefore is a cause of a violation of the publicly owned treatment works' National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with any of the following statutory/regulatory provisions or permits issued thereunder or more stringent state or local regulations: section 405 of the Clean Water Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), including title II, commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA); any state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle D of the SWDA; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act. 
    Medical wastes means isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood byproducts, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, fomites, etiologic agents, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis wastes. 
    Milligrams per liter (mg/l) means the weight-to-volume ratio expressed in metric equivalent. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    New source means: 
(1)  Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with the section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; 
b.  The building, structure, facility or installation replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
c.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity at the existing source should be considered. 
(2)  Construction of a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of subsections (1)b or (1)c of this definition but otherwise alters, replaces or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
(3)  Construction of a new source as defined had commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun or caused to begin, as a part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
1.  Any placement, assembly or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
2.  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation or removal of existing buildings, structures or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss and contracts for feasibility, engineering and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this subsection. 
    Normal domestic wastewater means the normal wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewer of the city in which the average concentration of suspended solids is established at 250 milligrams per liter (mg/l), the average concentration of five-day BOD established at 200 milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    Pass through means a discharge which exits the publicly owned treatment works into waters of the United States in quantities or concentration which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the publicly owned treatment works' National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
    pH means a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a substance, expressed in standard units. 
    Pollutant means any dredge spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, agricultural and industrial wastes, and the characteristics of the wastewater, i.e., pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, chemical oxygen demand (COD), toxicity, odor. 
    Pretreatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to or in lieu of introducing such pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes; by process changes; or by other means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard. 
    Pretreatment requirements means any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment imposed on an industrial user, other than a pretreatment standard. 
    Pretreatment standards or standards means prohibitive discharge standards, categorical pretreatment standards and local limits. 
    Prohibited discharge standards or prohibited discharges means absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain substances. These prohibitions appear in section 26-404. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such degree that all particles shall be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particles greater than one-quarter inch in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have equal rights and the use of which is controlled by public authority. 
    Publicly owned treatment works (POTW) means a treatment works, as defined by section 212 of the Act (33 USC 1292), which is owned in this instance by the city. This definition includes any devices or systems used in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes and any conveyances that convey wastewater to the publicly owned treatment works treatment plant. The term also means the municipal entity having jurisdiction over the industrial users and responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the treatment works. For purposes of this article, the term "publicly owned treatment works" also includes any sewers that convey wastewaters to the publicly owned treatment works from persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city's publicly owned treatment works. 
    Publicly owned treatment works treatment plant or POTW treatment plant means that portion of the publicly owned treatment works designed to provide treatment to wastewater. 
    Receiving stream means that body of water, stream, or watercourse receiving the discharge waters from the wastewater treatment plan or formed by the waters discharged from the wastewater treatment plant. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water and groundwater, or unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed. It shall include all sanitary sewer trunk lines, main lines, collector lines, lateral lines, and sewage treatment plants and all sewer lines connected to the city's sewer lines or treatment plants, whether owned by the city or not. 
    Septic tank waste means any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
    Significant industrial user means any industrial user of the city's publicly owned treatment works: 
(1)  That is subject to categorical pretreatment standards; or 
(2)  Any other industrial user that: 
a.  Discharges an average of 25,000 gpd or more of process wastewater; 
b.  Contributes a process wastestream which makes up five percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the publicly owned treatment works treatment plant; or 
c.  Is designated as significant by the city on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the publicly owned treatment works operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
    Single-family residential unit means a building containing one dwelling unit and designed for or used exclusively by one family. 
    Slug load means any discharge at a flow rate or concentration which could cause a violation of the prohibited discharge standards in section 26-404 or any discharge of a nonroutine, episodic nature, including, but not limited to, an accidental spill or a noncustomary batch discharge. 
    Standard analysis methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition at the time of analysis of Methods for Chemical Analysis of Water and Wastes as prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency's Water Quality Control Laboratory, Cincinnati, Ohio, or other procedures set forth in the federal regulations, 40 CFR 136, Guidelines Establishing Test Procedures for the Analysis of Pollutants. 
    Standard industrial classification (SIC) code means a classification pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget. 
    Storm sewer of storm drain means a sewer that carries stormwater and surface water and drainage but excludes domestic wastewater and polluted industrial wastes. 
    Stormwater means the resulting water from rainfall or any other form of precipitation. 
    Surcharge means the charge in addition to the user charge which is made on those users whose wastes are greater in strength than the concentration values established as normal domestic wastewater. 
    Suspended solids means the total suspended matter that floats on the surface of or is suspended in water, wastewater or other liquid and which is removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Toxic pollutant means one of 126 pollutants or combination of those pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency under the provisions of section 307 of the Act (33 USC 1317). 
    Treatment plant effluent means any discharge of pollutants from the publicly owned treatment works into waters of the state. 
    Two-family residential unit means a building containing two dwellings and designed for or used exclusively by two families; also includes the word "duplex." 
    Unpolluted water means water containing none of the following; free or emulsified grease or oil, acids or alkalis, phenols, or other substances imparting taste or odor to receiving water, toxic or poisonous substances in suspension, colloidal state, or solution; and noxious or odorous gases. It shall contain not more than ten milligrams per liter each of suspended solids and BOD. The color shall not exceed 20 color units as measured by the platinum-cobalt method of determination as specified in standard analysis methods. 
    User means a person having a contract for water service, at a particular location if the location has a sanitary sewer connection with the city system; or if there is no water contract on file, then the person who is charged with water bills for the location or who pays same, or if a private water supply is used, then the proprietor or owner of the location having the sewer connection. 
    User charge means the charge made on all users of the sanitary sewer system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values defined as normal domestic wastewater. 
    Wastewater means liquid and water-carried industrial wastes and sewage from residential dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial and manufacturing facilities and institutions, whether treated or untreated, which are contributed to the publicly owned treatment works. 
    Wastewater discharge permit means a permit issued under subdivision II of division 2 of this article. 
    Wastewater treatment works means all facilities for collection, pumping, treatment, and all city-owned facilities, devices, and structures used for receiving wastewater, industrial waste, and sludge from the city wastewater facility. 
    Watercourse means a natural or manmade channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1986, § 25-96(a); Code 2002, § 26-261; Ord. No. 1977NS, § 1, 8-7-2000; Ord. No. 2530NS, § 1, 2-18-2014)

    The following abbreviations used in this article shall have the designated meanings:
