(1)  The principal will at all times do all pruning, trimming and removing of trees strictly in accordance with this article; 
(2)  All work will be done in a good and workmanlike manner; 
(3)  The city shall be fully indemnified and held whole and harmless from any cost, expense, damages to real property or personal injury done to any person or property in the prosecution of such work as a tree pruner that may arise out of or be occasioned in the performance of such work; and 
(4)  He will cause all streets, alleys and sidewalks that have been impaired in any manner to be repaired and put in the same condition as they were before the work was done. 
(b)  No license shall be issued to any tree pruner until such bond has been filed with and approved by the city manager or designee. 
(Code 1986, § 26-6; Code 2002, § 27-57) 
Sec. 27-58. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Before any license required under this division is issued to a tree pruner, he shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy for an indemnity fund as provided in this section. 
(b)  The insurance policy shall be issued by any insurance company licensed to do business in the state and shall provide public liability insurance for every operation or job performed by such tree pruner for the injury or death of any one person, for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident and for property damage in any one accident growing out of such work. Such liability insurance coverage shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  The policy shall further provide that it cannot be cancelled until ten days' written notice of such cancellation has been given to the city clerk, and such policy shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city for any changes therein. 
(d)  The policy shall be approved by the city manager or designee and endorsed thereon. The policy shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. The policy shall be made for the use, benefit and protection of the city and for the use, benefit and protection of any person who may suffer injury either to his person or property because of any accident or omission or negligence of any tree pruner. If such policy is approved by the city manager or designee, it shall remain in full force and effect during the life of any such license issued. 
(e)  If, after the approval of such policy and after the issuance of the license, the policy is allowed to lapse or is not renewed by the payment of premiums, the city manager may cancel any license issued under this division, after notice to the licensee and after an opportunity to be heard. The cancellation of any policy shall in no way affect or terminate any liability arising prior to the effective date of such cancellation. 
(Code 1986, § 26-7; Code 2002, § 27-58) 
Sec. 27-59. - Labeling of business vehicles. 
(a)  Except for passenger automobiles, all motor vehicles used in any manner by a person issued a license under this division, while such vehicles are used in the scope of such business, shall be identified by having conspicuously placed on both sides of each vehicle an identification number issued by the city to the licensee. Such number shall be issued by the licensing clerk in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  All such numbers shall be printed at least two inches in height. They shall be preceded by the capital letter "S," indicating the city, and a second letter "T," identifying the type of trade. Identifying letters shall be followed by the identification number given to the licensee by the office of the city clerk upon application for the license or renewal of the license. 
(Code 1986, § 26-9; Code 2002, § 27-59) 
Secs. 27-60-27-74. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMUNITY BEAUTIFICATION COMMITTEE AND TREE BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2629NS, adopted Mar. 19, 2018, changed the title of Div. 3 from "City Beautification Committee and Tree Board" to "Community Beautification Committee and Tree Board." 

Sec. 27-75. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Beautification committee. The beautification committee is herein defined as the community beautification committee responsible for overseeing the long range planning and development for all city parks and open spaces, promote and orchestrate community enhancement projects, and serve as the tree board. 
    Park trees. Park trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
    Street trees. Street trees are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
(Code 2002, § 27-75; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 1, 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 2629NS, 3-19-2018) 
Sec. 27-76. - Creation and establishment of a community beautification committee. 
    There is hereby created and established a community beautification committee, hereafter referred to as "committee", as approved by the mayor and city commission. 
(Code 2002, § 27-76; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 2, 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 2629NS, 3-19-2018) 
Note- See editor's note at Div. 3. 
Sec. 27-77. - Composition, appointment and term of committee members. 
(a)  Composition. 
(1)  The committee will consist of one city commissioner; 
(2)  The committee will consist of ten at-large members whom shall only include individuals that are either: 
a.  Residents of the city; 
b.  Business or property owners within the city; or 
c.  Employed within the city. 
(b)  Appointment. At-large members shall be appointed by the city mayor. 
(c)  Term. The term of at-large members shall be three years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his/her successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Ord. No. 2606NS, § 1, 6-19-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2606NS, § 1, adopted June 19, 2017, amended the former § 27-77 to read as set out herein. The former § 27-77 pertained to term of office and derived from Code 2002, § 27-77; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 3, adopted Nov. 18, 2002; and Ord. No. 2323NS, § 1, Aug. 6, 2007. 
Sec. 27-78. - Compensation. 
    Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 2002, § 27-78; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 4, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-79. - Duties and responsibilities of the tree board. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the tree board, hereafter referred to as the "board", to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal, or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. The board, when requested by the city commission, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of this work. 
(Code 2002, § 27-79; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 5, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-80. - Operation. 
    The board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 2002, § 27-80; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 6, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-81. - Street tree species to be planted. 
    The following list constitutes the official street tree species for Shawnee, Oklahoma. No species other than those included in this list may be planted as street trees without written permission of the board. 
Small Trees: Medium Trees: Large Trees: Redbud Honey locust Kentucky coffee tree Maple, amur Oak, English Oak, burr Smoke tree Oak, red Oak, sawtooth Crepe myrtle White poplar Oak, Shumard Hawthorn Golden rain tree Oak, northern red Winterberry euonymus Chinese chestnut Oak, water Cherry laurel Chinese pistache Cottonwood (male) Yaupon holly Pear, Callery Bald cypress Pear, capitol Pear, aristocrat Elm, lacebark Pear, Redzic Maple, shantung Elm, cedar Pear, Cleveland select Osage orange Black gum Pear, chanticleer Western soapberry Hackberry Russian olive Caddo American holly Gingko Atlas cedar Improved loblolly London plane tree  
(Code 2002, § 27-81; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 7, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-82. - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 27-81, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: Small trees, 20 feet; medium trees, 30 feet; and large trees, 40 feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. 
(Code 2002, § 27-82; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 8, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-83. - Distance from curb and sidewalks. 
    No tree may be planted closer to any curb than four feet or any sidewalk than three feet. 
(Code 2002, § 27-83; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 9, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-84. - Distance from street corners. 
    No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet of any fireplug. 
(Code 2002, § 27-84; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 10, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-85. - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 27-81 may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Code 2002, § 27-85; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 11, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-86. - Public tree care. 
(a)  The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(b)  The board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(c)  This section does not prohibit planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with sections 27-81-27-85. 
(Code 2002, § 27-86; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 12, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-87. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the board. The proper technique to trim trees from around utility wires is correctional trimming or V-pruning. 
(Code 2002, § 27-87; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 13, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-88. - Pruning, corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs with constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Code 2002, § 27-88; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 14, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-89. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Said owners at their own expense shall do removal within 60 days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal on the owners property tax notice. 
(Code 2002, § 27-89; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 15, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-90. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Code 2002, § 27-90; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 16, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-91. - Interference with city tree board. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this division. 
(Code 2002, § 27-91; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 17, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-92. - Arborists license and bond. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating or removing street or park trees within the city without first applying for and procuring a license. The license fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule annually in advance; provided, however, that no license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of a bond and of liability insurance for bodily injury and for property damage indemnifying the city or any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. Such bond and insurance coverage shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2002, § 27-92; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 18, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-93. - Review by city commission. 
    The city commission shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree board to the city commission who may hear the matter and make final decision. 
(Code 2002, § 27-93; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 19, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 27-94. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this division shall be, upon conviction or plea of guilty, subject to a fine in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2002, § 27-94; Ord. No. 2077NS, § 20, 11-18-2002) 
Chapter 28 - WELLS, OIL AND GAS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oil and gas, 52 O.S. § 1 et seq.; municipal powers as to oil and gas, 52 O.S. § 137; municipal tax on utilities, 68 O.S. § 2601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned well means: 
(1)  Each well in which production casing has been run but which has not been operated for six months. 
(2)  Any well in which no production casing has been run and for which drilling operations have ceased for 30 consecutive days. 
(3)  Any other well for which there is no current city permit. 
    Artificial production means the raising to the surface of the earth, by means other than natural flow, of petroleum or natural gas. 
    Building means any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the words "or portions thereof." 
    City means the municipality of Shawnee, Oklahoma, its departments, boards or the officers thereof. 
    Corporation commission means the state corporation commission. 
    Deleterious substance means any chemical, saltwater, oil field brine, waste oil, waste emulsified oil, basic sediment, mud or injurious substance produced or used in the drilling, development, producing, transportation, refining and processing of oil, gas or condensate. 
    Enhanced recovery means an operation by which fluid or energy is introduced into a source of supply for the purpose of facilitating recovery therefrom. 
    Fire marshal means the duly qualified city fire marshal. 
    Flow lines means all pipelines starting from a particular well and connected to an individual oil and gas separator. 
    Gathering system means all pipelines operated as incident to the development and operation of oil and/or gas fields and secondary recovery projects. 
    Highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Motor vehicle means any automobile, truck, truck tractor, trailer or semitrailer or any motorbus or any self-propelled vehicle not operated or driven upon fixed rails or tracks. 
    Natural production means the rising to the surface of the earth, by natural flow, of petroleum or natural gas. 
    Oil and gas inspector means that person employed by the city to enforce this chapter or his authorized representatives. 
    Operator means any person who owns or who has ever owned any working interest in any well bore located within the corporate limits of the city and any person who operates or who has ever operated any well on a contractual basis for any working interest owner. 
    Permittee means the person to whom a permit is issued under this chapter. 
    Person means and includes any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, trust, cooperative or other type of organization. 
    Pollution means the contamination or other alteration of the physical, chemical or biological properties of any natural waters of the city, or such discharge of any liquid, gaseous or solid substance into any water of the city as will or is likely to create a nuisance or render such water harmful or detrimental or injurious to public health, safety or welfare; to domestic, commercial, industrial, agricultural, recreational or other beneficial uses; or to livestock, animals or aquatic life. 
    Pressure maintenance means an operation by which gas, water or other fluids are injected into a supply of oil to maintain pressure or retard pressure decline therein for the purpose of facilitating recovery therefrom and which has been approved by the corporation commission after notice and hearing. 
    Public building means all buildings used or designed and intended to be used for such purposes as deliberation, entertainment, amusement, health care or education. Public buildings include but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Armories. 
(2)  Mortuary chapels. 
(3)  Assembly halls. 
(4)  Auditoriums. 
(5)  Exhibition halls. 
(6)  Museums. 
(7)  Courtrooms. 
(8)  Libraries. 
(9)  Hospitals. 
(10)  Schools. 
(11)  Churches. 
    Right-of-way is expressly limited to all public rights-of-way or streets or other public property within the city. 
    Saltwater means any water containing more than 500 milligrams per liter chlorides. 
    State means the State of Oklahoma, its branches, departments, agencies, boards or the officers thereof. 
    Street means street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue, recessed parking area or any other public right-of-way, including the entire right-of-way. 
    Structure means that which is built or constructed. The term "structure" shall be construed as if followed by the words "or portion thereof." 
    Treatable water or fresh water means surface and subsurface water in its natural state, which may or may not require treatment to be useful for human consumption, and which contains less than 10,000 parts per million total dissolved solids and/or 5,000 parts per million chlorides. 
    Trunk line pipelines means common carrier pipelines and other main pipelines not included in the definition of gathering lines, expressly including their rights-of-way as defined and established by instruments of records in the office of the county clerk. 
    Waters of the city means all streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, irrigation systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface and underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through or border upon the city or any portion thereof. 
    Well means, unless specifically qualified, any hole or bore, of any depth, for the purpose of producing and recovering any oil, gas, minerals or liquified matter or for the injection or disposal of any of such. 
    Well site means the surface location of any intended well. 
(b)  All technical or oil and gas industry words or phrases used in this chapter which are not specifically defined shall have that meaning customarily attributable to the words and phrases by prudent operators in the oil and gas industry. 
(Code 1986, § 27-2; Code 2002, § 28-1) 
Sec. 28-2. - Purpose and intent. 
    In order to protect the public health, peace, safety and welfare of the city and its residents, this chapter is enacted to establish reasonable and uniform limitations, safeguards and controls for drilling operations and production of oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances within the corporate limits of this city. The provisions set forth in this chapter shall be considered as minimum requirements and shall not relieve any person from any duty imposed by law to use reasonable care and take reasonable precautions for the safeguarding of people and the protection of noninterference with property rights. 
(Code 1986, § 27-1; Code 2002, § 28-2) 
Secs. 28-3-28-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-31. - Oil and gas inspector. 
(a)  The city manager shall employ an oil and gas inspector and assistants, if necessary, whose duty it shall be to enforce this chapter. 
(b)  The oil and gas inspector shall have the authority to issue any orders or directives required to carry out the intent and purpose of this chapter and its particular provisions. Failure of any person to comply with any such order or directive shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  The oil and gas inspector shall have authority to enter and inspect any premises covered by this chapter to determine compliance with this chapter and the provisions of all applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards or directives of the state. Failure of any person to permit access to the oil and gas inspector shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(d)  The oil and gas inspector shall have the authority to request and receive any records specified in this chapter relating to the status or condition of any well or project or the appurtenances thereof within the city. This material shall remain confidential unless necessary as evidence of the violation of any of the sections of this chapter. Failure to provide any such requested material shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(e)  In enforcing this chapter, the oil and gas inspector shall have such power and authority as set forth in this section and elsewhere in this chapter. 
(Code 1986, §§ 27-10, 27-31; Code 2002, § 28-31) 
Sec. 28-32. - Geologist. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the city manager shall have the authority to employ a geologist to: 
(1)  Review the drilling permit application; 
(2)  Furnish the city manager oversight reports as needed; 
(3)  Supervise surface pipe installation; 
(4)  Conduct blowout prevention (BOP) tests; 
(5)  Observe cementing of casing; 
(6)  Inspect plugging operations; and 
(7)  Supply final reports as directed by the city manager and oil and gas inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 27-11; Code 2002, § 28-32) 
Sec. 28-33. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to violate or neglect to comply with any section of this chapter. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any of the sections of this chapter or any of the provisions of a drilling and operating permit issued pursuant to this chapter or any condition of the bond filed by the permittee pursuant to this chapter or who shall neglect to comply with the terms of this chapter shall be fined in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  The permittee and all of his co-owners, partners, associates, employees and contractors or any other persons who may have assisted in the commission of any violation of this chapter shall each be deemed guilty of a separate offense. 
(d)  The violation of each separate section of this chapter and provision of the permit and of the bond shall be considered a separate offense, and each day's violation of each separate section or provision thereof shall be considered a separate offense. 
(e)  In addition to the penalties provided in this section, it is further provided that the oil and gas inspector may, upon ten days' written notice to the permittee, hold a hearing to consider the revocation or suspension of any permit issued under this chapter. Any violation of this chapter or the terms of the permit shall be sufficient grounds for revocation or suspension. The written notice issued by the oil and gas inspector must specify the alleged grounds for revocation or suspension and the date, time and place of the hearing. 
(f)  Any continuing offense shall be considered a public nuisance, the remedies for which under law shall be in addition to those enumerated in this section. 
(Code 1986, § 27-34; Code 2002, § 28-33) 
Sec. 28-34. - Order to cease operations. 
    The oil and gas inspector shall apply to the city manager for a hearing upon an order issued under this chapter, which hearing shall be held not longer than 24 hours after the issuance of the order by the oil and gas inspector. The city manager shall determine if proper cause existed and, if not, shall order the permitted activity to resume without delay. If the city manager determines that proper cause did not exist for the order to cease activity to issue, he shall make whatever ruling is proper to ensure rectification of the cause of the peril. Such ruling and compliance with it by the permittee shall not be construed to absolve the permittee of any liability for any violation of this chapter or for any damage or injury caused thereby. 
(Code 1986, § 27-32; Code 2002, § 28-34) 
Sec. 28-35. - Relief by injunction or other action. 
    No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this division shall interfere with the city's right also to apply to the proper courts of the state for an injunction or other appropriate action against such person. 
(Code 1986, § 27-35; Code 2002, § 28-35) 
Sec. 28-36. - Appeals. 
    Any permittee aggrieved by any order, directive or ruling issued by the oil and gas inspector or by any ruling by the city manager made pursuant to this chapter may appeal the order, directive or ruling to the city commission, which shall hear the matter at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The lodging of such appeal shall not stay the enforcement of any of the sections of this chapter. The city commission, upon hearing the matter, may issue whatever ruling or order is appropriate, provided that such ruling or order be in keeping with the spirit and purpose of this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 27-33; Code 2002, § 28-36) 
Sec. 28-37. - Release of bonds and insurance on sale of well. 
    Upon the sale of a present operating oil or gas well, the city clerk will release certificates of insurance and bonds only upon the presentation of new certificates presented by the purchaser of the well. A fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule per well or a flat fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for ten or more wells will be charged as a processing fee. 
(Code 1986, § 27-25; Code 2002, § 28-37) 
Secs. 28-38-28-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 28-66. - Required. 
    It shall be an offense for any person to drill, operate, maintain or abandon any oil or gas well within the corporate limits or to work upon or assist in any way in such work unless a permit for such work is authorized by the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 27-16; Code 2002, § 28-66) 
Sec. 28-67. - Application. 
(a)  A permit required under this division shall be issued only to the designated operator of the oil and gas leasehold interest. Every applicant for such permit shall, at least 20 days prior to the proposed commencement of such work, file with the city clerk a written application addressed to the city commission for the permit. The written application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of each owner of an interest in the oil and gas lease under which such well is to be drilled or work is to be done. 
(2)  The name and address of the person in charge of the operation and maintenance of the well. 
(3)  The name and address of the person in charge of the work to be done under the permit. 
(4)  The exact physical location of the proposed well and a street address or descriptive general location easily identifiable by the public. 
(5)  If the proposed well is to be drilled and operated under a written pooling agreement of several leasehold estates, such area to be pooled shall be set forth and described: 
a.  That the owners of more than 80 percent of the surface area exclusive of streets and alleys within 300 feet, and 90 percent of such owners within 150 feet, of the proposed well site have consented in writing to the drilling of such well at such location. The mere execution of an oil and gas lease shall not be accepted as compliance with this requirement, unless such lease describes specifically the location of the proposed well and consents to such location; and 
b.  That the owners of the leasehold interest and persons in charge of the drilling, operation, maintenance and work of such proposed well are familiar with this Code and the city ordinances and will abide by the provisions thereof. 
(6)  A statement indicating the source of water to be used for drilling purposes. A water well may not be drilled for oil and gas drilling purposes within the city. 
(7)  A statement indicating the exact manner of transporting the product to market if the permitted well is completed as a producer. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied with a payment in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, which will pay for the permit fee and the first year operation fee. 
(Code 1986, § 27-17; Code 2002, § 28-37) 
Sec. 28-68. - Exhibits to application. 
    An applicant for a permit required under this division shall attach to his application exhibits reflecting the following: 
(1)  Exhibit A. A certificate of an attorney at law authorized to practice law in the state or a certificate of a bonded abstractor whose office is located in the county reflecting the names of the owners of interest in the real estate situated within 300 feet of the proposed well site. 
(2)  Exhibit B. A plat with detailed, scaled dimensions of the proposed well location, lot and property lines within 300 feet of such well site, with notation or reference thereon to the surface owner of all such property as reflected by exhibit A. 
(3)  Exhibit C. A dimensioned drawing of the proposed well site reflecting the proposed well and the location of the drilling rig, motors, tanks and other principal equipment to be used in the drilling, maintenance and operation and other work of such well with reference being made to property lines and structures (nature of structures being noted) located within 100 feet of the well site. 
(4)  Exhibit D. A copy of approved intent to drill received from the corporation commission. 
(5)  Exhibit E. A copy of a planned flow line from the well location to a gathering system. Such plan shall be reviewed by the city engineer, the oil and gas inspector and other related departments. (Methods of right-of-way acquisition needed and rules governing the construction of flow lines will be described in a later section.) 
(Code 1986, § 27-18; Code 2002, § 28-68) 
Sec. 28-69. - Bond. 
(a)  Every applicant for a permit required under this division, at the time of filing his application, shall submit a corporate surety bond in favor of the city in an amount as described in the city fee schedule executed by the applicant and a corporate surety authorized to do business within the state and conditioned that the applicant shall: 
(1)  Pay the city and discharge any liability imposed by law upon it on account of injury to property, private or public, or person, including death, received or suffered by the city or any person resulting directly or indirectly and however remote from the drilling, operation, maintenance, abandonment, plugging or any other work relating to such well. 
(2)  Defend the city and hold it free and harmless of all judgments, fees and expenses incident thereto from all claims and causes of action arising out of the granting of such permit and the drilling, operation, maintenance, abandonment and plugging of the well. 
(3)  Pay all fees and sums due the city under this chapter and comply with and abide by the city ordinances and laws of the state and, if the applicant fails to do so, to pay all costs and expenses incident for a determination, by test or otherwise, whether such failure to comply with such ordinances and laws has resulted in any damage to the city or others and, if so, pay the expenses and costs of correcting such condition created by such failure and all damages resulting therefrom. 
(b)  The city commission may increase or reduce the amount of each bond required at or after the issuance of such permit. 
(c)  If the applicant is the holder of permits to drill and operate oil or gas wells within the corporate limits, all of such wells may be covered by a blanket corporate surety bond in an amount as described in the city fee schedule in lieu of the bond for each well as provided in this section. Such blanket bond shall be issued upon same terms and conditions set forth in subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  In lieu of the corporate surety bond in an amount as described in the city fee schedule mentioned in subsection (a) of this section, the applicant may submit a continuing irrevocable letter of credit in an amount as described in the city fee schedule issued by a bank in the city. The letter of credit shall be subject to the approval of the city commission. The letter of credit shall be issued on the basis that the applicant shall perform all conditions imposed upon him pursuant to the terms of this division and upon the same terms and conditions set forth in subsection (a) of this section. If the letter of credit is submitted in lieu of a corporate surety bond, such letter of credit shall be issued to cover the entire life of the well plus 12 months after abandonment and plugging. 
(e)  Every well drilled in the city shall be covered by a corporate surety bond or letter of credit as provided in this section for the entire life of the well plus 12 months after abandonment and plugging. If bonds or letters of credit are issued on an annual basis, they shall be renewed, and such bonds and letters of credit shall contain provisions that, after the expiration of the term for which such bonds or letters of credit are issued, they shall cover acts and omissions which occurred during the term for which such bonds or letters of credit were issued. 
(f)  If any bond or letter of credit required in this section shall lapse or become void for any reason whatsoever, the permit issued under this division shall immediately become inoperative and void until a new bond or letter of credit shall be provided and filed with the city clerk or the existing bond or letter of credit reinstated in full force, and the well shall be shut down and all operations and production thereof suspended and discontinued until the filing of such new bond or letter of credit or reinstatement of such existing bond or letter of credit. The city manager shall have the power and authority under the city's police powers to suspend any permit on any well that is not covered by such bond or letter of credit and shut down the operation of such well until there is complete compliance with the terms of this section. 
(g)  The bond or letter of credit shall be approved by the city manager or designee and endorsed thereon. The bond or letter of credit shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(Code 1986, § 27-19; Code 2002, § 28-69) 
Sec. 28-70. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Before a permit shall be issued under this division, the applicant shall file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance on an insurance policy for an indemnity fund as provided in this section. 
(b)  The insurance policy shall be issued by a company licensed and authorized to do business in the state and shall provide public liability insurance coverage for each operation required in the conduct of such work. The insurance policy shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule insuring the applicant and the city against all claims or causes of action made against either or both the applicant and the city for damages to persons or property arising out of the drilling, maintenance, operation, production or other work done with respect to such proposed oil and gas well. 
(c)  The policy cannot be cancelled until ten days' written notice of such cancellation is given to the city clerk, and such policy shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city of any changes therein. 
(d)  The insurance policy shall be approved by the city manager or designee and endorsed thereon. The insurance policy shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(e)  The insurance policy shall be made for the use and benefit and protection of the city and for the use and benefit and protection of any person who may suffer injury either to his person or property because of an accident or omission or negligence of any person or his agents or servants engaged in such work. If such policy is approved by the city manager or designee, it shall remain in force and effect during the life of such policy. 
(f)  If the policy is cancelled, the permit granted shall immediately terminate without any action on the part of the oil and gas inspector, and the applicant's or permittee's rights to operate under the permit shall cease until the applicant or permittee files additional insurance as required in this section. 
(Code 1986, § 27-20; Code 2002, § 28-70) 
Sec. 28-71. - Publication; public hearing. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a permit, bond and insurance certificate required under this division, if 52 O.S. § 318.3 is not complied with, the city commission shall cause notice of such application to be published in three consecutive issues of a daily newspaper printed and having a general circulation within the city, which notice shall state the name of the applicant, the proposed location of the well and the date and place of the hearing of the city commission, at which time and place the application shall be considered. The hearing on the application shall be at the next regularly scheduled city commission meeting after the last publication of such notice. Upon hearing the application, the city commission may authorize the city clerk to issue the permit for drilling, operation and maintenance of the well; provided, however, that no application shall be approved by the city commission unless consent to such location of the well is given in writing by the current owners of more than 80 percent of the surface of the area within 300 feet and 90 percent of such owners within 150 feet of such proposed well site. 
(b)  The city commission shall have the power and reserves the authority to refuse any application for a permit where, because of the location of the proposed well and the character and value of the permanent improvements in its vicinity and the use to which the land and surroundings are adapted for civic or other purposes or for other reasons the city commission considers, such proposed well might constitute a hazard to the public health, welfare and safety. When a permit shall have been issued, the permit shall terminate and become inoperative without any action on the part of the city commission unless, within 120 days from the date of issue, actual drilling of the well shall have commenced and, after drilling of a well or rework shall have commenced, the cessation for a like period of drilling or rework operations or the cessation of production of oil or gas from the well after production shall have commenced shall operate to terminate and cancel the permit, and the well shall be considered as abandoned for all purposes of this division. It shall be unlawful thereafter to continue the operation or drilling or reworking of such well without the issuance of another permit. 
(Code 1986, § 27-21; Code 2002, § 28-71) 
Sec. 28-72. - Denial; cancellation of application. 
    If the permit required under this division is refused or if the applicant notifies the city clerk in writing that he does not elect to accept the permit as tendered and wishes to withdraw his application or if the bonds, insurance or letter of credit of the applicant are not approved, the cash fee filed with the application shall be refunded to the applicant, except that there shall be retained therefrom by the city a processing fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 27-22; Code 2002, § 28-72) 
Sec. 28-73. - Renewal fees. 
(a)  Every applicant who has been granted a permit for a gas well as provided in this division shall make payable, 30 days before the anniversary date, a renewal fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule for an annual renewal permit. 
(b)  Every applicant who has been granted a permit for an oil well as provided in this division shall make payable, 30 days before the anniversary date for an annual renewal permit, either of the following fee amounts: 
(1)  If the price per barrel of Oklahoma Sweet has averaged less than $15.00 per barrel for the 12 months preceding the anniversary date of the permit, a fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  If the price per barrel of Oklahoma Sweet has averaged $15.00 or more per barrel for the 12 months preceding the anniversary date of the permit, a fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1986, § 27-23; Code 2002, § 28-73) 
Sec. 28-74. - Prior nonpermitted wells. 
    All oil and gas wells drilled and operating prior to adoption of the application process of this division and governance rules shall bring all such wells into compliance in accordance with all rules, regulations and procedures as outlined in this chapter. Each well shall have six months from the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived to be brought into full compliance. At that time, each operator will file for an annual renewal permit in an amount as described in the city fee schedule with the city clerk. 
(Code 1986, § 27-24; Code 2002, § 28-74) 
Secs. 28-75-28-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATION AND EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 28-101. - Compliance with applicable laws. 
    All of the general rules and regulations of the corporation commission are incorporated into this chapter and may be enforced by the oil and gas inspector and city geologist. Any violation of any of these rules and regulations shall be subject to enforcement and penalties as provided for in article II of this chapter. If any conflicts occur between the sections of this chapter and the corporation commission rules and regulations, the more restrictive provision shall apply. 
(Code 1986, § 27-44; Code 2002, § 28-101) 
Sec. 28-102. - Well site location. 
(a)  No well site shall be located nor shall any tank batteries, well facilities or equipment be located and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location unless the owners of more than 80 percent of the surface area exclusive of streets and alleys within 300 feet, and 90 percent of such owners within 150 feet, of the proposed well site have consented in writing to the drilling of such well at such location. The distance shall be calculated from the well bore. 
(b)  No well site shall be located or shall any tank batteries, well facilities or equipment be located and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location which is nearer than 500 feet to any public building or religious building as defined in this chapter unless the applicant has obtained written permission for the location of the well from the owners and lessees of such public building. This distance shall be calculated from the well bore, tank batteries, well facilities and equipment to the closest exterior point of the building. 
(c)  No oil or gas well site shall be located and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location which is nearer than 300 feet to any freshwater well that has not been abandoned. This distance shall be calculated from the well bore to the freshwater well bore. 
(d)  This section shall also apply to any dwellings, public buildings under construction or to any freshwater wells being drilled on the date the application for a permit is filed with the oil and gas inspector. 
(e)  The application of this section to a proposed well shall be determined by examining the existing uses of the surrounding property as of the date the application for a permit is filed with the oil and gas inspector 
(Code 1986, § 27-40; Code 2002, § 28-102) 
Sec. 28-103. - Location in streets and alleys; blocking or closing of streets and alleys. 
    No oil or gas well site shall be located and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location which is within any of the city streets or alleys, and no street or alley shall be blocked or encumbered or closed in any drilling or production operation except upon the written approval of the oil and gas inspector, and then only temporarily. 
(Code 1986, § 27-41; Code 2002, § 28-103) 
Sec. 28-104. - Determination of routes to well site. 
(a)  At least 20 days prior to the actual commencement of any operations at the oil or gas well site, the permittee shall notify the oil and gas inspector in writing of the proposed date for commencement of such operations. Such notification shall also contain the following information: 
(1)  The permittee shall identify the maximum length, width and weight of any motor vehicles and the maximum weight of the load to be carried by any motor vehicle to be used in traveling to and from the well site. 
(2)  The permittee shall submit a complete list of the proposed routes to and from the well site for all motor vehicles to be used to travel to and from the well site. Such list shall identify any and all highways within the city limits proposed to be used by such motor vehicles in traveling to and from the well site. 
(3)  The oil and gas inspector may also require any additional information which he deems necessary to evaluate the proposed routes. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the notification required under subsection (a) of this section, the oil and gas inspector shall have five working days to review the information submitted by the permittee. 
(c)  Following review of the information submitted by the permittee, the oil and gas inspector shall prepare a written order which either approves or disapproves the routes to and from the well site as proposed by the permittee. If the oil and gas inspector disapproves of all or part of the proposed routes, the inspector shall designate alternate routes which are acceptable to the city. 
(d)  During all drilling and production activities for the particular well, all motor vehicles used by any person to travel to and from the well site shall be restricted to the highways approved by the oil and gas inspector as appropriate routes to and from the well site. 
(e)  The oil and gas inspector shall have the power and authority to amend the order designating routes to and from the well site upon his own initiative or upon application by the permittee. 
(Code 1986, § 27-42; Code 2002, § 28-104) 
Sec. 28-105. - Affidavit upon completion of well. 
    Upon completion of the oil or gas well, the operator shall certify by affidavit that the well has been set according to good engineering practices. The affidavit shall stipulate the number of sacks of cement, the class of cement, blended materials, weight of cement in pounds per gallon, cement displacement pressure, final pumping pressure and whether checkvalves (float shoes, float collar) held the pressure. Commencement and completion times of such operation shall be stipulated. The affidavit shall be completed by a cementing service company and signed by both the operator and the cementing service company. The affidavit shall be submitted to the city geologist. 
(Code 1986, § 27-50; Code 2002, § 28-105) 
Sec. 28-106. - Ingress and egress. 
    Lease roads to oil or gas wells shall be maintained in such manner as to safely and comfortably allow for ingress and egress of city or state personnel traveling in a common passenger motor vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 27-58; Code 2002, § 28-106) 
Sec. 28-107. - Safety precautions. 
    Persons drilling, operating or maintaining any oil or gas well shall use all necessary care and shall take all precautions which shall be reasonably necessary under the circumstances to protect the public. The sections of this chapter shall be deemed to be the minimum requirements for the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare, and compliance with the terms of this chapter shall not be deemed to relieve any person of any additional duty imposed by law. 
(Code 1986, § 27-73; Code 2002, § 28-107) 
Sec. 28-108. - Damage to public property. 
    Any damage to paving, sidewalks, streets, alleys, curbing, parking, sewers or other public property arising out of any work relating to an oil or gas well shall be repaired immediately by the holder of the permit for such well, and the repairs shall be made in accordance with requirements of the city manager or city engineer and under his supervision. 
(Code 1986, § 27-59; Code 2002, § 28-108) 
Sec. 28-109. - Noise and other nuisances. 
    All oil or gas well drilling and production operations shall be conducted in such a manner as to eliminate, as far as possible, dust, noise, vibration or noxious odors and shall be in accordance with the best available technology incident to exploration for, drilling for and production of oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances. Proven technological improvements in exploration, drilling and production methods shall be adopted as they became available, if capable of reducing factors of nuisance and annoyance. 
(Code 1986, § 27-47; Code 2002, § 28-109) 
Sec. 28-110. - Fire prevention. 
    All permittees under this chapter shall maintain adequate firefighting apparatus and supplies at the well site at all times during drilling and production operations. Adequate firefighting apparatus and supplies shall include but shall not be limited to all of the following: 
(1)  During drilling operations, the permittee shall provide a minimum of four portable fire extinguishers, the size, rating, distribution and maintenance of which shall be in accordance with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) standard no. 10 entitled "Portable Fire Extinguishers" and NFPA standard no. 30 entitled "Flammable Liquids Code." 
(2)  In locations where flammable vapors may be present, precautions shall be taken to prevent ignition by eliminating or controlling sources of ignition. Sources of ignition may include open flames, lightning, smoking, cutting and welding, hot surfaces, frictional heat, sparks (static, electrical and mechanical), spontaneous ignition, chemical and physical-chemical reactions and radiant heat. National Fire Protection Association standard no. 77, Recommended Practice of Static Electricity, and National Fire Protection Association standard no. 78, Lightning Protection Code, provide information on such protection. 
(3)  The permittee shall protect all hazardous materials and/or special hazards at the well site in accordance with applicable National Fire Protection Association standards. 
(4)  The permittee shall also comply with such other requirements that the oil and gas inspector or the city fire marshal may prescribe for the particular well. 
(Code 1986, § 27-48; Code 2002, § 28-110) 
Sec. 28-111. - Drilling equipment. 
(a)  All drilling, reentry and operations at any oil and gas well within the city limits shall be conducted in accordance with the best available technology. All casing, valves, blowout preventers, drilling fluids, tubing, bradenhead, Christmas trees and well head connections shall be of the type and quality consistent with the best available technology. The setting and cementing of casing and running of drill stem tests shall be performed in a manner and at a time consistent with the best available technology. All persons engaged in drilling or production operations shall observe and follow the recommendations or regulations of the American Petroleum Institute and the corporation commission, except as specifically addressed by this chapter. A copy of all logs associated with the surface casing shall be filed with the oil and gas inspector. 
(b)  Blowout prevention equipment shall be used on all wells being drilled, worked over or in which tubing is being changed. Wells being drilled shall have at least three hydraulically operated blowout preventers installed, and these blowout preventers shall meet the American Petroleum Institute recommendation for class 3M blowout preventers. Wells being drilled shall also have a kill line, chokeline and choke manifold which meet the recommendations of the American Petroleum Institute for class 3M blowout prevention equipment. 
(Code 1986, § 27-43; Code 2002, § 28-111) 
Sec. 28-112. - Surface casing and inspection. 
(a)  An oil or gas well in the city shall be cased and casing cemented from the top of such well hole to the depth not less than that recommended by the corporation commission and the city engineer. Such casing, commonly referred to as "surface pipe," shall be set and cemented as stated in this subsection prior to drilling the well beyond the depth of the surface pipe. 
(b)  The permittee shall notify the city manager at least 24 hours prior to running the pipe for such work, for the purpose of permitting the city manager or other authorized city representative to inspect such pipe on location, and at least two hours and not more than three hours before commencing the procedure to cement the pipe the city manager shall be notified thereof in order that a city representative may observe the procedure. No pipe shall be used unless approved by the city manager or other authorized city representative, and the cementing of the pipe shall be done in the presence of such representative and approved by him. 
(c)  The depth of surface casing shall be determined by the corporation commission. The cement used shall be class C and tested at 1,500 pounds per square inch after 24 hours. Test results shall be forwarded to the city geologist or oil and gas inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 27-45; Code 2002, § 28-112) 
Sec. 28-113. - Pits. 
    Steel mud or circulating pits shall be used for oil or gas wells. Such pits and contents shall be removed from the premises and the drilling site within 60 days after completion of the well. No earthen pits shall be allowed unless small and temporary and approved in writing by the oil and gas inspector. All such earthen pits must be lined and approved in writing by the oil and gas inspector. Catchbasin pits shall be used only for the purpose of catching any deleterious substance runoff and shall be not greater than 320 cubic feet. Emergency pits shall be emptied as soon as the emergency is over, and all such pits shall be emptied and then leveled within 15 days after completion of the well. 
(Code 1986, § 27-46; Code 2002, § 28-113) 
Sec. 28-114. - Disposal of mud. 
    The disposal of drilling mud from an oil or gas well shall be by transporting the mud to a state-licensed disposal site. The mud may not be buried in an earthen pit, pumped down the well bore or down the annulus of a well or spread on the surface of the ground within the city limits. 
(Code 1986, § 27-49; Code 2002, § 28-114) 
Sec. 28-115. - Open hole formation or drill stem testing. 
(a)  All open hole formation or drill stem testing of an oil or gas well shall be done during daylight hours, with adequate advance notification thereof to the city geologist to enable him to be present during such testing. 
(b)  All open hole formation or testing shall be done into steel tanks or flared properly in the case of gas. 
(Code 1986, § 27-51; Code 2002, § 28-115) 
Sec. 28-116. - Fracturing and acidizing. 
    In the completion of an oil and gas injection disposal or service well, where acidizing or fracturing processes are used, no oil, gas or other deleterious substance or pollutant shall be permitted to pollute any surface or subsurface fresh waters. 
(Code 1986, § 27-52; Code 2002, § 28-116) 
Sec. 28-117. - Swabbing, bailing and purging wells. 
    In swabbing, bailing or purging an oil or gas well, all deleterious substances removed from the bore hole shall be placed in appropriate tanks or pits, and no substance shall be permitted to pollute any surface or subsurface fresh waters. The permittee and operator shall also comply with article V of this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 27-53; Code 2002, § 28-117) 
Sec. 28-118. - Rupture in surface or production casing. 
    If a rupture, break or opening occurs in the surface or production casing of an oil or gas well, the permittee or the operator or drilling contractor shall promptly report the incident to the oil and gas inspector. Immediate action shall be to repair such casing and the repairs witnessed by the oil and gas inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 27-54; Code 2002, § 28-118) 
Sec. 28-119. - Depositing substances. 
    No person shall deposit, drain or divert into or upon any public highway, street, alley, drainage ditch, storm drain, sewer, gutter, paving, creek, river, lake or lagoon any oil or oily liquid with petroleum content or any mud, rotary mud, sand, water or saltwater or in any manner permit by seepage, overflow or otherwise any of such substances to escape from any property owned, leased or controlled by such person and flow or be carried into or upon any public highway, street, alley, drainage ditch, storm drain, sewer, gutter, paving, creek, river, lake or lagoon within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 27-56; Code 2002, § 28-119) 
Sec. 28-120. - Flaring of gas. 
    All produced gas from an oil or gas well shall either be sold or flared with the flaring procedures being approved by the oil and gas inspector and the fire marshal. 
(Code 1986, § 27-57; Code 2002, § 28-120) 
Sec. 28-121. - Facilities. 
(a)  For oil or gas wells, all lease equipment shall be painted and maintained in a good state of appearance and shall have posted in a prominent place a metal sign not less than two feet square in area which shall contain the following information: the permittee's name, appropriate phone numbers, lease name, location of the drill site by reference to the United States Survey and identifying numbers of all permits. 
(b)  The oil and gas inspector shall also have the power and authority to enforce orders of the city commission to require such general landscaping of any well site as it deems necessary. The term "general landscaping" shall mean the aesthetic improvement of land by adding trees, shrubs, lawns, ground cover, etc. 
(c)  All pumps, tanks and equipment used in the operation of a completed oil or gas well shall be enclosed on all sides by either a sightproof wooden stockade fence at least six feet in height or a woven wire fence of not less than nine-gauge chainlink wire mesh of not less than two inches, at least six feet high, with additional angular extension outwardly secured by three strands of barbed wire. Such fence shall be constructed not less than three feet from outside the base of the embankment within 90 days of completion of the drill site or erection of storage tanks, whichever occurs first. During drilling operations, a watchman shall be maintained on the premises at all times who will be charged with the responsibility of protecting the general public from any hazard resulting from the conduct of such drilling operations. If such watchman is not employed, the entire well location shall be fenced as in the operation of a completed well. The oil and gas inspector is empowered to determine which type of fencing is best for any particular location. 
(Code 1986, § 27-60; Code 2002, § 28-121) 
Sec. 28-122. - Motive power. 
    Motive power for all oil or gas well pumping equipment shall be electricity. The oil and gas inspector shall have authority to waive the requirements of this section if he determines in a particular case that electric pumping equipment is not necessary to protect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Code 1986, § 27-61; Code 2002, § 28-122) 
Sec. 28-123. - Loss of well control. 
    If loss of control of any oil or gas well occurs, the operator shall immediately take all reasonable steps to regain control of the well, regardless of any other section of this chapter, and shall notify the oil and gas inspector as soon as practicable after receipt of notice by his employees of the occurrence of such loss of well control endangering persons or property. If and when the oil and gas inspector certifies in writing to the city clerk that, in his opinion, danger to persons or property exists because of the loss of well control (briefly describing the circumstances) and the operator is not taking or is unable to take all reasonable necessary steps to regain control of the well, the oil and gas inspector may employ any well control experts or other contractors or suppliers of special services or may incur any other expenses for labor or material which the oil and gas inspector deems necessary to regain control of the well. The city shall have a valid lien against the interest in the well of all working interest owners who have voluntarily joined in the drilling of the well to secure payment of any expenditure so made by the city pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1986, § 27-62; Code 2002, § 28-123) 
Sec. 28-124. - Storage tanks and separators. 
(a)  Crude oil storage tanks shall not be constructed, operated or used except to the extent of two low-type steel tanks for oil storage, not exceeding 500 barrels capacity each and constructed and maintained in accordance with the recommendations of the American Petroleum Institute. It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to locate a storage tank or separator site nearer than 150 feet to any residence or commercial or public building within the city. 
(b)  A permittee may use, construct and operate a steel conventional separator and such other steel tanks and appurtenances as are necessary for treating oil. All such facilities shall be constructed and maintained to control vapors. Each oil and gas separator shall be equipped with both a regulation pressure relief safety valve and a bursting head. If excessive vapors are released from the tanks, the oil and gas inspector may require that a vapor recovery system be installed and operated to prevent the release of gas vapors into the atmosphere. 
(Code 1986, § 27-66; Code 2002, § 28-124) 
Sec. 28-125. - Impounding around tanks by diking. 
    When protection of adjoining property or waterways is by means of impounding by diking around the tanks of an oil or gas well, such system shall comply with the following: 
(1)  A slope of not less than one percent away from the tank shall be provided for at least 50 feet or to the dike base, whichever is less. 
(2)  The volumetric capacity of the diked area shall not be less than the greatest amount of liquid that can be released from the largest tank within the diked area, assuming a full tank. To allow for volume occupied by tanks, the capacity of the diked area enclosing more than one tank shall be calculated after deducting the volume of the tanks, other than the largest tank, below the height of the dike. 
(3)  To permit access, the outside base of the dike at ground level shall be not closer than ten feet to any property line that is or can be built upon. 
(4)  Walls of the diked area shall be of earth, steel, concrete or solid masonry designed to be liquidtight and to withstand a full hydrostatic head. Earthen walls three feet or more in height shall have a flat section at the top not less than two feet wide. The slope of an earthen wall shall be consistent with the angle of repose of the material of which the wall is constructed. Diked areas for tanks containing class I liquids located in extremely porous soils may require special treatment to prevent seepage of hazardous quantities of liquids to low-lying areas or waterways in case of spills. 
(5)  Where provision is made for draining water from diked areas, such drains shall be controlled in a manner so as to prevent flammable or combustible liquids from entering natural watercourses, public sewers or public drains, if their presence would constitute a hazard. Control of drainage shall be accessible under fire conditions from outside the dike. 
(6)  Storage of combustible materials shall not be permitted within the diked area. 
(Code 1986, § 27-67; Code 2002, § 28-125) 
Sec. 28-126. - Leakage of deleterious substance. 
    If any leakage or spillage of any pollution or deleterious substance occurs from an oil or gas well, whatever the cause thereof, the permittee shall promptly notify the oil and gas inspector. If, in the judgment of the oil and gas inspector, such leakage or spillage represents a potential environmental hazard, he may issue whatever corrective orders he deems appropriate and additionally may require the appropriate testing of the surface and subsurface for pollutant incursion, the cost of all such testing to be paid by the permittee. 
(Code 1986, § 27-68; Code 2002, § 28-126) 
Sec. 28-127. - Accumulation of vapor. 
    The oil and gas inspector shall have the authority to require the immediate shutting in or closing of any oil or gas well if he finds that there exists, within a 100-foot radius of any well, any gas or gasoline vapor in a quantity sufficient to constitute, in his judgement or in the judgment of the fire marshal, a fire hazard. The well shall remain shut in or closed in until the hazard and its cause have been remedied. 
(Code 1986, § 27-69; Code 2002, § 28-127) 
Sec. 28-128. - Inspection of pressure lines. 
    The oil and gas inspector shall inspect all pressure lines in use at any oil or gas well or at any project. All tubing, fittings, equipment or connections shall be tight, safe and free from leaks. 
(Code 1986, § 27-70; Code 2002, § 28-128) 
Sec. 28-129. - Burning of trash. 
    No permittee or any other person shall burn any trash or debris upon the oil or gas well site. 
(Code 1986, § 27-71; Code 2002, § 28-129) 
Sec. 28-130. - Surface facilities, location. 
    Whenever necessary to protect the health, safety or welfare of the public, the oil and gas inspector is authorized to direct any permittee or operator to locate, relocate, remove or replace any oil or gas well surface facilities located within a particular drilling unit. 
(Code 1986, § 27-72; Code 2002, § 28-130) 
Sec. 28-131. - Abandonment and plugging; permit. 
(a)  Every person owning or operating any oil or gas well and the officers, agents and employees of such person shall begin removing all derricks, machinery, concrete foundations and any and all other objects that interfere with the leveling of the land within a period of 60 days from the day of abandonment of the well and shall remove such objects in a workmanlike manner. Such person shall also grade, level and restore the land to a condition better than before the well was first commenced. 
(b)  Whenever any well having sufficient surface casing to meet the requirements of this chapter is abandoned, it shall also be the duty of the permittee and the operator of the well to set a 200-foot cement plug in the bottom of the surface casing, with the bottom of the plug 100 feet below the surface casing section, and to set a 50-foot cement plug in the top of the surface casing. A 200-foot cement plug shall also be placed in the well bore within 100 feet of the shallowest zone known to produce hydrocarbons in the area. The oil and gas inspector may require that the two lowermost cement plugs be tested applying drill string weight on the cement plug after the cement has set to confirm that the plug has hardened and is in the correct location. When any cement plug is found to be deficient, an additional cement plug shall be placed in the well bore, or other appropriate corrective action shall be taken. No surface or conductor string of casing may be pulled or removed from a well. During initial abandonment operations, it shall also be the duty of the permittee and operator to flood the well with mud-laden fluid. This fluid shall have a density of not less than nine pounds per gallon and a viscosity of not less than 36 funnel seconds as measured with a standard Marsh funnel. However, in no case shall the density of this mud be less than the density of the mud used to complete the drilling of the well or less than the density required to create sufficient hydrostatic pressure to prevent the well from attempting to kick or flow. Prior to commencing plugging operations, the oil and gas inspector shall be notified so that he may witness the plugging operations. 
(c)  Whenever a permittee or operator desires to abandon and plug any well drilled within the city, except a dry hole, the permittee or operator shall apply to the city clerk for a permit to plug the well. The application for the permit to plug the well shall be on forms provided by the oil and gas inspector and shall be accompanied by a permit fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. In the application for a permit to plug a well, the applicant shall include evidence of the depth of the base of the fresh water in the vicinity of the well, copies of all corporation commission reports filed on the well, a well bore diagram showing the present condition of the well and a well bore diagram showing the proposed plugged condition of the well. Copies of any temperature surveys or cement bond logs run to determine the top of the cement outside the casing strings shall be included in the permit application. 
(d)  Whenever any well having a lesser amount of surface casing than required by this chapter is abandoned, it shall be the duty of the permittee or operator of the well to plug the well in accordance with this subsection. To effect the plugging of the well, the production casing shall be cut at a depth at least 200 feet deeper than the base of the freshwater zones, and the upper section of the production casing shall be removed from the well bore. The well bore shall be reentered and circulated clean to the depth of at least 200 feet below the base of the freshwater zones. A cement plug shall be placed in the well bore with the bottom of the plug located at the top of the production casing stub and the top of the plug located at least 100 feet inside the surface casing. If the production casing cannot be removed as required, the operator or permittee shall propose an alternative plugging procedure, but no plugging may be performed unless the procedure has been approved by the oil and gas inspector. The oil and gas inspector shall be notified so that he may witness the plugging of the well. The remainder of the plugging requirements for wells not having sufficient surface casing shall be the same as for wells which do have sufficient surface casing. 
(e)  In exceptional circumstances, the oil and gas inspector shall have authority to approve plugging procedures other than those set forth in this section. Such approval shall be in writing and shall be signed by the oil and gas inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 27-75; Code 2002, § 28-131) 
Secs. 28-132-28-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SWABBING WELLS 

Sec. 28-161. - Compliance. 
    No person shall begin the operation of swabbing an oil or gas well without first complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 27-80; Code 2002, § 28-161) 
Sec. 28-162. - Lubricator. 
    No oil or gas well shall be swabbed before a device, commonly known as a lubricator, has been placed on the flow casing above all outlets or flow lines of the well. The lubricator shall be not less in diameter than the flow casing and equipped with an adequate oil saver or stuffing box at the top. The total inside length of the lubricator shall be not less than five feet more than the total length of swab and turn back on the swab line. The lubricator shall have a nipple of not less than two inches in diameter and not more than four inches in length, placed not more than six inches from the top and on the flow lines between the gate valve on the flow lines and flow casings. The nipple shall be provided with a gate valve not less than two inches in size. All equipment and parts of the lubricator shall be of a type designed and tested to withstand a pressure of 3,000 pounds per square inch. All pressure tests shall be by the hydrostatic method. 
(Code 1986, § 27-81; Code 2002, § 28-162) 
Sec. 28-163. - Valves on lines leaving flow casing. 
    All lines leaving the flow casing of any oil or gas well shall be equipped with a gate valve of not less than 3,000 pounds per square inch test and the same size of the line and shall be placed not farther than 24 inches from the flow casing. 
(Code 1986, § 27-82; Code 2002, § 28-163) 
Sec. 28-164. - Deleterious substances. 
    In swabbing, bailing or purging an oil or gas well, all deleterious substances removed from the bore hole shall be placed in appropriate tanks, and no substance shall be permitted to pollute any surface or subsurface fresh water. 
(Code 1986, § 27-83; Code 2002, § 28-164) 
Secs. 28-165-28-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ENHANCED RECOVERY SYSTEM AND DISPOSAL WELLS 

Sec. 28-191. - Compliance; order to cease operation. 
    If the oil and gas inspector finds that any person is operating in violation of this article, he, in concert with the city manager, shall order the activity to cease until compliance is made with this article. No person shall renew such activity until the oil and gas inspector finds compliance has been made and permission given for the renewed activity. Any deviation from any approved plan of operations must be submitted to the oil and gas inspector for review and subsequently submitted to the city commission for approval. 
(Code 1986, § 27-98; Code 2002, § 28-191) 
Sec. 28-192. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person or operating company shall initiate any enhanced recovery system or reenter any oil or gas well or drill an original oil or gas well to be used for enhanced recovery purposes or disposal of saltwater or other deleterious substances without first obtaining the necessary permit therefor. Such permit shall consist of two separate parts as follows: 
(1)  Permit to operate. 
(2)  Permit to drill or reenter and construct. 
(b)  No person or operating company shall convert any well from natural or artificial production to be used for enhanced recovery or disposal without first obtaining the necessary permit therefor. 
(c)  No person shall reenter any abandoned or plugged and abandoned well or drill an original well to be used for enhanced recovery or disposal without first obtaining the necessary permit therefor. 
(Code 1986, § 27-86; Code 2002, § 28-192) 
Sec. 28-193. - Permit application. 
    An application for a permit as is required by section 28-192 shall contain complete information required by the city manager and the oil and gas inspector, including the following: 
(1)  A block map of each project well site showing all equipment to be used, location of the pipeline, access roads and distances from any well to any and all fences, public roadways and buildings within a radius of 300 feet. 
(2)  A city street map of the project showing the location of the following: 
a.  All supply, disposal, injection and producing wells. 
b.  Conduits. 
c.  Tank batteries. 
d.  Injection pumping station and appurtenant equipment. 
e.  All wells in the project area and those located in the sections immediately adjacent, to include producing, plugged and abandoned and disposal. 
f.  All public and domestic freshwater supply wells within 1,000 feet of any proposed enhanced recovery project well or proposed disposal well. 
g.  Access roads. 
(3)  Evidence that all wells in the project area and adjacent sections were plugged and abandoned in compliance with corporation commission regulations at the time well was plugged and abandoned. A plugging record (OCC Form 1003) to demonstrate compliance is acceptable. 
(4)  All wells associated with the enhanced recovery project shall be indicated by status (e.g., plugged and abandoned, injection, water source, oil, etc.) and shall show the following information: 
a.  Surveyed surface location. 
b.  Footage location (surface casing). 
c.  Derrick floor and ground level elevation (new permitted wells). 
d.  Drilled total depth. 
e.  Size, depth and quality of surface and production casing, including zones from which casing has been removed. 
f.  Location of all plugs, packers, cement plugs, tubing anchors, etc., within the well bore. 
g.  Packer body total depth. 
h.  Depth and nature of all cement squeeze operations. 
i.  Volume and type of cement used on surface and production strings. 
j.  Top of cement behind pipe. 
k.  Formation name and depth of all open perforations in a producing open hole. 
(5)  Fee and operator name for each disposal well. 
(6)  One copy of all cement bond logs and production logs. 
(7)  One copy of all work performed on the well. 
(8)  Copies of all information supplied to the corporation commission, and such commission's approval of the project. 
(Code 1986, § 27-87; Code 2002, § 28-193) 
Sec. 28-194. - Application and inspection fee. 
(a)  Each submitted application for an enhanced recovery project will be accompanied with a one-time fee in an amount as described in the city fee schedule. A similar fee will be required for a disposal well.
