(b)  An annual inspection fee is levied upon each well within an enhanced recovery project operated or maintained under a permit issued from the city. Such fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, payable to the city 30 days before the annual anniversary date of the issuance of any permit under this article. 
(c)  An annual inspection fee is levied upon each disposal well operated and maintained under a permit issued from the city. Such fee shall be in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, payable to the city on or before the annual anniversary date of the issuance of any permit under this article. 
(d)  No permit for any well shall be considered valid for any year for which the annual fee has not been paid. 
(e)  Upon the completion of the enhanced recovery project or disposal well application required and accompanied by the appropriate required fee, the city manager and staff shall have at least 30 business days to review the application and make a recommendation of approval or disapproval to the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 27-88; Code 2002, § 28-194) 
Sec. 28-195. - Operation and equipment requirements. 
(a)  Every enhanced recovery or disposal well shall be so constructed as to seal the injection zone from the upper portion of the casing. The annulus between the injection tubing and the casing shall be filled with a noncorrosive fluid, then sealed, and a one-fourth-inch female fitting with cutoff valve shall be attached so that the pressure in the annulus may be measured by the oil and gas inspector by attaching a gauge having a one-fourth-inch male fitting. The annulus between the production casing and the injection tubing shall be pressure tested to a pressure of at least 250 pounds per square inch greater than the injection pressure proposed for the well. The pressure testing shall be witnessed and state approved by the oil and gas inspector. Copies of the corporation commission form no. 1015 shall also be filed with the oil and gas inspector. Pressure shall be maintained in the annulus sufficient to monitor the fluids in the annulus. Any significant deviation from the established pressure shall be cause to shut down the well and may result in cancellation of the operating permit until such time as the established pressure can once again be maintained. 
(b)  Injection lines for such wells shall be buried in a trench not less than four feet and shall be pressure-tested (static) annually at a minimum of 150 percent of the pressure normally encountered at the injection pump discharge for a period of hours to be fixed by the oil and gas inspector. The oil and gas inspector shall be notified in writing five days in advance of such test and may supervise the test. Test results shall be filed with the city upon completion. 
(c)  The annulus between the production casing and the surface casing shall be equipped with the appropriate fittings to provide a one-fourth-inch female fitting equipped with a cutoff valve so that the pressure in the annulus may be measured by the oil and gas inspector. Any indication of pressure which deviates proportionately to the injection pressure to the tubing injection pressure on this annulus shall be cause to shut down the well and may result in the cancellation of the operating permit until such time as the problem can be corrected. 
(d)  The permit for an enhanced recovery or disposal well shall state the maximum injection pressure. Exceeding this injection pressure shall be considered a violation of this chapter. 
(e)  The injection tubing or injection line near the injection tubing shall be equipped with a one-fourth-inch female fitting and cutoff valve so that the oil and gas inspector may measure the injection pressure by the installation of a gauge equipped with a standard one-fourth-inch male fitting. 
(f)  Before performing any down-hole work on an enhanced recovery or disposal well, the operator shall notify the oil and gas inspector at least five days in advance of performing this work. The oil and gas inspector shall witness the installation of tubing and packer in an enhanced recovery or disposal well. The annulus between the injection tubing and the production casing shall then be pressure tested to a pressure at least 250 pounds per square inch in excess of the approved injection pressure. The oil and gas inspector shall witness the pressure testing of this annulus. The pressure test shall be repeated at least once a year and shall be witnessed by the oil and gas inspector. 
(g)  The permittee or operator of the well shall submit to the oil and gas inspector a monthly report stating the amount of water injected during the month and the maximum tubing pressure if requested. A copy of corporation commission forms 1012 and 1072 shall be submitted yearly to the oil and gas inspector. 
(h)  The location of all injection lines for enhanced recovery or deleterious substance disposal wells shall be recorded by the Oklahoma One Call System or otherwise brought into compliance with the Oklahoma Underground Facilities Damage Prevention Act, 63 O.S. § 142 et seq. 
(Code 1986, § 27-89; Code 2002, § 28-195) 
Sec. 28-196. - Additional bond and insurance coverage. 
    In addition to drilling bond requirements as stated in section 28-69, the operator of an enhanced recovery project shall provide the following within the project application process: 
(1)  A statement stating that permittee shall indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all liability attributable to granting the permit. 
(2)  The permittee shall carry a policy of standard comprehensive public liability insurance, and such policy shall: 
a.  Contain coverage for contamination or pollution of surface or subterranean streams, watercourses, lakes or public or private water supplies. 
b.  Be conditioned for payment of all damages due to injury to persons or damage to property resulting from the drilling, operation or maintenance of the proposed well or any structure, machinery, equipment, pipelines or appurtenances used in connection therewith. 
c.  Name the permittee and the city as coinsured. 
d.  Be issued by an insurance company authorized to do business within the state, and the policy shall be in the aggregate providing for a minimum coverage in an amount as described in the city fee schedule, combined single limit. 
(3)  The permittee shall file with the city clerk certificates of such insurance and bond. The insurance policy and bond shall not be cancelled without actual written notice received by the city clerk at least 30 days prior to the effective date of cancellation. If the insurance policy is cancelled, the permit granted shall terminate immediately, and the permittee's rights to operate under the permit shall cease immediately until the permittee files additional insurance as provided in this section. Further, if the insurance policy is cancelled or allowed to expire, the city manager shall notify the electric company of the violation, and service to all wells not conforming shall be discontinued immediately. For other wells (not electric) an injunction will be filed immediately. 
(Code 1986, § 27-90; Code 2002, § 28-196) 
Sec. 28-197. - Drilling, testing and maintenance of freshwater monitoring wells. 
(a)  Prior to the commencement of any enhanced recovery project or disposal well program, the permittee and the operator thereof shall be required to drill monitoring wells located in any and all freshwater zones within the enhanced recovery unit or disposal area. 
(b)  The number of monitoring wells will be determined by the city manager and oil and gas inspector. The criteria for determining the number of monitoring wells will be based upon the number of surface acres, number of injection wells, surface deterrents to the location of monitoring wells and other factors based upon the best judgment of the city manager and oil and gas inspector. 
(c)  Every six months from and after the issuance of the permit for the enhanced recovery or disposal well, the permittee and the operator thereof shall cause water samples to be obtained from the test water well by a registered hydrologist. The hydrologist shall then subject the water sample to an analysis to determine all of the following: chloride content, pH, conductivity, total dissolved solids, sulfates, the direction of freshwater flow and barium content. A certified report containing the results of such analysis shall then be forthwith filed with the oil and gas inspector. 
(d)  The testing and analysis required by subsection (c) of this section shall be the responsibility of the permittee and operator and at their expense and shall be conducted by a registered professional hydrologist approved by the oil and gas inspector. The oil and gas inspector shall be notified in writing ten days in advance of such testing and may be present for the testing. 
(e)  The oil and gas inspector is empowered to require further water testing procedures to be conducted and/or require additional wells to be drilled as are necessary, in his judgment, to safeguard all waters of the city from pollution. 
(f)  If reports from monitoring wells are unsatisfactory, the oil and gas inspector, with approval of the city manager, is empowered to require immediate remedies to be enacted, including the cessation of all operational activities. 
(Code 1986, § 27-91; Code 2002, § 28-197) 
Sec. 28-198. - Domestic and public water wells. 
(a)  Domestic and public water supply wells located within a radius of one-quarter mile of any enhanced recovery or disposal well shall be tested prior to beginning injection and disposal and annually thereafter for the presence of deleterious substances such as chlorides, sulfates and dissolved solids. Such testing is the responsibility of the permittee and, at the permittee's expense, is to be conducted by a registered hydrologist approved by the oil and gas inspector. The oil and gas inspector shall be notified five days in advance of such testing and may be present. Test results shall be filed with the oil and gas inspector upon completion. If the permittee is unable to comply with the required tests, the permittee shall submit a written statement specifying the reasons for noncompliance. 
(b)  The permittee is liable for damages to any domestic or public water supply wells located within the permitted enhanced recovery unit. 
(c)  Failure to comply with mandatory testing and without city-approved reasons for noncompliance by the permittee is grounds for fines to be levied. Determination of the fine will be made by the city manager and the oil and gas inspector. 
(Code 1986, § 27-92; Code 2002, § 28-198) 
Sec. 28-199. - Standards for fittings and other related material. 
    Under this article, all fittings, tubing and pipeline materials which come into direct contact with saltwater or other deleterious fluids shall be designed and manufactured from corrosive-resistant material. Pipe and fittings must be designed with sufficient wall thickness or must be designed with adequate protection to withstand anticipated external and internal pressure loads that will be imposed on the pipe and fittings after installation and must meet a minimum in design factor of 1.5. 
(Code 1986, § 27-93; Code 2002, § 28-199) 
Sec. 28-200. - Special requirement for injection pipelines. 
    The placing of injection pipelines pursuant to this article shall be done under provisions located within this chapter with the following additional requirements: 
(1)  Nonmetallic materials shall be buried with a metallic tracing material. 
(2)  There shall be installed adequate monitoring devices and safety controls which will shut off or isolate systems deviating from normal operating pressure and rates. 
(3)  If soft material, rocks or other unsuitable material of poor bearing qualities are found at the bottom of pipe trenches/excavations, stabilization shall be achieved by over excavating and backfilling to grade with an approved compacted bedding such as sand, fine gravel, crushed stone or a concrete foundation with a sand bedding. 
(4)  Pipes shall be sleeved and otherwise protected from damage should tunneling or street boring be necessary. 
(5)  Pipes shall be sleeved and adequately supported where conditions are such that the piping must be elevated due to obstacles such as rivers or other similar conditions. 
(6)  Backfill around pipes shall be free of rocks, frozen chunks, broken concrete and other rubble which may damage or misalign the pipe during the backfill and tamping operation. 
(7)  All buried pipe shall be provided with a warning tape installed at an approximate depth of 12 inches below the surface of the ground above the pipe. 
(8)  Pipeline warning posts shall be arranged and designed to clearly identify the buried pipeline and provide an emergency phone number should a break occur. 
(Code 1986, § 27-94; Code 2002, § 28-200) 
Sec. 28-201. - Drilling, completion and maintenance of water source wells. 
(a)  A drilling application must be submitted for an enhanced recovery water source well. The application will be the same format and the applicable fee will be the same as any well application drilling permit. 
(b)  The entire well bore will be cemented. 
(c)  A bond log will be submitted to the oil and gas inspector. 
(d)  If any leakage or spillage of any pollution or deleterious substance occurs, whatever the cause thereof, the permittee shall cause the city manager or the oil and gas inspector to be notified promptly. If, in the judgment of the city manager, such leakage or spillage represents a potential environmental hazard, he may issue whatever corrective orders he deems appropriate and, additionally, may require the appropriate testing of the surface and subsurface for pollutant incursion, the cost of such test to be borne by the permittee. 
(Code 1986, § 27-95; Code 2002, § 28-201) 
Sec. 28-202. - Stationary equipment noise abatement. 
(a)  Stationary equipment or other appurtenances used in relation with an enhanced recovery project or disposal well shall be maintained at a low noise level. The following are rules and requirements for such a procedure: 
(1)  The following table shall be used to determine the acceptable noise level for all sites: 
TABLE 1. FOR LIMITING SOUND LEVELS FOR LAND USE SITES 
Zoning District Classification Time Averaged Minimum/Maximum Sound Level Limits, dBA Residential 7:00 a.m.-10:00 p.m. 55-65 10:00 p.m.-7:00 a.m. 50-60 Commercial/ 
business 7:00 a.m.-10:00 p.m. 60-70 10:00 p.m.-7:00 a.m. 55-60 Industrial/ 
agriculture 24 hours a day 70-80  
(2)  The permittee of an enhanced recovery project or disposal well is obligated to install devices, buildings or other procedures to maintain an acceptable noise level. 
(b)  Authorization for the city to ascertain acceptable noise levels is indicated in sections 20-170(a)(1) and 20-171(4). 
(c)  The oil and gas inspector is authorized to use acceptable scientific measuring devices to determine the noise levels at any operational location. This shall be done on an irregular schedule. 
(d)  If the noise level is above acceptable levels at any operational site, the oil and gas inspector shall inform the permittee to immediately apply remedial methods to lower the excessive noise. 
(e)  If the excessive noise level is not lowered as determined by the oil and gas inspector, the city manager is authorized to assess a penalty of an unspecified amount which may include an operational cessation order. 
(Code 1986, § 27-96; Code 2002, § 28-202) 
Sec. 28-203. - Deepening and sidetracking wells from existing well bores. 
    Under this article, deepening an existing well bore or sidetracking a well from an existing well bore shall be permitted upon proper approval from the corporation commission and the city manager or the oil and gas inspector and may require city commission approval. 
(Code 1986, § 27-97; Code 2002, § 28-203) 
Secs. 28-204-28-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PIPELINES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-231. - Supervision by city officials. 
    The city manager, director of public works, oil and gas inspector, city engineer and the chief of police shall exercise constant supervision of the pipelines, flow lines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment located in the streets, alleys and public places and report to the city commission all violations of this article and all dangerous defective or unsuitably placed pipelines, flow lines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment and guard the public at all times from the dangers incident to the erection, maintenance and operation of all pipelines, flow lines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment used in connection with the sale or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in the city and its environs and in the gathering of raw hydrocarbons from producing oil and gas wells within the city limits and in the transportation of water or saltwater used in connection with enhanced recovery of oil and gas wells within the city limits in, under or upon the streets, alleys or public places. 
(Code 1986, § 27-106; Code 2002, § 28-231) 
Sec. 28-232. - Limitations upon rights granted. 
    The sections of this article or any acts and proceedings conducted under this article shall not be construed as a grant by the city of the right or privilege to use the streets, alleys or public places for the purposes provided in this article or any purpose except for and during the annual period immediately succeeding the time fixed for payment of fees to the city and then only if such payment is actually made. 
(Code 1986, § 27-107; Code 2002, § 28-232) 
Sec. 28-233. - Interpretation. 
(a)  None of the sections of this article shall be construed or operate to prevent or render unnecessary the securing of any franchise for the erection, maintenance or operation of pipelines, flow lines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment in, under or upon any of the streets, alleys or public places if the pipelines and the equipment referred to are used in the sale or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in the city and its environs, nor shall any section of this article or any act or proceeding conducted under this article be construed as a grant by the city of the right or privilege to use the streets, alleys or public places for the purposes provided. 
(b)  The compensation provided by ordinance for the unfranchised use of the streets, alleys and public places shall be in lieu of damages for occupation and use and shall be in addition to other penalties provided for in this article. 
(c)  The city does not waive any of its rights to have the charges provided for in this article upheld as a tax as authorized under the Charter. 
(d)  This article or any part of it may be altered or repealed at any time, and no rights or privileges shall ever be acquired under it which may not be withdrawn, altered or modified by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 27-108; Code 2002, § 28-233) 
Sec. 28-234. - Violations. 
    Each day's violation of any section of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 27-122; Code 2002, § 28-234) 
Sec. 28-235. - Abatement of nuisances. 
    The city engineer, oil and gas inspector and/or the chief of police shall summarily abate or remove any of the pipelines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment declared by this article to be a nuisance immediately upon the order given by the city commission. No person shall prevent or attempt to prevent any city officer or employee or agent from abating or removing any such pipelines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment declared to be a nuisance or interfere with such officer, employee or agent when engaged in or attempting to engage in such work. 
(Code 1986, § 27-121; Code 2002, § 28-235) 
Sec. 28-236. - Fee collection procedure. 
    The taxes and fees required to be paid by this article shall be deemed a debt to the city, and upon failure to pay them the city may maintain a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction for the recovery and collection of the debt. 
(Code 1986, § 27-119; Code 2002, § 28-236) 
Sec. 28-237. - Discontinuance of unsafe pipeline. 
    If a pipeline becomes unsafe or is not maintained as provided in this article or if any of the contents escape, the person in control of the line shall immediately discontinue its use and shut off all its contents until the line is repaired. 
(Code 1986, § 27-120; Code 2002, § 28-237) 
Sec. 28-238. - Special provisions for refined natural gas pipelines. 
(a)  All pipelines, connections and fixtures installed or used for the purpose of the transportation of refined natural gas shall be equivalent to the specifications of the National Gas Safety Code adopted and approved by the United States Department of Commerce and now in force as to thickness, weight, size, strength and general character of material, workmanship and manner of installation. 
(b)  The location of pipelines used to transport refined natural gas to consumers will be located in the utility reserve associated with the granting of the franchise permitted by ordinance. Extensions of such lines may be installed in private rights-of-way after being granted permission by the individual surface owners. All plats relating to the installation of consumer lines shall be made available to the office of city engineer. 
(Code 1986, § 27-109; Code 2002, § 28-238) 
Sec. 28-239. - Special provisions for hydrocarbon flow lines and gathering systems. 
    The granting of an application for drilling within the city limits implies the applicant has the right to retrieve and transport oil, gas and water from the oil or gas well. Certain restrictions related to health and safety shall be placed upon the method of transportation of these products. They are as follows: 
(1)  A gathering system with lines larger than 2 7/8 inches outside diameter pipe shall be laid in the least restrictive rights-of-way. Such should be within a sparse population area with no major restoration processes necessary. These areas may be within private or public property designations. Such an area may be designated as a "pipeline corridor." 
(2)  Individual flow lines to specific wells located from the pipeline corridor may be permitted for lines of 2 7/8 inches or less to be placed within a utility right-of-way or private property for not more than three-quarters of a mile. This type of line may carry oil, gas or water or a combination thereof. Permission for use of a private right-of-way must first be obtained prior to an application being presented to the city for approval. Private surface permission should be based upon proper compensation, surface restoration and particular individual restrictions. The formal application for a specific flow line shall be submitted to the city engineer for inspection prior the issuance of street boring permits. The cost of permits is defined by ordinance, and all restrictions applicable to the laying of lines are listed in other ordinances and compliance will be monitored. 
(3)  An applicant for the permit required by this article shall file a plan with the city engineer showing in detail the size of the pipeline and the depth and width and the exact location of the excavation or pipeline with particular reference to all structures or lines of the city or any public utility company, sidewalk, pavement or other public improvement. Plans for a gathering system shall be submitted to the city engineer for inspection prior to the issuance of street boring permits. The cost of permits are defined by ordinance, and all restrictions applicable to the laying of lines are listed in other ordinances and compliance will be monitored. 
(4)  All street crossings will be bored and cased with proper identifications installed after construction is finished. No bore will be attempted without a boring permit granted by fee from the city. Such fee is established by ordinance. 
(5)  All proposed gathering systems and specific flow lines will be granted final approval by the city commission. 
(6)  A cathodic protection of pipelines will be installed for all lines. 
(7)  Line markers and other appurtenances will be installed as needed. 
(Code 1986, § 27-110; Code 2002, § 28-239) 
Sec. 28-240. - Pipe specifications for flow lines and gathering systems. 
(a)  Pipe specifications for flow lines will conform to the following requirements or better: 
(1)  The pipe shall be new, no more than 2 7/8 inches outside diameter, coated and wrapped, capable of maintaining a minimum 1,000 pounds of pressure. 
(2)  Individual sections of pipe will be joined by either a continuous butt weld or by the electric resistance weld. 
(3)  All pipe will be inspected by the appropriate officials before the pipe is welded. 
(b)  Pipe specifications for gathering systems lines shall comply with rules and regulations supplied by the state corporation commission and the state department of transportation and other regulations as specifically supplied by the city engineer and other city officials. All metal pipe shall be coated and wrapped. All pipe will be inspected by city officials prior to installation. Metal pipe sections will be joined by either a continuous butt weld or by the electric resistance weld. 
(Code 1986, § 27-111; Code 2002, § 28-240) 
Sec. 28-241. - Pressure limitations. 
    Under this article, pressure in any line shall not exceed those permitted by the rules, regulations or orders of the corporation commission in force. All lines shall be operated and maintained in a safe manner at all times so as to prevent all leakage or escape of their contents. 
(Code 1986, § 27-112; Code 2002, § 28-241) 
Sec. 28-242. - Ditches. 
(a)  All ditches for pipelines shall be excavated in a manner that will have the smallest possible opening in the public and private property. Specifically, flow lines of 2 7/8 inches or less shall be placed in a ditch not less than four inches or not wider than six inches. Gathering system lines larger than 2 7/8 inches shall be placed in a ditch at least six inches (plus or minus) wider than the outside diameter of the pipe so that there is a minimum six-inch (plus or minus) space between the outside diameter and the ditch wall. 
(b)  The right-of-way shall be restored to the original or better condition during restoration operations. 
(Code 1986, § 27-113; Code 2002, § 28-242) 
Sec. 28-243. - Pipes under streets. 
    On streets and alleys, all pipelines shall be buried to a minimum depth of 30 inches below the normal surface of the ground, the depth to be measured from the top of the pipe, and shall be approved by the city engineer and/or street department supervisor. 
(Code 1986, § 27-114; Code 2002, § 28-243) 
Sec. 28-244. - Removal or change of pipe. 
    If it becomes necessary to change or remove any pipeline, the entire expense of change or removal shall be borne by the owner upon the approval of the city engineer and/or street department supervisor; removal or change shall be made within five days after notice is given by the city. 
(Code 1986, § 27-115; Code 2002, § 28-244) 
Sec. 28-245. - Testing of transmission, gathering system and flow lines; correction of defects. 
    Each owner or operator of a transmission, gathering system and flow lines shall have it tested at least once every six months for the purpose of determining whether it is in safe condition and free from leaks, breaks or open spaces and shall make a report of the test supported by an affidavit by the person making the test to the oil and gas inspector. The test may be by the stench method, electrical detection method or any other method other than a pressure method approved by the oil and gas inspector, provided that each line at the time of its installation shall be tested by the oil and gas inspector and a report of the test shall be filed with the city engineer before the operation of that line. Testing periods shall end on September 15 and March 15 of each year. No person shall continue the operation of any pipeline after the termination of any testing period provided in this section without having it tested and making the required report. For failure to make the test and report or if the report discloses or it otherwise appears that any line is leaking, defective or unsafe, the oil and gas inspector shall, within five days of such disclosure or within five days after the closing of any testing period, close and shut the pipeline. 
(Code 1986, § 27-116; Code 2002, § 28-245) 
Sec. 28-246. - Fees for interchanging of pipelines. 
    If a pipeline covered by this article is placed in a ditch where another similarly covered pipeline is being removed and if it is not necessary to deepen the ditch and a high-pressure line is not exchanged where a low-pressure line has previously been, a fee in the amount established by ordinance shall be collected. However, when it is necessary to deepen the ditch and the new pipeline being placed in the ditch is a high-pressure line taking the place of a low-pressure line, an additional fee in the amount established by ordinance shall be charged for the removal of the old line. 
(Code 1986, § 27-117; Code 2002, § 28-246) 
Sec. 28-247. - Alternative to removal of pipelines under paving. 
    In lieu of the actual removal of a pipeline or portion thereof located underneath any paved street or alley, the owner of a pipeline for which a removal permit has been applied for and issued may relinquish his ownership and abandon that portion beneath any paving by first pumping the pipe full of mud and securely plugging each end of the pipe left beneath the paving. Before abandoning and plugging the pipe, the owner shall file with the city clerk or shall incorporate in the application for the removal permit a written transfer and assignment to the city of all his interest, possession and title in and to the abandoned pipe and shall give 48 hours' previous written notice to the city engineer and/or street department supervisor as to when and where the owner proposes to plug the pipe. The work shall be subject to inspection and approval of the city engineer and/or street department supervisor or authorized representative. 
(Code 1986, § 27-118; Code 2002, § 28-247) 
Secs. 28-248-28-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCAVATION PERMIT 

Sec. 28-276. - Required. 
    No person shall make an excavation in any part of the public property or in any public utility reserve for the purpose of laying, removing, installing or maintaining a pipeline without first having obtained a permit from the city commission. 
(Code 1986, § 27-127; Code 2002, § 28-276) 
Sec. 28-277. - Consent of property owners. 
    Where a pipeline is laid in any public utility reserve, the applicant for a pipeline permit shall first obtain written permission or consent from all owners of property through and over which the public utility reserve runs before applying for a permit under this division. 
(Code 1986, § 27-128; Code 2002, § 28-277) 
Sec. 28-278. - Expiration; renewal. 
(a)  A permit issued pursuant to this division shall expire one year from its date of approval and shall be renewed upon payment to the city clerk of the fee established by ordinance, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Any permit may be revoked upon ten days' notice for failure to pay the fees required, and each day's continuance of the pipeline after such revocation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1986, § 27-129; Code 2002, § 28-278) 
Secs. 28-279-28-305. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL GAS DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS 

Sec. 28-306. - Franchise or permit required. 
(a)  No person shall erect, lay, maintain or operate any pipelines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment used or which are to be used in the sale or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in this city and its environs and maintained or operated in, under or upon any of the streets, alleys or public places or assist or participate therein without a franchise or permits as required by this article. 
(b)  All pipelines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment used in the sale or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in this city and its environs and maintained or operated in, under or upon any of the streets, alleys or public places without a franchise or permits as required by this article are declared to be public nuisances. 
(Code 1986, § 27-137; Code 2002, § 28-306) 
Sec. 28-307. - Nonfranchised pipeline fee. 
(a)  For each year a person who maintains or operates any pipeline used in the sale or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in this city and its environs in, under or upon any of the streets, alleys or public places without a city franchise, he shall pay, on May 1 of each year, an annual oil and gas regulation and inspection fee in the amount established by ordinance. Copies of such ordinance are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  If the person has or secures a franchise to maintain and operate the pipelines or any of the appliances referred to in section 28-306 in, under or upon the city streets, alleys or public places, he shall not be required to make any further payments as provided in subsection (a) of this section during the life of the franchise unless such provision is made in the franchise. 
(Code 1986, § 27-138; Code 2002, § 28-307) 
Sec. 28-308. - Permit for excavations. 
(a)  No person shall, without a franchise, make any excavation in any part of the city streets, alleys or public places for the purpose of laying or installing any pipelines or meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment for use in connection with the sale or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in this city and its environs unless he shall first have obtained a permit from the city commission to do so under division 2 of this article. 
(b)  If any pipelines or other appliances referred to in subsection (a) of this section are laid or installed without first obtaining the permit, the maintenance or operation of it in the streets, alleys and public places shall constitute all offense, and each day that the pipeline or other appliances are so maintained or operated shall constitute a separate offense. However, if the person has or secures a franchise to maintain and operate the pipelines or other appliances enumerated in subsection (a) of this section in, under or upon the city streets, alleys or public places, he shall not be required to obtain the permits provided in section 28-239 unless such provision is made in the franchise. 
(Code 1986, § 27-139; Code 2002, § 28-308) 
Sec. 28-309. - Annual report of pipeline use and gross receipts. 
(a)  Any person maintaining or operating any pipelines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and related equipment used in the sale, or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in the city and its environs in, under or upon any of the streets alleys or public places without a franchise shall, on April 10 of each year, file with the community development director a statement or diagram verified by an affidavit of the general or local manager or agent of such person showing the number of pipelines and the number of rods of the pipelines which occupy the streets, alleys or public places which are maintained or used by him. 
(b)  Any person so maintaining or operating such pipelines, meters, valves, gauges, pumps, appliances and equipment as set forth in subsection (a) of this section and conducting such business of selling or distributing natural or artificial gas to consumers of the city shall also file with the city clerk, on April 10 of each year, a statement verified by the affidavit of the general or local manager or agent of such person showing the gross receipts of such person for the previous year from March 31 of that year to and including March 31 of the year in which the statement is made resulting from sale or distribution of natural or artificial gas to consumers in the city. 
(Code 1986, § 27-140; Code 2002, § 28-309)
